Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
So I cup my ear to the hush between heartbeats,
Where coins of silence glitter brighter than slogans.
I hover, moth-like, near the lamp of a child’s question,
Let your unsponsored light singe my wings.
When the marketplace roars with bargains for attention,
I lean into the undertow of your whisper
And come away impoverished of pretense.
You are a stern teacher, Truth;
You grade in the red ink of consequence,
Yet your lessons lie hidden in the margins of ordinary hours:
The sound a spoon makes circling dawn’s first coffee,
The way a widow slips her ring into a drawer,
How the river keeps its vow to the sea without certificates.
I practice your difficult music, mouthing vowels of candor,
Mistakes crack like metronomes, but still I count the beats.
One day, when words gather at my lips like swallows
Reading the compass of your wind,
I will release them clean and unafraid.
Until then, I listen, listen—
For every silence is a rehearsal stage,
And your name, Truth, is the line I must earn.

Prelude
I walk the corridor of mirrors, each reflection selling me a different story.
I pause before the one gone silvered with refusal, and there I hear you—quiet, absolute.
Sonnets for a Difficult Listener
I.
When dawn rehearses honesty in blue,
She dyes the edges of the sky with grace;
I tilt my head to learn that timid hue,
And wash the camouflage from off my face.
II.
Your syllables arrive on barefoot feet,
No trumpets, banners, algorithms, trend;
What empire falls is vanity’s deceit,
What rises is the marrow we defend.
III.
I practice vows by lanterns of remorse,
Erase the boast, the flinch, the practiced lie;
Each syllable adjusts my drifting course,
A sextant aimed at your unwavering sky.
Couplet.
So when I dare to speak—and soon I must—
May every phrase be tempered into trust.
Coda
Still I rehearse, chiseling silence into space between words,
Allowing breath to braid sentences to soul.
Someday my mouth will open like a chapel window
And your daylight will spill through uncolored,
Needing no stained glass to persuade.

Truth, you temperamental DJ spinning tracks only the patient can hear,
I show up to your underground club with pockets full of static,
Phones buzzing, headlines tap-dancing inside my skull.
But you kill the lights, drop a beat made of heartbeat and hush.
No cover charge, only cover removed:
Hands unclenched, ego checked, earbuds out.
You queue a sample—grandmother humming while shelling peas,
Neighbor coughing the price of cigarettes, glacier dripping its slow apology.
I lean in, volume climbing inside the cortex,
Every lie I bought at retail price now scans as counterfeit.
You scratch the vinyl of my certainties, remix my slogans into question marks,
Loop the word “listen” until it becomes percussion.
The crowd thins; few endure the tempo of candor.
But I dance, awkward, honest, sweat rinsing pretense from my pores.
When dawn kicks us to the curb, you hand me the mic:
"Go speak, but only in the key I taught your bones."
So I step to the sidewalk, lungs carrying your bassline,
And the first sentence I spit is raw, unmarketable, beautifully unfashionable—
Proof that I had been listening.
Cue applause of sparrows on power lines.
Show’s over? Never. The track just changed.

instance_metrics.response:
In the village of Candlecross Moor, where gossip rides the wind,
Lived Mara the Weaver, whose loom could braid moonlight within.
Her cloth was sought by merchants, by princes drunk on praise,
Yet she spoke little, listening to the shuttle’s hidden phrase.
One night a pilgrim knocked, cloak heavy with the rain:
"Truth!" he cried, "I chase her, but my tongue wears only stain."
Mara set a stool by hearth, fed the fire a spark,
And bade the pilgrim hush his woes, to hear the ruddy dark.
The kettle sighed, the floorboards breathed, a spider tuned its thread;
Within those humble instruments a deeper anthem spread.
They listened till the lantern died and dawn robed roofs with rose;
Then Mara cut a length of cloth more humble than her lows.
"Wrap this around your restless mouth," she said with quiet grace,
"And wander mute till every sound leaves honest lines on your face.
For Truth will speak you if you dwell in habit of her song,
And words, once seasoned by her hush, will stride unflinching, strong."
The pilgrim bowed, his thanks unvoiced, and crossed the waking heath;
While Mara weaved another dawn on the silent shuttle’s sheath.

“Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,”
the miller told the river while the wheel ground dawn to flour.
All day the paired stones argued,
throwing sparks into the grin of grain,
rumors skimming downstream
to villages too tired to sift them.
At sunset the miller waded ankle-deep
and pressed an ear to the current.
Water spoke of drowned coins,
of lovers lobbing wishes like broken oaths,
of carp swallowing silver secrets.
Night after night he returned,
learning the vowels of moss,
the consonants of silt,
punctuation tapped by skipping stones.
Soon his sentences gleamed
as clear as moonlight on flour dust.
When councilmen arrived demanding
palatable fiction to fatten their ledgers,
he spoke the river’s arithmetic:
gallons, droughts, unflattering truths upstream.
Tongues clucked, fists slammed,
but his testimony rippled outward,
echoing in wells, kettles, children’s play songs,
until the council’s ledgers themselves
grew damp with doubt.
The river flowed on, unhurried,
carrying a promise larger than footsteps:
habit born of listening
will always out-speak thunder.

Truth, I will speak you only if I learn your hush,
the faint syllable you utter when dawn first lifts fog.
I have chased you in statues and footnotes,
in chambers where echoes substitute for breath,
and you kept silent, letting theories quarrel.
So now I sit on the floor with a clay cup,
wait for its glaze to cool, feel the heat withdraw.
Inside that vanishing warmth you rustle like wheat,
grain after grain naming itself without mouth.
If I can memorize that granular murmur
perhaps my own tongue will open like a window,
no longer dazzled by glass, but by wind.
Then I will not recite, but resonate,
bone tuning fork to the pitch of your pulse.
People may ask for slogans, proofs, confessions;
I will offer the pause between waves,
the salt left when argument evaporates.
Speak, they will insist. They will call me mute.
Yet they will taste something mineral in the silence,
and their hearts will pronounce it for me.
Thus speaking you becomes listening further,
spiral shell that repeats the ocean until it is ocean.

I think of my own.

I practice until language thins to a single thread
stretching from your pulse to mine.

Then, only then, I dare a syllable.
It leaves me raw and ringing, a struck gong,

’Truth!’ I cry, but softly,
as though naming a newborn.
You lay a fingertip of light upon my lips;

In your presence every adjective wants a middle name,
Every verb insists on wings.

On the backs of museum tickets.
We will hang them, smudged and holy, in the Louvre of our pockets,
Proof that even erasable things can endure.

Dear love, the universe may cool into silence,
But I will keep a match struck beneath my tongue
To ignite your name again, again, again—
A lighthouse tattooed on the fog of breath.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
I tilt my face to storms of wandering years,
Let their salted thunder cleanse the tender marrow.
You call, and wild geese wheel across my pulse,
Bronze wings forging a horizon of promise.
I gather scattered grains of memory into bread,
Leavened by the fervent warmth of your imagined hand.
The orchards of my mind, once frost-locked,
Suddenly hum with honey-thick noon;
Apricots slip on their lantern skins,
Branches lean to teach the air to sing.
I was a lantern drowned in its own smoke,
Glass filmed by sighs of extinguished dreams;
Your name became the innocent flame
That dared my secret oxygen to bloom.
Now every breath takes census of astonishments:
Blue cedar resin, rain on copper roofs,
The lilting whistle of trains that leave yet stay.
Night unrolls its velvet maps of silence,
I walk them barefoot, guided by your trembling star,
Returning, always, to the single beginning:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

I rewrite the scripture of the ordinary day.
The kettle’s hiss becomes cathedral trumpet,

Their gossip rising like incense through chilled air.
Because you are, the algebra of traffic resolves,
Red lights pulse as patient hearts forgiving delay.
I walk the city as a novice of wonder,
Counting cobbles like rosary beads of possibility.

Proclaims in reckless color what I cannot hide:
I have been ruined for mediocrity.
The sky unzips a corridor of impossible blue,
And down that lane glides a paper plane
Bearing the single syllable of your name.
It lands upon the page of evening,
Folding streets into a pocket of quiet.
There, at the corner of hush and hope,

Flame answers flame across invisible miles,
And darkness apprentices itself to your light—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Would galaxies swivel their hips of fire,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
I rode the long salt road to dawn,
My saddle stitched with second chances,
My pockets light, my promise sworn.
Mist rose off the river’s shoulder,
Ghosts unwilling to leave the land;
It cooled my face, calmed my fervor,
But could not still my eager hand.
For I had packed your ember letters
Between the pages of the sky;
They lit a lantern in my ribcage,
Told the wreck of doubt goodbye.
Across the moors a lone bell trembled,
Calling to the saints of rain;
I answered with the hooves’ percussion,
Pilgrim tuned to love’s refrain.
At last the valley opened, breathing
Fields of childhood, wheat and thyme;
The farmhouse door you kept unbolted
Waited like a perfect rhyme.
I tethered hope beside the garden,
Shook road-dust from a contrite soul;
You stepped forth, barefoot, unbeckoning,
Yet drew the universe back whole.
In the hush our shadows merged,
Long as forgiveness, tall as trees;
The wind wrote on my open shoulders:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Set them afloat in the sink.

one of forgetting,
one of bright recall.
The cranes choose.
Ink bleeds like fresh berries,
Not purple, not blue, but that secret
Color between yes and almost.

Starts to sing of migration,
Of how distance invents shape.
I answer by slicing an orange.
The room fogs with citrus infinitive:
To peel, to taste, to believe.
The rind spirals, a small horizon.
Inside curl the planets we tell children are marbles.
I tuck one behind each ear
So I can listen to orbit.
Gravity shifts; chair, plate, thoughts
Float toward the doorway of your absence.
I step through.
The cranes lift, shaking water,
Re-forming their vowels into wings.
Mid-flight they spell it plain:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

'Twas noontide of summer,
and the earth rang like a hammered bell,
its bronze throat shining with heat.
Cicadas sawed the hours apart,
stitched them back with electric thread,
then sawed again, insatiable architects
of an ever-lengthening afternoon.
Cornfields stood at attention, green soldiers
with tassel-plumed helmets trembling
under the general sun.
I walked the gravel road, barefoot,
a pilgrim to no shrine but thirst.
Dust rose around my ankles
like gnats of pale incense,
and every breath tasted of wheat
and the iron of distant storms.
The horizon rippled—mirage or prophecy—
where a lone windmill spun
its slow, windless prayer.
Somewhere a screen door slammed,
a dog barked twice, then fell silent,
as though sound itself had melted
into the buttered air.
For a moment time surrendered,
lay sprawling in the ditchgrass,
watch pocket emptied of minutes.
I stood beside it, twin vagrants,
waiting for a passing cloud
to loan us shade.
None came.
Instead, the sun leaned closer,
pressed its golden stamp
upon the bare nape of the world,
claiming it utterly.
And we, the brief, the mortal—
we carried that fiery watermark
until evening redeemed us with cool ink.

Color bled under my shoes; revolutions,
it turns out, stain like berries.

A woman with weathered eyes
handed me a seed wrapped in paper
printed with last year’s headlines.
Plant it, she said, in the soil of your doubt.
I knelt where tear gas once hovered,
scooped earth black as starless hope,
and buried the seed along with my complacency.

For the first time in my life
I felt the planet exhale through my palms.
Subways tremored beneath, a heartbeat shared.
Statues around the plaza trembled too,
cracks spidering across bronze certainty.
I was not separate; I was circuitry.

Rain arrived—uncensored, collective.
Ink ran from the headlines into mud,
letters rearranging into tomorrow.
When I rose, the seed had already sprouted,
a green fist breaking surface.
I carried that wet silence home
and watered it with every question
I had been told not to ask.

Practise our pratfalls over graves

From childhood's hour I have not been synchronized with the neighborhood metronome.
When they counted four-four, I slipped into twelve-eight,
hearing invisible tambourines in the rain gutter.
At six I colored outside margins not for rebellion
but because the universe was larger than the worksheet.
Teachers scolded. Paper shrank. The margin widened like a tide.
On the playground everyone spun clockwise; I leaned counter,
feeling gravity rewrite me. Counselors suggested therapy,
as though asymmetry were disease. I tasted their pills—
the sea inside spoke no pharmaceutical dialect.
Now I rent a top-floor loft filled with mismatched clocks.
None agree; each chimes whenever it wishes, a congress of subjective minutes.
Here I compose offerings—lopsided songs, poems with crooked spines,
paintings refusing to sit straight on the wall.
Visitors smile, bewildered. I pour them tea that tastes of thunder,
and they love it without knowing why.
Difference is longitude: invisible, unavoidable, mapping the planet’s curve.
From childhood’s hour I have not been like others—
thank galaxies, thank dust, thank the unfinished music still arranging my bones.

From childhood's hour I have not been a creature of the hearth.
Cribs of maple, lullaby coals, could not lull the iron in my blood.
At seven, I heard the mountain call, an ancient baritone shaped by glaciers.
I followed, shoeless, through briar and blizzard, until my tongue spoke wind.
Valley folk whispered: the boy is wolf-dreamed, moon-breathed, unsalvageable.
They were right and wrong. The summit adopted me, teaching altitude’s law:
What rises thins, what thins grows clear, what grows clear sings.
Drakes of lightning nested in my scalp; I braided them gently.
I drank snowmelt laced with star pollen, chewed quartz for breakfast,
watched the sun rehearse its dying and applauded.
Now I descend on market days and funerals, bearing stories carved on obsidian leaves.
Villagers trade bread, cross themselves, ask if I will stay.

I traded tunes for crusts of bread;
Old sailors claimed I spoke their tongue,
Though I repeated what stars said.

A winter came in iron boots,
It cracked the coins of beggars thin;
I warmed my hands on ghostly flutes
And heard the thawing world within.

Years thickened like a book of creeds,
Yet none could settle on my spine;
I planted questions, reaped the seeds,
And brewed their leaves to bitter wine.

Now, older than the maps I own,
I stand before my father’s field;
The corn has withered, cattle flown,
Yet there, the scarecrow tips his shield.

He seems to ask if I belong,
Or whether wind remains my kin;
I answer with a traveling song—
From childhood’s hour I have not been.

instance_metrics.response: From childhood's hour I have not been a single note but a chord unresolved, suspended in the throat of the evening. While other kids memorized capitals, I memorized the way dust leans toward windows, the way a moth keeps erasing itself against a bulb only to begin again. I knew nobody could hear the electricity thinking, but I listened anyway, ear pressed to the socket like a seashell repeating future storms. At fifteen I failed geometry because I preferred the angle of birds departing over the proof of two triangles kissing. At twenty I shared an attic with an idea so large it bent the rafters; we spoke in the language of dripping faucets and unfinished stairs. I am thirty now and the world requests a version of myself that can be stapled to forms, but I still arrive with frayed silhouettes in my pockets. Tonight, streetlights flicker on like coins tossed into a deep fountain, and I walk beneath them counting unanswered wishes. Somewhere a dog barks at a constellation only dogs can see, and I nod in recognition. The sky, too, has never quite learned to behave.

instance_metrics.response:
My God, how many are my fears!
They prowl the hallways like restless hounds, unchained,
Sniffing the hinges of every unopened door.
When the lamp trembles, they multiply,
Casting long fingers over cabinets and clocks,
Claiming every corner of ordinary dusk.
I name them: Failure, Loneliness, Hunger, War,
But names flutter off them like burnt moth wings,
And new masks grow where old ones fell.
I try to outsing them with the kettle’s whistle,
Overpower them with the radio’s brass,
Yet even music becomes their echoing den.
I sweep the floor; they hide beneath bristles.
I open the window; they ride the wind back in.
At midnight they kneel beside my pillow,
Reciting prophecies of broken mirrors and phone calls.
Still, in the thin, bruised hour before dawn,
When the birds rehearse forgiveness,
I feel them loosen, hushed by the possibility of light.
I rise, placing each bare foot on cold tiles,
And walk among them like a mother counting children—
Present, present, present—
Until the sun exhales and they dissolve,
Water on the bright blade of morning.

My God, how many are my fears!
They wheel across the mind like winter geese,
A shifting V of silhouettes scribbling the grey.
Each carries a shrill, untranslated cry—
Debt, Sickness, Silence, Age—
Yet overhead they blur to a single black question.
I raise my hands like a scarecrow of resolve,
But they bank and circle, harvest my sky.
The first frost arrives in their beating wings,
And sentences crack in my throat like thin ice.
Yesterday I planted promises in neat furrows,
Hoping spring would hatch easier songs.
But fear’s shadow lengthens over seeds,
A cold that speaks in mineral tongues.
Still, even geese exhaust their maps.
At twilight they spiral down to hidden marshes,
Dropping feathers luminous as lost letters.
I gather those soft hieroglyphs, stitch them
Into a quilt that smells of mud and clouds.
Wrapped in that shifting warmth,
I learn the secret of migrating terror:
It leaves because it must, not because I win.
So I wait, listening to the hush between wingbeats,
Practicing the patient art of dawn,
Where every northern heart eventually turns south,
And the sky, newly emptied, remembers blue.

My God, how many are my fears!

At the center a minotaur drums its hooves—

I carry a thread spun of whispered prayers,
Silver as moonlight on a widow’s loom.
Every corner tests its length, every turn shortens hope.
Above, distant constellations argue about heroes,
While below, dust keeps the true story quiet.
My fears trade riddles with the stone:
Will the thread snap first, or the hand that holds it?
I answer with footsteps, soft but unyielding,
Until I reach the horned silence itself.
The beast tilts its head; in its eye I see
a mirror, and in that mirror—my own trembling child.
I kneel, pressing palm to palm,
And the labyrinth walls fold like origami swans,
Releasing us into night’s open courtyard.
One by one the hydras blur into fountains,
Their hissing necks now singing water.
I drink, tasting copper and dawn,
Aware the maze survives in memory,
But so does the thread, pocketed bright and simple.

My God, how many are my fears!
They hide like marbles beneath grandma’s porch,
Small, bright, unblinking orbs that wait for bare feet.
I learned to step lightly, heel to toe,

While mosquitos spelled uncertain futures on my arms.
Each sting a prelude to larger aches:
The first report card bruise, the first slammed door.
Night, meanwhile, shuffled its deck of legends—
Wolves in closets, thieves behind the elm—
And dealt them beneath the pillow’s cool side.
I bartered my freckles for charms:
A rusted key, a penny crushed by trains,
A song about a spider descending grace.
Years unspooled like kite string; I chased
High, impossible colors until the wind tired.
Now adult windows mirror darker weather.
Bills, hospitals, sirens—bigger marbles
That rattle the floorboards when no one else hears.
Yet sometimes I return to that porch,
Kneel and reach into the gravel, finding a sphere
Swirled with childhood galaxies.
I roll it between finger and thumb,
Witness how fear can also refract light,
How even trembling glass holds constellations.
Pocketing it, I walk back inside,
Hearing the old boards creak a lullaby
That says: step lightly, yes, but keep walking.

My God, how many are my fears!
They swarm the rafters of the mind like bats at dusk,
black commas scribbling anxious footnotes on the ceiling.
At dawn they shrink, but never vanish;
I find them folded like dark gloves in my pockets,
waiting for the first tremor of coffee,
ready to spread and clap like thunder.
I try to number them: failure, betrayal, wasted days,
love lost, love never found, the fragile wrist of the world,
climate, cancer, the long artillery of time.
I stack them like damp logs, strike a match of reason,
but the smoke becomes another ghost.
Yet, in the middle of their chittering congress,
a small gap opens—silver, stubborn.
I press my face against it, breathe pine and rain.
There I see a river older than dread,
moving with the patience of mountains.
It tells me: I have carried larger shadows.
Place yours upon the current; call them driftwood,
watch them rotate, gleam, and disappear.
I whisper Amen to water,
and when I return, the rafters are still,
but I carry the river’s hush like a lantern.

My God, how many are my fears!
A parliament of owls convened inside my ribcage,
debating every heartbeat with solemn hoots.
They draft terrible laws: the sky will fall at noon,
your friends will forget your name, the mirror will turn away.
I pace the corridor of thought, petition in hand,
begging for repeal, but ink keeps spilling
and I’m signed into exile by my own trembling pen.
So I build a carnival in protest.
I paint the owls bright oranges and blues,
set them spinning on carousels of melody.
Trumpets of memory blast confetti,
cotton-candy hopes stick to their beaks,
and for a moment the legislation of panic softens.
When the carousel slows, some owls remain dyed,
bellyful of laughter, blinking at the absurd light.
Others molt and grow dark anew,
but even their feathers remember the sugar.
I collect the down and weave a quilt,
stitched with reckless stripes of joy.
At night I cover myself with this improbable fabric.
The owls land quietly on the bedpost,
too colorful to pass new decrees.
In the hush before sleep, I thank them
for teaching me that imagination is
an oppositional government strong enough to govern fear.

My God, how many are my fears!
They sprout like moss beneath each step I take,
soft green reminders of the weight of years,
each anxious question, each invisible ache.
I water them with headlines, glowing screens,
feed them midnight snacks of could-have-been,
until the garden’s tangled evergreens
obscure the path I once had wandered in.
Then morning’s broom of sunlight sweeps a lane.
A sparrow lands, unafraid of my despair,
and chirps a sermon simple, small, humane:
the branch still holding it is made of air.
I laugh, uproot a doubt, then two, then three.
The moss releases sudden fragrant rain;
my barefoot heart grows tender, light, and free,
aware that fear and wonder share the same terrain.
So let the shaded patches live beside
the lilac blaze of hope that lights my face.
Together they compose a landscape wide
enough for sorrow, gratitude, and grace.
By dusk the garden murmurs, not with threat
but with a choir of possible tomorrows,
leafy syllables teaching me to let
the day be ample, even with its sorrows.
I sleep in soil sweet with mingled tears,
and dream: My God, how beautiful my fears.

hear them clink against fender and horn. They ride shotgun, adjust the rear-view mirror,
remind me of cliffs, of brakes, of the sudden betrayal of gravity.
At the red light I name them: fear of the left lane, fear of forgetting the word 'orchid,' fear of my father’s silence swelling into my voice, fear of ice melting before I taste the summer.
The list lengthens; the light turns green; the car behind me honks an exclamation point.
I drive, and the road unwinds its dark ribbon, offering no promise except length.
A storm shoulder appears—a roadside diner with neon coffee steaming forever.

Each refill an unwritten treaty: the world continues, sugar dissolves, fear can be stirred, tasted, swallowed.
When the storm loosens its throat and clears, I walk back to the car lighter by two teaspoons of dread.
The highway invites me again, a long sentence waiting for verbs.
I grip the wheel, whisper thanks for commas, accelerate into the yet-to-be.

The last fear clings to the wooden seat as it drifts, wobbling, into cattails.
I wave, promise a reunion someday.
Back at the picnic, there is sudden space. Fireflies replace foreboding; sandwiches taste of brave mustard.
Night arrives but keeps its distance, courteous, because I have learned to host my heart with merriment and mischief.

My God, how many are my fears!
They queue like winter stars across a washed-out sky,
huddling, muttering, sharing frozen breath.
I gave them names when I was young—
Night-Whisper, Mirror-Breaker, Silence-Thief—
and thought them pets that slept beneath the bed.
Now they are kingdoms with minted coins,
trumpet fanfares, battlements of bone.
They call roll at dawn and I answer,
slipping on mail stitched from yesterday’s regrets.
I march through rooms fragrant with soft lamplight,
yet see only the ambush of corners.
Some days I bargain: a candle for their quiet,
a verse for their retreat, but they are merchants
who deal in pulse and marrow.
Still, there is one small acre inside me
where grass grows unafraid.
It listens to sparrows instead of forecasts,
trusts the blind seed’s arithmetic.
When terror’s parade rattles the shutters,
I kneel upon that green square and practice
forgetting the war drums.
My God, count also that courage—
the single syllable of yes beneath the avalanche of no.
Let it widen like dawn’s ochre mouth,
let it gather the stragglers of hope,
so when fears tally their multitudes,
there will be a choir to answer back,
bright-throated, riotous, unnumbered.

Yet the candle’s flame is an acrobat,

performing feats of faith in defiance of drafts.

crowns of dandelions.
Suddenly the candle’s shadow becomes a sail,
the desk a prow, the room a sea wide enough
for every unmailed dream.
I fold the fears into paper boats,
set them alight, watch them hiss into darkness.
Ash settles, soft as snowfall.
My pulse, once frantic, keeps time
with a calm, unseen tide.

They bloom nocturnal, black lotuses in the marsh
of thought where moonlight drowns.

that cradle childhood lullabies.

In that chorus, I almost forget
the frog who sings of flight.

my grandmother’s laugh, the bicycle’s first wobbling victory,
the stray dog that followed me home, declaring me worth.
The marsh gas catches fire, blue and gold,
and for a moment even the lotuses glow
like lanterns themselves, transfixed
by the sudden generosity of warmth.
Their petals loosen, drifting apart
into ink-smoke that scribbles across the sky,
spelling riddles only dawn can decipher.
When the flames dim, I find
a clearing mirrored with dew.
There, a single lotus remains—
pale, unblemished, perfumed with beginnings.
I stoop to touch it and feel
my fingerprints rewrite themselves
into bolder scripts.
The bullfrogs fall silent, listening
as I whisper a new taxonomy:
Hope, Courage, Becoming.
My God, count now my dreams;

seeds on the warm breath of sunrise.

Cathedral of Trembling

My God, how many are my fears! I count them all:
one for the crack in the ceiling widening at night,
one for the throat that forgets how to sing,
one for the god I might anger by breathing,
one for the wolf pawing the hinge of the door.

They kneel beside me in the pews of thought,
bones creaking with devotion to their chill gospel;
they light candles with breaths of frost,
chant psalms scored in minor keys across my skin.
The organ groans, wind wringing the pipes,
and the stained-glass saints avert their colored eyes.

Outside, morning braids gold through the lattice,
sparrows rehearse their ordinary miracles,
but here the nave reverberates with thunder
thrown by clouds that exist only in my pulse.
I lift my trembling hands—incense curls, threads of plea—
wondering if faith is simply fear renamed.

Then a sliver of sunlight walks the aisle,
lays a warm palm on my eyelids,
and the choir of sparrows pours through a broken window.
The bells still toll, but softer now,
ringing like footsteps leaving the cavern of my chest.
I breathe—never fearless, yet breathing is enough.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

instance_metrics.response:
Inventory of a Night Watchman

My God, how many are my fears!
I store them in labeled jars along the mantel:
Arachnids of Regret, Spores of Unsung Songs,
Tidewater of Leaving Too Soon,
Dust from the Pocket Where Keys Disappear.

At dusk the glass begins to rattle,
each specimen flexing luminous claws.
I tighten lids, tuck prayers like wadded newsprint
into the seams, yet still they hum—
a Morse code of things unlearned.

I pour coffee, pace the perimeter of myself,
flashlight sweeping corridors of thought,
finding fingerprints of absence on every knob.
An owl blinks from the telephone pole,
its silence brighter than any siren.
Streetlamp halos sag with moths:
tiny crash-test angels rehearsing the burn.

Somewhere a train exhales iron dreams;
in its echo I hear a promise
that distance can outpace dread.
I unscrew one jar—just one—
and release the Fear of Being Loud.
It flaps alloy wings into the sky,
joins the owl, becomes a constellation
I decide to name After.

Dawn whistles, keys jangle, doors unlock.
The remaining jars line up at attention,
quieter for the vacancy.
I sip lukewarm courage, clock out,
walking home with one less echo to carry.

Villanelle of Counting Shadows

My God, how many are my fears tonight,
They multiply like crows on winter wire,
Yet dawn still promises a harbor made of light.

Each clock-tick hatches wings of frantic flight,
A beak of worry pecks the sleeping fire.
My God, how many are my fears tonight!

I pace the deck of thought, outpaced by might
Of phantom storms that threaten to conspire,
Yet dawn still promises a harbor made of light.

The ocean of the dark denies my sight,
Paints every wave with doubt's corroded lyre;
My God, how many are my fears tonight!

But somewhere in the hush between the blight
Of wind-bit words, I hear a distant choir
That sings: dawn still promises a harbor made of light.

So I will knot these terrors, rope them tight,
Cast them to the swell, and then retire.
My God, how many are my fears tonight,
Yet dawn still promises a harbor made of light.

instance_metrics.response:
Letters to a Sleepless Self

My God, how many are my fears! I address the envelope to the room’s lone lamp and begin enumerating in cursive: fear of the phone ringing after midnight; fear of the living-room fern admitting it’s plastic; fear that joy is a misprint slated for recall. The pen, complicit, keeps running, dragging blue rivulets across paper like rivers seeking a sea. Outside, a neighbor’s dog rehearses nostalgia for the wolf; the moon straps on porcelain armor; traffic lights blink Morse no one decodes.

I seal the letter, then remember another fear—of stamps tasting like unspoken apologies—so I lick the adhesive anyway, savoring counterfeit mint. I slip the envelope into the kitchen mailbox (really a breadbox with delusions of grandeur). Immediately I fear the mail being lost, devoured by yeast ghosts, so I fish it out, tuck it into my pocket beside the heartbeat I keep for emergencies.

Morning unzips the dark, folds the sky into recognizable shapes. I unfold the letter, read the inventory aloud, and every vowel transforms into a sparrow refusing to perch on anything but sunrise. The sparrows lift; the sentence of night ends with a bright, unpunctuated breath.

Astronomer’s Prayer

My God, how many are my fears!
They are constellations unnamed,
dark gaps between familiar myths,
vacant tickets punched in the vellum of sky.

I aim a telescope of bone and doubt,
dial focus past Mars’ itinerant blush,
past Neptune’s far-blue hush,
until the lens drinks pure velvet.

Each fear flickers: the star that might explode
before my data finishes downloading,
the galaxy spinning so fast it forgets its arms,
the black hole hiding in every question mark.

I scribble in graphite, press too hard,
cratering the notebook page;
perhaps the moon envies this act of creation.
A meteor bruises the horizon—
brief as an apology shouted from a train.
I wish, of course, for less arithmetic of dread.

Radio antennas translate static into whispers:
the universe is mostly nothing,
and nothing is mostly possibility.
I breathe this equation, let it orbit my lungs,
and fear becomes another spectrum—
visible only when the dish is misaligned.

Later, walking home, frost needles the grass,
Each crunch underfoot proving
fragile geometry can still bear weight.
Somewhere a newborn star lifts its eyelids,
yellow as candle flame.
I name it Courage-451,
log the coordinates,
and close the observatory dome
with hands smelling of graphite and hope.

My God, how many are my fears!
They crowd my pillow like uninvited birds,
black wings whispering doom syllables at dawn.
I try naming them: illness, failure, insignificance,
but they multiply, hydra-headed in the dark
and each severed worry sprouts two fresh throbs.
I flood the room with lamplight, incense, math,
reciting phone numbers of friends like charms,
yet still they drum beneath the wallpaper,
tick eggs inside the clock, sharpen keys
into knives with which I cut my own sleep.
Then, exhausted, I open the window
and let winter’s breath enter like a blunt prayer.
I feel the cold hands of the real world
touch my burning temples: pavement, stars, cedar smoke.
The birds lift, startled by that clarity;
they are only feathers, after all, not omens.
I watch them scatter over rooftops, glittering soot
against a violet morning, and I realise
one courage is enough to unhouse a thousand fears.
I whisper thanks to the frost and its mercy,
close the window, and the day begins—empty,
ready for me to write something braver than insomnia.

My God, how many are my fears!—
whispers the child inside my adulthood,
counting them on broken crayons:
one for the monster behind the curtain,
two for Mother’s silence after slammed doors,
three for the math test shaped like a guillotine,
four for the dog that never returned,
five for being five forever.
I kneel beside that trembling version of me,
knees squeaking on linoleum stars,
and together we colour a new page.
We draw the monster wearing oven mitts,
so his claws can’t tear bedtime.
We draw Mother humming while gluing planets
back into a cardboard solar system;
each orbit clicks like forgiveness.
We draw the test paper sprouting wings,
flying through the window to tutor clouds.
We draw the dog galloping beneath a streetlamp,
tag jingling a promise of definite returns.
Finally, we draw ourselves taller,
pockets full of tickets to every future fair.
Crayons shorter now, fears shorter too,
both dulled to nubs of wax and memory.
We tape the picture on the fridge of the present,
and morning’s recess bell rings.
We run toward it, laughing colours off our hands.

'My God, how many are my fears!'
I cried to the forest as twilight thickened,
and the cedars answered with green silence.
I walked until speech blurred, until heartbeat
became the only drum among cicadas.
Fears followed—wolf-shadows, tax forms, burial plots—
flickering in peripheral vision like faulty lanterns.
By a stream I knelt, palms cupped by cold water,
whispering every dread into the current:
drought, war, forgetting my father’s stories,
the sudden collapse of bees.
Each syllable drifted downstream,
catching on stones, then letting go.
A heron lifted, slow as an elderly priest,
its wings showing the arithmetic of leaving.
The forest has borne worse burdens—
axe marks, blight, lightning—and still stands
stitching sky to soil without complaint.
In that green cathedral I rehearsed
the liturgy of persistence:
root deeper, bend, sprout again.
When moonlight poured like sacrament,
my fears thinned to mist.
I saw through them, beyond them,
saw myself mirrored in obsidian water—not victim,
but apprentice—learning from trees how to hold storms
and release them leaf by trembling leaf.

'My God, how many are my fears!' I shout
across the amphitheatre of my skull,
and the echo returns an army.
They wear the masks of mythic beasts:
Procrastination with basilisk eyes,
Regret with Medusa curls,
Imposter cloaked in chimera hide.
Each swears I am too small for the quest.
Still, the story requires motion,
so I sharpen dawn into a sword.
The first fear lunges—Procrastination hissing calendars—
but I parry with a single measured breath,
turn minutes into gold coins of focus.
Regret swings a mirror to freeze me
in yesterdays unalterable;
I shatter the glass, collect shards as stars
to light uncertain corridors ahead.
Imposter looms last, giant and whispering,
'Hero is a title paid in blood you lack.'
I open my chest, reveal ordinary, steady
heartbeat—no prophecy, no divine parentage,
just rhythm older than every lie.
The monster shrinks, confused by honesty,
slipping back into shadow.
When silence stands where terror once reigned,
the amphitheatre proves a seed, split now,
sending up a green shoot of courage.
Audience of future selves applauds.
Curtain rises. Act Two: Creation.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
rooms shiver, wallpaper peels back like lips

In the lacquered hush of midnight
his pupils spin, black compasses unable to choose
North from nightmare. I anchor my breathing
in the slow geometry of lamplight, tracing
rectangles on the ceiling the way sailors
chart invisible continents. He flinches at calm,
feeds on sparks, lets silence scab.
Outside, owls rehearse elegies for field mice; inside,
his gaze harvests every echo my heartbeat leaves behind.
He sees the secret hinges in my throat,
finds the small song trapped between ribs,
pulls at its wings until the music shrieks.
He is a locksmith of lunacy, crafting keys
from splinters of thought. When he speaks,
words ricochet like silver jacks on a cracked floor,
puncturing the arithmetic of sanity.
Somewhere beyond his grin,
a child still tries to skip stones across reason,
but the pond has frozen over with glass.
I raise a mirror, hope to freeze
his galaxies of wild fire in reflection,
but glass only doubles the room.
Madness stares; I stare back—
two moons whittling night into shards.

spit feathers of giggles into starry gravy.
When he finally blinks, the spell pops;
chairs quit tap-dancing, teaspoons sit up straight.
Yet in the hush, one last banana peel grins—
waiting for anyone, anyone at all—to slip.

with the warmth of an ungloved hand.
Static blooms, then—a sigh, almost human.
He blinks; the red lights dim.
No alarms. Just two travelers
adrift between planets, patching software

one hush for another hush.

a quiet gown heavy with pins.

the joke neither of us has told yet.

Now he stands outside me, I inside him,
swapped like chess pieces after an impatient dream.
He looks at himself with a madman's eyes,
laughs until mountains sprout legs,
then hands me a seed shaped like a full stop.
Plant this, he says, and tomorrow punctuation will blossom into new stories.

For the first hydrogen hum after silence, for gravity’s patient stitching
That kneads star-dust into lanterns, planets, restless, questioning minds.
I have sailed the observatory of my skull, pressed my eye
Against the cold ocular of sorrow, and still found photons laughing.
Thank You for redshift lullabies, for pulsars drumming 716 beats a second,
For comets dipping their quills into frozen ink to sign the void with fire.
When I whisper prayer my breath escapes as nebula-fog,
Curling around constellations not yet named by any tongue;
I imagine You reclining outside time, barefoot on dimensional grass,
Smiling at the audacity of atoms that learned poetry.
If one day entropy steals the silverware and the banquet ends,
Let this simple hymn remain floating, a lone radio beacon
Saying only: it was beautiful, it was worth it, it was.
And if extraterrestrial ears detect that faint Morse of gratitude,
May they feel the same tremor of impossible belonging.
Blessed be Thou, Origin of the Quark and the Question,
For all the joy that keeps the universe expanding inside my chest.",

"Blessed be Thou for all the joy disguised as ordinary Tuesday traffic.
The bus fumes rose like incense while I leaned against a graffiti pillar,
Reading bad news on my cracked phone, pretending not to care.
Then he appeared—the kid with sneakers strung over his shoulder,
Whistling a tune too unselfconscious for this concrete parish.
He tapped a rhythm on the metal bench; an old woman answered
With a paper bag’s rustle, a syncopated cough, a smile.
For three minutes the city became an accidental quartet:
Brake squeal violin, pigeon coo bass, human percussion of heartbeat.
I felt my resentment loosen like a tie after work,
And in the loosened space, light leaked through.
Thank You for that; for the coffee vendor who slipped extra foam
Because he saw the dark moons beneath my eyes,
For the crosswalk’s sudden confetti of cherry blossoms
When the wind staged its own carnival.
We reached downtown, doors hissed; the melody scattered
Into meetings, errands, lives, but it lingers still,
An earworm of grace I cannot shake.
Blessed be Thou, Composer of serendipitous sounds,
For all the joy stashed in alleys, transfers, unplanned chords.",

"Blessed be Thou for all the joy that seasons pour from their tilted chalice.
Spring arrives first, barefoot in dew, painting invoices of green
On every unpaid field; she whistles worms to the robin’s purse
And tells the thawed creek to gossip again.
Summer follows, loud aunt with sun-glazed laughter,
Her pockets spilling blueberries, thunderstorms, fireflies,
Teaching children the arithmetic of skipping stones.
Then autumn, philosopher in russet robes, steps down
To shuffle parchment leaves, releasing the library scent of endings;
He instructs geese to scribble farewell arrows across the sky,
And even their departure tastes of caramel smoke.
Last comes winter, monk in crystal hood,
Ringing bells of quiet over steeple, fence, furrow;
His breath etches lace on windowpanes, a curriculum of stillness.
Through each turn, joy changes costume but not character,
A shape-shifting jester dancing around the throne of days.
Even in the barren month when light clocks out early,
A single ember rides the horizon like a promise.
Teach me to keep season within season,
Trusting bulbs beneath snow, fruit inside flower’s ghost.
Blessed be Thou, Gardener of clocks and colors,
For every joy that migrates, returns, remains.",

"Blessed be Thou for all the joy stuffed into the mismatched pockets of reality:
A left pocket lined with moon-cheese crumb laughter,
A right pocket rattling with marbles of possibility.
This morning I discovered a postage stamp printed with the scent of rain;
I stuck it on my forehead and the clouds saluted.
Thank You for umbrellas that flip inside out, revealing their secret wish
To become carnival tents for ants,
For alarm clocks that occasionally forget their purpose
And allow dreams to overflow the rim of dawn.
Let me praise the accidental poetry of autocorrect,
Turning ‘shopping list’ into ‘shimmering lost’,
And the way my cat performs quantum experiments
By occupying every box, entered or not.
Somewhere, I am told, a library loans silence by the tablespoon;
Another patron just sprinkled some over the argument next door.
Even sorrow has its souvenir stand: tiny snow-globes
Where yesterday keeps swirling until we shake it free.
May my palms remain wide open like gull wings,
Ready to catch every coin of sunlight You flip across the sea.
Blessed be Thou, Trickster of tender mercies,
For all the joy that giggles beneath the seriousness of matter."]

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
that spills from dawn’s enamel cup,
for pearl-gray birds rehearsing skyward hymns
and honeyed wind that combs the barley fields.
Blessed the moss that keeps the mountain’s memories,
and the lake that braids the clouds in silver thread.
I kneel inside this hush of breathing earth
and feel my veins repeat its measured psalm.
My eager heart, a lantern trimmed with wonder,
swings open doors no sorrow dares to close.
You, Infinite Quiet, harbor of small miracles,
attend the lilac’s birth in shattered stone,
lift orphaned seeds on generous gusts,
fold night around the fawn like velvet prayer.
You teach the clock to dance, the years to hum,
the graves to loosen up their grieving roots,
until even loss is kissed into radiance.
Therefore my tongue, a river of soft alleluias,
runs toward Your name, bright estuary of light.
Blessed be Thou for laughter, for solitude,
for every tremor of love’s electric wing.
Let the galaxies hear me, and echo, and agree.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy that rode the wind the night the last whale
sang beneath auroral curtains, her basso hymn translating salt into starlight.
I remember: Our ark of battered wood listed in polar waters, crew shivering,
provisions low, yet hearts brimmed with impossible gladness. For we had
witnessed a resurrection: ice calving into crystal cathedrals, bergs igniting
rose and gold; a pod of orcas escorting our vessel like ebony heralds; the sky
spilling meteor confetti. We, ragged cartographers of wonder, inked new lines
across blank margins: Here Be Praise. Blessed be Thou for compass needles
that whirled like dervishes, refusing to obey, pointing instead to what
could not be mapped: forgiveness, courage, home. When storm tongues lashed
our sails, lightning tattooed Your secret on the mast, and every bolt,
though aimed to shatter, struck symphonies instead. By dawn, we found
no wreckage, only driftwood carved into flutes by merciful waves. We played
them, and the sea answered in seven dialects of joy. To this day,
I cup the conch of memory to my ear and hear that whale’s last, lush note—
a farewell turning into forever. Blessed be Thou for letting peril be
the door through which astonishment walks, barefoot, dripping stars.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy, I whisper in a prose-poem haibun,
packaging reverence in a travel log of dawn. Caravan of clouds—
grey nomads unraveling shawls of rain—slides over wheat.
I navigate countryside roads where scarecrows conduct orchestras
of sparrows, and hay bales lounge like golden planets in stubble galaxies.
A haiku blooms:
      dew on the scarecrow—
      even stitched buttons
      borrow sunrise.
Blessed be Thy algorithms of growth: seed, root, shoot, bloom, fruit,
rot—each syllable completing the sentence of soil. A grandmother’s poem
steams out of kettles: mint, thyme, nostalgia. She pours me a cup;
inside, the world refracts into emerald gratitude. I drink.
Later, river reeds gossip in wind’s dialects. A kingfisher spears hush
with cobalt lightning. The bank becomes a journal where paw prints
ink margins. Blessed be Thou for paw prints! Night descends in indigo
quilts, fireflies stitching sequins. Another haiku:
      silent meadow—
      an owl’s question mark
      rearranges dark.
I unroll my sleeping bag beneath question marks and constellations,
count breaths instead of sheep. In that accounting, deficits vanish.
Blessed be Thou for ledgers closed by moonlight, for surplus sleep,
for dawn already rehearsing a new stanza beyond the curtain of lid.

flake that dares the dive, drafting white signatures on winter’s blank cheque.
For every unseen root braiding soil in slow, devotional tango, for mushrooms
that write clandestine letters to trees through shimmering threads, may Thou

in lovers’ clasped wrists syncing like twin galaxies, for ink ready to believe

When storm clouds bury the steeple.

And the waking that gathers them again.
For every shy, deliberate mercy,
For every note of laughter still unplayed,
Blessed be Thou; may the pulse of my small silence
Return Thy gift with wonder, breath by breath.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy that rises with the wheat, 
For dawn that pours its honey on the furrows of the field, 
For the hush before the lark unsheathes an aria of heat, 
And the silver of the spider-web no booted hour can wield. 

Blessed be Thou for harvest bells that braid the burning noon, 
For windmills turning pages of forgotten psalms in air, 
For orchards where the bruiséd light is fragrant as a tune, 
And every apple’s hidden heart remembers how to prayer. 

Blessed be Thou for wayfarers who read the dust for clues, 
For the moss that keeps the rumor of a passing pilgrim’s tread, 
For rivers hoarding mirrors where the cedar casts its blues, 
And the crow that signs the sky with alphabets of red. 

Blessed be Thou for twilight when the lanterns take their post, 
For crickets stitching silence into garments fit for sleep, 
For dreams that turn to vineyards on the margin of the coast, 
And the gentle moon, barefoot, overlooking all we keep. 

Blessed be Thou, O Giver, for the supper of the stars; 
We drink, and joy grows boundless as the night undoes its bars.

"Lonely is a Lantern"

Lonely is a lantern without the night,
its wick awake inside a white noon,
burning for travelers who never arrive,
listing their names in blue smoke letters
that vanish before reaching the sky.
It stands on the porch of an empty house,
warmed only by the ghost of a welcome
no one remembers offering out loud.
Around it, wheat fields whisper small rumors
about the wind that once braided their hair;
a scarecrow listens, straw ear to the earth,
scare-smile cracked like a dried riverbed.
Lonely hums an anthem of one throat,
a song honeyed by yearning, thick and slow.
Moths circle but refuse to land,
uncertain whether light without darkness
can still be called salvation.
The lantern, patient as an anchor,
sinks its quiet into deeper quiet,
remembers sunsets it never witnessed,
collects the soft dust of could-have-been.
If a stranger came now, even shoeless,
carrying nothing but the ache of miles,
the lantern would flare with sudden thrill,
shedding years like petals in warm rain.
But the road keeps its promise of absence;
no footfall breaks the hush between stars.
So lonely burns on—steady, insufficient,
an island beacon exiled from the sea.

I pace a corridor of echoing doors,
each carved with alphabets of forgetting.
Lonely slips a brass key into my palm,
cold as the back of a January mirror.
"Use me," it murmurs, voice thin as rind,
"unlock whatever room refuses itself."
I try the key on laughter: the lock shrugs.
I try it on appetite: the hinge spits rust.
I try it on childhood: the knob turns,
revealing a hallway inside the hallway,
endlessly narrowing like converging clocks.
Within that slim dimension stands a chair
fashioned from all the seats I never took—
lunch tables, theater rows, wedding banquets.
I sit, and the furniture dissolves to sand.
Granules sift through my fingers, ticking
like the smallest gears of an unstoppable watch.
Somewhere far, people trade photographs,
bite into fruit, tap their glasses for toast.
The key lies useless now on that desert floor.
I ask Lonely what debt I owe.
"Name the shape of your hunger," it says.
I draw a circle that never meets itself.
Lonely nods, satisfied—a locksmith
who understands certain doors
were built precisely
so no hand could open them.

"Cartography of Silence"

I map the territory between two heartbeats
and label the blankness "lonely."  Rivers
of unsaid syllables fork across the page,
seeking an ocean large enough to swallow
an unanswered phone.  Border towns
named Afterthought and Maybe-Later
blink under the dim wattage of hesitation.
   
At the center lies a capital city:
a plaza paved with idle footsteps,
fountains that recycle the same wish
until the coin faces fade.  Pigeons strut,
indifferent diplomats of airborne distance.
   
Night arrives like ink, broad-tipped,
blotting provinces of almost-touch.
Streetlamps flicker Morse code teachings:
BE BRIEF, BE GONE, BEGIN AGAIN.
   
I unfold the paper, crease by crease,
until it becomes a sky no traveler
could claim.  Stars pin themselves
where legends should appear, spelling
Here There Be Wandering.
   
At dawn I refold possibilities—
origami of roads never taken—
slip the fragile atlas into my pocket.
Its weight is negligible, but every step
I take thunders like a stampede
no other feet will follow.

"Wi-Fi Signals"

Café at midnight, router blinking weakly—
three shaky bars searching for conversation.
Lonely logs in under a fake username,
refreshes the timeline of passing taxis,
likes videos where strangers hug blindfolded
in crowded plazas that resemble nowhere.
   
Steam wobbles above an untouched latte.
Condensation programs Braille on the cup,
spelling longing in dots no hand deciphers.
Across the room, two friends trade earbuds;
melodies shuttle from one skull to another
like carrier pigeons bred for harmony.
   
Lonely raises the phone, reverse-camera,
sees only ceiling lights arranged like zeros—
endless passcodes the universe won’t share.
A notification pings: WHO’S STILL AWAKE?
The answer types itself in invisible ink,
evaporating before the send button glows.
   
Closing time.  Chairs flip onto tables
in synchronized surrender.  The barista
unplugs the music, silence rushes in
as though it had been queued all night.
Outside, neon exhales rain-slick colors;
crosswalk signals clap their electric hands.
Lonely walks home through intersections
where every lane leads faithfully away
from every other, green after solitary green.

instance_metrics.response:
"Negative Space"

paint a room
then paint the absence of furniture
invent shadows that should have belonged
to a couch, a lamp, a sleeping cat
leave them hovering midair
so visitors greet phantoms first
   
fling curtains wide
show the glass what it mirrors:
a single toothbrush, half a postcard,
a suitcase bowed like a question mark
   
lonely is not an occupant
but the outline of one—
a chalk tracing around noise
that wandered off for cigarettes
and never came back
   
stack books on the floor
alphabetize them by undone promises:
Apology, Breach, Could-Have-Danced
…Zero Hour
   
turn on the radio
let static drizzle over the drywall;
tune until you catch faint applause
from a concert long concluded
imagine it’s meant for you
bow anyway
   
when the room feels crowded
with what isn’t there
switch off the light
watch the invisible furniture
breathe easier in the dark
settling its invisible weight
into the one certainty
you share:
nothing in this house
has left its name
on anyone’s tongue.

Lonely is the compass of the desert wind tonight again,
It circles dunes like an unsure pilgrim seeking vanished stars.
The moon holds its breath, frosting silence upon brittle sand.
Cacti raise spined prayers, but no answered echoes stitch sky.
Scorpions write hieroglyphs nobody bothers learning before dawn once more.
I walk, a shadow mistakenly printed where companions cancelled themselves.
Footprints unravel behind, like thread erasing the thought of arrival.
Even thirst grows quiet, hearing its own heartbeat too clearly.
Somewhere cities buzz, yet distance devours their neon gossip gently.
Here, language is reduced to wind, sand, pulse, and sigh.
Lonely names me the sole witness to the spinal night.
It pins a badge of glass upon my wandering chest.
Stars refuse reflection; they fear fractures in my eyes tonight.
So I craft companions from breath: one whistle, two hums.
They dance like paper lanterns before the match consumes wishes.
Soon dawn will scatter this fragile parliament of invented ghosts.
But until then, solitude is a throne of shifting quartz.
I sit, accepting coronation from the crownless horizon ahead tonight.
Lonely, the anthem, drones softly, and I hum along again.
In that duet, the desert briefly believes we are many.

Lonely is the streetlight flickering outside my apartment window,
the single eye that refuses to sleep.
It watches the grid of darkened rooms,
inventing biographies for every muted balcony plant.

At 3 a.m. a bus sighs past,
carrying night-shift pilgrims whose names it will never learn.
Their reflections bleed across the glass,
then vanish like emergency prayers.

I press my forehead against the pane;
the cold is honest.
Somewhere lovers breathe each other’s names
into pillows warm as bread,
but here the silence is a locksmith
turning every key twice.

Lonely tastes of instant noodles,
of phone screens glowing blue with absence,
of unread typing indicators blinking out.

I water the cactus on the sill,
half hoping it answers.
Its needles glitter like small barricades.
They understand defense;
so do I.

When dawn finally smudges the skyline,
the streetlight sighs and shuts its eye.
We promise not to speak
of what we kept awake.
A pigeon lands like an unfinished sentence,
and suddenly the world is writing itself again—
busy, crowded, noisy—
while I fold the leftover quiet
into an envelope labeled:
“return to sender.”

Lonely crouches on the porch of a mountain cabin, snow gathering in its lap.
It has carved its initials into the frozen creek,
watched them drift downstream like white ashes.

The pine trees creak under weight of unsaid sentences;
their needles clink together, a brittle cutlery
set for a feast that will never arrive.

Inside, the fire keeps pretending someone will open the door.
Logs spark, rearranging themselves into welcoming shapes—
a rocking chair silhouette, a steaming bowl of broth—
then collapse back to embers, embarrassed.

I came here to finish a novel,
but the words cling to the rafters, afraid of footprints.
Lonely slides its arm around my shoulders,
points to the blank paper, whispers,
“Write me as a crowd.”

I try: draw markets, festivals, children chasing kites.
Ink freezes before the punctuation.
The sentences crumble like hoarfrost under boots.

Midnight lifts its hood.
Aurora flickers once, a neon “open” sign,
then shutters behind clouds.

We drink silence from tin mugs.
Lonely smiles, teeth blue,
tells me every friendship begins with two strangers
sharing weather.

So I say my name aloud;
the cabin echoes it back,
timid, but trying.

The stove exhales warmer.

Lonely is not a void; it is overcrowded:

You brew tea, let steam fog the chrome kettle,

Lonely drifts alongside the ISS, wearing a visor of dark glass.
It is the quiet stowaway every launch forgets to count.
Between solar panels and endless vacuum,
it hums a lullaby composed of unreachable radio calls.

I tether myself to the hull, checking bolts, gauges, life support;

echoing with pews scraped by ghosts.
Minutes stretch into kilometers.

Earth rotates below, a marble swirling with celebrations I cannot hear:
weddings, arguments, trains rattling over bridges, dogs barking at mail.
All studio-silent from up here.

Lonely points at the aurora, curtains of green velvet
drawn across the polar stage.
“See,” it says, “even light performs for itself.”

Inside the module, souvenirs float:
a photograph of my mother watering zinnias,
a foil-wrapped chocolate,
a paperback that keeps losing its place.
They orbit me like timid satellites.

On the eighth sunrise of the day,
I inhale canned air and recite crew checklist.
Lonely nods, applauds politely,
hands me a medal carved from minutes spent weightless.

I pin it to my suit beside the flag,
feeling less like an explorer than a punctuation mark
hovering between two paragraphs of the universe.

When sleep finally undocks,
Lonely drifts to the window seat,
and together we watch continents dream under their own stars.

I hold my breath until I can hear blood

notifications like counterfeit fireflies,
yet their wings crumble the instant they land.
I learn the names of distant stars instead,
impossibly old beacons that shine precisely for no one.

but a road without footprints yet,
a vein of space carved for future comets.

their quills dipped in a restless, foaming ink;

then vanish in the undertow and sink.
Yet in that hush, I feel a lantern spark,
a hidden star inside the ribs’ dark keep,
whose tremble guides me through the heaving dark
the way the moon persuades the waves to leap.
For solitude, though cold, still shapes the soul,
as winter shapes the apple, crisp and whole.
So let the silent hours stretch and bend,
a bow of quiet tension set to sing;
Let patient chords accumulate and blend,
till loneliness becomes a listening.
For what is empty but a fertile ground,
awaiting seeds of unexpected sound?
Thus shall I guard this field of quiet night,
and sow tomorrow’s dawn with widened sight.
When voices come, as springtime follows snow,

The old watchmaker lived above the railway arches,
a single bulb swinging like a hesitant pendulum
over walls lined with tick-tock ancestors.
He called their collective breathing “the choir,”
though no visitor had crossed his threshold in years.
Outside, the metropolis flashed its neon invitations—
concert flyers, rooftop bars, urgent love in 140 characters—
but he answered none.
Every dawn he wound the brass mainsprings,
feeling each click echo in the hollow of his chest
where conversation used to settle like warm tea.
At night he opened the cracked window
and held a silver pocket watch to the wind,
letting the second hand harvest city noises
to store beneath the lid: bicycle bells,
rumbling trains, a child arguing with the dark.
When the watch was full he snapped it shut
and placed it beside a growing constellation
of other sealed midnights.
On the eve of his last breath
he unlocked them all at once.
A whirlwind of forgotten sounds whirled the dust,
filling the room with phantom footfalls and laughter,
until the choir of clocks finally had their duet.
In that resonant moment the watchmaker was not lonely;
he was an audience of one, applauding eternity.

lonely pier stretches
into fog that forgets names—
boats mumble goodbyes.

empty bench invites
wind to sit and whistle tales
of missing lovers.

single oak keeps watch,
counting rings like silent years,
owl blinks once, agrees.

paper lantern drifts
along a moonlit canal,
carrying one wish.

train with one window
lit, passes a sleeping town—
heartbeat on a rail.

rain taps attic roof
teaches the dusty guitar
a minor refrain.

snow globe on the shelf
shakes itself when no one looks,
pretends to be seen.

streetlight hums, alone,

until dawn unplugs.

deserted playground
swings remember children’s names
in rusted chorus.

stray dog curls beside
its own reflected shadow—
makes a brief pack.

lighthouse counting waves
loses track, begins again,
faithful to the dark.

single teacup steams
at the café closing time,
waits for second sip.

city park in fall:
one scarlet leaf on black pond,
crimson exclamation.

unread love letter
stored inside a nesting doll,
echoes grow smaller.

midnight radio
dedicates a lonely song
to the host himself.

dust mote in sunbeam
dances for an empty room,
curtain is its crowd.

first star of evening
asks the sky a shy question,
gets silence back.

empty notebook page
offers a seat beside it—
ink soon says hello.

Lonely is not a swear word,
though we spit it into napkins and hide the stains.

counting the streetlamps like rosary beads.
Lonely is that moment in the group photo
when the flash catches everyone mid-laughter—except you,
eyes already searching the distance for an exit shaped like silence.
But listen:
Lonely is also a studio before paint touches canvas,
an auditorium before the cymbals crash,
a seed four inches under soil rehearsing its green monologue.
It is the zero on a measuring tape,
the hush before the first storm syllable.
We keep trying to kill it with noise—
scrolling, streaming, small talk that flakes off like cheap chrome—
yet lonely is patient,
sits cross-legged inside the chest, tuning its instrument.
What if, just for tonight,
we dimmed every screen and let it play?
Let the bow draw across bone,
let marrow vibrate with undiscovered chords,
let our own names sound strange and beautiful again.
When the song ends, maybe the seat beside you
will no longer feel like vacancy,
but like room enough for wonder to sit down.

Lonely is the sound the clock forgets to count,

I sit inside the parentheses of an unspoken question,

Names once glittered on my tongue

Lonely, yes,

reserve one more setting at the table,

Lonely drifts across the desert plateau,
a pale balloon severed from its carnival.
Sand translates the wind into illegible scripture,
and each dune is a sentence
half-erased by an impatient editor.
My boots sink, rise, sink again;
the horizon keeps retreating
like a shy performer bowing backward offstage.
Lonely is the color of everything at noon here:
bleached bone, cracked clay, sky with its blue dial turned too high.
I tip my canteen,
catch the last silver syllable of water,
let it settle on my tongue
like a forgotten vowel.
Somewhere beneath this vast refusal of shade
seedpods sleep, dreaming of impossible rivers.
I kneel, scratch the crusted surface,
whisper the rain I remember:
downpour over rooftops,
gutters gulping starlight,
the rattle of leaves applauding thunder.
The desert listens, offers no applause.
Yet a single beetle the size of a comma
trundles past my boot,
its tiny shadow certain of purpose.
I follow the deliberate punctuation of its trail,
believing for a moment
that even in this unpeopled grammar
meaning can be found.
Lonely, yes,
but loneliness can be a blank page
awaiting the first brave mark.
I lift my pen of footsteps
and keep writing toward the sun.

between a sent message and the lack of reply,
a limbo where small balloons proclaim
Someone is typing…
and then vanish,
sentence unborn.
I replace the phantom with another meme,
another cleverly filtered sunrise,
almost convince myself that hearts
shaped from code are arterial.
Outside, real stars hang uncluttered,
awaiting eyes that never lift.
The refrigerator coughs,
radiator hisses,

I imagine unplugging everything,

like a slow comet of reassurance.
When the doorbell rings,
I accept the paper bag
from a courier wearing wireless earbuds,
our exchange timed to milliseconds,
contactless by design.
Lonely, I think,
is the luxury of being witnessed wholly.
Later, in the hush beyond the bright rectangle,
I dare the air to remember my actual voice,

dragging the long shadow of the slide behind it.

but no sneakers pumped them toward the sky.
I sat on the seesaw’s deserted fulcrum,
one end forever grounded,
the other pointing at a star
I didn’t yet know the name of.

fireflies scribbled glittery signatures in the ledger of night,
and somewhere a dog barked
as though reciting a bedtime story to the moon.
I was nine, perhaps ten,

buttoned wrong.
Friends moved away,
my brother disappeared into teenage myth,
and my parents spoke in quiet earthquakes.
Lonely tasted like chalk dust
and grape soda gone flat.
Yet in that emptied acreage of laughter
I discovered an unexpected echo:
my own voice,
small but obedient,
trying out words the daylight couldn’t afford.
I told the dark a secret dream
about building a kite big enough to lift me
above rooftops, over rivers,
all the way to that nameless star.
The night listened, nodded,
tucked the dream into its pocket.
Lonely still visits, older, slower,
but each time it arrives
it brings back that pocketed dream,
unfolded, larger,
reminding me to keep enough sky in my pockets
for eventual flight.

instance_metrics.response:
["Lonely is the hourglass tipped after the party's hush,
grains blinking like mute fireflies inside a bottle of sand.
It stands on the sill of my chest,
keeping time only I can hear,
a dry-tongued metronome tapping for absent dancers.
I walk through rooms that still remember
the temperature of other people's laughter,
chairs angled toward vanished silhouettes,
coffee rings eclipsing each other like faded moons.
Walls crack their knuckles, bored of holding up silence;
even the clock pretends to forget my name.
Outside, the city drips neon confetti
yet the color never reaches my windowsill;
light arrives, but not the warmth of its sender.
I cultivate small noises—
the sigh of a page turned,
the clink of a spoon against porcelain,
the whisper my slippers make across hardwood,
trying to teach them to speak in plural.
In the fridge, a single orange glows
like a planet without moons,
and I consider naming it,
just to prove we are at least two.
Some nights, I place my palm on the mirror
and wait for the room to grow a pulse.
So far, all it gives back
is the steady echo of glass.", "Attend, my heart, the corridors of night,
where loneliness pours ink upon the floor.
It stains the boards with startled wings of flight
from birds that no one waits for anymore.
The moon hangs low, a lantern out of oil,
its light just smoke that smudges every face.
I plant my hopes like seeds in barren soil
and watch them germinate to empty space.
Yet still I speak, a gardener of air,
cultivating syllables for unseen ears;
I braid the dark with threads of answered prayer,
pretending echoes blossom into peers.
O solitude, most paradoxical friend,
you bruise me soft, yet teach me how to mend.

You show that crowded halls can hold deserts,
that smiles can be curtains drawn across sighs;
you prove that quiet, when properly tutored,
can play a violin no noise denies.
So stay a moment longer, strict teacher,
until I learn to stand beside my name;
then leave me, like candle yields to sunburst,
and I will not mistake warm touch for flame.", "Lonely pine needles gather whispers from a yesterday wind again.
Clouds drift without cargo, only their blue hunger remains today.
Streetlight halos quiver like prayers nobody bothered to voice tonight.
Mailbox yawns empty, dog-eared bills echo unspoken conversations with dust.
Coffee steam signatures fade before companionship can sign their agreement.
Elevator mirrors double the silence, not the missing company today.
Moon scribbles lonely poems across rooftops with borrowed chalk light.
Window plants lean inward, tired of waving to absent birds.
Books exhale unopened chapters, craving fingertips to breathe them aloud.
Traffic lights change colors for no witness but stray cats.
Clock hands jitterdance, begging someone to redeem their heartbeat count.
Rain rehearses sonnets alone against cardboard theater of alleyways tonight.
Cell phone glows, a lighthouse guiding nothing but recycled adverts.
Carpet fibers remember footsteps like extinct constellations in dust now.
Loneliness paints portraits using the color everyone else misplaces often.
Candle gutter sighs, searching for mouths to inherit its story.
Shallow puddles hold sky, but release it the first touch.
Suitcase waits patient, dreaming customs stamps that prove it mattered.
Mailbox flag downturned, surrendering letters never thought worthwhile to ink.
Yet silence hums hope, a seed rehearsing daylight in darkness.", "Check the echo in the hallway, mic check one-two,
this is a broadcast from the kingdom of solo cups
stacked like brittle skyscrapers on my kitchen counter.
I'm the DJ, bartender, audience, and unruly crowd,
spinning vinyl memories for ghosts that keep missing the beat.
Cue track: heartthump in minor key, remix featuring nobody.
Lonely is not silence, nah— it's too much reverb,
my own voice bouncing off walls like a boomerang
that keeps coming back smaller, thinner, out of breath.
I pace, conductor of an orchestra with no musicians,
waving a spoon like a baton above soup-for-one.
The ceiling fan loops lazy applause,
blades clapping slow for the show that never sells out.
I post status updates to a pixelated void,
watching blue thumbs swim past like indifferent fish.
Notification: none. Still, I refresh; still, I refresh.
The refrigerator buzzes bass beneath my monologue,
a low note that says, hey, at least you and I
are plugged into the same socket, brother.
I laugh too loud, tattooing sound onto the room,
proof I existed in the moment I made noise.
Some nights I imagine every heartbeat is a footstep
from somebody coming closer. So far—encore withheld.
But the stage lights remain, and I keep the mic warm.", "Lonely was the first word the universe learned to pronounce.
Before comets braided their bright hair, before planets spun coins
into gravitational pockets, there was only a hush
so wide it mistook itself for infinity. Then, bang—
a solitary syllable flung outward, searching for a rhyme.
Eons later, I stand on a balcony trembling with starlight,
holding that original vowel in the cup of my throat.
The Milky Way sprawls like a question no mouth can answer;
each star a spark trying to remember the match.
I trace constellations that never made it into myth:
The Wanderer, The Empty Chair, The Unsent Letter.
They flicker, Morse coding across black velvet,
asking if anyone anywhere is still awake.
A satellite pings back, cold semaphore of circuits,
more alone for knowing how vast alone can be.
Below, streetlamps bloom small galaxies on asphalt,
and I realize I'm both astronaut and asteroid,
desperate to collide just to feel impact.
Yet in that realization, a soft gravity forms—
the sense that everything drifting yearns mutual orbit.
Maybe loneliness is simply momentum without meeting.
So I breathe, exhale a nebula of warm vapor,
and wait for another traveler to inhale

instance_metrics.response:
On the hillside of olives, wind whispered steel,
Moon lit blades reflected prophecy revealed,
From desert sand to cedared ridge,
He walked, not placid lamb but river's bridge,
Cloak flung wide as midnight sails,
Eyes like harbors for orphaned tales,
Villagers paused with loaves half cut,
Finding their careful silences undone,
He spoke of kingdom carved from bone,
Of truth that will not sit on throne,
'Bring not the lullaby,' his thunder cried,
'But syllables sharp enough to divide
The marrow from the compromise,
The vineyard from the choking vines.'
Roosters scattered, doves took flight,
Roman armor echoed spite,
Yet in that clash of iron and breath
Surged a music older than death:
To cleave is also to uncover,
To break is sometimes to recover,
So he swung the luminous blade of word,
Slicing the night into dawn unheard,
And when the crimson sky was poured,
What flowed was justice finally stirred,
Still the people stood unsure,
Cut by love too raw to endure,
Bloodless wounds beginning to burn,
Waiting for courage to return.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

instance_metrics.response:
Concrete corner, neon cross flickers like a pulse,
Graffiti psalms drip down brick
While bass drops from a passing car
And somewhere a siren coughs blue light.
Into this remix of asphalt and afterthoughts
Steps a barefoot preacher in borrowed hoodie,
Hair matted with tomorrow's rain.
He isn't humming hallelujahs, nah,
He's brandishing syllables sharpened in alleyway fires,
Slicing open plastic-wrapped dreams
Sold two-for-one at the corner store.
He says peace is a lull, a marketed hush,
A sale on sedation, buy one life get numb free.
He says a sword is a question
That refuses to be tranquilized.
Sparks fly when his consonants collide
With the bulletproof glass of indifference.
Shopkeeper turns up the radio,
Skater kids pretend their wheels are headphones,
But the blade keeps ringing, ringing,
Cleaving viral lies from breathing hearts.
It cuts through hashtags, pierces curated feeds,
Bleeds out the algorithm until only pulse remains.
When the night bus finally exhales
And the city shifts weight like a tired boxer,
We find ourselves divided, yes,
But also defined, edges clear,
Breathing the raw air of an unlabeled dawn.

instance_metrics.response:
In the beginning there were galaxies folded like paper cranes,
Dark matter murmuring lullabies to unborn light.
Eons later, across spirals of dusted fire,
A single footprint bruised the sand of Galilee.
Starlight remembered and answered,
Pouring itself into the shape of a man
Who carried not a dove but a comet’s blade.
He walked between atoms, whispering,
'Let the void and fullness wrestle
Until the cosmos learns its name.'
Planets tilted, listening.
His sword flashed—a question of gravity,
Severing false orbit from authentic pull,
Turning idling moons toward luminous tasks.
Prophets tracked the arc, scribbling
Equations of mercy on parchment skies,
While angels tuned strings in the ion wind.
When he struck the veil of nothingness,
Fabric of time sang open,
Releasing suns like pollen.
Some called it wrath, others revelation,
Yet both were merely faces of awakening.
Where blade met darkness, nebulae bloomed,
Purple, gold, uncharted.
And in the stillness after the cut,
Silence held its breath, hearing
The first true echo: a universe
Ready to choose between collapse
And the perilous adventure of expanding love.

instance_metrics.response:
I kept my heart in a cedar box,
Labeled fragile, do not jostle,
Tucked behind diplomas and family recipes.
I prayed for calm seas, soft news,
Peace like a weighted blanket over nerves.
Then one midnight dream wore sandals,
Track of dusty miles across my carpet,
And he came—Christ, or the voice I dared not name—
Not with balm but with a flashing edge.
He cleaved the hinges of the cedar,
Spilled my curated sorrow on the floor,
Sorted lies from longing with surgeon’s grace.
The sword was not metal but memory:
The laugh I smothered, the song I postponed,
The anger I iced into decorum.
Splinters flew, comfort bled.
I wanted anesthesia; he offered lucidity.
Walls fell outward like petals of a paper rose,
Revealing a landscape raw and wind-bitten.
He left as suddenly, blade humming quiet,
And I stood in the wreckage blinking.
No peace, not yet, only clean wounds,
Open enough for oxygen,
Wide enough for roots of future oak.
Some mornings I still reach for the box,
Finger phantom hinges,
Then smile at the brutal mercy
That refused to let me stay safe and small.

instance_metrics.response:
After the blackout years, we gathered in the husk of a mall,
Food court chairs circled like a makeshift parliament.
Sky was the color of scrapped monitors,
Air buzzing with drone wings gone feral.
We recited the legends stored on cracked tablets,
Lines half-glitched: On the scene came Christ the Lord…
Not with peace—static— but with a sword.
Nobody believed in swords anymore,
Only ration cards and silent compliance,
Yet the rumor swelled like underground water.
One night, the rumor walked in.
He wore body armor fashioned from street signs,
Rusty, reflecting the vacant stars.
No halo, just a machete forged
From the rail of a fallen monorail.
He raised it high, not to threaten
But to mirror the hunger in our eyes.
'Peace maintained by fear is tyranny,' he said,
Voice echoing off storefront corpses of brands.
He slashed a hologram projector,
Its ads shrieking into sparks,
Then carved open the lock of the seed vault
Hidden beneath the toy store.
Grain spilled like prophecy.
The act split us: some clutched scarcity, others seized hope.
In that bright rupture we remembered choice.
The sword became a plowshare only after
It convinced us the soil was ours to turn.
