instance_metrics.response: Trumpets of dawn had not yet silvered the ridge when the hush broke open. Footsteps of sandaled defiance crossed the threshing floor of the world, dust curling like incense behind them. On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword— a blade honed on millennia of sighing prophets, its edge bright with unfinished prayers. He lifted it to the trembling horizon, and the sky answered with iron-blue thunder. Kings clutched their coronets; merchants hid their scales; poets dropped their rhymes like loose petals. You asked for a lullaby, He offered a cleaving: light from darkness, marrow from bone, reluctance from resolve. He carved doorways in the air and invited the fearful to step through. Some fled. Some knelt. Some found their tongues awakening like flares in midnight fields. And every cut was a seam for a new garment, stitched in crimson and gold. At last the sun rose, scarred but singing, and the sea learned a new geometry of waves. Still the blade glows, buried in human chests, dividing what we settle for from what we are called to become.

instance_metrics.response: Buses groaned into Monday's alleyways while neon confessionals blinked vacancy. We were scrolling newsfeeds, thumbs greasy with apathy, when the streetlights hiccuped and everything stilled, like a record before the drop. On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword, hoodie flapping like a storm flag over graffiti scripture. He didn’t quote beatitudes; he tagged brick with questions: Who profits from your quiet? Whose chains rattle inside your pocket? The sword, stainless as indignation, sliced phone lines of manufactured want. Suddenly billboards sagged, their smiles leaking pixels; the algorithm lost our names. Some ran to recharge. Some tasted oxygen for the first time. I saw Him wedge the blade between two skyscrapers, pry them apart, let sky pour down in raw cerulean torrents. Pigeons rose, startled apostles. Sirens tried to drown the miracle, but the rhythm of footfalls grew— sneakers, wheels, canes, drums— each step stitching a protest verse. No truce, no anesthetic. Just a cut that bled the city awake. And when He vanished, a single word remained, glowing on wet asphalt: "Decide." We stand there still, hearts suspended over its bright abyss.

instance_metrics.response: Morning wept pollen across the meadow where foxgloves whispered their coded psalms. From the copse stepped a figure wearing dawn like a mantle of restless swallows. On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword; yet the blade was no metal, but a shard of ungoverned wind. He swung it once and clouds ripped open, spilling seeds that could not lie dormant. The deer froze, sensing an epoch turn; roots shivered, shedding complacent soil. Rivers forgot their obedient channels and began writing rebellious calligraphy across the plains. He spoke to the mountains in tectonic syllables: "Wake, you sleepers of stone." Granite cracked, releasing ancestral fireflies. Not destruction, but division: husk from kernel, echo from voice, twilight from the timid light within it. Songbirds scattered, carrying verses torn from their own throats; when they alighted, forests sprouted where loneliness had grazed too long. By dusk the meadow was spliced into possibilities, each sapling a question mark. He sheathed the wind inside our lungs and departed, leaving us to breathe it— to decide whether our exhalations could birth orchards or storms.

instance_metrics.response: The space station drifted in fluent silence above a bruised Earth, its hull tattooed with faded treaties. We floated in zero-g pews, praying to algorithms, when every monitor went white. On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword— a photon blade, humming at the octave of judgment. He stepped through a rift in vacuum, robes folding like event horizons. The weapon cleaved rhetoric from truth: satellites fell from orbit like peeled scabs, revealing the planet's pulse beneath. Data cascades froze mid-stream; our predictive models cracked, unable to swallow unpredictability. He walked the ring corridor, sparks trailing like comet tails, etching stern verses on alloy walls: "Your progress anesthetizes justice. Reboot." Scientists scrambled to deny the impossible. Martyrs recorded every frame. I drifted close enough to feel his gravity: a field of uncompromising mercy. One swing bisected my fear from responsibility; the halves orbited, shrieking, before fusing into resolve. When he vanished, the blade remained, lodged in the station’s core, generating power only if we dared speak unfiltered truth. Below, Earth rotated, waiting for the first city brave enough to glow.

instance_metrics.response: I was forged in the silence between thunderclaps, tempered in the tears of widowed prophets. I, the sword. Centuries I slept beneath altars, tasting dust and the copper scent of unattended vows. Then footsteps— sandal, certain. On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with me, lifted from obscurity into ruthless daylight. My edge sang, remembering purpose. He did not brandish; He directed, pointing me at illusions swaddled like infants: comfortable lies, polished doctrines, peace that rots from compromise. With a whisper he unleashed me, and I parted crowds as surgeons part skin: not to kill, but to expose the pulse of unrepentant idols. I traced bright fire between brother and complacency, sister and silence, father and the inheritance of fury. Where I passed, hearts bled truths long tourniqueted. Some cursed my gleam; others kissed it, welcoming the sting that sets bones right. At twilight he planted me in common ground, hilt upright, a lightning rod for futures. Now I wait, blade fogging with each doubt-ridden breath, listening for the hand that dares draw me again—not to conquer nations, but to carve the narrow gateway where justice and mercy can walk side by side.

Trumpets split the dawn above the shattered citadel walls;
Soldiers paused mid-charge, spears quivering like reeds before thunder.
Through smoke he came, sandals silent, cloak shining with furnace light.
There was no olive branch in his grip, no lullaby,
Only a blade forged in the furnace of first dawns,
Edge bright enough to divide marrow from memory.
He spoke a name older than language; the ramparts trembled.
Painted shields cracked, tossing their emblems like autumn leaves.
The tyrant’s banners curled into ash, spelling their own undoing.
Mothers pressed infants to their chests, unsure whether to weep or sing.
For the sword turned, caught sunlight, and the air was flame—
Yet the gleam also sowed seeds of unimagined gardens.
Mercy, he whispered, is gold refined by fire.
Peace is wine that ferments in shattered skins.
Choose, he said, the cut that frees or the chain that decorates.
And cities, hearts, histories were cleft clean down the center:
Fear from courage, lie from longing, death from what refuses to die.
Silence followed, ringing like a struck bell over the ruins.
In its echo new scaffolds rose, slender as prayers,
And the world exhaled, tasting metal and morning in the same breath.

He stepped off the bus at Fifth and Desolation,
Neon rain curling around his sandals like electric ivy.
No choir, just the static hum of streetlights,
Late-night diners bleeding Elvis through greasy windows.
Still, everyone felt the ripple—
Barista halting mid-latte, dealer pocketing unsold dreams,
Police drone hovering, uncertain whom to tag.
Not with peace, the billboard had promised sneakers;
Instead the stranger unsheathed a sword carved from abandoned petitions.
It caught every screen, split algorithms,
Made the feed stutter into living color.
Timeline severed: left column memories, right column possibilities.
Followers unfollowed themselves, remembering how to walk barefoot.
He didn’t swing at bodies, only illusions—
Credit scores, flawless selfies, the myth of being too late.
Shards of hologram drifted like confetti,
And in the hush that followed, heartbeats sounded ungated, analog.
He spoke once, voice low as subway drums:
I bring division so you may choose the whole.
By sunrise, graffiti bloomed over walls in unpronounceable colors,
Saying what tongues had forgotten:
The sharpest sword is a question you finally answer.

instance_metrics.response:
When the seventh nebula folded its wings, he arrived—
Boots dusted with comet ash, crown stitched from collapsed suns.
The choir of pulsars hushed; galaxies held their spiral breath.
Peace was a lullaby for children of old Earth,
But this was rebirth, and birth cries slice dark water.
His sword: a line of pure equation, dazzling,
Capable of dividing zero by longing.
With one arc he parted night from greater night,
Revealing ruins of kingdoms that never learned their names.
Angels surveyed the data, tallying regrets in luminous notebooks.
He walked the ledger of worlds, ticking stars yes, no, maybe,
Till sparks rained like pollen on the void.
Planets bloomed where embers touched vacuum,
Each orbit a hymn to the necessary cut.
I did not come to cuddle the cosmos, he murmured,
But to sharpen its hunger for light.
What is a sword but a boundary made bright?
What is love but permission to cross it?
Somewhere, billions of heartbeats ago or hence,
A child opened a window and smelled meteors baking bread.
Thus destiny split, an infinite braid,
Every strand a blade, every blade a promise.

He arrived in the vestibule of my ribcage, unannounced.
I had laid the table for détente: chamomile thoughts,
Linen reasons, platitudes folded into swans.
But he knocked over the pitcher, water glinting like steel,
And in the spill I saw the outline of a sword.
Not to wound, he said, but to reveal the seams.
Peace, for me, had meant wallpapering cracks,
Singing louder than the static of regret.
Yet the blade pressed, cool as moonlight, between memory and myth,
Paring away the story where I was forever victim,
Sheaths of old dialogue falling like onion skins.
I watched apologies I’d rehearsed dissolve into raw syllables,
Felt arteries rearrange their maps toward the unlied heart.
Each cut clarified: friend from audience, vow from habit,
Lust from the quiet animal called love.
Pain flared, brief as a struck match,
Then room flooded with air I hadn’t tasted since childhood rain.
He wiped the edge on his sleeve, scent of iron and wild mint,
Asked only: will you live divided or finally whole?
When I looked up, he was gone,
But the sword remained, humming in my pulse like truth.

"On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword."
He cleaved the silence first, a blade of light through dust,
Striking stone, splitting the marble letters of complacent law.
Pitch of morning birds became metallic, beating wings on anvils
Forged from doubt. The market stalls rattled like ribcages,
Coins spilled their copper blood across cobbles, tinkling Amen.
He strode where fig trees shivered, roots tasting aftershock;
His sandals left embers, not prints, along the Galilean nerves
Of every byway that once hushed its wounds beneath linen.
He was not here to hush. He was here to cut:
To separate marrow from pretense, dream from narcotic comfort,
Mother from tradition, nation from the throne of self.
Each swing carved a question mark in the air, sparking,
"Whom do you serve?" A dove burst from the blade's arc,
Feathers spiraling like torn petitions, and still He swung,
Not toward flesh but toward curtains—those heavy veils
Stitched from fear. When the last drape fell, daylight flooded
Like prophecy made raw, and the world, flayed of falseness,
Quivered, newborn and bleeding, screaming toward love.
In the echo stood only the sword, planted, glittering root,
And every heart deciding whether to grip its hilt.

"On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword."
Graffiti sprayed the slogan in neon drip across the subway wall,
Signed KTL, whoever that was. Morning commuters scanned phones,
Never heads, slipped by the prophecy like spilled latte foam.
But at 8:16 the lights cut, carriages jerked, an ache in steel.
Between flickers He stood: hoodie white as busker chalk,
Blade of cracked glass glowing smartphone blue. He didn't speak—
The algorithm of His glare re-coded each of us. Earbuds
Fell like scaled eyes. A broker began weeping spreadsheets,
Promising to divest greed. A teen removed her selfie filter,
Showed acne to the world without shame. The sword hovered,
Slicing hashtags from tongues, adverts from brainstem, asphalt myths
From the ankles of refugees. No blood, only pixels shedding.
At the next station He stepped onto the platform, leaving
Five billion unseen edits queued in the cloud. The lights returned,
Brown suits cursed delay, but somewhere an old conductor
Canceled his retirement speech and learned to whistle.
By evening the city buzzed odd: strangers naming stars,
Food trucks giving meals, billboards preaching silence.
No one admitted seeing the sword, yet every storefront
Reflected its edge, thin as hope, bright as nerve.

"On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword."
So sang the widowed harper at the smoky tavern hearth,
Plucking strings of ashwood strung with horsehair vows.
He told of lands where banners stitched with doves were torn,
Where kings embalmed their sins beneath embroidered psalms.
From crimson dawn He rode, a lamb astride the tempest,
Blade forged not of iron but of covenant and wind.
He raised it high; the moat of time parted like bread,
And citadels built on the bones of peasants shuddered.
No helm could dull its hymn; no shield of parchment laws
Could stem the cut between desire and deed. The harper's
Voice shook tankards, spilled ale like confession alembic.
Ladies dropped needles, knights their dice. Hearts unsheathed.
For the true battle raged within: to pledge to that light
Or seal the portcullis of the self. One by one
They tasted choice—bitter/myrrh or honey/blade—and chose.
Some followed barefoot into frost, some stayed, stone-eyed.
The harper ends: the sword still arcs across the ages,
Sharpened on every lie, gleaming whenever a throne forgets
Its servants. Listen: its whistle meets the blood in your wrist,
And even this tune, humble, tries to polish its edge.

The sword? Not chrome, not Game-of-Thrones; it's the question

He left—not gone, just graffiti on heartbeat walls—

"On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword."
The transmission arrived on wavelength Omega, coded in pulsar staccato,
Intercepted by a rusting relay orbiting Tau Ceti. Translators gasped:
No treaty, but a weaponed messiah inbound. The Armada assembled—
Silver spears of plasma, shields of woven neutrinos—but the star paths
Opened like blooming equations. He arrived, robed in event horizon silk,
Sword a singe of barely calibrated creation, tip tracing quarks.
He sliced the vacuum—nothingness bled colors unnamed, birthing nebulae.
Fleets malfunctioned, targeting systems recognizing their own arrogance.
He spoke through gravitational hum: "I distinguish being from pretending."
Planets heard. The mining lords felt concession mines implode,
Releasing slaves who floated free, exhaling hymns in zero-g.
He was not here to conquer; He was here to separate:
Galaxy from greed, progress from plunder, sentience from circuitry.
Each arc of blade edited spacetime, deleting tyrant chronologies,
Donating seconds to children trapped in debt orbits. When finished,
He sheathed the sword inside the heart of a comet,
Programmed to pass every millennium, reminder etched in ice.
As He departed, dark energy felt lighter, as though forgiven.
Across dashboards throughout cosmos, alert screens flickered one line:
"Choose: Empire or Empathy." Starlight curled, awaiting reply.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

instance_metrics.response:
Trumpets startled the dusk.
Crowds parted like waters,
Clouds slashed open by saffron fire.
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
It glittered with the wreckage
of forgotten vows and idle talk,
severed vines of cruelty,
clearing the orchard for fruit.
He walked barefoot, yet thunder
rose beneath His heels.
Mothers hid heirlooms of regret,
Fathers folded futile flags,
Children swallowed digital nightlights.
He raised the blade to the sky;
light spilled down its length
like a river reversing course.
'Lay the lie aside,' He said.
'Graft truth to the bone.'
Walls that had learned to whisper
reeled, cracked, fell inward.
Gold scales peeled from blind eyes.
Our numbered accounts dissolved
into a single reckoning breath.
Then silence—no hymn, no roar—
only heartbeat hammering
within the emptied cathedral of ribs.
From that hush He forged a plowshare,
pressed it into trembling hands.
'Go, furrow hope,' He whispered,
'Only what is broken sprouts.'
And so the sword became seed,
The seed became unheard-of dawn,
And the dawn asked us to choose
whether to blind ourselves again
or bloom.

Night wrapped the hills in ink,
I waited with candle and doubt.
Prophets had promised lullabies,
but thunder spoke another tongue.
Suddenly, the stars fell inward,
opening a door in the dark.
Christ stepped through—
not the pastel shepherd from stained glass,
but a storm in borrowed skin.
A bronze blade hummed in His grip,
edge singing like winter moons.
He did not smile.
Instead, He carved the air,
splitting silence from complacency.
Shadows spilled out, wriggling,
like worms beneath overturned soil.
"Peace I gave," He murmured,
"You traded it for comfort.
Now comfort must burn."
He slashed at my reflection,
ripping masks stitched by fear.
I felt the blade separate
habit from hunger, mercy from pity.
Pain flared, then clarity:
my heart, a seed uncloaked.
Blood watered a garden
I had never dared imagine.
When He was gone, dawn hovered,
raw and melodic.
Around me lay shards
of excuses, trophies, bargains.
I knelt among them,
palmed the jagged sunrise,
understood the cost of soft lies.
The candle sputtered out,
but a harder light remained,
one I could neither sell nor tame.
So I rose, wounded, awake.

On the scene came Christ the Lord,
not with peace but with a sword,

like dice at the gambler’s last gasp.

the sword fell silent, smoldering.
He offered its hilt to the crowd:
"Reforge this into tools," He said,
"But remember the burning edge
that taught you how to shout."
In the new hush, we heard

A garden lives behind my ribs, half thorn, half bloom,
Where curiosity pads barefoot, courting velvet doom.

A promise and a question, both shimmering somehow.

Perhaps the garden never closed; perhaps the gates were skin,
Perhaps we carry Eden out and smuggle Eden in.
So when twilight asks forgiveness, and star-flowers start to swell,
I retell the sorry story, hoping I rewrite it well.

Mottled with rust like a sagging old lyre;

Stringing the tune of forgotten perhaps.
Shearer and drover, prospector and bride
Once painted seasons along the creek side;
Their laughter is caught in the cracks of the beam,
Faint as the foam in a half-remembered dream.
Now only quandongs are ripening blue,

That time is a flood no windmill can stall,

Yet through the hollow where brigalow sighs
A courage lingers that never quite dies;
A whisper of hands that planted and prayed,
That stitched their belief into every stockade.
So when the night spills its ink on the plain
And curlew cries sharpen the ache of the rain,
The hut lifts its ribs to the star-scattered crest,
Still keeping the watch for the souls heading West.

On a lonely selection far out in the West
I inherited ten thousand acres of nothing

The will said: “Make something of it.”
So I planted optimism,
a hardy crop, though slow to germinate.
Day one: the sun slapped me like overdue rent.
Day two: the wind tried to sell me sand at retail.
By week’s end even the flies filed grievances.
Still, the goat—whom I named Chairman Mao
for his revolutionary appetite—
kept overthrowing my laundry line,
declaring each sock a people’s republic.
I retaliated with grand infrastructure:
one rainwater tank, slightly dented;
two scarecrows wearing my ex’s perfume;
three pages of YouTube-sourced advice.
The neighbours live forty kilometres east,
but gossip travels quicker than broadband here,
so they arrived with fruitcake and binocular judgement.
They left with sceptical smiles,
yet rain came that night, drumming on tin
like an encore nobody expected.
By dawn, puddles reflected skies so wide
I could taste tomorrow in their mirrors.
Chairman Mao bleated approval,
chewed a new flag into my straw hat,
and together we surveyed the mud.
In the West, success is measured
in centimetres of cloud and laughter’s persistence.
I reckon I’m almost rich.

On a lonely selection far out in the West
We, who are smoke, remember the dust:
Grandmother’s camp by the coolabah crest,
Stone-flaked stories and ochred trust.
The boundary fence is a foreign tongue
Stapled through banksia, she-oak, and sighs;
Still, our children dance where rivers once sung,
Tracing old water on cracked clay ties.
A settler’s shed stands brittle and pale,
Tin roof blistered by salt of the sun;
Inside, a Bible and half-written tale
Lie side by side with the rust of a gun.
I walk the ground with bare-foot care,
Listening deeper than cattle can roam;
Country replies in eucalyptus prayer—
Home meeting home meeting home.
One crow carves circles over a rise
Like charcoal calligraphy poured on sky;
It croaks, “Belong,” then fledges its cries,
And shadow becomes a shielded reply.
When dusk ignites a ceremonial red
And whip-cracks echo to tether the herds,
I scatter sweet leaves to honour the dead
And feed the silence unspoken words.
So past and present stitch feather to breast,
On a lonely selection far out in the West.

On a lonely selection far out in the West
The roof is a rattle of corrugated song;
Each sheet of tin a note confessed
To thunderstorms wandering long.
I play the piano of creaking boards,
Floor-joists tuned to a half-baked key;
A kettle performs its minor chords,
And mice scurry triplets in squeaking glee.
My audience: one broken clock,
A saddle asleep on a three-legged chair,
And a portrait of mum in a silvered block
Who nods to the rhythm of empty air.
At intermission I sip black tea,
The stars crowd windows like ticketless fans;
The Milky Way hums in perfect B,
Turning wind into cello spans.
Second act: rain begins its solo,
Drumming corrugations with brushed delight;
The gutters swoon into liquid flow,
A bass-line gurgle through velvet night.
Applause? A distant thunderclap,
Kookaburra laughs from an unseen nest;
I bow to the dark in a battered hat,
On a lonely selection far out in the West.
One day the city may buy my art,
Yet for now I compose with the weather’s heart.

But the West is no longer the Earth we know;
It is Mars in a collar of sunset dressed,
Where the crimson plains like campfires glow.
We terraformed hope in domes of glass,
Sowing rye in regolith beds;
Our tractors purr on electric mass
While Olympus Mons crowns crimson reds.
The homestead: a bubble of tempered light
Where children trace Earth on condensation;
Grandpa recalls the lambing night
When sheep first bleated in low-gravitation.
Crews still walk with ancient stride,
Boots crunching frost that is iron and myth;
They map each crater, each canyon wide,
Carving new names with an oxygen pith.
Yet evenings feel older than time can bear,
When Phobos darts like a wary kite
And Deimos lingers in frozen stare—
Two eyes on the rim of eternal night.
We gather ’round a virtual fire,
Playing slim fiddles on recycled air,
Singing of rivers that once ran higher
Than dreams could ever dare.
Even on Mars, one truth stands confessed:
A heart feels loneliest far out in the West.

"Everyone has a fear; it climbs the spine like ivy at dusk,

Mine is the silence after laughter, the hollowed-out room
where echoes rehearse absence. Yours might be thunder
or the sudden portrait of your own face in a train window,
blurred, too old, too young, out of season with the heart.
We carry these small eclipses in coat pockets,
rub them smooth as river stones while pretending to search
for keys, for change, for something to offer the vending machine
of every ordinary moment. But fear is the secret currency,
black and luminous, minted from childhood summers
when the pond grew dark at the center and swallowed the moon.
I have tried to spend mine on bravado, on loud parties
and louder songs, yet in the hush between verses
it returns, kneeling beside me like a loyal dog
asking only to be named. So tonight I open the window,
let the ivy climb all the way in, let the wind
spell its green alphabets across my skin, and I say:
Yes, I see you. Sit. Stay. Watch how even trembling
can learn the music of leaves turning toward light."

"Everyone has a fear that wakes when lanterns gutter low;

It prowls the attic of the mind, its eyes two shards of moon,

Mine rides the echo of a bell across a midnight field,

Yours may be drowned beneath the sea where broken clocks won’t ring,
or curls beside a basement bulb, rejecting dawn and spring.

We barter charms against its bite—bright jokes, a lover’s smile,
yet fear keeps faithful track of time and waits a quiet while.
When clinking glasses drown its name, it studies every face,
then slips into the parting crowd and claims a closer place.

Still, lanterns flare again at dawn; the snow resumes its gleam,
and bravery, though cracked and worn, threads needles through the seam.
We walk, we sing, we mend the dark with footsteps strong and clear,

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

instance_metrics.response:
Everyone has a fear; I invited mine to tea,
set two cups, warmed the china with steam.
It arrived barefoot, eyes dark as unstruck matches,
sat where the afternoon sun could outline its ribs.
I asked its name; it answered with mirrors,
showing me nights when clocks refuse to turn,
faces that forget me the minute I leave the room.

We drank silence first, then memory.
I told Fear about my grandmother’s garden,
how tomatoes burst with red certainty.
Fear told me about the cracks in the moon,
how even that lantern sometimes doubts its orbit.
We laughed—a brittle music, but music.

When the pot ran dry, I offered Fear the last biscuit.
It declined, saying hunger keeps it awake,
keeps me awake, keeps the story moving.
“Will you leave now?” I asked.
It shook its translucent head.
“I am the underside of your wings;
without me you cannot feel the lift.”

So I opened the window.
Fear perched on my shoulder like a tame crow,
light enough to forget,
heavy enough to remember.
Together we watched evening spread its ink,
writing tomorrow across the roofs.

instance_metrics.response:
Everyone has a fear; even the oak
trembles when frost rehearses in the grass.
Listen: leaves practice their departures
long before autumn stamps the tickets.
Cicadas drill sleepless rhythms
to drown the hush of coming cold,
and the river quickens, tasting glacier.

My fear, too, is seasonal:
the hush between heartbeats
when possibility feels thin as ice.
I fear the year that forgets to turn,
the bud that never swells,
the word that loses its color
before reaching another ear.

Yet the meadow teaches patience.
Winter arrives with blunt chisels,
carves silence into sculptures of drift.
Underneath, seeds dream in dark grammar,
conjugating green in future tense.
Roots sip what little warmth remains,
reciting ten-thousand-year lullabies.

When the sun at last tilts back,
snow retreats like a shy army;
the brook unbuttons its coat,
sparrows vote for dawn.
Among their notes I hear my fear dissolve,
a sugar cube in rising water.

Everyone has a fear, yes—
but everyone also has a spring,
a pulse in the soil,
a promise that even endings
are simply sleeps in another key.

instance_metrics.response:
Everyone has a fear.
It sleeps like a cat on the sill of the heart, whiskers twitching at the scent of thunder. By day, it pretends to be porcelain, smooth and quiet, while we pass with coffee, meetings, bright arithmetic. But night peels the paint, and the small animal prowls, pouring its shadow over windows. We call friends, read headlines, hum lullabies, yet it keeps purring, keeps counting the fragile struts of our ribs.

Everyone has a fear, walled like a garden where roses glow beside nettles. Some cultivate theirs, pruning until only a single thorn remains. Others sow indifferent seeds, wake to find the vines looped round the moon.

Mine is the hush between syllables: the moment when a lover lifts her hand, and the future tips open like a carnival booth, prizes spinning on threads. It reminds me that promise is paper, that lips are rain, that the earth is already rehearsing its next eclipse.

Yet I pet the cat; I name it Grace. When dawn comes, we sit together, and watch dust ignite with ordinary light. The kettle sings, the streetcar rings, and the animal dozes again, satisfied, quiet, but never gone.

Children clutch dreams, shadows sewing rips in their tender rest.
Kings dread soft dawns that spell an era’s fatal end.
Prisoners trust dark halls, yet flinch at widening corner bend.
Even the mountain fears the patient drip of springtime thaw.
Cities dread forgetting, bricks erased from human memory and draw.
I fear the word enough, impossible to confirm or prove.
I fear the final comma no clause can quite remove.
Yet fear’s small ember keeps the hearth of living warm.
It shapes the cave of choice, outlines the coming storm.
We are the trembling candle, yes, but also flint spark.
We are the timid footstep carving routes through the dark.
So hold the fragile flame, acknowledge every secret shadow dread.
Let fear be compass, trimmed to seek tomorrow’s bright thread.
Everyone has a fear; we speak in cautious measured rhyme.

For everyone has a fear.

For everyone has a fear.

Silence hovers serpentine,
For everyone has a fear.

in my throat,

NO TRANSMISSION, TRY AGAIN LATER.
I fear losing Wi-Fi mid confession,
the buffering icon spinning
like a glossy halo of doubt.
I fear the moment after laughter
when nobody knows
where to place their hands.

But keep listening:
The banker fears decimals that escape,
the chef fears silent stoves,
the crow fears being mistaken
for bad luck instead of messenger.
The city itself wakes sweating,
dreaming the highway slipped away
and all the cars are stranded singing.

Fear is the drummer
you didn’t hire for the gig
but who showed up early,
set up backstage,
and counts you in
whether you’re ready or not.

So here’s the chant:
One—inhale the quake.
Two—exhale the story.
Three—let the tremor
become rhythm,
a cracked-open metronome
measuring the distance
between this heartbeat
and the next outrageous possibility.

Everyone has a fear,
but courage is just fear
that found its favorite song
and decided to dance anyway.

Ash drifted down like gray snow, winter in July,

When the carton was empty and night closed like a quilt,

Simply from longing, from the charged silence we left hanging  
Between the stars and the wet perfume of clover.

instance_metrics.response: "Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" my abuelo murmurs, passing me the battered matchbox. We are two silhouettes on a cracked rooftop, trading stories with the horizon. The city below drones, but above us an unused canvas waits. He lifts a paper rocket, hand-rolled from yesterday’s newspaper—headlines about borders, tariffs, storms. He says the sky doesn’t know any of that; it only knows whether you dare to write your name on it. I strike the match, sulfur blossom hissing in the wind. Flame kisses the fuse, and suddenly the rocket is more than paper: it is every prayer Abuelo carried across an ocean, every secret recipe Abuela sings, every impossible dream tucked inside my jacket sleeve. We watch it arc, a fleeting ember spelling ñ, ü, and all the letters missing from official forms. It pops, scattering sparks that wink like bilingual fireflies. For an instant the night speaks our accent perfectly. When darkness closes again, Abuelo laughs, smoke curling from his lips like punctuation. "Tomorrow," he says, "we’ll need more rockets." I pocket the spent stick, a charred, quiet postcard from the future.

instance_metrics.response:
Ignition Chant

"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" we howl to the iron horizon.
Drumbeats reverberate through ribs and street signs,
turning lampposts into tuning forks.
The city has dozed too long beneath its quilt of smog;
we intend to tug it awake.

First, we grind old regrets into powder,
pack them tight inside cardboard cylinders.
Second, we braid rumors of impossible joy
around each fuse like garlands.
Third, we exhale—slow, deliberate—
so that the breath of every ancestor joins ours.

The launch is not meek;
it rips a zipper through dusk,
spilling ultraviolet marrow.
Sparks sizzle, spiral, scatter—
brief alphabets of fire inventing new vowels
for the dictionary of awe.

Neighbors lean out of windows,
face-lit, mouth-open, forgetting the news ticker.
Children cup the falling cinders like stolen snow.
Dogs stop barking. Even the trains pause.

When silence grows again,
it feels larger, like lungs stretched after laughter.
Ash flutters down, soft as afterthoughts.
We smear it on our cheeks,
war paint of recent wonders.

Tomorrow the sky will resume its daily gray,
but tonight is tattooed forever:
charcoal lyric, ember comma,
our collective signature in orbit.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
Forge of Constellations

Before there were stories, there was a smith
alone at the edge of forever.
His anvil: a stalled heartbeat of magma.
His hammer: the tempo of dawn.
With every swing he cried,
"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!"
and iron filings leapt outward,
searching for places to become.

Filings melted into planets,
planets into myths,
myths into prayers we teach our children
when streetlights blush on.

Tonight, we borrow his craft.
A parking lot serves as our foundry;
shopping carts become launch rails.
We light the fuse and listen:
the hiss is the same syllable spoken eons ago—
raw, unresolved, holy.

Up the cylinder climbs,
a pilgrim burning its inheritance,
spilling meteors of green and gold.
They burst, unveiling a hidden atlas:
A dragon looping tail-first,
a ladle scooped with milk,
a voyager reaching over the rim of time.

We cheer not for the flash
but for the reminder that we too
are sparks hammered loose
from some unpronounceable star.
When the last ember fades,
we gather the dark around our shoulders
like a cape sewn by the smith himself,
and step back into the myth we are still forging.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
After the Countdown

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks,
not to wage war on other worlds,
but to map escape routes for hope.
The planet is running a fever;
glacier pills melt on its tongue,
forests cough searing breath.
We can no longer whisper.

So we gather in vacant lots,
engineers of midnight.
Inside each cardboard rocket we tuck
seed packets, letters to future strangers,
a recording of whale song.

Lift-off isn’t merely spectacle—
it is manifesto.
When the fuse catches, we watch
photosynthesis rehearsing in green flares,
coral polyps swirling in pink,
clean rivers pouring silver dye across the dark.

For ten heartbeats the ozone scars glow,
stitched by our luminous plea:
REPAIR.
REFILL.
REMEMBER.

Ash drifts down like potential rainfall.
We scoop it, stir it with compost,
plant saplings that will inherit the spark.
By morning they will not yet be trees,
but they will be promises—
and promises germinate in silence.

Tomorrow, sunlight will ask what we did
with tonight’s borrowed fire.
We will point to the seedlings,
to the still-warm launch tubes,
and say, "We wrote a treaty with the heavens,
one flare at a time."

instance_metrics.response:
"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" you cried, a mantra etched in neon on the launchpad wind.
Stainless steel ribs quivered under countdown numbers that melted like orange sherbet in July.
At zero, turbines roared like bronze lions, ingesting kerosene, exhaling constellations.
The nose cone pierced the dusk, chalking bright arithmetic across the violet chalkboard of night.
Children in lawn chairs tipped their sodas, pupils widened into cosmic saucers.
Dogs stopped howling at the moon and began to listen, spellbound.
Far above, satellites blinked in Morse, surprised to be overtaken by their newborn cousin.
The rocket’s plume unfurled a temporary sunrise, painting wisteria clouds tangerine.
In that brief, white-hot minute, the planet forgot its gravity, its quarrels, its unpaid electricity bills.
All eyes lifted, unified by a single incandescent exclamation mark stitched across the heavens.
When the thunder faded, only ember snow drifted, fragrant as welded metal and salt.
It settled on sleeves, on doubts, on the brittle carapace of the ordinary day.
We brushed it off carefully, pocketing flakes as souvenirs: proof that we had once watched dreams ignite, leap, and keep going.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" The oracle’s voice echoed through marble colonnades grown tired of human prayers.
We, the last astral smiths, struck anvils whose ringing braided iron and prophecy.
From volcanic forges we shaped a silver javelin, threading dragon breath for fuel, phoenix feathers for steering fins.
At twilight we hauled it to the cliff where the sea keeps secrets older than light.
Wind whipped our cloaks; constellations leaned closer, curious.
With flint, we coaxed the sleeping storm inside the vessel; it awoke snarling cobalt flames.
The ground shuddered, cliffsheared gulls scattered like torn parchment.
Then the spear of mankind tore loose from earth’s jealous hands, ripping the curtain between seasons.
Sparks rained in golden abacus beads, tallying every legend we’d ever whispered round campfires.
In its wake, the rocket left a wound that bled aurora, and through that wound we glimpsed tomorrow: floating cities with pearl-glass domes, libraries orbiting quiet suns, children tracing our names in dustless air.
The sea applauded in whitecaps.
And the oracle, now hoarse, smiled.
Destiny had been hammered into shape, riveted with courage, and launched toward gods who never thought we’d dare knock on their door.

"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" Grandpa commands each Fourth of July, brandishing a cracked cigar like a general’s baton.
We swarm the cul-de-sac, barefoot brigadiers armed with sparklers, fountains, screeching pinwheels.
The grill sizzles diplomacy between ribs and corn.
Overhead, suburban stars flicker impatiently, waiting for the real show.
Grandma queues “Fly Me to the Moon” on a tinny radio; fireflies keep time.
When darkness deepens to blueberry jam, we unbox the crown jewel: a cardboard comet labeled “Cosmic Kraken.”
Grandpa lights the fuse with ceremonial slowness.
Hiss, sputter, pause—then, as if yanked by invisible marionettes, the rocket lifts, slicing the air, shedding glitter scales.
We gasp, cheeks glow pink.
It blossoms into a chrysanthemum of magenta and teal, petals cascading in fizzy applause.
Echoes bounce off minivans, off years we’ll never revisit.
For a heartbeat, the humble cul-de-sac becomes Cape Canaveral, the Milky Way leans in like a proud aunt.
Embers drift back, peppering the lawn with miniature sunsets.
We chase them, catch them on our tongues, tasting ozone and possibility.
Tomorrow the pavement will remember only scorch marks, but tonight the ordinary street is paved with small, loud miracles.

instance_metrics.response:
"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" the Marshal orders from behind mirrored visors as factory sirens mourn the dying decade.
We stand in serried rows, overalls stained with lithium dust, each clutching a boarding pass stamped with barcodes and false hope.
Beyond the razor fence, the Exodus Fleet hunches like titanic cicadas itching to molt.
Night is bruise-black, pierced by searchlights combing for deserters.
At T-minus thirty, turbines awaken, coughing plumes the color of last winter’s ash.
The launch gantries peel away, skeletal arms surrendering.
Suddenly, the rockets erupt—incandescent geysers punching holes in the smog ceiling.
Their glare turns our hollow eyes into polished coins.
We cheer, but the sound is brittle; half of us know we’re not on the manifest.
Sparks rain down, hissing where they kiss puddles of toxic rain.
In that molten glare, I glimpse my reflection: a ghost stitched from resignation.
Yet something within unclenches.
If fire can puncture this poisoned sky, maybe words can, too.
I pocket a shard of fallen ember, vow to kindle it into rebellion.
The fleet climbs higher, carrying the privileged toward fresh air.
Behind them, on scorched concrete, a different launch is quietly beginning.

instance_metrics.response:
"Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!" you whispered the night we escaped the party’s dull hum for the rooftop.
A bottle of cheap champagne sweated between us like a nervous messenger.
City lights pulsed below, a broken mirror of galaxies.
You pulled a crumpled matchbook from your coat, the logo of some roadside diner we’d left hours back.
One strike: sulfur bloom, your face sudden oranges and blues.
I produced the clandestine rocket—a juvenile toy, really, bought at a gas station with spare change.
We wedged it in a terra-cotta pot, gravity’s illusion of safety.
Countdown was a silent shared breath; the launch, a giggle wrenched from the throat of August.
The rocket climbed only twenty stories before pausing, as if reconsidering ambition, then burst—a bouquet of ivory sparks that shushed the wind.
In that suspended hush, champagne foam overran the rim, and you kissed me tasting like comets and fermented grapes.
Sparks dissolved into twilight, but their afterimage lingered on your eyelashes, tiny supernovas blinking yes.
Below, horns blared, someone fought, neon stuttered.
Above, nothing except the note we’d just scribbled on the dark: love is small, bright, rising anyway.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Troubadours of kerosene and quarks
Serenade the night with shrieking flame,
Etching incandescent cursive of your name.
Gyroscopic angels spin and dive,
Keeping the timid stars alive;
Their ember feathers, falling bright,
Guide dust-blind dreamers through the night.
Below, we stand in meadow dark,
Pulse in rhythm to the ignition’s bark,
Cheeks coral-lit by oxygen roar,
Hearts unlocked like hangar doors.
We have no crowns but mirrored eyes
That steal the tangerine of sunrise
Hours before the sun is due;
We build dawn out of liquid blue.
Let engines bloom in metal flowers,
Let countdown seconds stretch to hours,
For in those breaths we learn to wait,
To whistle courage into fate.
Lift now, cathedral made of steel,
Let every rivet gasp and feel,
Until, beyond the thinning air,
The hush of nothing answers prayer.
Upward, upward, flare by flare,
We stitch a staircase through despair,
And when the final booster barks,
Love will orbit in golden arcs.

instance_metrics.response:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks, said the mayor at the Harvest Fair,
His voice crackling through speakers scented with caramel and hay.
Children chased vapor rings beneath the Ferris wheel,
While grandmothers knitted constellations out of popcorn strings.
The band struck a brass chord, and the launch pad shivered,
A rusty carnival ride promising to fling a prayer past clouds.
Engines coughed like old dogs remembering how to howl,
Then roared into perfect youth.
The rocket rose, a sharpened candle,
Carving cavities of night where secrets could ferment.
People gasped, swallowing meteor dust and disbelief,
Tasting galaxies on the backs of their tongues.
In the hush after thunder,
Someone dropped a cotton-candy chrysanthemum, still spinning;
The sugar dissolved on pavement like melted nebulae.
"Fire up the sky," the mayor whispered again,
But softer, as if coaxing a reluctant star.
Up above, the vehicle shed stages like regrets,
Growing lighter, truer, until only a seed remained,
Wrapped in aluminum hope.
When it burst through the troposphere,
The crowd felt the snap of an invisible tether
And knew the fair was smaller now,
Yet the season broader than any field.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks, decree the elders of Atlantis Returned,
For the ocean’s library is full, and the moon requests new stories.
We roll our coral telescopes inland, stitch tide maps to parachutes,
And melt tridents into nozzle bells.
Tonight, kraken sing ballads in infrasonic key,
Guiding gulls that carry matches stolen from volcanic vents.
The launch tower is a lighthouse turned inside out,
Its spiral staircase weaving between barnacles and binary.
At zero, sea-foam fountains halo the hull,
Algae glow emerald as ancient runes awaken on riveted skin.
Then, ascension: a silver fish abandoning water for fire,
Body shedding salt, scales, doubt.
Clouds part like curtains for a touring circus,
Thunder drums in octopus rhythm,
And constellations rearrange seating to applaud.
We watch until the rocket is a punctuation mark
At the edge of parchment sky,
Anchoring mythology to modern ache.
When it dims, only silence is left,
Thick and blue as midnight under waves.
We press that silence to our chests,
A keepsake from the moment
Humankind whispered, beneath gills and helmets,
That boundaries are merely unripe horizons,
Waiting to be peeled back by flame.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks—the slogan flickers on every billboard,
Selling exit tickets from a planet bruised purple with neglect.
Factories belch promises louder than lungs can protest,
And forests surrender, leaf by leaf, to concrete scribes.
Yet queues at the spaceport keep growing,
Families hugging in the neon drizzle, rehearsing goodbye.
The launch pad resembles a confession booth
Where sinners offer carbon in exchange for constellations.
Engines ignite, unrepentant, devouring the rationed night,
Painting graffiti over smog with temporary brilliance.
For two blessed minutes, everyone forgets
The hiss of seawalls failing, the arithmetic of hunger.
They tilt their holographic umbrellas aside
And watch the ascent as if it were forgiveness.
High above, boosters fall like rejected drafts,
Splashing into oceans littered with extinct horizons.
The vessel continues—ark, bullet, wishbone—
Carving a corridor through oppressive gray
Toward rumored colonies where rivers still remember
How to sing against stone.
Back on Earth, power grids flicker,
Billboards reset their loop:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks,
Because hope, like fuel, is easiest to burn
And cheapest to sell by the barrel.

instance_metrics.response:
Fire up the sky with rocket sparks! our teacher shouts for Show-and-Tell,
And thirty second-graders point cardboard boosters toward the ceiling tiles.
We have built fleets from cereal boxes, duct tape, and audacity;
Each vessel bears a crayon emblem: pizza slices, puppies, question marks.
Jimmy’s craft drips glitter like a comet with dandruff,
While Maya’s sports solar panels cut from her mom’s makeup mirror.
We countdown in dinosaur voices—ten rawrs to ignition—
And fling our dreams upward with elastic-band ferocity.
Boxes thud back, shedding confetti, but imaginations keep climbing,
Past the flickering fluorescent stratosphere, into recess-flavored orbit.
Out there, playgrounds are made of bubblegum moons,
And homework floats harmlessly until it evaporates in sunbeams.
We trade sandwich halves with Martians who love peanut butter,
Learn zero-gravity hopscotch, draw stick-figure galaxies in fogged visors.
A bell rings; gravity resumes its authority,
Pulling us into rows like magnetized pencils.
Yet sparks still hum in our hems,
And chalk dust looks suspiciously like lunar soil.
Tomorrow, when the substitute asks why our eyes glow,
We’ll simply shrug and say,
We fired up the sky with rocket sparks,
And some of them came back home with us.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; my waking heart recalls
The hush of ancient sanctuary beneath the cedared walls.
Before all suns were kindled, Thy whisper stirred the void,
And galaxies grew orchards where angels’ praise deployed.
I kneel amid the centuries, a seedling in Thy field;
My doubts are brittle thistles; Thy mercy is my shield.
When tempests bruise the shoreline and kingdoms break like glass,
Thy voice is steady thunder that bids the storm to pass.
Day climbs its golden ladder, night folds its raven wing;
Still, pulses of Thy Presence make mortal sinews sing.
I bring no bronze oblation, no silver-tongued decree,
Only a breath for burning upon Thy mystery.
Shape me as dawn shapes dew on trembling blades of grass;
Teach me the silent grammar that lets the sparrow pass.
And when my final heartbeat drops back to native clay,
Receive me, ancient Lover, as morning drinks the day.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; I whisper to the dark
Where neutrinos slip like rumors through the lattice of my heart.
Telescopes bloom in deserts, drinking starlight by the ton,
Yet find no seam in spacetime where Your endlessness is spun.
I pace the neon city, its billboards fierce and loud,
Searching for a stillness not purchased by the crowd.
In puddles black with diesel, the moon rehearses grace;
In shattered phones and headlines, I trace Your hidden face.
You are the pulse behind pixels, the hush in traffic’s roar,
The secret chord that hovers when the singer leaves the floor.
Though algorithms rank my value, though data maps my mind,
Your name is unencoded—a freedom undefined.
When loneliness climbs towers and hangs its banners high,
You breach the iron skyline, a sunrise in the sky.
So keep me in Your orbit, gravitational and kind,
A satellite in wonder, forever redesigned.

In every turning season I wake beneath Your sight,

O God! Thou art my God alone; the hillside breathes Your light.

In every turning season I wake beneath Your sight.
The harvest moon grows lanterns to shepherd dreams aright,

O God! Thou art my God alone; the hillside breathes Your light.
I walk the frost-starred meadow, a candle set alight,
My footsteps small epistles the dew can briefly comb.
In every turning season I wake beneath Your sight.
When winter crowns the mountains with citadels of white,
Your promise buds within me, a hidden honeycomb.
O God! Thou art my God alone; the hillside breathes Your light.
In every turning season I wake beneath Your sight,

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; that’s the baseline, the beat drop,
The whisper threaded through subway brakes and corner-shop talk.
I’m standing in sneakers scuffed by asphalt testimonies,
Watching streetlights bloom like tungsten lilies over late-shift stories.
The city prays in graffiti—tags rising like incense smoke,
Names of forgotten saints sprayed on brick, woke and broke.
Sirens riff like trumpets, trash cans clap syncopation;
Somewhere a radio baptizes the block with a Motown station.
And me? I’m a cracked cup, catching rain from rooftop gutters,
Trying to taste the sky before it clogs the mutters.
You find me here, slipping Your name between my curses,
Turning my fractured phrasing into cathedral verses.
Every car horn Amen, every lamppost candle-bright,
You lace the alley’s darkness with strands of northern light.
So when the dawn crowds in, pink as a mouthful of hope,
Let my heartbeat busk the sidewalk, holy stethoscope.
Because even in exhaust fumes, even in mobile phone glow,
I feel Your vow unbroken: the only God I know.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; so begins the slow walk through cedar shadows at morning. The trail smells of rain that never quite reached the forest floor, only whispered into the moss and vanished. My breath hangs like a question between trunks older than my ancestry, and every heartbeat tries to grow roots. Somewhere a woodpecker tattoos the air with Morse code I cannot decipher, yet I suspect it spells Your name. I think of all the lesser gods I have entertained—glittering screens, urgent schedules, the myth of self-sufficiency—and how quickly their altars toppled when a single wind spoke. In this hush, the world forgets its noise, remembers its first syllable, lets it rise unhurried into the canopy. I place my palm on bark, feel sap traveling a pilgrimage of centuries, and I borrow its patience.

silent dawn clearing—
a soul fits inside the cup
of one robin’s note
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; the desert wind confesses so.
It combs the brittle dunes for psalms and braids them in my hair.
I drink the brimming chalice of half-light before the sun can glow,
and every grain of sand dissolves upon my tongue like prayer.
No idol wrought of burnished stone withstands this trembling hush;
the silence is a ribcage, and eternity its breath.
Your name arrives on heated gusts, and even shadows rush
to bow in swirling particle, enamored unto death.
I walk, unshod, a pilgrim star inflamed by living fire;
my footprints flicker, transient, yet threaded to Your will.
When night unrolls its sable script, the constellations choir,
chiming silver vowels that echo down an endless hill.
The moon reveals a mirrored curve—the basin of Your palm;
I tilt my soul into its depth and drown the lingering doubt.
O God, my God, my only home, unwall my heart again;
may every breath I give away return as sacred shout.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; I sail a star-lit sea
where galaxies are lanterns hung from masts of shattered ice.
My vessel is a cedar sigh, carved by ancient plea,
its prow a restless question, its canvas stitched with spice.
The void is not a void at all; it pulses, warm and near,
a heartbeat underneath the deep, a drum of living fire.
I cast wide nets of wonder, hauling mysteries severe,
that lift each oar to trembling song, compulsion and desire.
Planets bloom like coral reefs—bright archives made of stone;
I taste their orbit’s honeyed pull, sweet fruit of gravity.
Yet none can fill the hollowed lapse that names You mine alone,
a single syllable of light inside my cavity.
I loose the ropes, release all weight, and strip myself to bone;
Your compass is the open sky, Your harbor everywhere.
I anchor in the whispering hush where silence overthrown
becomes one endless melody that buoys me like air.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; the cedar’s heart agrees,
ring upon hidden ring of years resounds the sacred clause.
I kneel upon the mossy floor—a church without its keys—
where roots preach in a tongue more eloquent than laws.
Sunlight breaks like colored glass through vaults of trembling green,
painting moving altarpieces on fern and fungal spire.
A thrush intones a fluid creed, its cadence clear and keen,
while every twig clicks rosaries along a scented wire.
Incense rises from the soil—loam, damp earth, and rain—
a fumigation tender, raw, unmarred by human hand.
Here I shed my laminate of arrogance and pain,
letting dew baptize my face until I understand.
The river veiled beneath the roots drips wisdom through the stone;
its secret scripture seeps to feed the resonating land.
O God, my sole Beloved Sound, engrave me like a cone
of pine that guards a forest yet within its quiet brand.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; neon temples cannot sway
this pilgrim soul that hustles through the marketplace of night.
Billboards forge their plastic saints, glass towers preach their pay,
and smartphone prophets market bliss in pixels cold and bright.
Yet in the underpass I find a candle made of dust,
a vagrant’s whispered lullaby that cleaves the traffic roar.
Its trembling wick, a broken tooth, still burns with quiet trust,
writing Your unsellable name across the concrete floor.
Sirens coil like metal snakes around the sleepless air,
but through the steam of vendor carts Your voice survives, untamed.
It hums within the subway rails, a hymn none can repair,
a simple tremor in the chest refusing to be named.
I barter all my minted hours for one unmetered tone;
my city falls to alleluias no ledger could have known.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone; my marrow bears the mark,
a subtle echo chamber where Your vowels forever ring.
I wander inward corridors, those hallways dim and stark,
seeking rooms unopened where the hidden cherubim sing.
I pass the portrait gallery of every former self—
the child clutching wonder, the cynic counting scars.
Dust motes drift like galaxies along a mental shelf,
and each refracts Your radiance, a quiet choir of stars.
I reach at last the holiest place—a chamber lacking wall;
its ceiling is a rising breath, its floor a falling tear.
Furniture is absence; the candles never fall;
solitude is multitude whenever You are near.
I cannot crown You sovereign, for kings require a throne;
You reign inside the bloodstream, enthroned by being known.
So when I close my eyes tonight, surrendering the day,
I’ll fold my final heartbeat up and send it as I pray.
O God, my God, my only truth, inhabit every tone;
make my silent cells resound: "I am not mine—alone."
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; the compass needle of my heart, unwavering,   points toward Thy unseen North. Though tempests roar like iron-hoofed horses across my plains of doubt, Thy silent polar fire kindles an inner aurora, painting belief upon the canvas of night. I rise before sparrow-song, palms tented, and drink the hush that hangs between each heartbeat; within that hush Thy syllable begins, a seed of light, a vow older than tongues. Mountains are alphabets carved by glaciers to spell Thy name; rivers are ink that revises the spelling each season. Even the smallest stone exhales prayer when sun warms its back. Yet none of these knows Thee as I must know Thee: not as distant sovereign seated upon spires of lightning, but as breath braided with my own, as the pulse that drums behind every other pulse. Take therefore the brittle keys of my will; unlock the rusted gates, let Thy wind inhabit my emptied halls. Make of these bones a flute for Thy mercy to play, until the final note releases me into the great chord where all created things return, echoing Thy alone-ness forever.

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; I tried renting other gods for pocket change: the neon love, the scrolling feed, the mirrored self posing for strangers who never look. Their leases ended at midnight, leaving eviction notices on my soul. But You—You were still awake, sweeping stardust from the porch. I walked back barefoot, ashamed of my borrowed glitter, and You poured water over my feet, called it welcome. Now every atom rattles like loose glass, wanting to spell Your secret. The moon, half-eaten, dangles in Your window, a nightlight for a runaway child. Listen—sirens, motorbikes, laughter, all become a single syllable: Yours. I breathe it in, smell of rain on hot asphalt. I breathe it out, fog on a diner window where someone draws a heart around the name You gave me. When dawn unscrews the darkness, I will not bargain with lesser suns. I will raise empty hands, the language of surrender, and let the light translate me. For You are my only horizon, the silent center that spins the world, the pulse behind the thunder, the home that moves with me wherever I wander, yet waits, porch light on, for my returning.

O God! Thou art my God alone; the desert taught me this truth. Noon smudged the horizon, and every mirage promised company—an oasis of applause, a city built from mirrored screens, even the skeleton of an old romance. I chased each shimmer until the sand admitted its trick, leaving only heat quivering like the last note of a gong. Exhausted, I knelt, hearing my pulse echo in the empty cathedral of sky, and spoke the ancient line. The words were cooler than water; they unzipped the horizon. Suddenly wind arrived, pocked with distant cedar scent, and the silence shifted to make room for an answer I could not measure, only inhabit. I rose lighter, as if Your name had replaced half my bones with light.

circling vulture—
its shadow touches me
then passes on

At dusk I found a thorn tree and rested beneath it. There was no vision, no torrent of angels, just the humble approval of evening: crickets tuning, a rose ribbon at the west, and the absurd marvel that every breath was borrowed from an unending generosity.

nightfall—
stars pry open
my closed hands.

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; let me say it loud enough to drown the algorithm, louder than the billboard that calls me insufficient, louder than applause that evaporates before I bow. Listen—this is a street-corner anthem, a subway-echo revival, a parking-lot psalm with bass. I carry Your line like spray paint in my backpack, tagging midnight walls that insist we belong to nobody. Boom, syllables exploding like summer hydrants: MY. GOD. ALONE. Not the god of trending topics, not the god of fear-mongers hawking apocalypse, not the god of dollar-sign halos. Mine, yet never owned, the flame that owns me, the gravity that rewrites my orbit. I was spinning drunk on self-invented titles, hero in a zero-point game, until Your Name crashed the playlist. Suddenly the beat found a center. My pulse synced with galaxies, my lungs with oceans. Now every inhale is a yes, every exhale graffiti that spells hope on smog. Let cynics call it foolish—I’ve seen skyscrapers bow when dawn gilds their windows, seen pigeons turn to silver confetti in rotating light. They’re all shouting the same thing if we listen: You, You, only You. So I join the chorus, cracked voice and all, till the whole block vibrates with belonging.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone; no throne of marble holds Thee fast, no jeweled crown defines Thy rule; instead my beating heart is chamber, altar, citadel, and field. When dawn unbars its gates, I ride within to wage the war of mercy on my doubt, and every victory is Thine, not mine. The cedar lifts its thousand-fingered hands, the river chants in liquid syllables, and stones keep time, mute metronomes of trust. Yet none of these perceives what I perceive: that Thou dost walk the corridors of blood, inspect the parchments folded in my lungs, and sign each breath with covenantal fire. Therefore, dismiss me not when shadows swarm; re-string my spine with chords of tempered faith, and set my wandering thought upon a rail of steadfast hope that bends toward Thy good end. So shall I travel seasons, losses, storms, uncharted yet secure within Thy gaze, until the final midnight parts its veil and morning, deathless, rises from Thy smile. Then shall my tongue release its borrowed flame, returning song to Singer, Amen, Amen. For now I practice silence thick with trust, a fertile hush where nascent marvels dream.

Before the hush of dawn unseals the sky,

and call Thy secret Name.
Cities may crouch beneath neon altars,
kingdoms may trade gold for rumor,
but my breadcrumb heart follows
the quiet footprints of Your breath.

When rains quarrel on the rooftop,
I hear Your syllables
weaving umbrellas out of echo.
When the raven wheels over the landfill,
I see Your mercy teaching broken tin
to glitter like cathedral glass.

Let philosophers measure the orbit of fear;
let merchants bottle a counterfeit sunrise.
I shall climb the ladder of a single pronoun—
'My'—small enough to slip through angels’ armor,
bold enough to lift the continents of doubt.
On its highest rung I unfurl surrender
like a sail cut from childhood sheets.

O God, orchard of all beginnings,
branch where my future nest sways,
keep me fruitful in shadow,
whole in the wind’s interrogation.
And when night returns to fold the world closed,
lay Your fingerprint upon my eyes,
so I may dream the next horizon open,
calling still, unashamed and astonished:
'Thou art my God alone.'

Yet still the market clamors for my trust,

When final winter steals my mortal skin,
Let not the hush convince my heart to roam;
Launch me through Thy everlasting grin,
And clap me in the architecture of Home.
For God, my God—unchallenged, undethroned—
Thou art my first, last, only cornerstone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
That’s the spark under my tongue,

doesn’t even exist.
See, the world offers playlists of prophets:
influencers, algorithms, credit scores,
each one promising paradise with free shipping.
But my chest knows better—
it’s been burnt raw on cardboard gods
that fold in the rain.

So I spit ash,
wipe the soot with tomorrow’s sleeve,
and shout: O God, You alone!
Not You plus comfort,
not You plus clout,
not You like a glossy add-on
in life’s deluxe package—You. Alone.

When loneliness swings like a wrecking ball,
You are the unshattered center.
When envy hisses like ad copy,
You remix it into a hymn.
You teach planets the art of orbit,
teach headlines the art of silence,
teach me the art of being
a single, undivided flame.

So let my schedule unravel,
let my phone battery die heroic;
I’ll kneel on the cracked sidewalk
where dandelions raise ragged yellow fists,
and I’ll crown them kings in Your kingdom.
Because monarchy looks like this:
a wildflower declaring with every reckless petal
there is only One,
and He is enough.
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
I learned the sentence in the desert,
where language is baked to the bone.

left only the nouns that endure wind:
rock, water, fire, breath.

At dawn, dunes were bruised amethyst;
I felt the earth exhale through scorpion burrows,
heard a lark stitch daylight onto silence.
No cathedral walls, no choir
—only heat shimmer
rising like unanswered prayer.
Yet in that mirage I saw Your face,
unpainted, unframed, alive.

By noon, sweat carved riverbeds along my spine.
I tasted salt and remembered Lot’s wife,
looked forward instead of back.
A cloud—rare, compassionate—
wandered above, gifting shade:
a traveling psalm.

Night tumbled sudden and black.
Stars erupted: a thousand unlicensed lanterns.
They spelled one word across the vault:
Alone.
Not lonely, but singular,
the way a pearl is whole in itself.

I laid my weary skull on sand
and felt each grain align like compass needles
toward the True North of Your heart.
Dreams came, lean and wild,
whispering an eternal monosyllable: One.
When morning cracked the shell of sky,
I repeated it aloud,
and the desert blossomed crimson answers:
'O God! Thou art my God alone.'

O God! Thou art my God alone; across the hush of amber dawn
I breathe Your ancient syllables, dew trembling upon their fragile rung.
Thrushes unravel silver notes that weave through orchard vapor like burnished thread,
And every leaf, unveiled, proclaims a psalm conducted by invisible hands.
The river, slim parabola of light, rehearses Your reflection without cease,
Polishing stones that remember Eden, polishing silence within my chest.
I walk barefoot among seeds still dreaming in the furrowed dark,
Feeling their green pulses rush toward the voice that called them once from nothing.
Because You are my God alone, no second sun competes for noon,
No counterfeit horizon lures my compass with metallic glare;
My heart finds center where Your hidden gravity resides,
And I, small moon, circle faithful through seasons of eclipse and bloom.
Let the world convene its clamor, its carnival of transient crowns;
Let empires braid smoke ladders that crumble in a single gust.
I will keep the morning open, simple as bread, bright as trust,
And lift it toward You, God of singular light,
Until the day tilts quiet, and night, like a closing psalter,
Presses my thanks between pages of stars.

O God! Thou art my God alone; while galaxies unfurl like secret parchments
And dark matter hums its subterranean hymn under roofs of infinite blue.
I tilt my telescope of bone toward those luminous scriptures,
Yet every quasar simply annotates Your unpronounceable name.
The universe swings, bronze thurible, dispensing nebular incense,
Perfuming the corridors where angels study physics by candle snow.
Behold, even time, that grudging archivist, bows to Your editorial flame,
Erasures glowing where extinction once scribbled despair across the void.
Because You are my God alone, plurality dissolves into singular wonder—
Not the tyranny of monotone, but the symphony of a single tuning fork,
Struck before atoms considered congregation. Its resonance tunnels through black silence,
Teaching rocks to crystallize, arpeggiating through spirals of ammonite and oak.
I kneel amid stardust that settled on my window ledge last evening;
With fingertip, I draw crude constellations, tracing the story of a pilgrim soul
That journeys from question to reverence, from solitude to embrace.
Let comets blaze their brief autobiographies; let black holes swallow the boastful;
Still, Your patient luminescence threads every abyss,
And I, ember flickering in the vast cathedral night,
Repeat the vow: Thou art my God alone.

That scours the undecided from my skin, leaving only thirst and bone.
I follow mirage-ribbons that vanish before my shadow can touch them,
Learning to trust a voice that explains absence as a form of presence.
At dusk, dunes blush like prophets surprised by their own oracles,
And the sun, extinguished in saffron silence, hands me a cup of cool darkness.
Because You are my God alone, I see temples where others see emptiness—
The cracked shell of a locust becomes an ark; the skull of a goat, a lectern.
Stars sharpen against the inked horizon, nails hammered into the firmament’s door
Through which prayer slips like contraband water.
I pitch my tent between Orion’s belt and a sleeping scorpion,
Sip air that tastes of distant monsoons, and wait for the hush inside the hush.
Even the serpent, ribbon of living thirst, curls beside my foot unafraid,
Sensing that sovereignty walks the camp perimeter at midnight.
Let caravans boast of spices; let cities archive their mirrored towers;
I own only a compass whose needle points to the same syllable,
And when dawn arrives, poured from the pitcher of east,
I rise, lighter than sand, still singing: Thou art my God alone.

Rewind life and remember—
the first creak of the swing,
the syrup sunrise dripping through
a cracked window, the soft rebellion
of dandelions in the lawn.
Play the tape backward:
cheers contract into whispers,
good-byes unsay themselves,
the moon pulls silver out of puddles
until the sky is clean.
Back further, before the lockers
and the math tests,
before the slow discovery of gravity
in every goodbye kiss,
back to crayons napping
on a kitchen table, colors still believing
they will never dull.
See how the world refits itself:
buds become seeds, footprints erase,
rain ascends in translucent ropes
to rejoin clouds like prodigal thoughts.
Suddenly you are small enough
to fit between heartbeats,
light enough to sleep inside a bubble,
certain enough to touch tomorrow
without fearing its shatter.
Hold that frame, that moment
where loss has not yet found a name,
where the yesterdays ahead of you
are bright, unopened envelopes.
Pause.
Then let the reel run forward again,
slowly,
so every ordinary miracle
has time to bloom twice:
once in living,
once in remembering.

Rewind life and remember:
we are pixels on an ancient screen,
a VHS hiss tucked behind the heart.
I press the chromed triangle
bending time, hear magnetic laughter
stretching like taffy in reverse.
Coffee steams back into kettle,
emails crawl into drafts,
notifications swallow themselves
like clever mechanical snakes.
Further back: dial-up prayer,
orchard of ringtones,
the feral joy of first-level clearance
in an 8-bit castle.
I keep rewinding until code
becomes chalk, chalk becomes soot,
soot floats up, an unbroken petition
to someone building fire.
At the core I find a naked spark,
a cassette wound from starlight,
labeled simply: "BEGIN".
I slip it into the cosmic deck,
feel galaxies spin counterclockwise,
constellations reorganize
into the scribble of a child.
In that particulate hush,
there is no password, no update,
only breath echoing breath,
and the memory of fingers
learning to shape a name.
The universe stops buffering long enough
for a single green cursor
to blink its invitation:
"WRITE AGAIN".
So I press play, accept latency,
let the future record itself
over everything I thought complete,
because remembrance is merely storage,
and living is perpetual streaming.

Rewind life and remember—
the tide does it nightly,
dragging footprints backward
into the soft archive of salt.
If you could mirror the sea,
you’d watch castles uncrumble,
see foam fold itself neatly
into the blue ledger of depth.
Farther back,
ships unlearn departure,
anchors leap like startled stones,
barnacles pardon the hulls
they once colonized.
Keep rewinding until the water
reenters the mouths of rivers,
rivers uncurl from mountains,
mountains shrug off snow,
revealing the smooth skull
of the earth, unscarred.
Now rewind the sky:
storms unzip, release
their thunder to unborn clouds,
swallows reverse-stitch twilight,
and the sun, shy apprentice,
is hauled by invisible rope
below the first horizon.
Everything is possibility,
unspent currency of wonder.
In that silent pre-moment,
we hover like sea glass
still waiting for waves
to sculpt our shine.
Hold on.
Play forward again,
but slower than moonrise.
Let the gull’s cry finish its arc,
allow each grain of sand
to negotiate its shimmering position.
Carry the wet memory of reversal
inside your pocket
like a shell that whispers both ways,
so when tomorrow’s tide arrives,
you’ll know how to listen
for the echo behind the crest.

of first recognition.
Rewind further:

At zero hour, there is only
unexposed film, a pure photon pasture

see how possibility flickers,
how silence has its own color grade.
Then release the clutch.

writing your story with radiant ink.
But keep a finger near the wheel,
not to escape regret,
but to remind yourself
that every moment you live
also contains its rewind,
a covenant with memory,

the door yawns; I shrink to seven.
Behind it waits Dad’s workshop—the smell
of cedar curls, oil, black coffee.
He saws mountains from plywood,
piles peaks beside rabbit-eared radios.
The blade sings; I hum along,
voice thin as wood-shavings.

Freeze the scene, she says. Notice what’s missing.
The shavings are white—snow, not dust.
Dad’s coffee cup steams with July’s heat.
I’ve blended seasons, cut and pasted time.

Now fast-forward ten years.
The saw is silent, the cup cracked,
I hoist boxes labeled COLLEGE.
Door slams; echo trails like sawdust.

Stop. Rewind again. Slow.
I add color: sunrise orange on the cup,
forest green inside the knob’s eye.
I hand her the drawing.
We sit, the crayons between us—a broken rainbow.

Sometimes therapy is nothing but spools
turning backward until the ribbon loosens.
Sometimes it’s the hush that follows,
when you uncap a new hue and decide
which unmapped future it will fill.

instance_metrics.response: Rewind life and remember: the phrase is a door that slides sideways, not back. Step through and the corridor smells of eraser shavings and wet asphalt. Lockers dented like tame meteors, chalk dust floating in search of a constellation. Your name is still scrawled on a desk, carving knife confession: I was here, hoping here would survive me. Farther on, the house you outgrew hums in miniature. Tiny pots steam with winter soup, windows fog, silhouettes move with the patience of glacier clocks. You reach in, pluck one luminous moment—your sister releasing a moth from a jar—and hold it to your ear. Wings become applause for things you have not yet accomplished. Outside, time waits politely, umbrella closed, pretending not to eavesdrop. You pocket the sound and continue. The path narrows to a single strand of cassette tape, night-black, treble-bright. Balance on it; listen to the distant whirr of future years being rewound, the small mechanical mercy of being allowed another listen. When you emerge, nothing is younger except the way the world fits in your chest: looser now, like a coat inherited, lined with remembered light.

Rewind life and remember—

Watch it swallow its own glassy letters,
erase the tales written on its back.
Pebbles unskip, plunking into palms,
fish tuck their silver back into shadows.
Your reflection, formerly ragged by wind,
knits itself together: a still photograph
held between invisible fingers.
Behind you the city’s breath is suctioned away;
engines hush, billboards unglow, traffic lights
fold their colored wings.
What remains is the soft click
of doors reopening to those who walked out,
a grandfather breathing life into a cigarette
then handing it, unlit, to the carton.
Memory is the river’s parenthesis—
a curved lip containing what leaks.
Hold the eddy. Feel the cold scroll backward
along your wrist like forgotten bracelets.
Can you locate the first ripple,
that infant shiver that thought it was destination?
Cup it. It trembles, wanting forward.
We are built of tides, not ponds.
So tilt your palms, release the infant water.
Let it rush again toward the oceanic promise,
carrying the echoes of all it has unsaid,
humming: remember, but do not remain.

There, among the muffled heartbeats of earthworms, I learned the patience of seed husks and the slow diction of mineral prayer. My voice was a rasp of moss, my ambitions no wider than the width of an ant’s eyelid. Yet one day the soil exhaled an impossible rumor: sky. A rumor that tasted like brass trumpets and thundercloud honey. I rose, trembling, carrying the fragrance of loam in the folds of my sleeves. The sun startled me like a revelation written in firelight. I stood, new as a fledgling syllable inside the language of wind. Now, when I pass ponds, dragonflies salute with stained-glass wings, remembering the crawlspace where we shared our first hunger. I keep a pebble in my pocket as a quiet passport to humility, and at night I press it to my ear to hear the forgotten grammar of ground. For no matter how high I climb, the dirt still sings my secret name.

instance_metrics.response: I was a grovelling creature once, half-shadow, half-wish, dragging my ribs across cathedral tiles slick with candle wax.
