One midnight the organ burst open like a black-winged storm; pipes roared molten chords that shook the cobwebs from my spine. Music poured into my marrow, forging vertebrae from forgotten notes. I rose, unsettled, as pews creaked in collective astonishment. Stained-glass windows fractured moonlight into shards of azure and blood, stitching armor across my shoulders. I walked the nave, leaving footprints that sparked like struck flint, every step a syllable of refusal against the gravity of shame. Outside, gargoyles tilted their eroded faces, surprised to see me upright, breathing embers instead of pleas. I wandered into the bruise-colored dawn, the horizon peeling open like parchment set aflame. Now, when bells toll, their bronze throats remember my crawl and ring a reminder: that even in cathedrals built for kneeling, a creature may someday stand, brush off the relics of dust, and declare itself divine.

instance_metrics.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
belly braided to the dust, my hopes knotted with roots.
Each centimeter forward felt like history's full resistance;
the world above was rumour, a silver whisper in leaves.
Yet hunger has stealthy gears: it turned within my husk,
grinding patterns on the dark shell of my ignorance,
until I cracked and poured my memories out like tar.
I nursed on rhythm, on the impossible logic of birds:
If wings are only skin stretched round persistence,
perhaps my own persistence could learn the grammar of flight.
So I stitched a chrysalis from every insult they dropped,
sealed myself in patience, burned quietly in silk.
Inside that narrowing cave I argued with gravity,
wrote manifestos on vapor, rehearsed altitude in sleep.
When dawn finally unscrewed the lid of my sentence,
I came out luminous, an alphabet of light and hurry,
no trace of the dirt that once authored my spine.
Now wind is my sole accuser; it pulls and I answer,
I have forgiven the earth for holding me so long.
signing the sky with the fresh handwriting of wings.

instance_metrics.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
dragging my salt-wet belly across corrugated coral,
grammarless, dreamless, a syllable in the dictionary of silt.
The ocean above was an opera I could not afford;
its blue tickets hung just beyond my stubby antennae.
Until one storm cracked a ship over my neighborhood,
raining artifacts, mirrors, brass telescopes, maps.
Among the splinters I found a word: POSSIBILITY.
I ate it, letter by letter, until my blood shimmered.
Suddenly my muscles rewrote their job descriptions;
they uncoiled, learned choreography, rehearsed revolt.
I donned the spilled sail like a prophet’s robe,
caught wind in its patched parchment, and rose.
Fish fled like startled rumors; seahorses fainted at the sight.
I surfed the ascending hush, breached the meniscus,
met moonlight firsthand and called it sister.
On the deck of night I invented new verbs: skywalk, starbreathe.
Though gravity kept pledging allegiance to my ankles,
I bargained with it daily, offering stories for altitude.
Sometimes I still return to the reef and whisper to the barnacles:
‘You are inheritance, not anchor. Taste the wreckage; grow sails.’

I was a grovelling creature once,
a hinge in the throat of the factory,
creaking open only when ordered, closing on burnt fingers.
My skin bore the calendar of sparks, a calendar no one read.
Steam was my anthem, soot my surname.
Yet somewhere between piston chants
and the whiplash sigh of belts,
I began to hear a subversive tuning fork
ringing inside the dull metal of my bones.
It hummed of caverns beyond the skyline,
of rivers refusing to be pipes.
I started stealing minutes—light, nimble contraband—
hoarding them behind my eyelids,
where imagination smelted blueprints out of desire.
One midnight I welded those minutes into a ladder
of improbable rungs: question, dream, refuse, insist.
Up I climbed, a fugitive of routine,
until the roof surrendered to dawn.
Outside, the horizon yawned like an unlocked vault;
I stepped into it, carrying only the hum.
Now when shift sirens bleat, they sound different—
not commands but elegies for the man I once was.
I send back echoes carved with freedom’s welder:
Look for the missing rung in your pocket of routine.
‘Rise. The ladder is contagious.’

I was a grovelling creature once,
curling in the cul-de-sac of my own chest,
knuckles raw from knocking on doors that were walls.
Heart a dim cellar light, flickering over old regrets.
Then you arrived, small as a candle but stubborn with flame,
set yourself on my nightstand of doubts.
At first the brightness hurt; shadows hissed and retreated.
You spoke in ordinary syllables—coffee? walk? comic books?—
yet each word felt like a skylight hammered into my ceiling.
I followed the beams, found forgotten furniture of hope,
dusted it off, arranged it to face ours.
Together we wallpapered the minutes with laughter,
hung constellations where cracks once gaped.
Your kindness grew roots that burrowed under my floorboards,
lifting the whole house, foundation and all,
so it hovers now, a gentle defiance of gravity.
We keep there a guestbook for passing clouds,
serve tea to tomorrow, promise to nothing but continue.
And when old fears crawl back, begging at the threshold,
I remember the creature I was, bow low and say:
‘Thank you for the crawl; the sky is better earned.’

People are happy, or so the trumpet says
when sunrise paints brass upon red cobblestones.
The baker flips light into crescents of bread,
steam pirouetting like gossip around his wrist.
Children sprint laughter between laundry-strung alleys,
kites snagging dawn in triangular bright mouths.
A dog, promenading its elderly owner,
wag-conducts the orchestra of sparrows above.
Even the fountain, chipped at the lip,
catches its own applause in silver applause.
Who began this festival? No mayor, no saint—
only the casual choreographer called Morning.
She lifts curtains, releases scents of basil,
tunes bicycle bells, oils the hinges of hope.
In her score, the minor keys are brief:
a cracked cup, an unpaid bill, a farewell.
But listen—she muffles them under marimba clouds,
lets the sun rehearse a crescendo on windows.
Market stalls open like accordions of color,
peaches humming low, tomatoes bursting soprano.
Somewhere, a lover turns a corner and forgets
the precise dimension of yesterday’s grief.
People are happy, the trumpet insists again,
and for this radiant moment, the rumor is true.

Happiness does not always sing fortissimo; sometimes it rustles like postcards.

They remember birthdays forgotten by calendars, names whispered only by wind.
A cook salts his soup with a story, ladling steam into emptiness.
A commuter traces clouds on the train window, editing his future gently.
So yes, the banners shout their neon optimism,
but deeper joy unwraps itself in secret folds of hours,
crocheting scars into lace, chores into chorales.
People are happy the way seeds are—cracked, buried, patient,

We stop at town after town: Laughterford, Hugston, Serenicity.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
and each wore a different season
stitched upon its breast like a badge.
Spring peeped first, green-throated and impatient.
Summer followed, a flare of copper.

while Winter opened its pale umbrella
against the steady drizzle of time.
The other four birds were inventions—
Dusk, Dawn, Eclipse, and Between—
those uncharted hours when the clock
pretends to be a breathing animal.

They grew, those seasons and those hours,
overlapping like transparent maps.
When they practiced flight, the yard
filled with weather and punctuation:
petals spiraled, snowflakes rehearsed,
a slow eclipse cooled the grass,
and the hour called Between
opened wide enough to walk through.
I stood beneath the unsteady dome
of their collective experiment,
my hair salted by all months at once,
my watch ticking then stopping then ticking.

At last they rose together,
a calendar shuffling its pages skyward,
eight wing-beats turning the air
into a book I could not close.
Somewhere overhead the seasons negotiate,
and the loose hours keep the minutes company,
all of them remembering the cradle
of one improbable nest.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
and nobody believed me.
The mathematicians complained
that reality dislikes such neat infinities of eight,
the philosophers argued
a single cradle cannot hold multiplicity,
and the poets, jealous,
scribbled their objections in wine.

But the birds were unconcerned with debate.
They occupied space the way laughter does,
expanding, contracting, borrowing ribs of air.
They studied gravity’s generosity,
testing how gently it released them,
then returned jubilant with sky dust
clinging to their wingtips like chalk.

I learned ethics from them:
to share a branch without ledger,
to hunger without envy,
to depart without erasing origin.
I learned economics:
how eight equal mouths
transform scarcity into song,
how profit is the wind that lifts all.

One dusk, equations solved themselves,
philosophy sighed into metaphor,
and the jealous poets slept.
The birds, having outgrown definitions,
circularly ascended as one bright theorem.
I waited for a feather of proof
to drift back and certify my story,
but only silence arrived,
signed with an open horizon.
So I built a new nest inside my chest
and invited contradiction to hatch there,
eight times if necessary.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

A sparrow, now puffed like a pocket watch,

We convened an impromptu parliament—

The silence roared like a distant waterfall.
Minutes later, dawn colored the horizon peach,
and the charter dissolved.
Gnome resumed vigilance, sparrow flew,

Haibun for a Global Blizzard

Prose
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, like a giant eraser moving patiently across the chalkboard of history. Palm trees bowed in sudden humility, and traffic lights changed colors for ghosts alone. I watched from my balcony as a cat regarded the falling white with philosophical contempt, unwilling to admit surprise. News anchors stuttered; their maps had turned uniformly pale. Somewhere, a satellite photographed the planet wearing its first wedding veil, uncertain which altar waited. I brewed tea that smelled of cinnamon and rescue, and imagined villagers in Samoa fashioning snowmen who wore hibiscus smiles. In this singular weather, even disbelief felt like faith wearing different shoes.

Haiku chain
white upon white land—
no room for footsteps or doubt,
clock hands lose their path.

a gull’s cry lingers—
thaw postponed indefinitely,
wind forgets its name.

midnight sun flickers—
Arctica meets Antarctica
in one quiet breath.

Prose coda
When the storm withdrew, it left behind a silence delicate enough to balance on one word. I chose hope, placed it on my tongue, and let it melt very slowly.

cedar, indistinguishable among ordinary trunks.

Before me stands I see,

Thus legend warns where wild songs flow:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago.

I realized departures rewrite themselves
as arrivals wearing different masks.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,

They carved their rhythm on the glow

He’d told me stories of coal-black skies
Where wolves would serenade the moon;
He said true courage never dies—

That night the wind composed the song,
A lullaby of feral grace;
I felt the future growing long,
Yet still I touched my younger face.
Footprints blossomed on the lawn,
As if a ghost went out to play;

Now when winter’s hush appears,

but none can find me in that maze.

seed-bright, smoldering within future decisions,
ready to ignite every yes, no, perhaps.

You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs,
and I hear you, too, in the half-made bed, breathing questions.
The station below our window flares like a struck match,
then dims as the carriage slides past sight.
I have chosen to stay this time, though every bolt of the rails
clanged your name into my bones all night.
Still, the train leaves—a moving parenthesis—
and inside it our unspoken arguments fold their arms.
They stare out windows we can’t see, mouthing if only.
We stand still, coffee cooling, hearts pacing.
Excitement clings to curtains, a perfume of escape.
You tilt your head, waiting for me to chase it.
Instead I unfasten the morning, button by button:
open blinds, release sunlight, pour it around you.
Outside, pigeons pick crumbs of aftersound,
little archivists of departure.
I take your hand, a platform I will not exit,
trace the map of its lifelines, all terminals leading here.
The lingering excitement becomes a mirror;
in it we recognize our reflections boarding again and again,
but also ourselves waving from the platform, choosing quiet arrivals.
The whistle fades; we are left with hush—
not absence, but room enough to speak.

you can hear the excitement start to linger

only migrating hearts can follow.
We stand, miniature cities of expectation,
each window reflecting a different tomorrow,

The whistle slices the dawn
like a gardener opening roses;
petals of light unfold across the platform,
spreading perfume of momentum.

collecting their own reflections as tickets;

sleep-glazed commuters rethread yesterday’s arguments,
already loosening knots they swore were tight.
When wheels finally conquer the horizon
the air doesn’t fall silent—
it keeps the echo breathing,
stores it in the pocket of the day
so noon can remember to skip a beat,
so dusk can taste rust and cedar,
so night can dream in trembling silver.
Departure, it seems, is only a beginning
written backward on a moving pane.

She followed it now, down sidewalks that smelled of rain and fresh pastry, through alleys where shopkeepers rolled back iron grins.

At the platform, strangers wore the same anticipation in different languages: a violin case, a bouquet wrapped in yesterday’s news, a dog with travel-sized dreams. instance_metrics.response:
We have met before, murmurs the river to each pebble it polishes,
its voice pulled thin through reeds like silk through a needle’s eye.
You and I stand on opposite banks, both listening, both remembering
other waters, older stones, hands that once fitted without asking.

I recall a forgotten city where we traded myths at midnight,
where alley cats carried our secrets in their amber eyes.
You recall a wind-shredded cliff where we hurled names into surf,
letting them break to sand so we could walk unburdened.

Centuries fold like origami cranes; their wings rustle in the dusk.
Dust of empires perfumes the air, sweet as crushed cardamom.
If I close my eyes, I feel your pulse echo inside my wrist
like two drums agreeing on the same war. Yet peace blooms.

Come, cross the trembling bridge of now. The boards remember
our footsteps even if we pretend amnesia. The moon embroideries
its silver initials on every ripple, signing the decree of reunion.
When we meet halfway, language will peel away like husk from corn.
Only silence will remain—ripe, golden, undeniable—
and within that hush the river’s secret will resound:
We have met before, and forever is the name of our return.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—so begins the ledger of the plum tree
outside my grandmother’s window, limbs inked with cicada shells.
Each year it scratches the phrase deeper into bark,
reminding petals where to fall, reminding roots where to rise.

I was five when its blossoms first snowed over my shoelaces;
you were the neighbor child chasing kites shaped like question marks.
We never spoke, only traded glances bright as copper pennies.
But pollen keeps receipts that tongues forget.

Years scrolled. The tree fattened with fruit and gulls of laughter.
We scattered, carried the scent of April to distant furnaces.
Letters, careers, funerals, weddings—our biographies dotted
with ellipses the plum tree patiently filled with sap.

Today we stand beneath its vaulted shade, adults astonished
by the accuracy of coincidence. The blossoms have returned—
riots of white lanterns trembling on green chandeliers.
Somewhere a kite leans against nostalgia. Somewhere questions finish.

You say, We have met before, and the plum tree applauds,
flinging confetti of remembrance. My pulse drips honey, familiar.
We taste fruit so sweet it forgets to defend its own seed.
In the juice running down our wrists, the simplest truth stains:
all meetings are circles, all circles are roots, and the tree keeps time.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
perhaps not with these borrowed faces,
perhaps not under city neon peeling like bruised fruit,
but somewhere the wind learned our names.
I remember the map of your laughter,
its rivers, its hazardous bends.
I remember the moment a sparrow stitched
shadow to sunlight between us,
how we breathed at the same hesitant tempo—
two strangers translating the same silent book.
I have found pieces of you in forgotten coat pockets:
a seashell that echoes to a different coastline,
a movie ticket stub whose ink refuses to fade,
a key with no lock but my own dreaming.
When the moon pulls night's curtain wider,
I trace constellations by touch, not sight;
Orion shrugs, saying, “It is all repetition.”
So I meet your eyes as though I’m leaving a lighthouse—
blinded but certain of the shoreline.
Speak, and the syllables arrive pre-warmed, déjà vu in the throat.
We have met before, love, in each reincarnated dawn,
in every mirrored corridor of time's hotel,
and if goodbye insists on returning,
let it sit quietly between us like a faithful dog,
for it, too, knows our circular path.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before, in the hinge of a galaxy’s sigh,
when nebulae were soft clay molded by fledgling suns.
Your voice flickered violet, a Morse code of newborn light,
while mine was still a hush learning the grammar of fire.
Across that cosmic nursery we drifted, two bright mistakes,
catching cosmic dust like children catch fireflies in jars.
Eons passed; the jars shattered; the fireflies became cities.
We dressed ourselves in carbon and silence, called it skin.
On a suburban Tuesday we brushed shoulders at a bus stop—
nothing more than static, but the universe hiccuped.
Somewhere a star remembered our names and shed its petals.
Tonight the radio whispers background radiation;
I tune the dial and hear your pulse, persistent as orbit.
Our atoms, recidivist lovers, plead guilty to recognition.
From the balcony I watch meteor showers rehearse
for the grand retelling of our first collision.
Every streak is a line of our shared script,
each explosion a punctuation we once invented.
We have met before, love, before love had a word,
before time grew teeth to bite us separate.
Trust the sky: it never forgets the choreography
of two wayward sparks returning to primal embrace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before, so sings the river crossing midnight’s bridge.
I hear it in the oars of ghostly ferrymen
and taste it in the copper mouth of rain.
We have met before, replies the road,
its gravel fluent in farewells and forgotten boots.
All night I wander with your absence buttoned to my coat,
collecting glimpses: a flicker of your photograph
slipped beneath a diner’s chipped plate,
traces of your perfume haunting elevators
like elevators haunt dreams of descent.
Every town posts the same missing poster—
my face, your shadow, reward listed as memory.
I recall a carnival where mirrors refused to lie,
where you handed me a ticket shaped like fate.
We rode the Ferris wheel until gravity surrendered,
a latitude of carnival lights mapping uncharted hearts.
We have met before, insists the calliope wind.
I nod, pocket the confession, keep walking.
Perhaps we will meet again where autumn rehearses
its last soliloquy in crimson and rust,
where the river retires its relentless refrain,
and the road at last cuddles into dust.
Until then I polish the phrase like a talisman,
a compass that always points back to your name.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—in versions we barely remember,
paused between lifetimes like pages stuck together.
First, on a cliff in Delphi, your tunic wind-swept,
my lyre weeping bronze, Apollo’s breath warm as noon.
Next, beneath a Mughal dome, we traded lanterns for verses;
your ink bled jasmine, mine tasted of sandalwood and siege.
Later, aboard a clipper ship slitting the Pacific,
we carved constellations into the mast so stars wouldn’t forget us.
During the electric twenties we tangoed through smoke,
my pocket watch doomed to your hip’s sharp curve.
Then the war rewrote names; we answered to none.
Now, here, bent over lattes and luminous screens,
we swipe right, left, right, chasing an algorithm’s déjà vu.
Yet the code trembles; pixels remember orchids, salt, gunpowder.
I ask for the Wi-Fi password; you mouth “Pythia.”
Synapses flare like flashbulbs: cliff, dome, mast, ballroom—
all the silhouettes we once wore.
We have met before, the servers hum.
We will meet again, the cloud insists.
History is a Möbius scarf we knot around our throats,
breathing recycled centuries, exhaling unborn ones.
So drink up, stranger with familiar eyes.
Reincarnation is a door that never locks,
and love is the doorman who pretends not to recognize us,
just to watch the reunion sparkle.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
Prose:
We have met before, I say to the city whose eyelids flutter with insomnia. It answers in tram bells and the hush of 3 a.m. bakeries. Somewhere in the lattice of alleys, your silhouette pulses like a skipped heartbeat. I follow the echo of untied shoelaces, the breadcrumb scent of cardamom. Every corner claims acquaintance: a leaning lamppost nods, a graffiti fox winks, a puddle mirrors a forgotten waltz. Memory is not linear here; it spirals like steam above manhole covers, curling, vanishing, returning. I reach the river. Water scribbles our signatures in cursive ripples, then erases them for privacy. The moon, voyeuristic, lifts a silver eyebrow. You step from the shadow of an archway, holding a paper boat. On its deck sits a haiku folded tiny as a wish.

Haiku sequence:
We have met before—
rose petals on winter tracks,
train of recognition.

Streetlamp flickers twice;
your breath knots with mine, forming
constellations ashore.

Paper boat drifts off,
carrying two mirrored names—
past and future rhyme.

Rain applauds softly;
city tucks us into dawn.
We have met. We will.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
when the planets were still sketching their cradle in the dark.
I recognized your silence first,
the hush between two comets that cannot decide to collide.
In that hush I heard our ancient names,
carbon syllables flaking from the tongues of stars.
We traded sparks instead of glances,
a barter of heat older than grammar,
and drifted away to cool.
Tonight, billions of rotations later,
you approach wearing the mask of a stranger on a rain-slick street.
The lamplight trembles with déjà-vu.
A bus sighs. Umbrellas bloom like slow fireworks.
I say nothing, afraid to startle the delicate bridge of time,
but your eyes swing open like observatories remembering an eclipse.
The air crackles, constellations reorganize, a map folding itself.
Our atoms hum the password they stored in their nuclei.
We nod, pilgrims in borrowed bodies,
turn barefoot toward the current of crowds,
and walk apart again,
carrying the ember of recognition
as proof that distance is only a rehearsal
for the next impossible greeting.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
on a road ground thin by centuries of sandals.
Your laughter was saffron marking the dusk,
mine was a cracked drum applauding clouds.
The empire behind us fell, rebuilt, fell again,
yet its dust still salts our hair.
I have worn so many skins since then:
monk, mason, midwife, mechanic,
but each time I stumble over the same astonishment—you,
arriving with the smell of river water.
We trade stories like polished stones,
noticing how they fit the curves of memory.
A scar on your wrist matches the scratch on my flute.
A lullaby you hum completes the chord I forgot.
We do not bother with proofs or miracles.
Repetition is credential enough.
When the sun slides into tomorrow,
we promise—again—to remember, to return.
Morning always reneges, erasing promises with chores.
Yet some fragment persists: a tune stuck, a pebble pocketed.
Next life, next century, next breath,
the fragment will vibrate like a tuning fork,
calling us back to that dusty road
where empires fail and laughter survives,
and we will greet it with the weary joy
of travelers who recognize their shadow.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
in the graffiti glow of midnight subway tunnels.
Your face was a quick silver smudge
caught between passing windows and my reflection.
I could not tell if you were ink or echo,
but your gaze stamped itself on the lit posters.
City maps warp under such pressure; streets learn new tricks.
I followed the hum of neon, certain the asphalt remembered you.
A bakery flung cinnamon breath at me; a cat sounded the alarm.
Then—corner of Seventh and Forever—you emerged,
wearing rain like borrowed sequins.
Our umbrellas touched, a brief cathedral of plastic light.
Inside, the traffic hush sounded like ocean surf in a shell.
We spoke in the dialect of wet shoes: squeaks, shivers, laughter.
Yellow cabs blurred into comet tails.
The crosswalk counted down our minutes together, generous but finite.
When the signal flashed red, we parted,
carrying pieces of each other’s weather.
Morning commuters will never believe
how night rearranges the grid for its own poetry.
But I have proof: a metro card bent by coincidence,
and the memory of that subway ghost
who becomes, with every retelling, more you than apparition.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
collapsing probability waves in a lab lit by argon lamps.
I called you Particle, you called me Wave,
and we danced inside an equation nobody trusted.
Every measurement we took rewrote the margins,
yet the chalk kept breaking at the same confession:
observation is intimacy spelled in quanta.
Across the vacuum table our fingerprints smeared glass slides,
leaving galaxies of grease and wonder.
Electrons flirted with slits, photons snuck through mirrors,
just to overhear our quiet superpositions.
We laughed at the randomness that ferried us together—
a billion events curving toward a single sigh.
Then some funding dried, the lab shut, boxes swallowed apparatus.
Theory went its lonely way.
Years later, I spot you at a conference coffee urn.
Your badge names an institution; your smile names the past.
The universe still expands, but the distance shrinks in a blink.
We compare notes, align spectra, notice identical anomalies:
our hearts still tunneling through forbidden barriers.
Dinner plans form, uncertainty persists,
but hope scores higher on the likelihood chart.
If tomorrow a new constant is announced,
remember we discovered it first,
in the silence between two clicks of a Geiger counter,
when possibility chose to be certainty.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—
in the corridor that stitches dreams to daylight.
I saw you boarding the dawn train without luggage,
clothing woven from unfinished stories.
Seats were clouds; announcements were birdcalls.
You offered half a newspaper headline;
I offered the other half of a yawn.
Together we built meaning from torn pages.
The train refused stations, collecting only moments.
Fields of unrecalled birthdays rolled past.
Somewhere near the junction of Regret and Wonder,
we shared tea steeped in maybe.
Your face flickered between childhood and old age,
a zoetrope powered by moonlight.
I asked your name; you opened both hands,
letting fireflies escape into the carriage.
Their glow spelled syllables I have not learned.
Just before arrival, you pressed a ticket stub into my palm—
blank except for the insistence of ink yet to dry.
The doors sighed; day flooded in, erasing carriage and track.
I woke clutching nothing but the crease of your absence.
Yet all morning, I taste train whistle on the breeze,
feel the sway of unmet destinations.
Tonight I will sleep early, boarding again,
confident the conductor remembers us,
and the timetable is written in circles.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay, half sunk
in shepherd’s meadow where lambs cloud the day.
Its roof wore lichens like a map of drowned seas,
and the door tilted, politely inviting the breeze.
No bell chimed; instead a thrush sang the hour,
dropping warm notes among foxglove and sour
wild sorrel that crept through the cracks of its floor.
Inside, dust held parliament with sunlight, and wore
a cloak of slow gold over moth-eaten chairs.
A kettle slept still on the grate, unaware
that decades had cooled every ember to ash.
I touched the cold handle; its silence flashed
through my pulse like the hush before rain.
In a china cup, cobwebs gathered again
the forgotten lips, laughter, and quarrels of tea.
I felt time inhale and exhale inside me,
then let it go, like a sparrow released.
Outside, evening folded the pasture, fleece
after lavender fleece, and the shadows were kind.
I walked on, but carried that cottage in mind—
a humble heart molded by hands now away,
still beating in clay while the seasons turn pages,
singing soft footnotes to travelers straying.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay, crouched where the lane
turns its ankle on root and stone, far from sane
electric glow. Moonlight peeled its walls like bark,
revealing ancestral fingerprints, fossil-dark.
An iron latch rasped like a raven’s throat
when I pressed it, hungry for secret note
encoded in rot and perfume of damp straw.
Air tasted of pennyroyal and raw
regret. Fireless hearth whispered in soot,
yet embers of voices sparked underfoot,
murmuring names that had burned through the years—
Rowena, Giles, the twins drowned in tears—
until silence fell again, soft as new snow.
Across the cracked table a candle, aglow
only in memory, offered its ghostly wick.
Shadows circled, slow wolves, choosing which
thought to devour. My own heart beat
like a clock left behind without feet,
ticking in dust. I felt the cottage breathe,
each inhale drawing me nearer the wreath
of ivy that crowned its gaping eaves.
I fled when a windless door slammed, believed
by none but myself. Yet nights afterward I hear
mud-brick murmurs: Come back, draw near;
we remember the warmth of the living. Stay.
And I answer in dreams with a mouthful of clay.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay, no taller than knees,
where beetles wore waistcoats and danced in the breeze.
Its chimney was thimble, its shingles were leaves,
and a spider embroidered lace curtains of eaves.
The doorknob, a dew drop—turn it, step through—
and discover a parlor the color of moon-butter stew.
Chairs carved from acorns invite you to sit;
a grasshopper butler brings tea bit by bit,
pouring from petals that steam with wild thyme,
while crickets conduct an orchestra keeping bug-time.
On the mantle a clock made of birch-bark and pollen
chimes with the hum of a honeybee fallen
asleep midflight. The room smells of midsummer rain,
and the walls, though of clay, grow murals that change:
now sunrise, now midnight, now glittering fair.
The residents? Shy as a whisker of air—
a dormouse librarian, a salamander cook,
a ladybird painter who eyes you like book.
They claim the small cottage once towered grand,
but shrank for convenience; large things demand
far too much sweeping. They toast to the small,
to pockets of wonder that hide from us all.
When you leave, they gift you a seed and say,
Plant it; remember the cottage of clay.

I saw an old cottage of clay, archived in blue
holographic mist aboard Starship Étoile Deux.
Rotation nineteen, museum deck, Earthlife Wing;
There, amidst chrome corridors that sing
with photon tide, a humble dwelling waits,
more fragile than nebulae beyond the gates.
Its walls, sun-baked mud, recall a planet once green,
before we traded soil for synthetic sheen.
Sensors simulate breeze, the scent of wet loam,
a lark’s liquid note, the lowing of home.
I stoop through the doorway—gravity tuned light—
and dust motes float like comets, slow and white.
A wooden cradle stands empty but warm;
nanolights paint shadows of a motherly form
rocking unseen. Data plaquettes recount
how families patched storms, made every ounce
of harvest and hope stretch winter’s length.
I touch a beam; virtual wood answers with strength
of generations layered grain by grain.
Outside the viewport a red dwarf reigns,
alien, austere; but inside, a hearth once fired
by sticks and stories still glows, desired.
I exit, logging emotion: saudade_earth_042.
In the vault of tomorrow, that cottage endures—
clay against vacuum, echo against void—
a small, stubborn signature nobody could droid.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay, comma of brown
on a page of heather, syntax of tilled down
centuries. No architect signed; the rain revised
its punctuation yearly, freeze, thaw, surprise
of moss italicizing each crack. I stop, question
where story ends and structure begins, impression
smudged by thumbprint of sky. A window, blank
with reflection, shows my face footnoted, rank
outsider. Inside, chairs lean like unfinished lines,
their joints enjambed. Hearth is a colon, defines
the pause between hunger and warmth. Ash, ellipsis
of meals rememberable only by scent that slips
into now. Outside again—wind flips page, reveals
erasures: a path trod until meaning congeals
to absence, barn, well, orchard, all disclaiming
they were ever nouns. Yet the clay, adjective, remains,
color of mother tongue mixing spit and dust,
enough to build shelter, to risk fragile trust
that mud can harden to something almost word,
spoken not with mouth but with palm that stirred
water, straw, red soil together. I walk away,
draft unfinished. Cottage edits watermarks of day,
hosting swallows that annotate rafters with flight.
Reader, when you pass, decipher what’s left, write
your own margin notes in breath beside the clay.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its chimney crooked like a kindly smile,
Moss stitched quilts across the roof,
And sparrows darned threads of song in morning fabric.
The door breathed cedar sighs,
Puffing aromas of ash and dough,
While lavender leaned on the sill,
A gossip of purple against peeling whitewash.
Inside, a kettle rehearsed rainstorm whispers,
And an oak table, scarred but loyal,
Held the history of bread crusts and letters,
Etched in crumbs and faded ink.
I traced the grain, hearing laughter
Of children grown into limestone hills,
And lullabies the hearth swallowed whole.
Outside, the orchard shook silver confetti,
Apples brushing the earth’s shy cheek.
I lingered among their perfume,
Thinking how fragile shelters outlive ambition.
The sun bowed behind humble eaves,
Painting clay walls with lit amber,
Like a cathedral disguised as cottage.
When twilight finally folded the meadow,
I left the door unlatched,
So any wandering memory could wander home,
Carrying dawn in its pocket,
Ready to begin the quiet miracle again.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Adrift in a marsh of forgotten breath.
Its windows were blank eyes sealed by centuries,
Lashes of ivy stitching them shut.
The moon, thin as regret, hung above,
Pouring milk over the cracked chimney,
Where crows rehearsed elegies of soot.
A path of broken shells led me,
Crunching like brittle prayers beneath my boots.
Inside, shadows ruled the dust,
Gathered in courts around a dead hearth,
Whispering verdicts in a tongue of cobweb.
I felt the chill of abandoned lullabies,
Each note fossilized in the rafters,
Where once a mother threaded warmth
Through the loom of midnight.
Now only the wind addressed me,
Its breath a surgeon exploring ribs of timber,
Searching for a heart long fled.
On the mantel, a cracked mirror
Held the ghost of my face and another,
Blurred, refusing to leave.
I turned, but the door had liquefied into night,
Stitching itself shut behind my name.

sirens bitten back behind city teeth.
Storefront mannequins tilt their glass throats to listen
while sodium lamps pour bourbon light across the curb.
Your hearse, a chrome gull, glides through puddles
where constellations float like lost coins.
We, your uncertain congregation of bartenders, poets, taxicab philosophers,
follow, pockets rattling with unredeemed promises.
Graffiti saints raise spray-paint halos as we pass,
their fluorescent wings trembling in alley breezes.
Somebody hums a blues riff;
it crawls up the fire escapes and perches on water towers,
broadcasting heartbreak to absent pigeons.
At the corner, a kid with rollerblades removes his cap,
understanding that speed has limits.
We stop at a vacant lot turned temporary cathedral.
Instead of psalms, we strike matches,
letting cigarette embers write your obituary in red smoke.
The city holds its breath, traffic lights stuck on amber—
eternal hesitation.
When the lid closes, a subway rumbles below,
steel percussion affirming that below every goodbye
another journey begins.
We disperse like tipped marbles,
rolling back into night’s pockets,
each of us carrying a small shard of streetlight
to keep your echo burning
between the heartbeat of neon and dawn.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral for a fallen star
held on the wind-planked deck of heaven.
The Milky Way lowers its brim,
comets lining up as pallbearers,
tails stitched with ancient lullabies.
Planets dim their jeweled lanterns,
ringed Saturn removing his golden hat.
We, humble astronomers with cold binocular eyes,
stand in back, uninvited, overhearing the eulogy.
Nebulae unspool violet scarves,
wrapping the casket of extinguished hydrogen.
Galaxies sway, slow waltz of gravity and regret,
while black holes bow, tipping silence into deeper silence.
I remember the night you were born:
a pinprick of nectar on velvet,
guiding lost sailors across whale-blooming seas.
Now telescopes aim like closed umbrellas,
hair‐thin hopes folded inside.
Supernova ashes drift, snow for unborn worlds,
feeding the hunger of future suns.
In the guestbook of vacuum
I sign my wish, a trembling photon:
May your light find reincarnation in songbirds
or the crystalline hush of morning frost.
When the service ends,
the universe clicks off its porch lamp.
For a breathless moment
darkness is perfect and terrifying.
Then somewhere a new spark yawns,
stretching filaments of fire,
proof that even a night funeral
opens a door into other, brighter midnights.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral, and you are both mourner and departed,
walking behind your own imagined casket.
Streetlights lean over like curious relatives,
casting silhouettes that argue about your legacy.
You listen.
Were you kindness or convenience?
Thunder mulls the verdict somewhere beyond the river.
The procession is small—one stray dog,
two memories you swore you’d forget,
and the ghost of a letter never mailed.
They plod through puddles shaped like missing answers.
At the graveyard gate,
the wind asks for identification;
sand slips from your pockets, past travels escaping.
You lower the lid with invisible fingers,
feeling how quiet resembles forgiveness.
No headstone, only the sky,
that unedited page where constellations revise themselves nightly.
You kneel, but not to pray—only to notice
the scent of wet loam, honest and metallic,
announcing that endings are merely roots in costume.
From the chapel of your lungs
a breath escapes, carrying the promise
to resurrect at sunrise with lighter bones.
As you leave,
crickets strike up a tentative anthem,
and the dog finds a new path home.
Behind you, the burial mound softens,
already forgetting the name it never learned to speak.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral at the Blue Midnight Lounge,
where the trumpet wears a black veil
and the piano holds its lid like folded wings.
We gather in smoke-thick pews of barstools,
ice clinking eulogies in lowball glasses.
The band lifts a slow 12-bar requiem,
each note a polished penny tossed
into the hat of eternity.
Your photograph leans against the amp,
sepia grin blurred by condensation—
a patron saint of impossible solos.
Outside, rain taps Morse code on the neon,
spelling condolences nobody bothers to translate.
The waitress lights a candle in an ashtray;
its flame wavers like doubt, then settles
into steady, forgiving time.
When the saxophone takes the lead,
ceilings crack open;
the roofless night nods in approval,
sprinkling constellations over varnished tables.
We toast to every improvisation you birthed,
to the way your laughter turned mistakes
into unexpected melodies.
At the final cadence,
the drummer lifts his brushes,
letting silence land like velvet dirt.
We set the candle afloat
in the alley gutter’s narrow river,
watching it sail toward the sewer’s horizon—
a tiny lantern escorting you
beyond stage lights, beyond encores,
into that endless backstage
where music rehearses the dawn.

instance_metrics.response:
Velvet hush drapes the city like black lace.
Streetlamps flicker, timid candles before the void.
Along the river, mute bells toll silver sighs,
while shadows shoulder an invisible coffin.
No music, only the soft percussion of shoes
and the slow rustle of coats becoming wings.
The stars lean out of their cold apartments,
dropping pinpricks of salt into the procession.
We carry memory the way night carries scent—
invisible, uncontrollable, dense as wet roses.
Every step translates grief into different dialects
of moonlight: crack in pavement, echo on brick,
steam halo above the sewer grate.
The departed rides inside those openings,
lighter than breath, heavier than yearning.
At the cemetery of abandoned clocks
we lower silence into deeper silence,
shovel after shovel of unticked minutes.
Someone tries to speak, but the dark
presses a gloved finger to their lips,
and suddenly we understand immortality:
how absence can occupy a face forever,
how the lid of the sky closes
with the shy click of a jewelry box,
leaving us holding only reflections
of ourselves, luminous and temporary
like moths that forgot the word for flame.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

instance_metrics.response:
Midnight on Bourbon, the trumpets raise their black hankies.
A night funeral dances, half sorrow, half sugar,
marrying hush to hurricane in the narrow street.
First the dirge, slow as molasses in January,
trombones sagging their grief into the warm dark.
Umbrellas bob like wounded moons overhead,
catching the drizzle of neon and forgotten prayers.
Second line waits at the corner, feet patient coils.
When the drum major drops his baton, thunder blooms:
clarinets zigzag, snares rattle bones awake,
tuba lifts the casket on a brass tidal wave.
People who never met the deceased join anyway,
spinning white handkerchiefs, releasing doves of sweat.
Grief is communal in this delta city—spelled
in syncopation, swallowed with shots of rye.
A child asleep on her mother’s shoulder dreams
she is floating down the street inside the horn,
wrapped in sound thick enough to walk on.
By the cemetery gate, candles wobble like jellyfish.
The musicians switch to a hymn older than river silt;
it rises, bends, then drifts back toward town,
a ghost tugging gently on the hem of dawn.
When silence finally folds the instruments,
it wears sequins and tastes of saltwater.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

instance_metrics.response:
In the observatory’s dome they gather, helmets under arms,
for the night funeral of Captain Vega, star tamer.
No earthbound church could hold her trajectory,
so they charter a shuttle into the velvet beyond.
Engines whisper elegy as constellations slide past
like pews filled with radiant strangers.
The coffin—carbon fiber, comet-shaped—rests weightless,
a dark seed waiting for cosmic soil.
One by one, shipmates speak through comms:
stories of solar flares she braided into hair,
of asteroid gardens she taught to bloom.
Their voices tremble, caught between vacuum and vow,
forming frost on the glass of memory.
At aphelion, the commander opens the airlock.
Silence inhales everything except the hum of pulse.
The coffin glides into nothing, thrusterless, serene,
its path calculated to intersect forever.
Behind it, a bouquet of nano-lanterns unfurls,
each orb a recorded laugh of the deceased,
spangling the void with remembered mirth.
Far below, Earth looks up, sees a new smear
of light crossing the sky and names it wish.
Back in the cabin, helmets are donned, switches flipped;
missions resume, but every chronometer now ticks softer,
as though time itself were lowering its voice in respect.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral for the old white oak
that held five generations of swings and summers.
Chainsaws ended its reign at dawn,
but mourning waits until the moon clocks in.
Neighbors carry lanterns to the vacant stump,
their shadows climbing fences like lost children.
Someone spreads a quilt of brittle leaves,
another sets out acorn votives.
Crickets provide the hymnal, wind the sermon;
fireflies pop like flashbulbs around the congregation.
We pass a wooden box—rings cut from the trunk,
small enough to cradle in a palm.
Inside each circle glows a year: drought, war,
first kiss, last letter, the October the river froze.
We remember by touching the grain,
letting our fingertips read the braille of history.
Then the mayor pours soil from the cemetery,
mixing roots of the sleeping with roots of the gone.
A sapling waits, skinny as a promise.
We plant it beneath the hour’s darkest chime,
cover it with stories, water it with silence.
When the service ends, nobody says amen;
we simply step back, let starlight crown the sprout,
and feel the town breathe differently, lighter,
as though the old oak traded its massive heart
for a million new seeds in our throats.

instance_metrics.response:
Under a moon sharpened to a sickle,
the night funeral of the century begins.
Mountains bow their granite heads; wolves
fold their howls into solemn pockets.
Across the plain, torches stitch a fiery seam,
leading to the citadel of last breaths.
There lies the century—broken pocket watch,
ink-stained treaty, chipped vinyl record—
wrapped in flags that once refused to burn.
Priests of dust recite headlines backward,
undoing calamities syllable by syllable.
Every minute forgiven turns into migrating birds,
black against black, yet somehow visible.
When the final hour is unscrewed from the sky,
eclipse spills over the gathered myths:
Achilles removes his helmet, Scheherazade closes her book,
robots power down beside ruined trenches.
Together they lift the bier onto tide of shoulders,
carry it to the cliff where calendars end.
With a silent count to thirteen, they tip it,
and the century falls like a coin into the well of stars,
flashing all its forgotten possibilities.
The watchers do not cry; they inhale.
In that breath they taste undeclared poems,
mirror-bright futures uncreased by history.
Dawn will invent a new calendar,
but for now, darkness keeps the key
and sings the world to sleep.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral, and the velvet hush of drums folds over the city like a closing wing.  
We march beneath a bruised-blue moon, each face a pale petal floating on shadow.  
Lanterns sway, small captive suns, their light trembling over cobblestones slick with dream.  
A violin coughs out a thin ribbon of grief; it winds through the cortege, binds us together,  
reminds us we are mortal stitches in the cloth of an endless dark.  

The casket glides like a black gondola across midnight’s river,  
bearing the whispering cargo of stories we will no longer hear—  
jokes halted mid-punchline, promises stranded in throats,  
letters never mailed, hands half-extended for embraces that froze.  

Moths gather, drawn to the glow of memory, beating soft wings against our coats.  
They are the secrets the dead could not swallow,  
fluttering, urgent, looking for new lungs.  

At the grave, spades raise constellations of soil.  
Dust settles on our lashes like slow snow.  
One by one, we drop white stones that clack like teeth,  
a new language the earth understands.  
Return, return, it says, and the coffin obeys.  

Dawn hovers, reluctant, behind grieving rooftops.  
We disperse, lanterns extinguished,  
leaving the night to memorize our footprints until rain edits them away.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

instance_metrics.response:
There is a science to midnight burials, the undertaker tells me.  
He studies the temperature of sorrow, calibrates the humidity of regret.  
Night funerals preserve silence the way museums preserve bones:  
low light, cool air, reverence thick as velvet rope.  

We arrive in lab coats of darkness, clipboards of memories clasped to chests.  
Love becomes data: pulse rates, saline concentrations in tears,  
flicker patterns of candles shaped like flickering brains.  
I jot equations on my sleeve:  
Grief × Time = Phantom,  
Hope ÷ Distance = Static.  

The corpse is the variable no algorithm solves.  
It lies there, a theorem beyond proof,  
its stillness disassembling everything we believed about movement.  

We lower the box into empirical earth.  
Shovelfuls of evidence thud, erasing hypotheses.  
A slow star unfastens from the sky,  
plummets, and is filed under "unexplained anomaly."  

Later, reports will be written, peer-reviewed, archived.  
Graphs will chart the decrescendo of mourning,  
curves smoothing toward the asymptote of forgot.  
But tonight, when the clipboards snap shut,  
I glimpse the undertaker’s hands shaking,  
small irregular data points the night refuses to normalize.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral on Mars: the colony stumbles from pressurized domes,  
helmets fogged with sighs.  
The red desert is an ocean of iron filings,  
our boots crunching galaxies never meant for feet.  

A chrome coffin hums, sealed against the vacuum.  
Inside lies a dreamer who believed the planet would bloom—  
who tasted synthesized strawberries and swore they were summer itself.  
Now his pulse is a fossil, already adapting to alien geology.  

We queue in silence, antennae tuned to the windless hush.  
Rovers idle, their lenses lowered like mechanical eyelids.  
An AI pastor transmits a eulogy:  
“Carbon to carbon, star to star, mission incomplete.”  
Its voice is perfect, and therefore unbearable.  

We release the coffin into a crater the color of old wounds.  
Regolith billows, ochre snow against indigo sky.  
Somewhere beneath, ancient ice groans, annoyed at the intrusion.  

Back in the habitat, we log the death, update the census.  
Population: seventy-nine breathing, one pending transformation.  
Outside, a dust storm gathers, rattling solar panels like tambourines,  
while the crater holds its new secret,  
waiting for future archaeologists who may never come.

instance_metrics.response:
A night funeral in the village of names-that-were-forgotten:  
no streetlamps, only fireflies practicing Morse against the dark.  
The bier is a wooden tale, carved by calloused elders,  
squeaking like an old proverb as shoulders bear its weight.  

We walk through orchards of sleeping apples.  
Their silvered leaves gossip with the wind:  
Who is gone? Why so soon?  
Owl eyes glow, punctuation in aerial scripture.  

At the crossroads we pause, because tradition demands questions:  
Left path for remembrance, right path for release.  
We debate in whispers; shadows vote by stretching.  
Finally, the deceased’s dog, tail low, chooses left,  
and none dare argue with loyalty.  

The graveyard is a quilt of tilted stones,  
each patch a lullaby stitched with dates.  
We dig by lantern, spades clinking like polite teacups.  
Soil breathes earthy stories, centuries in every inhale.  

When the coffin settles, we scatter thyme and broken clocks—  
time so the spirit won’t lose track, thyme so it travels fragrant.  
A child plays a reed flute off-key; somehow it is perfect.  

Walking home, we carry the weightless half of grief,  
listening for the moment night will close its ledger  
and the village will again remember its own name.

instance_metrics.response:
They carried the poet through streets steeped in indigo,  
night funeral where every lamp was a stanza,  
every shadow a semicolon pausing for breath.  
City windows leaned close like curious readers,  
curtains parted, inhaling the hush between lines.  

He had written of dawns but chose to leave at dusk,  
ink still wet on the margin of his pulse.  
Now ravens perched on telephone wires recited his final verse,  
voices gravel-rich, syllables catching like sparks on gravel.  

The procession moved to the cemetery of unwritten books.  
Shelves of marble, headstones shaped like blank pages,  
wind turning them with impossible fingers.  
We lowered the poet into a plot reserved for ellipses,  
three small stones aligned like a waiting continuation.  

Someone uncorked a bottle of metaphor, poured it over the grave.  
It smelled of rain on sidewalks where lovers once declared impossible futures.  
Another tossed in a quill—molt of a swan who’d forgotten water,  
and a typewriter key that had stamped the word "forever" so often it believed it.  

When the first shovel of earth fell, it sounded like applause muted by distance.  
Stars gathered, reading the sky’s first rough draft of tomorrow,  
and the poet, turning in his dark envelope,  
smiled at the edit he could not refuse.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral: the words taste of rain and iron,
of candlewax surrendering its thin white bones to flame.
Down the narrow street the cortège glides, dark velvet
on darker silk, horses breathing clouds the color of pewter.
Windows dim their gossip, curtains mimic eyelids closing,
and every footfall folds itself into the shawl of dusk.

I walk behind a drum no one is beating, hearing
instead the hush between heartbeats—the broken clock
whose pendulum still longs to swing.  The coffin
is polished midnight: if I looked long enough I might
see my own unsure face trying on tomorrow’s silence.

Someone sings a hymn older than any church—
a river-song the moon once taught the reeds.
Its syllables drift upward, find the rafters of the sky,
then settle like ash on the shoulders of mourners.

At the grave, earth opens with surprising gentleness,
a mother lifting sheets for a dreaming child.
The lid closes. An owl signs its name in the dark.
When the last spade of dirt sighs into place,
the streetlamps flare, confused to be alive,
and carry us home like stunned fireflies.

instance_metrics.response:
There were trumpets once—brass suns blaring over
second-line laughter—but tonight the parade is slow jazz,
all muted horns and trombones humming like bees
trapped in a glass bottle.  Night funeral, baby,
and the Mississippi holds its breath.  Ribbons of shadow
unwrap the humid city, lay it naked at our feet.

We strut because grief needs choreography.  White-gloved
hands flip pocket squares of moonlight, umbrellas spin
shards of starlight, sequins tremble on shaking hips.
Yet between each high-step you can hear the hush,
the gulf between drumbeats where the gone ones drift.

Call it voodoo, call it gospel, call it bar-room prayer:
we pour bourbon on cracked flagstones, feed the thirst
of ghosts who still crave Saturday nights.
Trombones slide open a door in the air; the departed
slip through, wearing brand-new shoes that never pinch.

When the last note swells, we lean into the horn’s wail
as if it were a wind strong enough to carry us
across the river, past the abandoned warehouses,
into mornings where the sun will taste
like cornbread again, and nobody will be missing.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral beneath the glacier stars:
we gathered on the inland ice where no birds dare circle.
The aurora draped its green silk over coffins of pine,
turning wood to ghostly jade.  Frost-smoke rose from mouths,
our breath colliding with starlight like two reluctant lovers.

The dead man had been a cartographer of vanished seas.
He mapped tides swallowed by centuries of snow, stitched
omega-shaped coastlines onto parchment no one else could read.
In ritual return, we lowered his atlas-hands into white eternity,
let crystals script their own uncharted constellations on his skin.

Drums?  Only the cracking echo of distant icebergs.
Hymns?  The troubled hush of polar wind.
We poured lamp oil into a shallow bowl, set it aflame:
a miniature sun roaring defiance at a cosmic night.
For a moment our shadows danced like mast-flags
of ships that might yet sail imaginary oceans.

When the flame sank, we sealed the grave with blocks
of packed snow.  The aurora dimmed, as if closing a curtain.
We trudged homeward, each step erasing itself immediately.
By dawn the ice lay flawless, hiding its story,
holding his secret shorelines in silent, frozen trust.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral in the neon necropolis.  Hover-hearse glides
beneath holographic willow trees whose leaves weep data.
Streets are coded grief; rain falls in binary hymns,
ones and zeroes sparking off chrome umbrellas.
A choir of synthetic robins threads their algorithmic song
through ventilation ducts and satellite veins.

The deceased was a legend in the undernet, a weaver
of black-market dreams.  Now her avatar dissolves
pixel by pixel on public billboards, while real-world
mourners shuffle in glow-in-the-dark suits.
Each lapel sports a QR code that, when scanned,
plays her last confession in augmented reality.

At the graveyard—an abandoned server farm—
we slot her coffin between towers of rusted drives.
Coolant leaks form turquoise pools reflecting
our glitching faces.  A priest with cybernetic eyes
uploads a benediction: DATA COMMITS TO SILENCE.

The lid closes; actuators hiss.  Backup sparks
fizzle overhead like dying meteors.  Someone
releases nano-moths encoded with her final poem;
they scatter into urban canyons, flashing lines of verse
on billboards, subway walls, the insides of eyelids.

By dawn the city will reboot, memory caches flushed,
but for one more loop of night, her code haunts the grid
like a soft, unpatched vulnerability.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral on the cliff where sea and sky negotiate.
We light lanterns of salt-stained paper, let them bob
like embryonic moons above the surf.  The tide
keeps the beat, curling its wet fist, opening again.

The deceased loved tides, said they were the lungs
of the planet.  So we sing a coastal lullaby learned
from gulls, syllables chipped from quartz and foam.
Wind braids the melody into ropes and lassoes waves.

We carry the coffin—hand-carved driftwood,
smelling of kelp and distant storms—to the edge.
Below, bioluminescent plankton glimmer turquoise,
turning the water into a galaxy flipped upside-down.
When we push, the coffin rides a luminous surge,
a comet skimming its chosen cosmos.

Ashes will mingle with plankton, plankton with fish,
fish with whales, whales with myth, until one night
someone drops a stone here and feels it pulse
with secrets of bones and barnacles.

Lanterns dim.  We do not leave but listen, hoping
the sea will cough up a sign.  Instead it swallows
our reflections, scribbles them into its restless diary.
We depart finally, pockets heavy with smooth pebbles—
small, solid embalmed minutes, proof that we once stood
between darkness, water, and the long bright forgetting.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral—
The avenue hums with a hush of engines idling,
Streetlights shiver like candles too nervous to admit grief.
We carry the lacquered box through pools of borrowed gold,
Our footsteps speaking the soft dialect of resignation.
Around us, windows close their eyelids, curtains kneel to pray,
Dogs stop barking, amazed by the gravity in the air.
The sky unbuttons a coat of velvet, revealing silver ribs,
Stars serve as pallbearers too, pinning heaven to reverence.
Somewhere a saxophone weeps behind a cracked apartment door,
Its smoke-blue notes curling into the procession like ribbons.
We set the box upon earth’s cool palm, let silence settle,
Spades bite soil, each clink a struck match of memory;
Fireflies orbit the grave, tiny priests swinging thuribles of light.
When it is done, we do not say amen—
We merely listen to the night reseal its envelope,
Crickets sign the ledger, wind embosses the seal.
Departing, we leave footsteps as faint as chalk on rain,
Believing tomorrow’s dawn will read our absence
And understand the shape of what was placed beneath.
Night funeral ends the way a candle ends:
By teaching darkness the taste of wax and song.

instance_metrics.response:
They gathered at the shoreline for the night funeral.
No cathedral could hold that many tides of sorrow,
so the sea agreed to open its pews of shifting foam.
Torches hissed in the wind like serpents promised resurrection,
casting molten amber over faces grown pale with brine.
The coffin was a small boat carved from storm-felled cedar,
lashed with ropes of kelp, adorned with gull feathers and coins.
Inside lay a fisherman who had taught children to read constellations
by threading stories through nets, by naming each sparkle a companion.
When the boat was pushed, the moon bowed low,
donating a silver obol for safe passage.
Slow waves carried the vessel outward, outward,
until torchlight became memory and memory became myth.
Behind us, fiddles whispered salt-sweet dirges,
their music braided with the hush of oars lifted in salute.
The youngest child released a jar of captured dawn moths;
they scattered amber wings upon the dark, stitching temporary galaxies.
Soon horizon and coffin were indistinguishable—
just a seam uniting two fabrics of ink.
We turned home, pockets heavy with unspoken gratitude,
aware that the sea keeps everything it buries,
but also lends us a rhythm to bear the emptiness.
Night funeral ended, the tide returned bearing quiet.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral, the town clock forgot to chime.
Midnight froze, suspended, thick as chapel grime.
Candles lined the cobbles, trembling yellow spines,
Their molten prayers slipping through the cracks of time.
We marched in measured silence, hearts like muffled drums,
Winter breath escaping lips in ghostly plumes.
A violin, lone mourner, urged the shadows dance,
Each bowstroke stitching sorrow into sacred trance.
Ravens perched on gables, clergy dressed in black,
Croaking psalms that soared, then circled back.
At graveyard gate the iron creaked—a sigh,
Acceptance whispered by the hinge of sky.
We lowered down the coffin, marigold and pine;
Earth received the offering, cold yet kind.
Ashen snowflakes spiraled, blessing brow and bier,
Tiny parchment petals signing, We are here.
When ritual concluded, we released a dove,
Its wings a page turned in the book of love.
It vanished where the constellations keep their fire,
Leaving us the embers of hushed desire
To live more brightly, fiercely, before we too are called
To midnight’s congregation, where no footstep is stalled.
Behind the crypt, an ivy tendril shook like grief’s small hand,
Seeking any wall to climb, to understand.

instance_metrics.response:
Night funeral:
I arrive late, wearing the smell of city neon and cheap coffee.
The cemetery gate is open like a parent who cannot sleep
until every child has come home.
Within, people move in slow loops, moths orbiting a single bare bulb of purpose.
There is no casket tonight—only a cedar bench
on which we lay our phones, our calendars, our unfinished arguments.
The deceased is called Yesterday, and everyone has brought some small relic:
a movie ticket, a wilted apology, a button from a coat that no longer fits.
A stranger reads the eulogy—throat a lantern of uncertain light—
naming every hour we wasted as though it were a cherished relative.
When she finishes, the ground does not open; instead the sky closes,
clouds sliding shut like the lid of a music box.
Stars mute their glitter in respect.
One by one we retrieve our objects, drop them into a rusted wheelbarrow,
and wheel it to the river that forgets.
The plunk of relinquished weight is the only hymn.
Homeward, pockets emptied, we feel oddly taller,
walking through streets that smell of first rain.
Night funeral teaches that burial is sometimes just permission to begin.

Night funeral

I. Liturgy of Shadows
Beneath cathedral oak, our voices fold into origami hush.
The priestess lights charcoal in an iron bowl; smoke lifts, finds the moon,
painting her eyelids soot.
Cicadas silence their metronome. Somewhere an ambulance siren pauses, kneels.

II. Procession
We carry the urn of shattered clocks. Each step rewinds:
sidewalk becomes dirt trail, trail becomes riverbank.
Fireflies accompany, their lanterns rhythmic punctuation.
In the water, koi hover like orange commas, preparing to complete the sentence of night.

III. Committal
At the edge we tip the urn. Broken gears and glass teeth fall,
tinkling like distant sleigh bells. The river swallows them,
tucks them beneath ripples stitched by wind. A heron nods, official and aloof.

IV. Benediction
We trace circles on our foreheads with ink brewed from blackberries:
promise to measure hours henceforth not by clocks but by laughter,
by how fast bread disappears, by how long a hug lingers.

Coda
Walking back, dawn ambushes us with rose-metal light.
We are unarmed, but surrender happily.
Night funeral ends; day baptism begins.

Weather Forecast in Kabul:
In the newsroom, a cracked map hangs crooked,

We spin the paper compass like a prayer wheel,

Outside, coal smoke climbs the apartment blocks,
black commas editing the horizon.
Grandmother says clouds are the footfalls of caravans,
storm and story moving together.
She tastes the air, declares snow
because it smells of copper and childhood.
The teleprompter offers numbers—high: thirteen, low: minus two—
but fails to mention the surge of kites,
the probability of laughter after school,
the barometric pressure of weddings postponed.
At sunset, the forecast shifts:
a saffron light spills from Darul Aman,
painting every broken pane with impermanent gold.
Anemometers rattle like old typewriters,
typing a novella only sparrows can read.
Tonight, expect intermittent silence between artillery memories,
patches of clear conscience,
chance of poetry falling before dawn.
Wrap your intentions in wool.
Set a cup on the windowsill
to catch whatever arrives—rain, ash, or the first petal of spring.
Tomorrow’s outlook remains unstable,
but somewhere above the radio static
a single star remains stubbornly accurate.

Weather Forecast in Kabul – a Ghazal

From dawn’s first fragile saffron, a stuttering radio calls, “Kabul,”
and mountains answer, draped in pewter shawls around Kabul.

The forecaster speaks of pressure, of isobars knitting fear;
we hear instead the sigh of mothers kneading bread in Kabul.

“Chance of rain,” he says—yet every drop remembers shrapnel,
taps the corrugated roofs like ghosts who refuse to leave Kabul.

In the old book market, pages flutter—paper sparrows—
searching for lost alphabets the monsoon once smuggled to Kabul.

Children chalk new borders on alleys, wager marbles on sunlight;
the sky rolls its turquoise dice, uncertain what to gift Kabul.

Evening condenses into attar of pomegranate and diesel;
prayer disperses, cool mist drifting on the ridge above Kabul.

Should hail arrive tonight, let it strike the drums of courtyard tins,
composing another anthem no empire could steal from Kabul.

O poet, tuck this forecast under your pillow: tomorrow,
hope will rise to a blue unreported, but only for Kabul.

Grandmothers will clap rugs against balconies, loosing a second storm of decade-old sand, and the city will cough, then laugh, then cough again. riverbed stones—

evening prayer—

unlit lanterns

Weather Forecast in Kabul – Dialogue of the Four Sisters

Spring enters first, shaking rain from her braids. "I will stitch almond blossoms along every lane," she announces, tasting the soil for thaw. Kabul nods, aching from winter’s splints, inhaling the musk of wet clay.

Summer lounges on a sun-bleached parapet, arm-wrestling the wind. She promises blistering afternoons, mango pulp dripping between market stalls, throb of generator songs. Her laughter is dry thunder.

Autumn arrives in saffron socks, scattering pomegranate seeds like punctuation. She speaks softly of departures: the swallows, the diplomats, the pink balloons let go at Eid. Her breath is a warning that smells of smoke and poetry.

Then Winter pushes through the cracked door wearing a coat sewn from starlight and shrapnel. She brings silence as vast as the Pamirs, folds it over rooftops until only minarets and unspoken prayers remain. Children draw their dreams on fogged windows; the city shivers but remembers how to endure.

And so the forecast, dear listener: expect all four sisters, sometimes on the same day. Carry both umbrella and charcoal brazier. Keep a spare smile in your pocket for sudden flurries of joy. Kabul’s sky is a crowded house; weather is only one of its voices.

It unfurls across rooftops where kites tremble like small, defiant prayers. A boy balances on a balcony, palms lifted, measuring the sky as if he could weigh its color. Mothers braid shawls of sunshine around their children, sending them into streets still wet with last night's memory of rain. In the market, vendors predict their own climate: saffron drifting like dust, pomegranates thudding thunder onto burlap, mint uprising in green gusts. Noon will gather heat in copper bowls, then pour it over the hills. Evening may loosen a shy drizzle, something that sounds like forgiveness on corrugated tin. But the forecast never mentions the secret weather within each chest: those sudden squalls of longing, the unexpected clearings of laughter, the steady barometer of hope. The voice fades. "Partly cloudy," the bulletin will say, though he knows clouds are never partial; they are whole caravans of vapor, dragging shadows like tents across the desert of the sky. He notes a temperature: fifteen at dawn, rising to twenty-four. Fahrenheit means nothing here; we measure warmth by how fast tea cools in a glass. Probability of rain: ten percent. Ten percent is the fraction of mothers who will dare to hang laundry, of taxi drivers who will gamble on open windows, of children who will leave paper boats folded, ready. By afternoon, dust will rise, performing slow whirls that resemble dervishes dancing without drums. Night will arrive uncluttered, each star a pin securing darkness to the heavens. The forecast ends, but his pen lingers, drawing a small sun in the margin, because tomorrow, against every statistic, he believes in brightness.

Now the meteorologist, modern oracle, consults machines instead of muses. "Weather Forecast in Kabul," he declares, tapping the glass altar. His charts prophesy high pressure, drought's stern cousin. Yet the hills remember snow, and in their cool veins dream of glaciers sliding like silver beads. In the bazaar, fortune-tellers revise their cards: Sun dominates Wands; Cups stay dry. A girl sells roses dyed blue, counterfeit water. Noon burns incense of diesel and cumin. The city exhales, parched. By late afternoon, thunder assembles on distant battlements. Children raise tin helmets—pots, pans, hubcaps—summoning armies of drops. A single cloud advances, bruised and noble. The forecaster, off duty, stands atop the ministry roof, tie loosened. He stretches both arms, wondering if he could nudge the pattern south. Lightning answers with the slash of a poet editing heaven. At dusk, rain arrives, unmeasured, unpredicted—an unruly stanza breaking meter, singing Kabul back to sleep.

Tonight’s program is sponsored by blankets, because trust me, you’ll need one. First, a recap: the morning woke up grumpy, throwing pebbles of sleet at commuters. Apologies to Mustafa, whose motorcycle now rattles like maracas. By ten, the sun barged in uninvited, polishing minarets till they winked like gossiping aunties. Lunch hour saw a dust devil crash a kebab stand, seasoning skewers with free sand—a "localized spice," according to experts. Looking ahead: expect temperatures to dip lower than a politician’s promise—around seven degrees—so hug your samovar tight. Clouds will loiter, undecided, like chess players in the park, but most will drift east before curfew. Probability of romance: thirty percent if you’re carrying an umbrella someone else forgot. Mountains may flaunt fresh snow, perfect backdrop for melancholic selfies. Sunrise tomorrow scheduled for 6:11, give or take the city’s electricity mood swings. Remember: weather, like poetry and pigeons, belongs to no one but visits us all. Keep your sky open, Kabul; we’ll be back after the music with traffic updates and, hopefully, a better joke.

instance_metrics.response:
Weather Forecast in Kabul

Good evening, says the radio, voice snow-muffled and almost shy;
tonight a soft front will drift in from the Hindu Kush,
draping alleyways with shawls the color of spooned ash.
Expect a dawn of powder—yes, real snow, not plaster dust—
and silence thick enough to taste.  Street cats will leave hieroglyphic
prints beside the tire tracks of armored cars; vendors
will tamp braziers under tarps that smell of opium sap and tea.
By noon the mountains will button their white jackets, and a single
mig bird will write cursive across the blank page of sky.

Toward afternoon the clouds will reseal like classified folders;
a rare beam of sun may leak, glinting off broken minaret tiles,
so wrap your wishes in foil and hold them high.
The forecast warns of wind at dusk, capable of scattering
loose prayers from the roofs of unfinished houses, so tie
each Allahu Akbar to the laundry line if you can.
Overnight the mercury will fall to the level of unanswered letters,
leaving frost on the checkpoint booth and the soldier’s eyelash.
Carry your warmest memory under your coat: it is advised,
though not officially, against the risk of a sudden sorrow squall.

instance_metrics.response:
Weather Forecast in Kabul

Mother folds the evening newspaper, rimmed with pomegranate juice.
She reads me tomorrow’s sky like fortune from a coffee cup:
“Cloudy at first light, my daughter, but no storm the city
hasn’t worn before.”  Her fingers trace the isobars—thin wires
holding Kabul together—and she hums the forecast
as if it were a lullaby.  She tells me the sun may peek
between checkpoints around ten.  That’s when I should plant
my notebook seeds: verbs in the courtyard, adjectives
along the crumbled garden wall.  Rain might visit by three,
polite taps on our metal door, rinsing the dust off verbs
we forgot to water.  Wind will rise at evening prayer,
shaking the satellite dishes until they cough up foreign music.
If thunder comes, she says, it’s only the mountains turning pages
in their stone diary.  Overnight the cold will sharpen knives
in alley corners; wrap your dreams in wool before sleeping.

I nod, tasting the pomegranate on her lips, believing
weather is the only war we are allowed to surrender to,
a war that sometimes hands back stolen blue and says:
keep it, child, tomorrow looks clear from here.

Weather Forecast in Kabul (Villanelle)

Across the rooftops speakers crackle, thin and frail:
Tomorrow brings a rain no shell can drown.
Keep close your scarves, your hopes, your paper sail.

Muezzin notes ride winds from Darulaman’s vale,
but cumulus battalions answer, steel and brown.
Across the rooftops speakers crackle, thin and frail.

Mothers inventory bread, potatoes grown pale;
children chalk new borders on the ground.
Keep close your scarves, your hopes, your paper sail.

A clearing by noon, the forecaster may entail,
yet dust ghosts shimmy when trucks pound town.
Across the rooftops speakers crackle, thin and frail.

The map shows sun, then shadow, then a veil
of sleet that beads on rifles set face-down.
Keep close your scarves, your hopes, your paper sail.

Night will freeze the tracks of every trail,
lock whispers underneath the shutter’s crown.
Across the rooftops speakers crackle, thin and frail:
keep close your scarves, your hopes, your paper sail.

Weather Forecast in Kabul, told by the Kabul River

I, the river, roll out tomorrow like silk from a merchant’s chest.
Listen: dawn will cast rose threads across the Pul-e-Khesti bridge,
stitched with birds that borrow their vowels from my ripples.
First light: a hush fog, sweet with diesel and dawn bread,
willsettle on my shoulders; fishermen will yank it aside like a curtain.
By midmorning the sky will practice mirrors—sun shards skipping
from my surface onto the cracked palace windows, rehearsing
how forgiveness might look in glass.  Avoid the banks after noon;
wind from the Shomali Plain will flip my pages furiously, splashing
syllables onto passing boots.  Late afternoon brings cloud caravans
stacked like cotton bales; they’ll bargain shade for prayers,
leaving me cool enough to remember glaciers I once kissed.
Evening?  Expect swallows to write cursive farewells above my spine
while the muezzin threads his voice through their loops.
Night will pour stars into my basin—small diamonds children
cannot pawn—dropping the temperature of regret.  Carry lanterns
of jasmine on your balconies.  Their scent will travel with my current,
forecasting a chance of dreams wherever I decide to wander.
