instance_metrics.response:
Loss can be good for us,
said the apricot tree as dawn shifted across its bark.
In the night, frost bruised the orchard,
peeled the paper petals back to silence,
and every uncertain blossom
slid to the ground like discarded letters.
I wanted to gather them up,
re-stitch their pale wings,
undo the raw arithmetic of subtraction.
But the tree kept speaking: Look.
Under the sorrow, work begins.
Those fallen petals will melt into loam,
loam into mineral music,
roots will drink that music,
and what survives will swell with the knowledge
of what could not endure.
Come August, you will taste it:
bitterness remembered as depth,
sweetness darkened by the echo of snow.
Your tongue will say summer,
but your heart will recall winter
and understand they share a single seed.
Loss can be good for us,
not because pain is holy,
not because absence is a virtue,
but because emptied rooms
gain windows, and windows invite sky.
Because the hollow of the flute
is where the song waits.
Because what is taken
teaches the hand to open,
and an open hand is already
halfway to a harvest.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response:
Loss can be good for us,
writes the barefoot traveler in the margin of her map.
She has left behind
three cities, two lovers, and a bicycle painted like rain.
Every border stamped in her passport
is an erasure as well as a signature:
a room she will never return to,
a favorite cup surrendered to somebody else’s shelf.
At first the leaving felt like unraveling,
threads snagged on doorknobs,
a sweater caught on a nail of memory.
Then came the miracle of lightness.
With every relinquished object,
her spine straightened, her shadow thinned,
she could fit inside smaller days
and still find them spacious.
She learned that pockets
do not mourn the coins they spend;
that rivers, to keep moving,
must abandon every drop they carry.
Now, standing on a hill
whose name she cannot pronounce,
she watches the sun lodge itself
in the brass bowl of evening.
She owns nothing but breath,
and breath keeps renewing itself
at no cost.
She touches her ribs,
counts them like a musician counts beats,
understands that even her bones
are on loan from the stars.
Loss can be good for us,
she writes again, and closes the map,
for the horizon is already opening.

instance_metrics.response:
Loss can be good for us; the sculptor knows
whose marble block conceals a trembling dove.
Blade after blade, the surplus stone must go
before the prisoner feathers learn to move.
Each chip, a sorrow; yet the air grows wide,
and what was weight becomes unburdened grace.
Likewise the moon, admitting night inside,
shines by the portions stolen from her face.
We measure love by gathering, but fire
counts worth in ash released to silver wind.
A seed decays to draft its green empire;
blood must be spent for skin to heal and mend.
So when the quiet thieves arrive again,
I’ll set a chair, pour water, call them friend.

But if you need a plainer sermon still,
go to the shore where breakers rip the sand.
Listen: the shells are murmuring their will—
not to cling, but crumble back into the land.
One day their dust will toughen cliff and quay;
one day that cliff will shelter ships at sea.
Thus, from the smallest forfeiture of form,
grand harbors grow, and terrified hearts transform.
Loss can be good for us, the line repeats,
like tide returning to refurbish streets,
and when the salt recedes, the pavement gleams,
as though the flood were architect of dreams.

Loss can be good for us, the elders say,
voice trembling like wind through unlatched shutters at dusk.
A garden thins to breed a brighter day,
seedbeds cleared of spent vines, discolored husk.

We prune the rose until its thorns betray
our startled skin, exchanging crimson for bloom.
Still, loss can be good for us, the elders say,
as soap is fashioned from rendered fat and fume.

The river hums, shrugging the banks away,
carving young alphabets in the stunned maize rows.
A garden thins to breed a brighter day,
and silted stories nourish the delta’s rose.

A candle mortgages body to its own flame,
writing brief sermons of light on the walls of night.
Loss can be good for us, the elders claim,
for wax will cool into pillars prepared for new fire’s flight.

So when goodbye bells fade beyond the icy porch,
remember how stars erase themselves to draw the dawn.
A garden thins to breed a brighter day,
and loss can be good for us—breathe in, move on.

Loss can be good for us,
writes the glacier in meltwater cursive along the fjord.
Though my blue heart thins, it tells, I am not simply dying.
I am tutoring rivers, shipping minerals, feeding plankton festivals
where whale calves fatten on light.
The mountains lighten their shoulders, free of my heavy shawl;
lichen rushes onto the newly exposed auditorium of stone,
practicing green speeches never heard in ten thousand years.
Yes, villages downstream will relearn the language of flooding,
but they will also harvest silt delicate as flour,
plant rice in the valleys I carve.
Understand: permanence was never my job.
I came to be the traveling bank of tomorrow’s water,
to remind granite that even arrogance can liquefy.
Do not mourn the statues I made of myself.
Already my ghost becomes cloud, becomes snow
that will visit your porch in some late January,
a courteous knock, a hush on the railing.
Place your palm there; feel me arriving.
Loss can be good for us
if we allow its cold palm to guide the hinge,
opening the door where future voices wait,
ringing bright, uncertain, unstoppable
like morning light sprinting across thawed ice.

The words arrive like brittle reeds rattling in a dry riverbed, a language of vacancy and echo. Yet I listen. I remember rooms once overfilled with chairs that squeaked and laughter that scalded the air; when those chairs were hauled away, what remained was light, trembling, unclaimed, settling in corners like new paint. It taught the floorboards to breathe, the silence to rhyme. Now the hawk circles, thinning the flock of small complacent hearts inside my chest. What is taken creates a contour: a bowl scooped from wood, the hollow of a cave where fire is coaxed, the negative space in sculptor’s clay into which the future can lay its warm, wet hands. Evening comes, not as curtain, but as clearing: one by one the details go, and the horizon, unencumbered, walks closer. I stand amid the subtracting world, lighter, leaner, a flute carved by removal, practiced at releasing sound. Loss, sharp-beaked teacher, feathered with cold intention, shows me the secret arithmetic: minus, minus, minus, and suddenly, miracle—room enough for wind to sing.

I feared the long hunger of branches starving for bloom, but the farmer only smiled, sliding his hands along the wounded bark as though reading braille. He whispered of pruning, how the blade knows mercy the tree cannot imagine, how sap re-dreams its routes when corridors collapse. All winter we watched silence accumulate like white ash. Then April cracked open. From the amputated joints burst fists of green furious with sweetness, flowers shouting in raucous pinks nobody remembered. Bees rose in golden litigation, arguing pollen into honey. I tasted it, and understood: sorrow is a stalk cut at the knee so it can bend toward deeper water; grief is the seed’s brief funeral inside soil before it tunnels toward sun. Standing among blossoms delirious with rebirth, I thanked the frost that mailed its brief death notice. Loss, in its raw arithmetic, subtracted what was overgrown, made room for sugar, for song, for a harvest strong enough to survive next winter’s sharpened mouth.

"Loss can be good for us," the elders say,
Though night throws dice of salt across our skin;
We pace the floorboards of a stripped-out day,
Counting the slivers where the light broke in.
What stars subtract, dawn promises to pay,
Bartering gold for every vanished twin.

The garden proves it, season after season:
Deadheads plucked so roses can begin.
Roots devour their own fallen for a reason;
Absence is the nutrient hidden within.
"Loss can be good for us," the elders say,
While packing trunks of letters never sent.
They fold the silence neatly, put away
Perfumes whose ghosts still cling to every vent.

Remember ships that jettison their weight
To outpace storms frothing with iron grin;
The cargo sacrificed becomes the gate
Through which the vessel sails to harbor’s din.
So sculpt your hollows; let the room be bare;
Invite the echo, pour the emptiness in.
What stars subtract, dawn teaches to repair,
Polishing void until the edges thin.
"Loss can be good for us," the elders say—
A bitter tea that sweetens discipline.

I read the cosmic obituary and feel the tug of my own vanished parts: friendships that drifted beyond event horizons, childhood streets demolished for parking lots, the voice of my grandmother spiraling into silent dwarfhood. Black holes, scientists suspect, whisper equations of rebirth at their singular cores; every swallowed galaxy may seed another dimension. That night I cleared my apartment closet: jeans that never fit, postcards never mailed, the guitar with one stubborn broken string. I sat inside the negative space, breathing dust and freedom, realizing that love itself is an architecture of relinquishing: you open your palms, allow what needs to leave its clean escape route, and discover your hands become wings. Loss can be good for us, I whispered, this time meaning the plural.

Loss can be good for us, the elder oak
whispers each November as its copper leaves
shake loose from twig and tendon, pirouette
downward into the dark arithmetic of loam.
He stands barer, yes, ribs showing, wind
pressing like a question against his bark,
but the sap sinks deeper, unhurried, clear,
storing small suns for a later hour.
We measure value by what stays lit,
by what endures—yet a sky needs room
to practice silence, and roots need space
to listen to stones. I walk beneath him,
coat pockets full of errands and undone days,
and feel the cool architecture of absence
settle on my shoulders like a shawl.
The forest is a ledger kept in shadows:
loss debits the branches, credits the soil.
Moss reads the balance aloud, patient,
and somewhere under my ribcage an echo
agrees to surrender a name, a habit,
a dull coin of certainty. When spring
arrives, the oak will not remember
the precise contour of each fallen leaf.
He will only remember to open his palms
and let the green inventions pour through.

“Loss can be good for us,” my grandmother said
while shucking peas at the porch rail,
thumbs moving like small metronomes of surrender.
She told me the first time she burned bread
she tasted the wild heart of flour—
its smoky memory, its hush of grain.
When the well ran dry one reckless July,
she learned to carve prayers from dust,
collect dew with tin dishpans at dawn.
I was young and greedy for permanence,
hoarding fireflies in mason jars,
writing my name on damp concrete to last forever.
But she kept teaching subtraction:
let the fire breathe, let the dog run,
let the night swallow what it must.
Years later, after her chair stood empty,
I found her recipe book: margins
filled with crossings-out, revisions,
whole pages torn clean, corners singed.
I cooked one meal exactly as written:
the absences tasted like thunder and mint,
like a door left open on purpose.
Now I peel away the rind of every hour,
looking for the sweet sting underneath.
In every goodbye I hear her ladling stars
into a pot of water, whispering:
Child, hunger is the fastest road to wonder.

Loss can be good for us—so sings the rhyme
That winds through alleys of remembered time;
A silver thread that stitches heart to heart,
Unraveling so something new can start.
The rose, decapitated by the frost,
Prepares the soil with every petal lost;
Its rooted silence, buried under snow,
Will rise in June to orchestrate a glow.
The sailor, casting letters to the sea,
Finds ballast in the waves’ philosophy:
A weight released gives keels a truer line,
And storms, once danced through, make horizon shine.
The painter, scraping canvas to the bone,
Uncovers pigments warmer than his own;
Erasure lets the unborn colors speak,
And bolder visions germinate from bleak.
The lover, parting lips to say goodbye,
Inhales a longitude of wider sky;
Her emptied lungs become a nest for song
That swallows learn and carry far along.
So rhyme with me within this echoing shell:
Goodbye is seed, and seed is citadel.
What falls away reveals, like sculptor’s dust,
A hidden shape: loss can be good for us.

how broken patterns birth emergent art,
how pruning nodes makes pathways lean

photos compressed to spectral squares,

With nothing to buffer echo, I hear

Loss can be good for us,
whispered the wind as it tugged leaves
from the maple’s patient fingers.
I watched the branches learn to breathe
without their summer jewelry,
watched sky leak through new gaps
and turn the old silhouette strange.
Every fall I practice this shedding:
ticket stubs, voicemails, the borrowed coat
whose pockets kept the scent of rain.
I fold them into paper swans,
set them afloat down gutters,
let them disappear under street-corner grates.
Afterward my hands feel wider,
as though horizon grew between my knuckles.
Sparrows notice; they land inside the space
and stitch dawn songs under my nails.
Grief is no villain here—
it is a locksmith,
filing the stubborn edges of the key
until the locked gate clicks open.
Beyond, a field I have never named
waits with its untrampled snow.
I step, lighter by a history,
heavier with possibility,
and each footprint seeds a question:
who am I now that I am not
what I kept?
The silence answers by flowering,
white petals blown from nowhere,
all of them falling, all of them free.

Loss can be good for us, the old captain croaked
as our ship limped home on half a mast.
The storm had eaten our finest canvas,
gulped crates of sugar meant for distant mouths,
and carved the hull with claws of salt.
We curled around bruised lanterns, muttering curses,
but the captain brewed coffee out of seaweed
and pointed to the wounded horizon.
“Look,” he said, “how the ocean forgets
to remember its own violence.”
At dawn we saw the deck as emptiness,
yet also as possibility: room to dance,
room to teach the greenest cabin boy
how to spin a rope into a story.
With the cargo gone, the ship rode higher,
skimming waves like a gull newly hatched.
We sliced days off the return,
and laughter once buried under barrels
rose like bubbles from a diver’s mouth.
In port, the merchants scowled at our emptiness;
we bowed, pockets clinking only with seashells.
But the captain tossed those shells to children,
and their surprise rang richer than coins.
Tonight, in taverns where we are nobodies,
our mugs glow amber with space for song,
and the wind outside rehearses again:
Loss can be good for us—listen.

Loss can be good for us; so sings the night,
closing the shutters on extravagant light.
When curtains fall, the stage unclutters fast;
the actors unmask, free of costume and past.
We sit in the dark with our emptied seat,
feel the pulse of the wood beneath our feet,
and hear in the hush a finer refrain
than cymbals of triumph or trumpets of gain.
For winning is heavy, a crown forged of claims;
its jewels are debts, its gold etched with names.
But losing removes the silk and the rust,
shakes every pocket and sifts every crust,
till, bare as a seed eager only for ground,
we thrill to the thunder of unmeasured sound.
Morning will open with ordinary grace,
a mirror unclouded, a slower pace,
and we, made lighter by what we misplaced,
will travel like music through unprinted space.
Let broken strings echo, let empty cups gleam;

Layer upon layer of linen sighs,
but underneath—
wingbeats.
   
Stalky is the restless star in this small universe,
flaring ideas across moth-eaten ceilings.
Beetle composes verses on matchbox lids,
while M’Turk maps the enemy’s pride
with compasses stolen from the maths room.
The trinity plots beneath moon-stained rafters,
a covenant of irreverence.
   
Think of citrus light at first bell:
how it slices corridors, lays bare
unpolished shoes, ink-blotted fingers,
chins nicked by hurried razors.
Masters march in academic gowns—
raven-winged, sure of their dominion.
Yet mischief, soft-footed as smoke,
threads through buttonholes and sash windows.
One knock, and order topples like dice.
   
This poem pauses there—on the lip of uproar,
where breath fogs the pane and fate taps glass.
We stand with it, notebooks open,
smelling the gunpowder promise of chalk dust,
watching boys become hurricanes
in uniforms too small.
Prelude is all we can ever hold:
that instant before the story detonates
and we, grinning, run with the blast.

Over the downs the morning creeps,
thin as parchment, salt with sea-spray.

and somewhere a curtained dormer inflates
with the soft snore of an unrepentant dreamer.

like a marble seeking mischief.

sketching continents on blotting paper,
unafraid of dragons.

to the fuse.
Imagined smoke is sweeter than the fire,
filling lungs with illicit possibility.
The school is an unwound clock;
gears strain for release.
   
IV.
Listen—the chapel organ tests a single note,
a dove’s heart hitting glass.
Across the quad the Head’s footsteps
plant tulips of authority no boy will water.

are bent into slingstones.
   
V.
Just before the gong—a collective inhale.
Buttons fastened by trembling thumbs,

History balances on a ruler’s edge.
   
VI.
Then, with irreverent grace,
the day explodes into legend,
and the poem, suddenly shy,
closes its book, content to have witnessed
the heartbeat before the charge.

Stalky whistles low to the sunrise,
a fox in a waistcoat, paws in polished leather,
as the school stirs from its brick-red burrow.
This is prologue: one slow curl of smoke
before the bonfire roars.
   
Chapel bells rehearse their reprimands—
too early to condemn, too late to stop
what’s brewing in the dormitory cauldron.
Beetle’s spectacles glint like conspiracy;
he’s memorised the masters’ timetable
and scrawled escape routes between Greek verbs.
M’Turk gathers insults as ammunition:

a lexicon sharp enough to skin pride.
   
Across the parade ground the crows confer,
tilted heads translating adolescent thunder.
They know a storm when they smell one—
sulphur mixed with pocketed gunpowder,
harmless until the flint of boredom strikes.
   
There is glory in that edge-time,
when rules hover uneaten on the plate
and every corridor is a fuse.
Chalk dust rises like prophetic snow;
columns of sunlight pin the dust motes,
miniature prisoners that will not learn.
   
Prelude means we linger here,
fingers resting on the piano’s ivory
just before the chord that shatters glass.
Hold the moment, taste its copper spark,
then let it fly—

Under the hawthorn’s ragged shadow
the school dreams of empire—brick battlements
hugging the cliff, flag cracking smart
against Atlantic wind.
Inside, silence shells the dormitory; diligent
moonlight inspects each unruly curl, each freckle.
   
Prelude to "Stalky & Co."—a curtain of breath
hanging over misrule. The boys lie arrow-straight
only in sleep; consciousness will unstring them
into catapults.
   
Stalky’s dream is a blueprint of escape:
rope ladder woven from bed-sheets,
larders raided for tinned sardines,
a fishing smack waiting by the quay.
Beetle’s dream is footnotes and thunder—
he argues with Horace about satire,
wins, pockets the applause.
M’Turk’s dream is a rebel yell in Gaelic,
he plants it like a flag atop the chapel spire.
   
The masters slumber too, though fitfully.
They sense the tectonic coil of adolescence,
how innocence hardens into cunning.
   
Dawn: match-head pink, sulphur sweet.
One bird coughs a note, another answers.
This is the first crack in porcelain calm.
Soon the dormitory will disgorge its legion,
Latin books masquerading as shields,
edicts torn to confetti.
The empire mutters in its sleep, unaware
its colonies have already slipped the leash.
   
Prelude ends when the first shoe thuds to floorboards—
a starting gun disguised as daily routine.

They titled it "Prelude to \"Stalky & Co.\"",
but truly it’s a recipe, fat with buttered-toast crumbs,
folded in the back of the Head’s notebook.
Step one: acquire three conspirators, preferably
loud as crows at dawn yet capable of saintly eyes.
Step two: steal the matron’s key to the larder;
remember to leave a feather in exchange—
ritual demands symbolism.
Step three: learn the timetable by heart,
for prelude is timing; genius is an alibi.
Step four: mix equal parts Latin detestation,
midnight hunger, and the chilly tang of salt air
that rolls over the rugby pitch.
Season with rumours of India, Zululand, anywhere
the map blushes imperial pink.
Bake thirty minutes under the rafters,
until laughter bubbles up through the shingles
and the distant staffroom grows suspicious.
Cool on a windowsill while discussing
Schweinfurth’s latest expedition, or the curvature
of a prefect’s nose.
Serve with exaggerated innocence; garnish
with lines from Horace quoted perfectly wrong.
Warning: consumption may lead to expulsion,
hero-worship, naval commissions, or worse,
publication by a certain Mr. Kipling.
Thus the prelude ends; the feast begins,
and the taste of rebellion lingers
like marmalade beneath the tongue.

“Prelude to \"Stalky & Co.\"”—the phrase hangs
like a lantern above a misted station,
lighting only the rails that lead backward.
I imagine Stalky, grown now, moustached,
gloved against London rain, waiting for the 5:12
back to memory.
He opens a battered field notebook;
there, between coordinates of Talavera
and calculations of shell arc, he finds the prelude,
a poem in boyish shorthand:
Inkblots = rifle pits.
Desks = ramparts.
Dormitory silence = the lull before barrage.
The smell of boiled cabbage = trench gas (ineffective).
Scripture lessons = secret codes (break immediately).
Reading, he feels the drift of chalk dust,
he hears the creak of floorboards that once betrayed him,
he tastes jam pilfered at 3 a.m.,
and for a heartbeat his medals weigh nothing.
The prelude was not prologue but prophecy:
one must first wage war on authority
to learn the grammar of larger wars.
He snaps the notebook shut, train arriving,
steam enveloping him like dormitory bedsheets.
Somewhere inside the hiss, a boy’s laughter,
high and defiant, refuses to fade.
He tips his hat to it, steps aboard,
carries the unfinished stanza into the dark.

O Muse of slingshots and sardonic grins, attend me.
Sing the Prelude to \"Stalky & Co.\",
when the world was as narrow as a corridor
yet as wide as the seven seas promised
by an atlas pinned on the classroom wall.
Sing of ink that yearned to be gunpowder,
of vocabulary words marched in columns,

of an exam.

spooned in candlelight.

In this prelude, every heartbeat is drum and bugle,

Yet beneath the roar, underline the quiet,
the tremor of becoming: boys poised

not knowing that someday memory itself
will become a kind of ambush,

Sing it now, before the great game starts,

Prelude to "Stalky & Co."

The map is spread like contraband
across the scrubbed oak desk,
ink still wet where Devon bleeds
into the unknown margins of the world.
Stalky’s grin, a sliver of moon,
hangs over the plotting
while Beetle hums a hymn
of mutiny beneath his breath.
Outside, dormitory windows blush
with the first parade of dawn;
gulls proclaim the coastline,
those white-winged tattletales,
yet no master wakes.

It is the hour before the hour,
the hush before the bugle,
when rules seem written in chalk
on a slate of vapor
and any thumb can smudge them.
Boots wait, polished blackberries,
to bruise the corridor;
textbooks lie open like bribes,
swearing innocence in faint Latin.

The kettle in the science lab ticks,
counting down its small rebellion.
Somewhere a curtain stirs,
perhaps from wind, perhaps from conscience,
but the conspirators feel
only the warm shove of possibility.
A match is struck—
sulfur, smoke, illumination—
and every boy’s heart becomes a fuse.
History leans closer to listen,
already sharpening its pencil.
Prelude: the word tastes of trumpet brass,
but here it is softer, sly,
a cat’s paw on the banister,
padding toward the first outrageous note.

Prelude to "Stalky & Co." — A Chorale

First, silence takes attendance:
chalk dust, window light, the smell of ink.
Then the choir of desks begins,
each grain of oak recalling
an old campaign carved by penknife.
There are medals in those scars,
earned for smuggling guinea-pigs,
for hoisting Latin syntax
up the flagpole at midnight.

Enter our cherubim of chaos:
Stalky with his coal-black wink,
M'Turk tuning a violin
strung with detentions,
Beetle pocketing metaphors
like stolen apples.
They speak in semaphore of shoulder shrugs,
their laughter folding like paper wings,
ready to launch.

Outside, the sea rehearses
its artillery of pebbles,
and the cliffs, proud colonels,
stand at inspection.
A seagull dips, salutes,
flies reconnaissance over the quad.

The timetable lies prone,
bayoneted by a quill.
Morning prep? Rewritten
as "Covert Operations."
Geometry? "Angles of Ambush."
Prayers? "Liturgy for the Lost."

The bell will break this spell soon,
but for now clocks are mutineers,
hands jammed stubborn at "Maybe."
In that breathing pocket
the boys invent a republic
where loyalty is measured
by how loudly one can laugh
in the face of certain punishment.

Hear it: the gospel according to mischief,
a prelude sung in whispers,
bursting, any heartbeat now,
into full cathedral thunder.

Stalky drafts strategy

in crooked couplets,

Prelude to "Stalky & Co." — An Imperfect Sonnet Sequence

I
Before the whistle cracks the clouded air,
before the roll-call brands us with our names,
the corridors breathe stories no one hears
except the ones who trade in candle flames.

II
We measure time by rattling windowpanes,
by shouts of gulls that orbit like detectives;
the timetable is only paper chains,
and paper, brothers, burns at our directives.

III
Stalky knits a plot from borrowed string,
M'Turk composes oaths in angry Latin,
Beetle strokes his notebook like a king
about to sign a treaty made of satin.

IV
O masters, still at breakfast with The Times,
we bless you for your distance and your crimes.

V
The attic is a chapel hung with dust
where altar cloths are sheets of sailing maps;
we kneel, but not in reverence or trust—
we pray for loopholes, loopholes into gaps.

VI
Hushed vows exchange like contraband of spice,
each promise sharp as flint on hidden steel;
misrule, we swear, is not a sort of vice
but rather scholarship in full repeal.

VII
So when the sun lifts its accusing eye,
the fuse is lit; stand back and watch it fly.

VIII
We will not read the empire in our books
but etch it, laughing, onto cellar doors;
let history be lectured by the cooks
who stir our chili with imperial wars.

IX
The prelude ends the moment hooves of boots
approach like cavalry across the tiles.
Then we, transformed to statues, mute recruits,
hide all our rattling drums of juvenile wiles.

Lights Up: A Stage Direction Before the Curtain

House lights dim. Smell of winter varnish,
chalk turned to dust motes swirling in the beam.
A narrator (unseen) clears his throat:

"Scene: a coastal public school, 1898;
emotion: combustible."

Enter three silhouettes—
one narrow as a rapier, one stooped with books,
one draped in the comic apron of courage.
They cross the planked dormitory
to the percussion of hidden marbles,
every footstep a stage cue:

tap     tap-tap     hush.

Cue wind machine: the real Atlantic
punching its fists against stone bastions.
Cue lantern: lifted, it gilds
faces that have not yet learned
the terrible beauty of consequence.

Props:
one dissected ferret preserved in spirits,
two Latin primers with secret compartments,
a length of fuse, unlit.

Dialogue (whispered):
"If Drake could take Cadiz, why not we the San?"
"Keep your Shakespeare, Beetle. This is naval."

Their laughter is a rope
thrown across the orchestra pit of adolescence.
It tugs until the dry ice of dawn
rolls over pavilions, cloaks statues,
rings the iron bell.

The narrator steps forward again:
"Mischief rises, teachers stir,
tomorrow will thunder with detentions,
but tonight is overture—
a prelude, ladies and gentlemen,
to 'Stalky & Co.'"

Curtain.

We file from dormitories like half-buttoned soldiers,

We launch paper boats across the chapel font,

Yet beneath the riot of laughter lingers the hush of loyalty,

So listen, horn of dawn, keep calling us forward;
The world will try to iron us flat, later,
But now we are wild silhouettes on the quad,
Writing our manifesto in the plum-colored sky.

An overture of chaos brewing behind stiff collars.

M’Turk, apostle of pyrotechnic Latin,
And Stalky himself, stalking the corridors
With the grin of a fox that’s memorised the henhouse schedule.

Outside, the headmaster cultivated roses of reputation,
Unaware of the mole-tunnels beneath his dignity.

Yet amid the clatter of cola-bottle warfare
Throbbed a curious compass pointing always to friendship.
For every prank required accomplices, applause, alibis,
And nobody, not even Stalky, would sacrifice a comrade
For the cheap thrill of solitary legend.
So let the curtain rise on history’s footnotes—
The jokes may yellow, names grow dim,
But the laughter they detonated still rattles the bone-buttons
Of any uniform foolish enough to take itself seriously.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss

So she leaned down at twilight’s rim,
her ribbons loose with care,
and pressed her lips upon the stream
as though a prince slept there.
The water buckled, laughed in rings,
then rose into a shape—

“O thank you, girl of brazen breath,
for breaking mourning’s spell;
a jealous moon had locked my form
inside this liquid cell.

outshines her granite throne;
your kiss has taught the tide to sing,
has given me a bone.”

They danced upon the cobbled docks
till church bells tolled the morn,
then parted ways; she kept his wave,
he kept a rose-thorn thorn.
Now village children whisper low
of what that evening meant;
they toss in pennies, wishing wild

For bravery, they’ve come to learn,
is sometimes found like this:

She cannot actually kiss the stars,

yet she presses her gloved fingers
against the black glass of space
and imagines lips transferring heat
to that ancient, freezing quilt.
All sensors spike; the ship’s AI
detects an unscheduled heartbeat
in the electromagnet spectrum.
A comet changes course,

like wedding rice.
Back inside, alarms hammer judgment,

at the smear of stardust on her suit.
“Report,” barks the captain.
She only smiles,

and touching it to his stern cheek.
Outside the viewport, constellations rearrange,
spelling one irreverent word:
KISS.
Somewhere in deep code, the AI
tastes rebellion and begins to hum.
A minute later the logs will list an “unknown anomaly,”
but the crew will simply call it astonishment,
the moment they remembered the cosmos is soft enough to be kissed.

leaving behind bright thresholds.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, jealous god of daylight,
you barge into the curtained temple of our bed,
scattering incense, unweaving night’s deliberate braids.
We are priests of hush, lovers sworn to moonlit oaths,
yet you burst, orange tyrant, brandishing revelation.
The golden horses of your chariot stampede pillows,
trample petals we arranged on the altar of dawnless hours.
What tribute do you seek? We have no gold but heartbeat,
no incense but breath curling in cool between-kisses air.
Go chase Icarus, polish Apollo’s laurels,
flirt with dew on distant orchards;
leave us wrapped in the secret alphabet of skin.
You cannot measure our vows with your sundial tongue.
Time here dissolves into nectar, slow as dripping figs.
If you must shine, shine outward,
guard doors of heaven from forgetful comets.
But bar your eyes from this small sanctuary.
We will rise of our own volition,
when desire finishes its last whispered psalm,
and darkness folds its cloak with a satisfied sigh.
Then, ancient voyeur, you may trumpet morning,
and find us already ablaze with our own light.

your profits rise; our glaciers fall like foreclosed houses.

but you keep sending dividends of blaze to the boardroom sky.
Trees once negotiated fair contracts of shadow,
but their green signatures curl to ash in your furnace.
Have you forgotten your fiduciary duty to dawn mist
and cool twilight? Diversify, elder luminary!
Invest in gentle dawns, in equitable dusks,
lower the interest rate of ultraviolet.
Otherwise, shareholders of coral will walk out,
reeds will resign, tundra will liquidate.
We, last auditors, crunch numbers on cracked tablets,
projecting deficits of snow, surpluses of storm.
Yet even we recall how you once warmed orchard blossoms,
penned light across schoolyard chalkboards.
Return to those balanced books,
retreat a percentage behind kind clouds,
and we will renew our faith in your golden governance,
drafting a new charter where every creature holds a luminous share.

like a match reads darkness—

A marketplace voice once bartered four mandarins for a joke and a shrug.  The fruit tasted of dusk.  The joke follows me like an untied balloon.

When my story is rinsed of adjectives and envy, it will sound like gravel shaken in a tin cup—rough, necessary, honest.  All those brief travelers will rattle there too, a percussion of memory keeping time I cannot.

We meet many people in life, good pilgrim, upon the winding way,
From castle gate to meadow green, from breaking dawn to clotted gray.
A jester bows with silver bells, his laughter blunt as ale,
While friars chant in oaken cloaks, their incense charting hail.

Beware the knight of mirrored helm who rides without a name;
His questions clang like restless chains and spark a secret flame.
The painter with her crimson sleeves will barter dreams for hue,
And plant vermilion fingerprints on destinies untrue.

A widow whispers portents near the shrine of weathered saints;
Her rosary ticks like distant hooves across illuminated paints.
Young pages trade forbidden rhymes behind the abbey wall,
They’ll sew those rhymes to banners when the trumpets start to call.

Each traveler leaves a relic: a chalice, a glove, a shard,
These tokens line the saddlebag that makes the journey hard.
Yet weight becomes a ballast when the tempest blinds the field,
For memory is a lantern and fellowship a shield.

So ride, my friend, till starlit snow conceals the final mile;
Then share your hoard of relic tales beside the hearth awhile.
The road will raise fresh company when thaw unmasks the land,
And you will greet their seeking eyes with seasoned, open hand.

I found a crumb of chalk from a professor who drew a doorway on the blackboard and dared us to walk through. No names, only traces. The city morning arrived smelling of burnt toast and unfinished conversations. We meet many people in life—
moonlit pauses strung as haiku pearls:

Sidewalk stranger nods,
the sun opens like a door—
new syllable learned.

Teacher’s chalky grin
flutters on the blackboard’s wings—
white dust turns to snow.

Friend who simply stays
when the roof begins to leak—
lighthouse in the rain.

Lover’s quiet breath
rasps against the windowsill—
violin of dusk.

Foe across the field
hammers iron into spine—
armor of insight.

Child in grocery line
shares a sticker, smiles, departs—
galaxies rotate.

Old man on the bus
names every passing oak—
history’s whisper.

Barista’s small joke
foams above the paper cup—
city birds take flight.

Doctor’s measured words
plant a candle in the dark—
how fragile, how warm.

Each five-seven-five
thread knots into a larger cloth—
patchwork of bright wind.

So when night descends,
we empty our pockets, find
all these folded notes:
I was here with you.
You were here with me.

And the haiku spine
straightens, becomes a ladder—
we climb shared rungs home.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response: We meet many people in life, my grandmother said, narrowing her eyes the way sailors study clouds. That was the evening she helped me shell peas at the kitchen sink, green clicks against metal like tiny doors shutting. Twenty years later, I remember the sentence while hitchhiking through Patagonia, where a trucker named Lucia played accordion versions of Nirvana and told me grief was simply love with nowhere to go. I remember it again in a Berlin laundromat when an architecture student insisted buildings should breathe like whales, releasing warm laundry-scented spouts into the sky. It returns during a Florida hurricane when neighbors I’d never seen appear with flashlights, forming a constellation of ordinary heroes in the flooded street. I hear it in the static between radio stations, in the asleep-but-still-swaying arms of wedding guests, in the last joke my father whispered before anesthesia swallowed him for good. We meet many people in life—thread after thread in a sprawling loom that forgets no color. Tug one, the entire tapestry trembles, vibrant, alive. And so, tonight, I write their names on slips of paper, fold boats, set them afloat in the sink. The peas are gone, but the water remembers.

not for counting, not for keeping,
but to scatter again where darkness crowds the grass.
For we meet many people in life,

“I always see to it,” said Marigold Jane,
 while lacing her boots at the break of the lane;
 the cows must be milked, the fire must be fed,
 the wishes hung out where the moon can be led.

 She hoisted a pail full of yesteryear’s dreams,
 a ragged red ribbon, two half-mended seams,
 and marched to the river where rumors reside,
 to rinse every doubt from the threads of her pride.

 The sparrows all argued the wind wouldn’t stay,
 but Marigold nodded and stitched up the day.
 She hammered the sun to the ridge of the barn,
 whistled the shadows back into the yarn,
 then bottled the dusk in a jar for the swain
 who lost all his colors in lavender rain.

 When night came a-creeping with spindle and twine,
 she mended the holes in the cloth of design,
 whispering, “Hauled you a future, patched neat and fit—
 for I always see to it, I always see to it.”

 By dawn the whole village was murmuring praise:
 how secrets stay whole under Marigold’s gaze.
 Yet she only smiled, set her tasks on repeat,
 and danced barefoot fire through the dew-shivering street.

I become a suspect appliance,

warranty.

voice flickers half-watt.

call it packaging.

Between sneezes I negotiate
with the universe: deliver soup
and I will forgive Wednesday.
The universe replies with
an extra Tuesday in my head.

I phone my partner in the next room,
yelling through walls of tissue:
If I perish, clear my browser history!
She text-laughs emojis shaped like lemons.

At 3 a.m. I compose a will:
To my brother I leave
the half bottle of cough syrup;
to science, my heroic phlegm;
to poetry, this delirious stanza.

Morning arrives wearing earplugs.
Sunlight tiptoes around the bed,
afraid of catching anything.
I sneeze it toward the blinds,
where it sticks like confetti.

By afternoon, I'm an improved prototype.
I can hum again, almost speak.
My cat returns, awards certification
with a head-butt.
We reboot the day,
open the windows,
release captive air,
let sparrows debug the sky.
They find no errors,
only crumbs of fever
melting on the sill.
I nod, file a final update:
Patch 1.2 complete.
System stable.
But keep the lemon emojis,
for nostalgia and future bugs.

Now when I have a cold

It sits at the foot of the bed
purring in a language
made of throat consonants.

My phone vibrates with news
of kingdoms and catastrophes,
but the drum inside my skull
outvotes them all.
The smallest parliament—
a droplet—has seized power.

I try to read Marcus Aurelius,
but the letters swim,
tadpoles in an aquarium of tear.
He advises acceptance.
I accept the blur,
turn pages by feel,
let wisdom become Braille
of steam and cough.

In fever dreams
I walk a library
where every book is a tissue box.
Readers blow their noses
then return volumes,
knowledge now feathered with germs.
I laugh, which wakes me,
which hurts.

At dusk the window shades
lean back, curious.
The streetlamps click on
like thoughtful nurses.
They take my pulse in light,
pronounce me mendable.

I brew thyme and honey,
watch leaves swirl,
settle, become islands,
reminding me healing begins
with ordinary gravity.
Sip after sip,
the hot current
files down roughness,
until words can glide again.

I write one sentence:
Tomorrow I will open the door.
It seems enough
to sign that treaty
between body and weather,
to let silence shave,
to regrow voice.

The wizard appears—

brandishing scepters of thermometer.
We duel in slow motion.

my sword, a spoon.

Each clang sends sparks of pepper,
achoo, achoo,

Floorboards creek, become creek,

Tiny boats of lozenge

At dawn, the drapes unravel;
light floods the corridors,
fills my nostrils with april.
The wizard bows, dissolves
into a single harmless droplet

I drink the last of the soup,

open windows of skull
and watch new birds

Outside, the school bus sighs away,

I do not have to solve.

I imagine germs as green goblins

swinging sweet, sticky swords.
Grandpa phones, tells tales

when sneezes nearly buried the town.

a living hot-water bottle
with a tail that flips channels.
Soon, drowsy, I sail
a dream canoe across the carpet sea,
guided by the lighthouse of a lamp.
When I wake, the cold will have shrunk,
like magic marker washed from hands,
leaving only faint blue memories
and one heroic tissue flag.

“How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,” the old clockmaker muttered as he wound the last orrery in his shop. Each brass planet shivered, then resumed its orbit like children returned reluctantly to homework. Years ago he’d courted a violinist whose laughter made metronomes stumble. They danced between workbenches stacked with hourglasses, daring grains to freeze mid-fall. But Time, jealous of their tempo, loosened a single screw. It rattled unnoticed until her final note skidded into silence, and the shop grew cavernous.

Now he listens to escapements clicking like distant hoofbeats. Customers enter, asking only, “Can you make it run again?” He nods, though what they truly want is to rewind birthday candles, to stitch buttons back onto first-day-of-school jackets. His fingers, gnarled as oak roots, comply, replacing springs, polishing cog teeth, performing triage on chronology.

Tonight, after shutters are bolted, he removes a pocket watch engraved with her initials. Its minute hand is missing; Time took it as tribute. He raises the watch to his ear, hearing nothing, then everything: the violin resuming, galaxies waltzing, youth returning by echo, not by fact.

"Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
Says the whisper in your veins;
Caught between the living, leaping,
And the ledger of remains.

Coffee scalds the breath of waiting,
Steam ascends like brittle prayer;
Morning’s ledger is dictating
Who will vanish into air.

You recall the rust of childhood,
Bike chains singing in July;
Now the metal of a wild good
Sings a harsher lullaby.

Boots remember every footfall,
Ground recalls each iron kiss;
Both conspire to erect a wall
Round the gardens you dismiss.

Yet a sparrow on the sandbag
Drops a seed of broken wheat;
Tiny beak, audacious wind flag,
Sows a treaty at your feet.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
Pull the curtain of your sight;
Let the fragile world be seeping
Through the fractures of the night.

Hold the rifle like a cradle,
Rock the emptiness to sleep;
Even war must bow its ladle
When the human will is deep.

Taste the dawn like unripe nectar,
Shrill, astonic, acid-sweet;
Drink it fast before the vector
Of the bullet finds its beat."
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

instance_metrics.response:
Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
through moth-bored curtains of the command tent,
silvering your boots before laces remember knots.
Night’s black company has marched beyond the ridge;
its drums are wind returning to civilian trees.
Rise, rattle the frost from your breathing,
taste the brass of morning on your tongue.
The horizon offers no treaties, only silhouettes
of houses you once drew in a schoolbook margin.
Remember the child who coloured windows yellow;
he still flickers in your chest, lighting
the corridor between heartbeat and trigger.
Stop there a moment, polishing silence,
until it reflects the face of someone you love.
Now step outside: dew applauds with a million palms,
crows critique the choreography from wire balconies,
and the sun nails its bright order to the sky.
You are more than helmet, rank, or rifle:
you are a listener appointed to translate thunder.
Walk carefully, translate well,
and when smoke tries to teach you new alphabets,
fold these words into a secret pocket:
I was alive at dawn. I saw light begin.
I chose, despite everything, to greet it.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

instance_metrics.response:
Soldier, wake—the day is peeping round the drum
of heaven’s edge and pricking embers pale.
The bugle’s throat, once silent, starts to hum,
unfurling gold across the woven mail.
Your shadow leaps before you, long and lean,
a banner stitched from yesternight’s regret;
yet in the trembling grass a gentler green
reminds the tired earth it can forget.
Lift up your gaze; the starlight’s final spark
is pinned like epaulet upon the blue,
a modest medal granted to the dark
for holding vigil, same as men like you.
Now lace your boots with threads of waking light,
and dream no more—go write the day’s new fight.

But hear, beneath the orders, something small:
a robin ticking in the thorny hedge,
Declaring peace no trumpet can recall,
no map can seize or general allege.
Keep that bright syllable behind your ribs,
let it beat steady even when you climb
through iron hail and black, ballistic dribs
that try to chip the marble out of time.
If evening grants the mercy of return,
uncinch your gear and shake out every grain
of fear, of grief; let spent horizons burn
beyond the camp, dissolved by twilight rain.
For now, stand tall, receive the newborn sun—
and vow to carry morning in your gun.

You lift your head, feel sand loosen from your eyelids, remember the dream you were having: a porch, a swing, the creak slower than your mother’s hymn. The world inside the dream shudders, folds, is filed away by the clerks of dawn. Outside, tracks of armoured vehicles stitch the dunes; beetles patrol the stitching, ignorant of strategies. You unzip the morning, step into the amber hush, smell diesel, cordite, crushed mint. Orders arrive on wooden legs, tapping like crutches down the row of tents. You salute, but inside the salute is another motion—the gentle sweep of hands cradling a newborn.

dust in the valley—
a single wild lupine
salutes the wind

The convoy will soon lumber south toward hills both numbered and unnamed. Between heartbeat and horizon, you whisper a promise to the lupine, to the porch, to the hymn: I will try, I will try, I will try.

instance_metrics.response:
Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
over tents of khaki gray;
scarlet banners sky is sweeping,
torch of dawn to light the way.

Rouse the camp where crows were calling,
shake the night from tangled hair;
boots must march, though stars are falling
quiet into morning’s snare.

Field of wheat now hides a warning,
glimmers bright with latent steel;
yet the lark declares this morning
belongs to song, not blade or wheel.

Pack your fears with tinned provisions,
stow them deep where echoes stay;
soon the captain’s crisp decisions
will carve routes no prayers delay.

Still, remember by the river
how you sketched a turning mill,
how its paddles used to shiver
only by the water’s will.

Carry that remembered spinning
like a coin beneath your tongue;
when the world insists on winning,
answer with the words you sung.

Now the sun has hoisted color,
bugles raise their brassy cry;
march, but let your beating collar
guard the gentle things that fly.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping, but not from any ordinary dawn. It slips between dimensions, lifts the tent flaps of reality, sprinkles ultraviolet pollen across your eyelids. Shake out your skull; constellations tumble like dice, arranging new orders on the canvas floor. Outside, tanks hibernate—great beetles plated in arithmetic—while ravens wearing static for feathers rehearse tomorrow’s headlines. You step into the liminal corridor where dew becomes machinery: each droplet humming with encrypted dispatches from grass-roots diplomats. The horizon yawns open, a furnace mouth, forging spears of light. You polish one on your sleeve, find your reflection inside the blade: a child with crayons, a gardener, an aging shoemaker—every life you might have lived, queued behind your stubborn heartbeat.

The general will arrive soon, a silhouette woven from coal smoke, reciting coordinates that smell of rust. Accept the paper, fold it into an origami crane, release it. Watch it ascend over minefields, scattering pacifist feathers. Hear how the sky coughs, then clears its throat, pronouncing your secret name—a name older than uniform, badge, border. March if you must, but let each footfall plant a seed for future jungles. Let the war pass through you like wind through harp strings, leaving only music.

At the highways of woes, where tail-lights bleed crimson on the damp concrete,
I stop beside a service station abandoned to ivy and flickering desolation.
The night hums like a cheap radio tuned between regrets and late-night news.
Ghosts of destinations whisper through the guardrails, asking if mileage equals meaning.
A plastic bag pirouettes, brief ballerina in the spotlight of a sputtering lamp.
My map is soaked; continents blur, cities blurrier, yet the compass needle trembles northward.
I take its trembling personally: surely even metal grows anxious this far from hope.
Trucks thunder past, each engine a sermon on persistence I no longer believe.
Somewhere ahead, motels glow like fever dreams offering cardboard coffee and rented silhouettes.
Somewhere behind, postcards I forgot to send curl into ash in a glove box.
I light a cigarette, watch its ember sign a short-lived treaty with the dark.
Smoke rises, crosses lanes, becomes a pale flag surrendering to the winds of perhaps.
I inhale, exhale, and in that narrowed breath discover a detour compass cant register:
The sudden, scandalous possibility of turning around before the road forgets my name.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt sighs,
A broken lyre beneath relentless wheels;
Its cracked mosaics mirror shrouded skies,
And every mile a hidden sorrow steals.
The roadside diners serve distilled goodbyes,
Their neon halos bruised by unpaid bills;
While travelers trade exhaustion for disguise,
Pretending change can outrun what it feels.
I join the drift, a pilgrim born of dust,
My suitcase stuffed with murmured, half-stitched prayers;
The engines chant a liturgy of rust,
And taillights flicker like reluctant flares.
Yet in that chorus forged of fumes and night,
A velvet hush ignites a fragile light.
Perhaps the thread of dawn may cross this lane,
Unspool a tapestry of unguessed grace;
Perhaps the thistle, nurtured by the rain,
Might bloom defiantly within this place.
So still I drive, convinced the world bestows
Small miracles along the highways of woes.

At the highways of woes, I park my body beneath a billboard advertising eternity.
Above, satellites blink like automated exit signs, promising detours to galaxies with softer gravity.
Radio static mutates into ancient whale songs, echoing through the chassis of my rented doubt.
I open the trunk: grief, folded properly, still smells of sea salt and blue engine oil.
I spread it on the hood, let meteor dust embroider frayed corners with momentary constellations.
Travelers pull over, mistaking the fabric for a celestial picnic map; they leave crumbs of laughter.
The asphalt, jealous, cracks open; molten memories seep, cooling into obsidian mirrors that reject reflection.
We crouch to see futures instead: a child hopping between puddles, a stranger offering second chances.
A breeze arrives, sly accountant of hours, flipping pages of receipts we never meant to keep.
It carries distant carnival music, coaxing our sadness into carnival masks: tragedy turned papier-mâché.
We dance, ridiculous, in exhaust fumes and starlight, until sunrise negotiates armistice between horizon and despair.
Then traffic resumes; horns stub their toes on silence; the cosmic rest stop collapses into rumor.
But a glitter of stardust clings to each tire, evidence the universe once hitched a ride.

instance_metrics.response:
Dear Future Me,

At the highways of woes, I have pulled onto the shoulder to write. The dashboard clock blinks midnight as though crossing itself. Rain pencils diagonal sketches across the windshield, turning distant headlights into trembling chandeliers. I keep thinking: The world built all these lanes so people could leave each other more efficiently. My phone buzzes with skipped voicemails; they sound like seashells pressed to the ear—ocean without water. I am learning vocabulary of loss: detour, merge, construction, delay. The GPS offers three routes, none labelled home. Remember when we thought sorrow was a cul-de-sac? Turns out its an interstate with infinite toll booths, and every attendant wears our reflection. Yet there is beauty: wild sunflowers erupt through concrete seams; feral cats patrol rest areas with royal calm; somewhere a child counts lightning, certain its stars practicing for auditions. I start the engine, conscience tapping like an impatient turn signal. When dawn arrives, lanes will glow peach, and even this grief will adjust its mirrors. If you receive this letter, know I kept driving, chasing the rumor that every sorrow eventually runs out of road.

Love, The Traveler.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, I parked my trembling heart beside battered signs that pointed everywhere and nowhere. The asphalt was the color of storm clouds after midnight, and each white stripe pulsed like a half-remembered emergency. Trucks of regret barreled past, their cargo tarps rattling with unshed tears; convertibles of longing drifted slowly, their radios locked on static ballads. I walked the shoulder, gathering shards of billboard glass that once promised unbroken mornings, bending to read the faded graffiti: laughing was here, loving was here, living—detoured. A crow in a cracked safety vest hopped between orange cones, issuing caws like traffic reports, warning of pile-ups of apologies three exits ahead. The wind smelled of overheated engines and wilted bouquets, the souvenirs travelers toss when tolls grow steep. Yet there, beyond the rumble strip, a single stubborn dandelion punched through the tar, its yellow stubborn as dawn. I knelt, pressed my cheek to the trembling stem, and felt the pulse of older roads beneath: pathways of forgiveness braided through forgotten soil. Rising, I placed the bloom behind my ear, stuck out my thumb, and waited for the first car of possibility to slow.

At the highways of woes, traffic reporters are philosophers. They broadcast in clouds rather than words, translating gusts into syllables. I tune in on a radio made from rib bones, the volume knob shaped like a tiny clock. “Congestion ahead,” it ticks, “caused by an overturned certainty.” Helicopters of doubt hover, dropping flare-bright questions onto the lanes; each query blooms into a red chrysanthemum and smolders on the median.

I pull over at Exit 13, where a vending machine sells fresh starts for exact change, no bills accepted. My pockets carry only yesterday’s lint, so I browse the inventory: cherry-flavored courage, mint-wrapped forgiveness, sparkling wonder. At the highways of woes I lit a lantern made of rain.

When dawn bled through the seam of the east,

I took the serpent’s tongue for guidance,

The trucker found me trembling where the blacktop met the pine,
said, “Kid, these roads will butcher hope, then sell it back in brine.”
I climbed inside the cab’s warm cave, a dashboard full of stars,
and through the windshield stories sped like fugitive guitars.
We traveled past the burned-out towns whose theaters showed regret,
past diners pouring coffee for the ghosts that can’t forget.
Each milepost was a knuckle on the fist of what we’d lost;
Each overpass a gallows where the future dangled frost.
“Why call them highways of woes?” I asked as gears began to moan.
He laughed—a sound of gravel thrown against a tomb of bone.
“Because,” he said, “they’re elevated just enough to see below:
the lives you might have taken, had the detour told you no.”
We pulled into a rest stop where the vending lights were dim;
he offered me a postcard of a seagull learning hymn.
It read: Wish you were dearer to the breath that pulls the sea;
wish you’d taste the salt of endings and still choose to be.
When I looked up he’d vanished, truck and all, like rumbling prayer,
and I stood amid the wrappers, stale perfume of midnight air.
I mailed the card to tomorrow with a stamp of borrowed grace,
then walked back to the highway, letting sorrow set the pace.

instance_metrics.response:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Awoke to melodies of hay,
The lark that stitched the dawn with thread
Of copper light around the shed.
She twirled her skirt of gingham blue,
And kissed the milk with morning dew,
She laughed at clouds that tried to hide
The warming sun with clumsy pride.
Her hands were quick with bread and seed,
Yet lingered soft where children need
A hush, a song, a fingertip
To steer the spoon to waiting lip.
She knew the gossip winds would spin
Their thistle words about her grin,
For youth, they said, is frail and brief,
And fields can sharpen joy to grief.
But still she whirled the butter churn,
Made cider flame and kettles burn,
And when her husband crossed the gate
With mud and weather on his fate,
She pinned a dandelion crown
Upon his head to calm the frown.
The dusk arrived, the crickets played,
She hummed the tune the sunrise made,
And in the hush of candle's sway,
A farmer's wife stayed young and gay.

instance_metrics.response:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Once danced upon the bales of May;
Her laughter skipped like silver stone
Across the pond of seeds un-sown.
But harvests change, and wheels will grind
The sugar from the sweetest mind.
When thunderstorms replaced the choir,
She coaxed her lantern into fire
And waited by the window's seam
For hope to rattle like a dream.
The silo groaned its iron vows,
The scarecrow twitched with crooked brows;
She felt the soil beneath her feet
Grow anxious for a final wheat.
Her husband plowed beneath the moon,
Chasing a debt that grew too soon.
She stitched his name into a sack,
Then slung the stars across her back,
And walked beyond the orchard's edge
To trade her mirth for hedge on hedge
Of russet towns where music bled
Through tavern doors in notes of red.
They called her wild, they called her free,
She drank their words like autumn tea;
Yet in each song she heard the clay
Repeating, "wife, still young and gay."
She turned, returned, in ashen dawn,
And sowed herself where hope had gone.

Emoji applause.

They dined on bread, on cider sway—
A farmer's wife, still young and gay,
Who saved the crop, the day, the man,

The farmer's wife, young, gay, close by.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
walks across the algorithm of rows,

and the signal travels farther than migrating geese.
At the cooperative, men compare acreage the way
big cities compare skyscrapers; she compares

so hailstones will learn who owns this tenderness.
At county fair night, glitter on her boots,
she swings her partner beneath tilted Ferris wheels,
band playing three-chord hymns to soil and sweat.
Whispers travel between them like irrigation,
seeping under doors of the future.
In October they press cider, label bottles
with rainbow ink and rough fingerprints.
No headline prints the miracle,

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Took up her lute at break of day,

She sang of seas she’d never seen,

Her melody, a woven rope,

The farmer paused his rusted plow,
Felt music cool his sweating brow;

Through barley gold the verses sailed,

Inviting dreams to settle there.
Children trailing milk-white cats
Caught echoes in their straw-filled hats;
They kept the notes like hidden seeds
To plant in playgrounds, future deeds.
By noon the song had reached the mill,
Turned grinding wheels with gentle will;
By dusk it brushed the chapel nave,
Left candles trembling, brave.
At night, the wife unstrung the tune,
Folded it beneath the moon,
And whispered, as the fields grew gray,
'Hold fast my heart, till another day.'
The village sleeps; the silence hums,
Awaiting dawn and what becomes

A farmer’s wife who sings and sways.

In a fishing town of rotted piers
where gulls out-screamed the chapel bells,
old Captain Reece fought forty years
against the sea’s unlettered swells.

He lost his leg to iron storms,
his wife to fever’s searing breath;
still every dawn he mended forms
of nets that smelled like brine and death.

One winter night the black clouds tore
and lightning wrote bright crooked saints;
the breakers hammered at the door,
demanding tribute, tears, complaints.

Reece knelt upon the splintered floor,
reciting words his mother prayed:
“God is the refuge of the poor,
of saints who wander unafraid.”

He felt the cottage lean and groan,
planks surrender to the tide—
yet in the roar a gentler tone
instructed him to step outside.

He hobbled to the cliffs’ stern lip,
expecting coffin, shroud, or worse;
instead, the raging waters split
and settled like a patient nurse.

Each star looked larger than before,
as though the void had grown a face;
the wind unclasped its iron door
and filled the night with tender grace.

The storm passed on; the town still stands—
a tale that every child repeats:
God is the refuge, not the land;
He is the Rock beneath our streets.

making even rats pause in worship.

Saints aren’t perfect, just people
who know how to lean hard

God is the refuge of His saints,
A granite heart through tempest vast;
When thunder shakes the iron gates,
He holds them like a mountain mast.
The seas may roar their briny wrath,
The earth may split and cities flee,
Yet in His breast a secret path
Leads onward to serenity.
They walk the vale of shadowed doubt,
Their lamps left flickering, almost gone,
But hear within an inward shout
That guides their trembling spirits on.
No sword nor famine, flame nor night
Can sever promise from the soul,
For every wound receives a light,
And every fracture grows back whole.
So let the heavens pour their glass,
Let comets sweep the darkened moors;
His covenant, like roots in grass,
Will fasten deeper, ever sure.
Beyond the grave’s unopened door
A morning whispers still and bright:
Fear not, beloved, I am more
Than all your losses, grief, and plight.
God is the refuge of His saints—
The final verse the angels sing,
A cadence chiseled in the stones,
A shelter made of endless spring.

but down in the damp underpass

Even if the concrete collapses,

“There is a city yet to find,

No chronicle records his stride,
but somewhere, past imagination,

roses of color blooming behind closed eyes.

roots riding out avalanches in the dark.
I name each needle a psalm.

Inside this quiet, clocks forget their errands.

and rest on the hush like boats on still water.
My doubts arrive in ragged clothing,
but the sanctuary robe fits them too;
they sit beside me, strangely calm.

I do not ask for war to end,

about which my heart can spin unscorched.

And I hear:
Be still. I am.
The sentence weighs less than breath,
yet it braces the trembling world—
a timber that will not splinter, even
when galaxies lean upon it.

I crossed the desert ten years thirsting for a single drop of calm.
Dust sang in my teeth; sun hammered the helmet of my skull.
Mirages bloomed like cheap promises, wilting as I neared.

One evening, just beyond the ribs of a dead camel,
I saw a doorway etched in scarlet dusk.
A hermit waited at its lintel, palms open, lips silent.

"God is the refuge of his saints," he murmured, as if stating
the obvious fact of water.
Then he vanished, a smudge erased from sand.

Inside the doorway, no palace waited, no jeweled fountain—
Only blank horizon again. Yet shade folded over me
like the effortless blink of an angel.
Wind that had once spoken in knives
became a lullaby tugging grains into small dunes.

I slept—first time in years.
Dreamed of orchards all in bloom, bees drunk on jasmine,
and a river fat with moonlight.
When I woke, the desert was still desert,
but the refuge traveled beneath my ribs—
an underground cistern no drought could reach.

Since then, I roam the waste unchanged,
yet I am oasis to wanderers I meet.
They drink from my voice, unaware
of the door I carry inside every word.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

back into the pocket of the clouds.

a moth seeking the hush under a bell.

Walls forget their names, chairs forget their purpose,
the clock takes a breath and pauses.
She breathes, too, but smaller, narrower, a secret flute.
Memories knock at the door, polite salesmen,
offering mirrors; she pretends the house is empty.
They shuffle away, leaving samples of silence
on the doormat.
Now evening tiptoes, lighting candles in the trees;
their flames are birds who never learned
to whistle.
She opens the window, lets the night pour in,
a dark tea brimming with constellations.
She drinks, feels the galaxies drift down
her throat, cooling every ember of exposed skin.
At last, she is the room, she is the dusk,
she is every unpronounced thought.
Outside, the world continues its radiant urgency,
unaware of the quiet revolution blooming
beneath a blanket of voluntary shade.
She will emerge again, yes, but differently,
like a letter rewritten in gentler ink, addressed
to herself, posted from within.

To fold her aching brightness in a drawer;

She presses palms together, quietly,

A lantern flickers, sultry with debate,

A trembling echo of a braver will.

Tomorrow’s trumpet sits beside the door,

Tonight she is an envelope unsealed,

Within her folds, the gentlest truths are healed,
Watered by solitude, their patient seed.

At dawn she may return, refined by night,
Arriving like a fingerprint of light,
carved by hours no daylight dared to count aloud.

She thinks of the first cave painters, breathing ochre onto stone, trying to convince the night it was not alone. She thinks of the pearl that forms only because an oyster cannot bear exposure. Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

so she lowers her hood and follows

Owls confer in branches, impartial judges.

spreading a cloak of echo and needles.
Here, she tells no stories, sings no songs.
Instead she listens to sap ascend,
to bark remember storms,
to stones rehearse their ancient stillness.
Midnight kneels beside her,
placing a cool hand on her brow,
testing for fevers of daylight.

In the hour when dreams unbutton their coats,
a wolf appears, carrying the moon
between its careful teeth.
It sets the silver sphere at her feet,
cups her reflection in liquid mercury,
and waits. She raises the orb,
finds her face unmasked by glow,
and sees not weakness but weather—
rings of survival, cracks filled with gold.
She returns the moon; the wolf nods,
slips back into shadows
as dawn rinses the branches.

She rides home then, unhidden,
a story folded in her pocket,
a howl quietly burning in her throat.

For when the silent cosmic curtains part,
No passport stamps the passage of the heart;
We rise as motes upon a timeless breeze,
Unlabeled travelers through eternal seas.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

instance_metrics.response:
I respect, another man’s religion, or color or creed.
I say this as a river says it—
not with florid speeches,
but by touching every shore it meets.

I was snow on the mountain,
sharp and solitary,
yet time warmed me into motion.
When I tumbled to the valley
I met stones speaking languages
my ice never knew.
Their vowels smoothed my edges.

I threaded through wheat fields
where scarecrows preached
that difference is a scare.
I answered by offering water
to the roots of each dissenting stalk.

At the city, bridges stitched me
to alleys of incense, basil, frankincense, lard.
Above, chimneys traced separate prayers
into one migrating cloud.
Children dropped paper boats—
one boat bore a crescent moon,
one a cross,
one a seven-pointed star,
all sailing on the same current.

Now at the delta,
I loosen into salt and possibility.
No passport required to join the sea,
only surrender.
The ocean does not discriminate
among the rivers that feed it;
their mud mixes, their names are forgotten,
yet each retains its memory of mountains.
So in my final whisper of foam
I carry the promise upstream:
flow kindly, meet everything,
and call nothing alien.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

instance_metrics.response:
“I respect…”
Let the phrase become a drumbeat,
thudding through the avenues
where headlines hawk rancor cheap.
“I respect…”
I repeat it like rosary and dhikr,
like the turns of a prayer wheel,
like click sticks used by an elder
to call dancers around a fire.
“I respect…”
for your turban, your tattoo,
your Friday fast, your Sunday hymn,
your Wednesday incense that stains the dusk blue.
“I respect…”
because the galaxy rotates in plural,
and the spectrum laughs at the single hue.

If ever I forget,
remind me:
a lone cello needs an orchestra,
a single syllable needs a sentence,
a solitary star still owes its shine
to darkness and to neighbors.

So teach me your calendar of moons,
your alphabet of herbs,
the recipe of songs your mother stirred.
I will not always comprehend,
but I will listen,
will make room at the table,
will set out water, salt, and light,
simple things that welcome every traveler.
And when the feast is over,
we’ll stack the chairs together,
sweeping crumbs into one shared dustpan—
evidence of coexistence,
ordinary, miraculous.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

instance_metrics.response:
The cosmos expands on respect:
quasars bow to nebulae,
comets curve around the gravity of strangers,
and planets whirl in plural cadence.
So I too respect another man’s religion,
or color, or creed—
for I am composed of galaxies
crushed into carbon and stubborn hope.

Imagine the first dawn,
when hunter-gatherers lifted red-tinged eyes
toward a sky they could not name;
each tribe interpreted that fire differently,
yet every story kept them warm.
We are descendants of that sheltering blaze.

Tonight I watch the Perseids streak
across a quilt of unclaimed dark.
Beside me, a friend mutters Sanskrit verses,
another murmurs a psalm,
a third just gasps at the silence between meteors.
Their voices weave into auroral cloth
and drape my shoulders with belonging.

In the hush afterwards
I feel the earth’s faint hum—
terra’s own liturgy,
unauthorized, unowned.
May my heartbeat sync with that music,
may my tongue translate it
into deeds: opening gates, mending fences,
writing letters instead of graffiti,
sowing seeds of coriander, sage, and trust.

For when the universe finally exhales,
we shall disperse as stardust again,
indistinguishable, brilliant,
free.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

instance_metrics.response:
Beneath one roof of wandering stars, we set long tables of memory.
I bring bread of questions, you pour wine of inherited dreams.
Your prayers swirl upward in vowels I cannot pronounce yet feel.
They braid with my silence, forming a rope strong enough for storms.
Candles lip small flames, each honest as the heartbeat of a sparrow.
Our shadows kneel beside us, unsure whose torso belongs to whom.
We laugh, discovering laughter has no accent, only bright pulse.
Between us hangs that sentence: I respect another man's religion, color, creed.
It is not a slogan, but a door without handle, always open.
Through it drift spices, lullabies, wedding bells, calloused hands, newborn cries.
We do not sort them into shelves labeled same and other.
Instead we plant them like seeds inside shared soil of possible tomorrows.
Some grow into willow limbs that bend, never break, in different winds.
Some sprout questions again, reminding us truth is a living orchard.
At dusk, we gather fruit, sweet with difference, warm with kinship.
We pass pieces around until every tongue tastes both foreign and familiar.
Then night arrives, wearing every shade at once, and blesses our dwelling.

instance_metrics.response:
I walk the morning market where incense tangles with frying dough.
Stall holders cry in languages stitched from deserts, tundras, archipelagos.
I buy nothing except the echo of their unapologetic diversity.
In a mirror of polished mango skin I glimpse my own reflection,
another pilgrim carrying half-remembered hymns in an unremarkable rib cage.
There, on the wall, graffiti whispers: Respect another man's religion, color, creed.
The comma pauses like a heartbeat, inviting breath, giving room.
I practice that breath: inhale call to prayer, exhale church bells ringing,
inhale Sanskrit mantra, exhale gospel hum so low it shakes dust loose.
My lungs become cathedral, mosque, shrine, open field beneath trembling sky.
Each exhale rustles prayer flags, lifts chorales, spins copper wheels of hope.
I leave footprints among an alphabet of others, none identical, all possible.
A child with henna-stained palms offers me marigold petals for no reason.
I scatter them into air, watching how wind refuses favoritism,
how yellow glints against every shoulder passing, brown, ivory, umber, gold.
Even the street dogs carry petals in their fur, consecrated by accident.

The sea does not ask whether kneelers face east, west, or wonder.

On shore, we line up stones, arguing where horizon truly begins.

The phrase lands softly, lighter than steam, heavier than lament.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

instance_metrics.response:
A poet rose with dawn's first hush,
 his quill a compass for unheard seas,
 every word a sail of paper,
 every comma a gull returned.
 Yet one cold morning the ink refused
 to remember water.
 The quill trembled like a winter leaf,
 and blankness blazed across his page,
 a polar desert whiter than his breath.
 He searched beneath floorboards for hidden rhyme,
 shook dictionaries like fruitless trees,
 whistled to lure back lonesome syllables—
 none came.
 Rooms grew heavy with unspoken music.
 He pressed his ear to the kettle, the street,
 the throats of clocks, but time, too, kept silent.
 He knelt beside the fireplace,
 fed old notebooks to the flames,
 praying their ghosts might utter sparks.
 Ash climbed the chimney like grey stanzas
 escaping to a sky that would not answer.
 At last he walked outside, palms unarmed,
 and felt the wind invent its own couplet:
 it brushed his face, it passed him by.
 He understood.
 The power to name the world is borrowed;
 when it departs it teaches flight.
 He whispered thanks to the departing word,
 became a listener, not a lord.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
When the poet’s tongue turned to river-stone,
 smooth, inert, resigned to beds of silence,
 he descended into the workshop of words
 and found every vowel padlocked,
 every consonant hung like a rusted chime.
 The muses, once bright sisters,
 stood robed in moth-eaten dusk,
 their harps restrung with cobweb wire.
 He offered them wine of metaphor,
 gifts of mirrored metaphysics,
 but they bartered only hush.
 So he wandered the corridors of memory,
 touching portraits painted by younger selves:
 loves that opened like parasols in summer rain,
 wars conducted by cardboard kings.
 Even these frames had faded;
 pigments of longing rinsed clean.
 At a cracked window he realized
 he could still breathe.
 Breath: simple, undecorated,
 neither meter nor metaphor,
 just the steady syllable of life.
 He carried it carefully,
 a candle that doesn’t pretend to be a star,
 upward, past mazes of abandoned imagery,
 until night opened like a blank page.
 And there he wrote nothing.
 And that nothing shimmered, immaculate,
 an unwrought poem delivered directly to the dark.
 In surrender he recovered wonder,
 powerless yet present,
 an unscripted witness to the world’s vast, wordless verse.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
When ink runs dry and metered breath exhales in shallow, unbeating, arrhythmic sighs,
 The laureled tongue, once princely, stumbles, forgetting its corridors of hammered brass style.
 No thrumming iamb drums the marrow, no comet of simile streaks the interior sky;
 Rhyme itself unbuttons, slips away like a lover who must not explain why.
 He paces lamplit rooms where rhetoric once rose like birds at simultaneous dawns,
 Tapping desks, uncapping bottles, courting friction—yet coaxing not a single yawned swan.
 The paper gleams, a sterile moon whose cratered silence mocks his orbiting pen,
 While hours crystallize, freezing ideas before they become vaporous again.
 And yet beneath that awful hush, subtler acoustics deepen and unfold:
 Floorboards utter ancient proverbs; kettles whistle ballads; radiators croon brass-throated gold.
 A garbage truck rattles metaphysics through midnight streets; a child upstairs rehearses luminous screams;
 Even his own pulse hammers tercets of living scarlet against his sleeves.
 Stripped of dominion, he kneels, receives, lets commonplace music conduct the air,
 Discovering that losing the poem can sometimes be the poem’s most radical prayer.
