instance_metrics.response:
The day the poet misplaced his power,
 planets re-aligned with an audible shrug.
 Comets he once christened with verbs
 streaked by, unclaimed, wearing anonymity like armor.
 He reached for Orion’s belt, found it unbuckled,
 stars tumbling out like loose buttons.
 Without his lexicon, the universe kept its originals:
 unnamed colors, unmeasured winds,
 the secret blue between twilight and thought.
 He wandered the city with pockets full of hush,
 listening.
 Billboards blinked mute neon scriptures;
 pigeons conducted grey symphonies without notation;
 rivers recited themselves in flawless liquid code.
 He realized he had been a careless cartographer,
 scribbling borders around infinities,
 branding every silence with a logo of verse.
 Now, relieved of labeling, he witnessed bloom.
 A dandelion erupted in quantum yellow,
 louder than any epithet of gold.
 A rusted gate moaned open,
 revealing a backyard multiverse of spiders
 engineering spiral poems no critic could dissect.
 Nightfall arrived uncaptioned and therefore boundless.
 He lay down beneath it, one atom among billions,
 content to orbit within breath alone.
 In the dark he dreamed of words
 returning someday,
 but not as servants, not as trophies—
 rather as constellations that decline to be named.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
He woke to discover the alphabet had filed for divorce,
 leaving twenty-six handwritten notes on the fridge:
 'It’s not you, it’s using us.'
 The metaphors packed their suitcases of like and as,
 hitched a ride with a passing cliché.
 The similes lingered, but only to borrow rent money,
 then skedaddled with the wi-fi password.
 Our poet, suddenly single,
 tried speed-dating new expressions:
 haiku apps, limerick chatrooms, free-verse yoga class.
 Nothing clicked.
 At the grocery he attempted an ode to oranges,
 managed only 'round… um… orangey,'
 which the produce manager graded a C-.
 He consulted a specialist who prescribed
 twelve units of lived experience daily:
 walk a dog, burn a grilled cheese, misplace your keys.
 Side effects included wonder.
 He complied.
 Soon rain soaked him into present tense;
 potholes recited slapstick couplets;
 a stranger’s sneeze rhymed with ease.
 Though still unarmed with dragon-slaying diction,
 he felt language warming like bread in pocket.
 One afternoon the alphabet returned,
 eyes glossy with nostalgia.
 'Have you grown?' it asked.
 He shrugged, fed it tea without rhetoric.
 They agreed to start slow,
 maybe share a grocery list.
 First entry: oranges,
 so perfect they required no poem at all.

instance_metrics.response:
A poet loses his power for poetry,
and the alphabet flutters away like startled starlings.
Pages once obedient begin to whistle their own songs,
ink beads evaporate, leaving ghostly rings on the table.
He turns to the window, mouth ajar, searching for a verb
hovering like a moth over lamplight; nothing descends.
Outside, children braid sentences in the dust, effortless
as skipping rope; he cannot borrow even a conjunction.

Afternoons lengthen like unfinished similes.
He inventories the furniture: chair, lamp, clock— nouns
that once marched into sonnets now refuse conscription.
Rhythm deserts him; his pulse knocks out of meter,
ragged as a boot against a locked door.
Night pours its metaphors across the ceiling;
he only feels the chill of literal stars.

In dreams he steps into a river of unwritten poems,
but water sluices through his cupped hands.
He wakes, palms dry, remembers the line
he meant to carry ashore, and finds it broken.

Still he records the hush, the vacant breath
between heartbeat and word, hoping silence itself
might be the seed of some new stanza.
Perhaps power for poetry is never lost,
only transformed into the ache that precedes singing.

the constellations shuffle, forgetting their bright geometry of snow.
Empty throats of bells forget the shape and purpose of time.

He inventories silence, grain by grain, like an archivist of crime,
seeking the stolen consonant, the fugitive verb’s shadow.
When a poet mislays the glimmer and torque of rhyme,

the sea no longer rehearses its hexameter against the brine;
waves arrive unmetered, sprawling prose upon the pier below.
Empty throats of bells forget the shape and purpose of time.

He keeps rewriting dusk, sandpapering clouds until they shine,
begging the horizon to rhyme scarlet with indigo.
When a poet mislays the glimmer and torque of rhyme,

sparrows unlearn their couplets, crickets lose their pantomime;
even the wind drops commas where it ought to blow.
Empty throats of bells forget the shape and purpose of time.

Still he lifts that hollow bell, crafts a pulse sublime,
ringing absence itself, letting resonant nothingness grow.
When a poet mislays the glimmer and torque of rhyme,
empty throats of bells forget the shape and purpose of time.

Listen: the poet’s mouth is a bakery gone cold.
There’s flour on the counters—white, expectant—but no bread.
The ovens forgot the language of flame; pilot lights out.
He walks the tiles barefoot; echoes stick like gum.
Yesterday he could season syllables, knead them, watch
their bellies swell with metaphor, yeast of yearning.
Today the clock ticks blank; even the sparrows
drop feathers instead of choruses.

So he hits the street, chasing graffiti for syntax.
Neon signs spit vowels. Bus brakes grunt consonants.
He samples every sound—whispers, sirens, sneaker squeaks—
but nothing sparks. The mix-tape of the city
plays, but his inner DJ’s gone on strike.

He remembers the line—A poet loses his power for poetry—
like a verdict stamped on paper already burning.
Loss tastes metallic, like biting a coin.
He flips it—heads, he quits; tails, he writes.
It lands spinning, spinning: a blurred halo of maybe.

And in that whirr, just before stillness,
he hears a shy syllable—a seed.
He pockets it, warm as a charge.
Tonight he will plant it in the cooling oven
and wait for the faint smell of new bread.

instance_metrics.response:
The day the verses left, I felt the sky
hang like an unstrung lute above the roofs.
Traffic kept its percussion, children still
drew hopscotch staves across the dusty street,
but every chord I knew dissolved to air.
I pressed my ear against the oak for clues—
the ancient engine humming in its rings—
and heard mere wood, no secret metaphor.

I walked the river path. The water spoke
in fluent ripple, mocked me with its gloss.
I could not translate. Once I was the mesh
through which the current threaded silver lines;
now net undone, I trailed behind the flow.

At dusk I built a fire, not for warmth
so much as color. Flames licked nouns to sparks,
then spat them out, charred commas on the stones.
I watched them cool, confessed I was afraid
that language, having tasted smoke, would flee.

Yet in the hush between two snapping sticks,
a rhythm trembled—small, unfinished, weak—
like pulse beneath the wrist of a newborn.
I breathed it in, and felt my silent chest
fill, as a sail accepts the smallest wind.
Loss is a harbor: grief the open sea
where words return, salt-laden, burnished, free.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
A poet once carried storms in his throat, each syllable a hammered nail, lightning pressed to parchment. One dawn he woke to a stillness heavier than snow. The room reverberated with nothing. No verbs soared, no metaphors unlocked hidden doors. He searched the pockets of his heart, found only lint and faded ticket stubs to places he could no longer name.
Birds outside rehearsed galaxies of song, their registers unreachable. He dipped his pen in silence, watched the ink refuse to darken. Evening arrived, a custodian sweeping echoes from corridors. Beside the window he whispered, “I am unrhymed, unwinged.” And the moon, pale librarian, closed the last unreadable book.
Wordless, he slept, dreaming nothing, even his breath unpunctuated. Yet in the garden, verbs still burrowed under soil, patient as bulbs. When spring shakes loose its colored sleeves, perhaps they will rise, find his mouth again, rebuild the cathedral of cadence, note by trembling note. Until then, he tends his quiet like a cracked teacup, holding whatever warmth is left, believing it may steep into syllables once more.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
Somewhere between Orion’s bent bow and the hush of attic rafters the ten muses convened. Their lyres glinted like teeth in wolf light. “He has grown careless,” Polyhymnia sighed, cradling a mute hymn. “He squandered verbs on postcards and grocery lists.” Terpsichore kicked dust from her sandals, rhythms unwinding. Calliope traced a comet’s scar, said, “Then we must reclaim the tongues we loaned him.”
At once the cosmos dimmed, vowels sucked inward like fish caught in a draining pond. On earth the poet felt the draught, watched consonants crawl from his wrists, climb the air back to their star-fed keep. He grabbed for a phrase, caught only a fraying conjunction. Even that dissolved, feather of salt.
He sat beneath the unspeaking sky, bewildered shepherd without sheep, until darkness shrugged an aurora over his shoulders. In its green cold shimmer he heard nothing but his pulse, ancient drum that no muse could confiscate. From that solitary beat a slow chant brewed, wordless, but his alone, promising that someday he would name the voids again, and they would answer. For now the silence was an apprenticeship, night’s ink soaking into his uncalloused palms.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
The city flickered like a fluorescent sign near burnout. Neon syllables once climbed its walls, synonyms darting across alleyways like bright cats. When the poet’s voice failed, power died block by block. Billboards blanched, newspapers printed blank lattices of grief. In the Metro, commuters mouthed sentences that never arrived; even the loudspeakers stuttered out static shaped like ellipses.
He walked among them, ghost of his own doing, pockets jangling with pencils sharpened to remorse. A child tugged his sleeve: “Tell me a story.” He opened his mouth, but only the copper smell of streetlights poured out.
Upstairs, his apartment was a greenhouse of unsent letters, vines looping around each envelope, sealing them shut. He placed his last sheet of paper on the windowsill, hoping moon or wind would write for him. Instead rain arrived, drumming coded Morse onto the page, dashes drowning dots. He deciphered nothing yet felt the message pulse: grow quiet, root yourself in asphalt, taste minerals of winter.
He understood that silence was not absence but seed, and blackout merely earth before the fuse of dawn. So he waited, apprentice to dark, until the first weed of syllable cracked the pavement open, exposing light thin as paper.

instance_metrics.response:
{Title:} EXHIBIT OF THE UNSAID

1.
The poet wakes to find his tongue archived in a museum of used metaphors. A small plaque beneath it reads: “Specimen no. 47—function retired due to oversaturation.”

2.
He presses his ear to the glass, hears past poems humming like archived bees. The curator whispers, “All wings, no nectar.”

3.
Outside clouds arrange themselves into crisp couplets, then disperse before he can jot them down. Sunlight forms an acrostic on the lawn; lawnmowers redline it into prose.

4.
He tries prayer, but every holy word has been lent to crusades.

5.
The gift shop sells blank notebooks at outrageous prices: “Authentic absence—take home your own hush!”

6.
He buys nothing, walks out with pockets full of unissued tickets to time. Pavement under his feet upholds a single certainty: weight. He studies its tacit grammar, each stone a period refusing to turn into a question.

7.
At night the empty page on his desk becomes a mirror. He sees in it the one word he never lost: still. He mouths it, and the mirror wavers, almost sings, a promise shaped like a door waiting for hinges.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
He buried his quills in autumn, convinced the veins were dry. Winter pinned silence to every window like parchment without ink. House plants drooped, deprived of soliloquy while neighbors shoveled driveways, their shouts forming crude haiku the wind erased. He thought himself finished, page and pulse equally blank.

One night he dreamed of glaciers shedding vowels into dark seas. The crash woke him; he tasted brine on his lips. Stepping outside, he found the moon cracked open, silver yolk spilling across the snow. He knelt, shaped a handful into a sphere, pressed it against his tongue. Cold syllables thawed, dripped down his throat, ringing like glass bells.

He whispered to test the hinge: “Begin.” The field answered with quiet applause, a million snowflakes rearranging themselves into lines he had never imagined.

At dawn he dug up the quills. Their shafts were green, tipped with unborn words. He placed them in a jar of thaw water, watched the letters swim like minnows. The first poem arrived shyly, five words long: I left but returned singing. He smiled, deciding loss was only the pause before the chorus, silence simply another instrument to master.

instance_metrics.response: When the final verb escaped his mouth, it flickered like a sparrow at dusk, uncertain of perch or horizon. A hush settled over the quills that had once trembled in his palm; they were only feathers now, husks of flight, mute as flint. He walked to the mirror to ask for a synonym of himself, but the glass answered with silence, showing only lips that moved without music. The muses packed their suitcases of thunder and metaphors, leaving coffee rings on the desk like faint eclipse. Outside, the wind rehearsed stanzas he could no longer hear; it braided the cedars, scattered syllables across the lawn, but none curved back to him. He tried to ransom a rhyme with memory, offered childhood streams, first kisses, grief, but the currency had collapsed. In the attic, past drafts wither like pressed flowers, fragrant yet incapable of bloom. Night unrolls its black parchment, and even the stars withhold their ink. Still, he strikes a match, tracing its brief gold through the dark, praying the small flame might remember an adjective, might whisper one surviving line: begin again.

instance_metrics.response: They say the tongue is a river, but his has turned to salt. He wakes inside a drought, all lips cracked maps to vanished springs. He carries notebooks full of desiccated ribs—skeletons of imagery rattling when he walks. In the market, color hawkers display baskets of vermilion and ultramarine; he touches the pigments, but they do not stain his skin. Children blow soap bubbles that rise like glass commas, yet he cannot finish their sentence. At night he listens to old recordings of rain, remembers the cadence of drops drilling roofs, how he extracted metaphors like diamonds from thunder. The recording ends. Static bristles the speakers, a white snow of unmade stories. He closes his eyes, thinks of ancient mesas where petroglyphs survive long after language. Maybe loss is not absence but a dry plateau, waiting for wind to carve new letters out of stone. He places his ear to the ground, hoping to hear the first syllable gather dust and breath beneath.

Once he could summon dawn with ink, ignite skylines within the narrowest margin alone.

Metaphor deserts him first, then rhythm, then the small bright verbs of rain entirely.
He opens windows, hoping breeze will barter breath for stanza, gale for grace today.
Outside, crows recite their harsh psalms; he cannot translate the black refrain of midnight.

He envies such closure, sentences that end without remorse, endings that simply seal shut.

He drafts a blank; even the blank refuses, whitening further into glass hard silence.
Night climbs the bookshelf, extinguishing titles like lamps along a forsaken street of thought.
He whispers prayer to keys: deliver me one phrase, one surviving seed of spring.
The keyboard answers clicks of dust, a monotonous snow of brittle echoes falling slow.
Still, tomorrow he will sit again, courting lightsmiths, courting the wayward wind to return.
For power lost is seldom dead; it circles, silent, preparing a resurrection of verse.

instance_metrics.response: In the museum of unsaid things he wanders corridors lined with locked display cases. He presses his forehead to the glass, searching for the secret latch, but fingerprints bloom like frost and fade. Guides move past with headset voices: "Observe how loss erodes intention, the way water hollows marble." Their laser pens trace empty air where adjectives should hover. Suddenly a child slips away from the tour, hands him a crayon the color of sunrise spilled on brick. "Draw something," she says. He makes a line, crooked as a tired river, then another. The crayon’s wax breaks, soft stub shivering in his fist, but the scratch glows—faint ember, unexpected. Alarms remain silent. The guards do not see. The child smiles, vanishes behind a revolving door of possibility. He pockets the fragment, warmth seeping through his coat like illicit dawn. Outside, traffic drills its prosody, pigeons apostrophe the sky, and somewhere a single word—raw, unmetered—begins to pronounce him alive again.

instance_metrics.response:
Tonight the quill refuses me.
Ink recoils like tide retreating from a moon that has forgotten its own gravity.
I stand on the salt-white seabed of the page, palm cooling on the dead sand,
wondering where the syllables went.
Once they came leaping—silver fish flicking water into stanzas—
now they circle beyond the breakers, eyes opaque as sealed jars.
I mouth their names; they do not answer.
The old rhythms, chimes that used to swing in my chest,
are clocks with unplugged cords, hands surrendered to noon.
Am I lessened or merely emptied,
a field after harvest, hollow but patient for seed?
I listen for the invisible tractor of inspiration,
hear only the parliament of crows debating in the wires.
I lift the pen again, stake of a forgotten claim,
and sign my silence.
Yet even that gesture smudges, a gray petal dropped from some earlier bloom.
Perhaps this is not loss but winter:
sap steeping in roots, roots remembering darkness,
darkness remembering stars.
If spring will come, let it arrive slow and ignorant of my fear,
so that the first bud may surprise even the poet
who could no longer imagine green.

instance_metrics.response:
He woke to find the Muse packing light, rolling constellations into a suitcase the size of an eyelash.
“It isn’t you,” she whispered, buttoning the horizon around her throat, “I just need a latitude with fresher verbs.”
He wanted to protest, but the verbs themselves had already abandoned him, hailing cabs made of commas, tipping the driver with forgotten chords.
So he sat in the doorway as she left, feet numb from the sudden draft where metaphors used to burn.
Neighbors waved, unknowing; the sky performed its ordinary blue.
But within his tongue a library caught fire.
Shelves collapsed in hushes.
The cardinal that once nested in his larynx flew out, leaving splinters of red feather and the echo of morning.
Days passed.
Letters drifted in the mailbox like dead moths.
He tried to read them but the alphabet kept rearranging into doorways that led nowhere.
Then one afternoon, a child knocked, selling seashells that hummed of distant breakers.
He placed one against the exile of his ear.
Inside, a single syllable knocked back—timid, barefoot, asking if there was room to grow.
He smiled, set a kettle on, made a bed out of blank paper.

instance_metrics.response:
breakage

a poet loses his power for poetry—
the announcement arrives
split across morning’s windshield,
spider-veined like guilt.

pages, once wings,                           stall.
spines of books count vertebrae of dust.

                                    silence is not quiet
                                    it is a room tiled in ticking.

he inventories the missing:

1 ink, still breathing but anaemic
2 metaphors, feral, last seen by river
17 verbs, disguised as spoons in a vacant diner
all the vowels, kidnapped by the mouth of a stray cello.

he posts flyers: HAVE YOU SEEN THIS SONG?
reward: a heart returned to beating.

night folds over day
folds again
origami of hours that cannot fly.

he swallows moonlight like aspirin,
overdoses on silver,
dreams of a dusk where words forget they are wounded.

dawn—
a sparrow coughs syllables into morning.
one lands on his shoulder, shy, undecided.

he does not snatch it.
instead he opens the window of his pulse
lets wind translate vacancy to invitation.

somewhere, between inhale and exhale,
a line forms, slight, unconfident—
but alive.

loss, it seems,
is only the temporary muting
of a throat rehearsing thunder.

instance_metrics.response:
In the bakery of language the ovens have gone cold.
The baker-poet stares at racks of unbaked sonnets, dough sagging like disappointed moons.
“Flour shortage,” he sighs, but knows the problem is yeast—those lively metaphors that puff and sing.
Yesterday they marched out wearing protest signs: NO MORE KNEADING, MORE NEEDING.
Now the shop smells only of memory and burnt coffee.
He tries to whistle a rhyme; the tune dribbles like lukewarm glaze.
Customers peer through the glass: critics, pigeons, former lovers.
On the door a chalkboard still promises Fresh Villanelles Daily, but the chalk is rain-soaked, syllables dripping down to the curb.
In desperation he opens the old recipe box: a pinch of astonishment, two cups of cadence, forgiveness to taste.
Nothing helps.
He considers selling hardware instead—verbs repurposed as hammers, adjectives as screws—yet every screw is stripped, every hammer soft.
Then a child wanders in hunting crumbs.
She hums a tune that doesn’t rhyme, leaves fingerprints shaped like question marks on the counter.
Something in the poet twitches, rises, a timid bubble in the dough.
Perhaps tomorrow the ovens will warm again; tonight, he writes her song on the receipt.

instance_metrics.response:
The hill he once climbed for sunrise now greets him with mute gold, as if the light itself forgot its adjectives.
Grasshead plumes bow but refuse to whisper.
Even the river, lifelong gossip, carries its stories underwater where his ears can’t reach.
A poet loses his power for poetry, and the world complies by locking its doors.
He walks the meadow in borrowed silence, hand tracing the air where simile used to hover like dragonflies.
They are gone, those electric insects that stitched sky to thought.
He kneels, presses cheek to earth, hoping the soil will dictaphone a root-song.
Nothing.
Only the slow pulse of consequential time.
Clouds roll over, stoic sheep without bells.
He remembers her voice—Muse? Lover? Both?—telling him language is a tide, not a possession.
Perhaps the moon has turned away for a season.
Perhaps he must practice ebb.
So he stays until night fills the valley, stars lighting like cautious candles.
One falls.
He makes no wish.
Instead he listens, truly listens, to the dark between cricket chirrups, and there, barely audible, a word uncurls, newborn, wet as dew.
He cups it, grateful as rain after drought.

In the hush where syllables once sparkled like meteors

He remembers the earlier climate—

and every comma was a door ajar.
Now the weather has changed.
Clouds of blankness roll in,
thick, patient, untranslatable.
Neighbors still call him “poet,”
but the title is a jacket he cannot fasten;
buttons are missing, threads fray.
He walks the market, weighing oranges
by their simple gravity,
envying fruit for needing no metaphor.
At night his heart pumps silent footnotes
to poems never written.
He stacks them by the bed,
invisible pages rustling whenever he turns.
Yet loss is also a cadence.
Silence has its own bold ink.
In the cavern between two vanished words
crickets rehearse immaculate choruses.
Perhaps power is not possession
but the ability to surrender,
to listen until language returns home
wearing new shoes, carrying stories
of deserts crossed, of names forgotten,
and says, Father, I have found you
another dawn.

His muse took a city bus at dawn,
left no forwarding address.
He searched the usual stations—
coffee steam, rain on tin roofs,

but the seats were empty of music.
He tried bribing the alphabet,
arranging the letters like dominoes,
hoping one brave vowel would fall
and start the chain.
Nothing tipped.
So he hired a locksmith
to pry open metaphors.
Inside he found only dust,
old applause, the smell of used stages.
Days stretched elastic and snapped.
He fed his notebooks to the fireplace,
watched sentences curl into charcoal snakes.
Neighbors thought the smoke smelled sweet;
they did not know it was vocabulary.
In the vacant space he heard
details he’d never bothered to record—
a dishwasher’s sigh, the slight wobble
in the earth’s spin at 2 a.m.
He began cataloging them
without ornament or rhyme,
just bare, bright facts.
The world, relieved,
let down its guard and spoke plainly.
That plainness was so terrible, so pure,
it became another kind of poem,
one that wrote itself
and needed no poet at all.

Libraries used to salute when he walked in,
rows of spines snapping to rhythmic attention,
ready to be drafted into his campaigns of image.
He could rouse an army from a single bookmark.
Now he enters as a ghost.
Dust motes ignore him, sunbeams do not rearrange.
He opens a book and finds blank chapters
where epics once growled.
He questions the librarian—
she shrugs, says the silence requested privacy.
He surrenders his library card,
returns home to inventory the damage.
Desk: intact but meaningless.
Ink: plentiful but insolvent.
Heart: beating but off-key.
He sits on the porch counting traffic lights
changing color down the hill—
green, amber, red, a trilogy
that needs no commentary.
Kids on bicycles shout raw syllables
that rise, collide, dissolve.
He envies them their reckless grammar.
As evening slides its velvet across the sky,
he admits what he has known all day:
a poet may lose his power for poetry
the way a candle loses flame in sunrise—
not by failing, but by being outshone.
So he lifts his face to the vast scripture of twilight,
lets it read itself aloud,
and applauds with both empty hands.

inside the chest where stories incubate.
When dawn cracked open,
he cupped the yolk-bright light,
but did not write.

wary of domestication.
Some powers return only
when you promise never to wield them

instance_metrics.response:
You who once summoned tempests with a tap of the wrist,

or it may carry new minerals,
strange glitter that refuses prior templates.
If it comes, greet it like a traveler,
offer neither leash nor dam.
Let it decide what shape of poem
the valley of your voice can hold,
or if no poem is needed at all.

There is a law which guarantees
the river will remember every pebble,
that every secret tremor in the leaf
will echo through the muscle of the wind,
and in its wake a hush of silver silt
will settle over someone's waiting heart.
It governs with an unrecorded ink, unseen,
binding breath to breath, footfall to distant shore.
Call it consequence, call it compassion,
call it the stitcher of scattered, impossible threads;
still it moves without negotiation.
Cast a stone of kindness, the circles return—
maybe seasons later, maybe in another name,
but always the water carries it back.
Cast a stone of scorn, and feel the same rings,
cold and self-reflecting, tighten round the wrist.
The galaxies swirl by its compass;
tidelines flex to its pulse;
the small blush in a stranger’s eye
awakens because it knew you once in passing.
Nothing drifted is ever entirely lost,
nothing grasped is ever fully owned.
Between the first pulse of a violin string
and the last sigh of summer dust
the law moves, patient, luminous,
guaranteeing that what we send
is already on its patient road home.

There is a law which guarantees
the bruised seed will someday open,
even when pocketed by frost,
even when buried beneath profanity and asphalt.
It is not written in statutes or courtrooms,
but on the tongue of rain.
A single dark kernel waits, listening
to the slow verdict of thaw,
and nothing—no decree, no fence of wire—
can overturn that ruling.
Yes, the ravens may convene,
the smokestacks may cough their black objections,
the turned backs of hurried people
may insist the alley stay an alley.
Still, chlorophyll rehearses
its tiny symphony in secret.
One morning the pavement cracks,
like a gavel striking marble,
and a blade the color of newborn laughter
lifts its face into the astonished world.
The law goes further:
where one green voice rises,
others catch the rumor.
Rust becomes trellis,
graffiti becomes mural of bees.
Children gather the evidence—
pocketfuls of petals,
handprints of humus—and find for the plaintiff, Hope.
By dusk the city smells of wet loam,
and the court of Heaven is adjourned
with unanimous applause.

There is a law which guarantees
the clock will never stutter backward,
that the teacup, once fractured,
will not knit itself whole except in dream.
Physicists sign its affidavit as entropy,
grand custodian of irreversibility.
But I have seen the rule wearing softer robes.
When grandmother forgot my name,
it was the same arrow, slipping forward,
carrying letters off the page of her mind.
When autumn unbuttons the maples,
the law is merely red confession.
We chase reversal—photographs, prayers,
stories told by the hearth until the syllables are ash—
but the ledger remains balanced.
Still, there is mercy in the statute:
though nothing returns unchanged,
everything transforms into usable light.
Cells compost into soil,
soil calls up mushrooms that taste of distant rain.
The song I failed to finish yesterday
falls like loose electrons into today’s melody.
Even grief, accumulating like snow
against the door, begins to glint,
reflecting a morning willing to move on.
Thus time’s stern decree
is also an artist’s clause—
all fragments will be recast,
all endings serve as openings
for another hand to lift the pen.

There is a law which guarantees

will be adopted by the earth.

the vultures circled under that charter:
no fire may languish, no story go unconsumed.
In hidden caverns salamanders nursed the coals.
In whale-road trenches mermaids braided emberweed
to keep the heat alive.
Millennia later a shepherd, cold and curious,
struck flint upon iron and felt the treaty flare
in the hush between two heartbeats.
So begins each legend:
petition, exile, unforeseen resurrection.
Consider the lost harp of Orpheus,
swept to sea, strings salted and gone.
By clause of the same ancient statute,
wind learned to hum its chords through pine,

named new stars after remembered lovers.
Everything forsaken acquires a guardian—
hollow bones echo with future flutes,
broken swords redeploy as ploughshares,
tears gather in secret aquifers
to sweeten the tongues of unborn camels.
Empires may decree oblivion;
the cosmos, older and quieter, only nods.
It has already filed its counterbrief:
all sparks travel, none are snuffed;
the dark itself is tinder awaiting breath.

in the laundromat of human hearts.

dots with dots, argyles with argyles, hopes with hopes.

against lint and gravity.

Some cosmic clerk stamped the paperwork:
Desire—approved, effective immediately.
Since then the statute has played out faithfully.

with the warmth of your mug-scented palms.
Even disagreements tumble, soften,
emerging brighter, resilient at the seams.
Skeptics appeal; they point to closets
stuffed with widowed garments.
We just shrug, secret holders of precedent:
Love, once sparked, cannot unravel
without simultaneously knitting something new.
There is a law which guarantees,
and in the spin of ordinary moments,
we keep signing our names beneath it.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

instance_metrics.response:
The breezes waved the silver grass beside the sleeping mere,
Where once the antlered gods convened to name the primal year.
Long before the iron plough, before the bell and book,
The land was kept by murmured vows that only rivers took.
At equinox the chosen two would light the patient flame,
And cast a mirror on the lake to tell the season’s name.
Tonight I walk the ancient path by lantern, hush, and rune,
My shadow doubling like a hawk against a jealous moon.
I carry seeds of yarrow, ash, and prophecy unknown,
To barter with the borderlands where flesh and myth are sewn.
Upon the mound the standing stones begin their argent hum;
They drink the turning of the wind, and drum, and drum, and drum.
The grass divides like silver fur beneath a giant’s stride,
Revealing glassy corridors where elder spirits bide.
A voice, neither male nor female, spills like tidal sand:
"Remember us, remember earth; forget the master’s brand."
Then silence wraps the meadow close, the stars regain their glass,
And dawn arrives, a modest scribe, to archive what shall pass.
I scatter seeds, extinguish flame, and thank the watching mass:
Tomorrow’s gods will waken when the breezes stroke the grass.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

The breezes waved the silver grass the night I chose to stay,
When leaving felt like gravity, and home was far away.
The road behind was littered bright with versions I outgrew,
Like ticket stubs to tragedies whose plots I never knew.
I stopped beside a restless field where moonlight had resigned,
And let the hush declare itself a counsellor of mind.
No doctrine came, no thunderbolt, just blade on gentle blade,
Performing every doubt I’d nursed, then teaching it to fade.
They bent without surrendering, they bowed but did not break,
Rehearsing, in that simple arc, the posture I should take.
I thought of all the brittle words I’d tossed to prove I cared,
And how apology can bloom when vulnerability is shared.
The wind revised my narrative, erased the needless gloss,
Leaving only oxygen, forgiveness, chlorophyll, and loss.
A cricket tuned its humble lute to underscore release,
While fireflies like floating commas paused to punctuate the peace.
I breathed until the rhythm matched the pulse beneath the grass,
And felt the courage wilderness can lend a wanderer pass.
When dawn unfolded watermark across the sky of brass,
I turned, unworried who I was, and thanked the silver grass.

The breezes waved the silver grass,

floated like undone buttons.

among the reed-thin syllables of wind;
so I listened, learning vowels of rustle,
consonants of sway, verbs that arc and bend.
In that fluent hush the hours thinned,

and I remembered rivers I have never seen,
horizons I have yet to travel, names
I was supposed to answer to but won't.

The breezes waved the silver grass,
a thousand tuning forks
for the invisible.

I.
air writes on water—
circle of minnows trembles;
reed shadows applaud.

sickle moon hanging,
whetstone chirp of katydid—
night prepares its bread.

III.
fallen star cools off
on the blacksmith anvil sky—
skylark sparks at dawn.

Between these sparks I walk,
stringing each brief image
like beads of chilled glass,
carrying them in my pocket
for afternoons that forget to sing.

IV.
old scarecrow confides
in the wind, sleeves outstretched—
no one gives reply.

V.
train whistle distant,
steel echo curls through barley—
fox pauses to listen.

The chain lengthens—
minute mirrors catching weather,
passing it hand to hand,
until the entire plain
glows with borrowed rumor.

VI.
thunderhead thinking
hard about a revolution—
sparrows keep voting.

At last the final link:
our breath, two leaves unsure
which side of the sky to fall.
On exhale, a tiny wave,
no larger than a promise,
ripples the silver grass again.

their drumbeat hearts took hold;

keep every story told.

So now I travel town to town
with verses in my pack;
wherever grasses shimmer down
I feel those breezes back.

Chorus of the Meadow

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A rippling choir of fragile blades;
They sang of dawns that softly pass
And moonlit, moth–illumined shades.

They shimmered like a mirrored sea
Where clouds set sail on foamy white,
And every hushed gust set them free
To dance the slow waltz of the light.

A thrush upon a leaning reed
Beat time with mottled, speckled throat;
Its slender song sowed hidden seed
That blossomed in each trembling note.

Below, a beetle rolled its star—
A pearl of dew in polished shell—
While distant hills, still faint and far,
Held secrets they would never tell.

I lay, a pilgrim on the loam,
My heartbeat matched the meadow’s hymn;
In silver throes it bade me roam
Beyond horizon’s hazy rim.

Yet when I rose, the field remained,
An ancient page forever turned;
The wind, the grass, the light unchained—
All lessons learned, yet still unlearned.

So wanderer, when dusk is cast,
And shadows knot the cooling reeds,
Remember how the silver grass
Gives voice to all we are—and need.

Inheritance

The breezes waved the silver grass,

a letter from the earth addressed
to everyone who ever felt unnamed.

storm, to the empty page before

I stood knee-deep in shimmering blades,

thousands of mirrored veins. Each
stem trembled, not in fear, but
anticipation, as though something
unseen were about to open a door.

My grandmother blew soap bubbles
into this same field when it was wheat;
my father camped here when it lay fallow; now
I witness its silver turning, the moment
between pulse and release.

The wind keeps nothing, yet carries
everything: pollen, rumor, laughter,
the smell of rain on copper soil.
Soon, autumn will comb these hills
with fire, and winter will button them

leans only to listen, to teach me the
shape of surrender.

When I leave, I’ll pocket a seed.
A silent syllable of belonging,
ready to sprout whenever my
heart forgets its language.

The breezes waved the silver grass, and the whole prairie seemed to breathe—long, careful inhales stitched to patient exhales. Ballad of the Wandering Lute

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A traveler tuned his lute;
His cloak was stitched with starlit tass
And roads of dust and soot.

He sang of citadels of jade
And dragons carved in snow;
Of lovers lost in evening’s fade,
Of rivers’ undertow.

The meadow bent to hear his tale,
Each blade a listening ear;
His notes rode on the roaming gale
Till even hawks drew near.

Between two chords, his voice grew low—
A hush fell on the land;
He told how hearts, like seeds, must go
When destiny commands.

An echo answered from the hills,
A flute no hands had played;
Ghost shepherds guiding phantom mills
Across the moonlit glade.

The traveler smiled, unstrung his lute,
Left silence as a vow;
For music, once it takes its root,
Outlives the who and how.

At dawn, the wanderer was gone,
His footprints choked with dew;
Yet when the sunlight lingered on,
The silver grass still knew.

And so it sways in rhythmic swell,
A chorus without name,
Repeating what no tongue can tell—
The song behind the flame.

enough to nourish the gaps in every family story.
But I leave one recipe behind, slipped between silver blades,
for another wanderer to find,
so the field will never go hungry
and the wind may keep its taste for words.

I sit with backpack, cracked thermos, phone turned face-down like a petulant oracle refusing prophecy. Somewhere beyond the hedgerow, diesel engines keep the economy thrumming; but their pulse reaches me only as a distant cartographer’s dotted line. I map by other metrics today: the angle of a dragonfly’s hover, the radius of a cow’s slow orbit, the percussive applause of cottonwood leaves rehearsing thunder. My calendar melts completely when a meadowlark steps onto a stalk, feathered diplomat negotiating gravity. Thirty seconds— maybe an hour— pass before she lifts away, treaty signed in invisible ink. The grass stands up again, shakes off the meeting, resumes its silver rumors. I remember breathing. I remember not scrolling. I remember sending a quiet message to nobody: still here, still listening, bars full, battery infinite. Even the clouds reply with textured thumbs-up shadows sliding over hills.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

instance_metrics.response:
"The breezes waved the silver grass," quoth dawn,
And gilded larks ascended courtly skies.
In dewy halls where shepherd knelt alone
His breath was prayer, his gaze a soft surmise.
For every blade did bow as burnished spear,
Aligned in ranks before the coming king;
Yet war was none, nor clamor born of fear,
But peace so vast it taught the stones to sing.
The brook recited psalms in liquid tongue,
While willows wove an organ’s velvet drone;
Each note entwined the hour, young yet unsung,
And sealed a covenant of green and bone.
O mortal heart, attend this quiet lore:
When tempests roll and tyrants clatter steel,
Recall the field where simple breezes bore
Such argent pennons on their gentle keel.
No empire holds a standard half so fair,
No law so sure as sunlight, leaf, and air.
Let memory be armor wrought of hush,
Let kindness be the banner you upraise;
For kingdoms fade like thistles into dust,
But mercies linger, lighting yet untrodden ways.
Go, wanderer, while amber summers last;
Drink twilight's wine from humble wooden cups;
Hear cricket choirs keep time with distant stars;
Trade every doubt for wind-carved syllables;
And carry dawn within your traveler’s pack.

instance_metrics.response: The breezes waved the silver grass, and the sensors logged the oscillation: amplitude three point six centimeters, frequency corresponding to a lullaby nobody had bothered to teach the new colonists. I closed the report. Out across the plain, the terraformers’ towers steamed like red giants cooling, but the meadow paid them no attention. It had grown itself from a single crate of engineered seed, bartered from Earth for a promise of allegiance. Now it whispered in dialects older than rocketry. I walked between the bio-lumescent blades, suit unsealed, helmet tucked beneath my arm like a moon relinquished. The air tasted of mint and unclaimed holidays. Each step triggered a hush of silver leaves brushing my boots, scanning, sampling, deciding. My implants filled with data— chlorophyll counts, wind vectors, subterranean moisture— yet the essential detail escaped the graphs: the field was singing to the planet, persuading it toward gentleness. I wondered if that argument might include us. Night’s first satellite rose, polished and impersonal, but its light merely gilded the grass, joining the choir. When the breeze shifted, seedpods lifted, drifting upward like pocket-sized parachutes, choreographing tomorrow’s cartography. I filed another report: recommendation— listen harder, upgrade humility.

instance_metrics.response: The breezes waved the silver grass, and grandma said it meant the ancestors were combing the world’s hair. I was eight, skeptical yet curious; I watched the ripples flow like shy laughter across scalp of earth. We carried buckets toward the pump, metal knocking like distant drums. Each gust cooled the water splashed on our calves, stamping temporary constellations on dust. Years later, city bound, I ride an elevator’s stale breath seven floors, exit into fluorescent weather. No grass here, only paperwork in captive rows, but sometimes the air-conditioner stutters— a small breeze— and the pages quiver just so. I remember the field then, remember grandma’s hands braiding my own unruly mane, telling stories of journeys done barefoot beneath clouds shaped like doors. At lunch I walk to the corporate roof where someone, perhaps a lonely intern, has snuck planter boxes filled with native switchgrass. I run my palms along their slender spears; they bow and rise, silver in hard sunlight, answering a language I finally welcome. I whisper a promise to comb gently through whatever world remains. Wind over bright stems— a forgotten lullaby returns, seed by seed.

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—five beads on a grey rosary.
I finger them before dawn, bleary devotion, coffee-steam incense.
A shuttle bus monks me to cubicles, luminescent cloisters
where spreadsheets chant. Noon tolls; plastic-fork communion.
I swallow microwaved psalms of sodium, dream of deserts
made of sugar. Afternoon drags its squeaking mop
across the clock’s tiled corridor. At five, release unbuttons
my collar; crowds pour from elevators like loose change.
Tracks converge toward flats glued to skyline, boxes
stacked like unanswered letters. Home, eat, sleep—the beads
slide back. Television glows—an aquarium of noise.
Clock hands unstitch the daylight like nervous tailors,
but leave frayed threads dangling on my wrists.
Where other lives swim luminous and mute, eyes close;
dreams contraband the ordinary, smuggling forests
through eyelids, folding oceans in shirt pockets.
Tomorrow customs will seize them, but now I wander
untaxed horizons, barefoot, refusing the bell.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—algorithmic mantra pulsing through the colony’s PA.
Dawn blooms artificial; domes tint from amber to sterile white,
shocking borrowed circadian circuits awake. Oxygen scrubbers hum
hymns of productivity while we strap on exosuits streaked
with Martian iron. We mine the rusted marrow of this planet
for metals that will build another identical dome two dunes away.
Noon vibrates in the suit’s stomach alarm: nutrient paste injected
through a straw, flavored faintly with nostalgia. In the airlock mirror
I glimpse Earth on my shoulder patch—a blue marble where the chant
was born. Evening, we trudge back along a crimson horizon so thin
it could snap, depositing samples like sacrificial offerings at the lab.
Home becomes a hexagonal berth, personal gravity at 0.9 so dreams
float slightly above the pillow. Eat, sleep: the final commands.
Yet somewhere between REM cycles a rogue subroutine stirs,
whispering of oceans unroofed by glass, of wind undistilled,
of sunrise unannounced by speakers. I wake before the lights,
palm against the dome, and imagine cracking it open just to hear silence.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Wake. The streetlights yawn off. Wake with sparrows still rehearsing.
Wake, kettle banging its little cymbal. Wake—a body recalling passwords
before it remembers prayers.

Work. Fingerprint accepted, headset on. Work while the fluorescent sun
never sets. Work inside sentences that sell things no one loves.
Work until language itself clocks out.

Home. Pass graffiti you could recite backward. Home to a hallway smelling
of neighbor’s curry, dog shampoo, someone’s divorce. Home, remove the
name badge, the grin stitched to it. Home where silence waits, patient
as an unpaid bill.

Eat. Microwave spins a tiny planet of leftovers. Eat standing, scrolling,
refreshing. Eat the news, the ads, the envy disguised as inspiration.
Eat until taste forgets difference.

Sleep. Screen light lingers on eyelids like afterimages of fireworks you missed.
Sleep with alarms nested one inside another. Sleep shallow, dreams buffering.
Sleep, while the to-do list sleepwalks across the brain, scribbling anew.

Yet—between beats of that mechanical litany—a thin music threads.
Wake to it. Work with it. Home it. Eat its impossible color.
Sleep inside its widening chord. Repeat, but differently.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep:
five stones the river rolls
from mountain dawn to delta dusk.
I, a leaf, ride the cadence,
turning in eddies of calendar squares.

Wake—dew writes calligraphy
on glass; a robin rehearses my name.
I promise to remember, fail by nine.

Work—city asphalt radiates
noon’s metallic sermon.
Emails flock like starlings,
shift shape, settle, scatter again.

Home—train windows splice horizon films
against my reflection.
A child across the aisle draws galaxies
on fogged glass; I borrow them later.

Eat—kitchen light soaks tomatoes redder
than traffic lights I ignored.
Between bites, basil lifts
a green flag of surrender to taste.

Sleep—moon walks barefoot
across the ceiling.
Dreams, small lantern fish,
orbit the dark, offering glow.

Morning will tumble the stones again,
but every smooth revolution steals a grain.
One evening they will click together
like dice into an unforeseen number,
and the river will pause, wondering
where it was rushing. I will climb the bank,
feet dripping, naming clouds
with nothing to trade but breath.

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—thrum of a buried ferris wheel
cycling beneath the skin of days. At six a.m. my car ascends,
rattling through fog to an apex where sunrise flashes like a cheap
camera, then plunges into cubicle catacombs smelling of toner
and apprehension. Lunch is halfway up the next arc, a paper plate
haloed by fluorescent glare. Descent again, the garage’s algorithmic
voice counts backward: five, four, three… Tires kiss asphalt darkness;
I pretend it’s applause.

Night stretches the wheel into a Möbius strip. Remote in hand,
I pace its single endless side, passing commercials, dishes,
social feeds—same landscape, different lighting. At midnight the strip
folds into origami: a crane flapping discontent inside my chest.
I pin it under the pillow and call it rest.

Yet sometimes, between gears, a gearless moment blooms: chorus
of street cats, scent of rain on copper, pulse reminding me this ride
is powered by blood, not clockwork. In that hush the buried ferris wheel
sprouts like a seed, busting concrete. For one revolution I rise
without passengers, naming constellations nobody has sold yet.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
“Wake, work, home, eat sleep,” the commuter chants,
as wheels of morning trains hammer an iron rosary.
Grey dawn hovers above the platform,
squeezing oranges of light over newspaper skulls.
Routine is a cage made of invisible wire;
it hums, it tickles, it claims to keep you warm.
Yet somewhere between the tick of badge scanners
and the fluorescent gossip of cubicles,
a stowaway bluebird knocks at your ribs: remember.

At noon the copy-key whirs,
the printer births contracts like sterile rabbits,
coffee queues snake, hiss, dissolve.
We type, delete, comply, comply,
until the bluebird swallows a staple and grows quiet.

Evening drops us like coins into apartment slots.
Microwaves glow, chairs accept our knees,
screens drift across our faces like patient drones.
“Wake, work, home, eat sleep” echoes again,
softer, as though spoken underwater.

But tonight, inexplicably,
you open the window instead of the fridge.
Streetlight pours in like raw honey;
the bluebird coughs out the staple, shakes its feathers,
sings an off-key chord that splits the wire.
You taste air unprocessed by ventilation,
and the chant, startled, forgets the next line.

Prelude:
Some say a life is merely stitched by hours,
plain garments made to weather wind and rain;
but seams can loosen, letting in the flowers,
whose roots crack concrete softly, grain by grain.

Wake, work, home, eat sleep—five beads upon a string,
Each day I thumb them, murmuring the tune;
A humble rosary to which I cling,
While months revolve like phases of the moon.
Yet in the seam where dawn unzips the night,
A violet spark escapes the ordered plan;
It pirouettes upon the cuff of light,
Inviting me to leave the marching span.
I hesitate, enchanted by its dare,
For habit’s hands are velvet-lined, but tight;
Still, something wilder shivers in the air,
A distant drum that stirs the appetite.

Coda:
Tomorrow’s wheel may tighten spoke and rim,
Yet I will walk with petal stains on skin;
For once the chant is carved instead of whim,

The microwave dings.

Night.
Screens fluoresce like canned galaxies.
I scroll, I like, I scroll.

Finally darkness—sleep? Nah.
Just rehearsal for the next encore.

Wake, work, home, eat sleep—
but one day I’m gonna
scratch that vinyl,
let the silence hiss,

the city outside the windows scrolling backward
like a film searching for a forgotten frame.

But tonight a typo appears in the schedule:
WAKE, WANDER, WORK? The conductor’s hat blooms feathers,
fare gates blossom into mirrors and ask for stories instead of coins.
I pay with a childhood memory—exact change—and step
into a carriage hung with moon-rind lanterns.

Co-travelers wear suits made of discarded minutes;
we trade pockets. I receive a handful of noon thunder,
oranges still warm with solar laughter.
We peel them. Clocks leak.

At the next stop, HOME is scratched out, replaced by HORIZON.
The serpent shivers, unlocked by a single letter.
We disembark onto a shoreline built from office chairs;
waves shimmy through keyboard reefs.
We eat constellations spooned from a thermos,
then fold ourselves into hammocks woven from canceled meetings.

Sleep drifts by on a paper boat.
I climb in, tuck the neon loop beneath the oars,

Balancing galaxies in marbles, rules yet unwritten.

Running barefoot through dishwater, dripping verbs.

Tomorrow the stones will roll again,
Rattle the same cage rhythm.

A feather, a ripple, a giggle, a stanza.

instance_metrics.response: Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—so the metronome ticks, parceling daylight into obedient squares. I rise with the chrome cough of the kettle, salute the indifferent sun through slatted blinds, and march down digital corridors where avatars pretend to smile. My hands perform their practiced ballet across glass and key, birthing spreadsheets, dispatching missives, steady as a loom weaving numbers into temporary cloth. Noon arrives like a brief carnival: microwave trumpets, plastic plates, coworker jokes recycled from last year’s holiday party. Then the carousel spins again. Five o’clock loosens its invisible leash, and I wander back through traffic, a salmon of steel and headlights. At home, walls receive my silence, television pours blue syrup on the couch. I dine with scrolling headlines, feed on headlines feeding on me. Finally, mattress opens its quiet envelope, and I slide inside, stamped, addressed to tomorrow. Yet somewhere between throb and hush, I hear a subversive rhythm—heartbeats tapping Morse against the cage. They spell out possible verbs beyond the rote procession: dive, wander, bloom, revolt. I fall asleep memorizing them, hoping they survive the dawn. To greet a sky ungridded by clocks, a sky that sings in irregular, generous strides.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response: Wake, work, home, eat, sleep: the five iron rings forged by a minor god of habit. At dawn he clamps the first around my ankle, yanking me from dreamwater. Coffee is the blacksmith’s hammer; it sparks against thought until I glow with compliance. The second ring snaps shut as I log in, pixels assembling like obedient soldiers. I push boulders of email up endless hills, whistle while descent resets the weight. The noon bell is a trick—its bronze bloom promises flight, but lunch is merely a lighter stone. The third and fourth rings, home and food, appear softer: upholstered, scented with garlic and basil. Yet velvet still restrains. I orbit sink and stove, perform domestic astronomy, my body the moon tugged by unpaid bills. The fifth ring glints beneath blankets. It tightens politely, whispering lullabies about tomorrow’s productivity. I sink, not into rest, but into a holding cell of dreams pre-approved for neutrality—no rebellions, no sudden kisses on strangers’ foreheads, no storms of desert color. Still, I stash a flint behind my eyelids. If one dream grows wild enough to brush it, sparks may melt links, letting dawn arrive unshackled, naming itself anything but Monday, or Tuesday, or any label that dulls the tongue.

Domino three flips me onto the couch at 6:07 p.m., where furniture and I exchange existential shrugs. I scroll social media until my thumb files for workers’ comp. The fourth domino is pasta, overcooked but enthusiastic, devoured while streaming a documentary on people who definitely have their lives together. The final tile is a pillow shaped like resignation. a rarer currency than gold.

But minutes are mutinous. Already the cyclist has vanished, the umbrella folds into a store, the dog has found fresher scents. The photograph changes exposure; sky tilts toward pewter. I raise the mug, sip the lukewarm middle of morning, and sign the treaty anew: the world may proceed; I will witness. That’s my window. This minute. Into the night forest she went, 
following a rumor of breath beneath bark.
With every step, trees parted like curtains,
revealing a black door bound in roots.

Shelves of rain, jars of orchard dust, 
blueprints for afternoons where laughter grows wild.

At dawn the river remembered itself.

Still, the villagers ask how she did it.
She only smiles, lantern now bright with new moths:

Under her watch the shadows safely creep.

owls by a wisdom of silence.

Let your pulse slow to an ancient drum,
echo of mothers who hummed by fires
when language was only wind in throats.
Let spine loosen its tower,
mind unlace its armored boots.
There is no test at dawn,
only another blank stage awaiting footprints.
Sleep is not escape but agreement—
a signature acknowledging shared kinship
with moss, nebula, and stone.
Permit the world to rotate without your steering.
Permit yourself to be turned.
Let the night sleep, let yourself sleep,
and wake inside a room widened by stars.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Let the night sleep—
Fold its velvet over the bruised horizon,
Sow silence in the furrows of glassy streets,
Pin each wandering worry to a stitched constellation.
We have pressed against hours like anxious moths
Fluttering at porch lamps, burning our soft edges;
Now extinguish every bulb with a soft exhale.
Permit the moon to loosen its pale laces,
To drift like cooled milk across a cathedral sky.
Crickets tune down the orchestra of grass.
Wind returns unpaid debts of fragrance from unseen pines.
Inside, hearts unclench, beating slower, kinder.
We pile our grievances in a wicker basket,
Set it adrift on the dark river of forget.
Let dreams unroll, long silk banners of impossible color;
Let the coyotes revise their rough lullaby
Into a song even shutters can believe.
Somewhere an engine hiccups once, then surrenders;
Somewhere a lost star finds its socket and dims.
Let the night sleep, its heavy eyelids drooping
Over the watchful barns, the restless harbors,
Let it dream of dawn not yet born,
Of cockerels practicing sotto voce,
Of dew rehearsing its silver vowels.
We will meet again when the sky blushes,
When night wakes refreshed, and yields the day.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Let the night sleep beneath scaffolds of extinguished neon,
Let it curl into the emptied coffee cups on rain-licked sidewalks.
We have wrung the city for its final syllable,
Hammered keys, chased deadlines, chewed through cables of glow.
Now close the laptop like a clam reclaiming its pearl;
Slide shutters over the trembling marquee of thought.
Taxis idle homeward, yellow eyes shutting;
Billboards forget their hunger for attention.
On the rooftop, a satellite dish lowers its head,
Listening only to the quiet breathing of clouds.
We sprinkle sand into digital gears,
Mute the algorithmic chatter of late feeds.
Pigeons roost in the sign that once yelled SALE,
Dreaming of breadcrumbs shaped like continents.
Even sirens soften to a blue murmur,
Cruising boulevards as if stroking a sleeping cat.
Let the night sleep, city—
Let it borrow your bridges as pillows,
Your fountains as white static to hush nightmares.
Streetlamps click off, one domino at a time,
Until darkness stands whole, uncluttered, holy.
In that hush, hearts recalibrate to analog tempo,
Breaths align with the slow semaphore of stars.
When morning unscrews the lid of light,
The city will wake wearing new vowels of promise,
Ready to speak gently again.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Let the night sleep, whispered Nyx from her cavern,
She gathered her sable shawl across the firmament,
Extinguishing each restless comet like a mother
Plucking stray sparks from a child’s blanket.
The gods had quarreled, their thunder in disarray;
Mortals had prayed until their tongues were ash.
So she lowered a hush over Olympus and alley alike,
A cool palm on the fevered brow of worlds.
Owls folded their parchments of prophecy,
Foxes sheathed their razored curiosity.
Rivers slowed, holding moonlight like suspended breath;
Even time, that tireless courier, sat on a stump and dozed.
Let the night sleep, crooned Nyx,
For dreams are the embers that rebuild the daylight,
And chaos cannot follow where slumber patrols.
She braided shadows into lullabies,
Tied them to the ankles of wandering thoughts
Until they settled like children into straw beds.
Across the plains, warriors unclutched their swords,
Blades reflecting only the gentle shiver of stars.
In farms, the last lantern surrendered, faith intact.
From the horizon rose a quiet so profound
That galaxies could be heard turning pages.
When dawn finally yawned, rosy and newborn,
Even Zeus woke rested, his thunder polished with mercy.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Let the night sleep, Grandma says, pulling curtains
Like thick eyelids over the window’s worried stare.
She tucks the house in with quilts smelling of lavender
And gives the hallway a kiss goodnight.
I leave my toys exactly where battles ceased,
Knights frozen mid-charge, plastic horses rearing
At a dragon made of yesterday’s homework.
In the hush, their tiny breaths become clock ticks.
Crickets begin whispering math I don’t yet know;
A far train spells my name in Morse of steel.
But I remember: Let the night sleep.
So I turn my thoughts down to a low hum,
Scroll my breathing to the slowest setting.
The ceiling turns into a planetarium
Where glow-in-the-dark stickers map secret routes
Between tooth-fairies and tomorrow’s recess.
Mom closes the door until it’s just a pencil line,
Light thin enough for dreams to slip under.
My heartbeat knocks once, twice, then tiptoes.
Outside, the moon dogs its chain of clouds,
Guarding the yard, head on silver paws.
Pillows become snowbanks; I burrow and vanish.
Even monsters clap muffled hands over their mouths,
Waiting for sunrise to resume rehearsals.
Until then, hush—let the night sleep,
So morning can arrive like a bright new marble
Rolling from pocket to palm.

instance_metrics.response:
Let the night sleep, Captain, the ship’s AI murmured,
Dimming the corridor starscape to a violet hush.
We have sailed three parsecs beyond worry; engines
Purr like kittens behind titanium ribs.
Crew drift in pods of amber suspension,
Dreams projected on glass like silent films—
Forests they left, names they forgot to speak.
I linger at the observation deck, helmet off,
Watching nebulas exhale their ghostly incense.
Once, night meant a small village of crickets;
Now it is a cathedral the size of forever.
Yet still, the order stands: let the night sleep.
We engage the blackout protocol: holo-screens fade,
Logs auto-save, circuitry yawns to minimal hum.
Even the war we fled lifts its bruised banner
And folds it into something almost like peace.
In zero-G, teardrops become planets
Orbiting the sun of my closed fist.
I release them, prayers to any deity
That audits the quiet in interstellar miles.
Beyond the hull, meteoroids pass silently
Like notes slipped under a locked door.
When alpha cycle dawn arrives—
A bloom of radiation the color of first chances—
We will wake, calibrate hope, plot new vectors.
Until then, let the night sleep,
For in its dreaming engines, we, too, are repaired.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
People whisper anchors, beg the harbor to memorize their names,
threading longing through rope, hammering permanence into drifting docks.
Yet the sea keeps its own diary of unraveling, the moon
turns pages nightly, and gulls scrawl erasures across the surf.
I walk the pier where boards complain with practiced doubt,
feeling splinters translate each heartbeat into Morse:
keep   moving   keep   moving.
A child releases a red kite—tiny flag of planet wander—
and the wind adopts it as a stray thought.
Far beyond, freighters shoulder continents of cargo,
proving mass itself can learn to roam.

We crave a chair that never rocks, a bowl that stays full,
a map already highlighted where we should arrive.
But moss thickens only on stones that sleep;
roots, once cozy, choke their trees.
If I become still, the dust will quilt me,
thoughts will yellow like newspapers forgetful of thunder.

So let the window rattle, let promises sway like lanterns
on a rope bridge above tomorrow.
Hope is the tremor before a word is spoken,
the hush between sparks and flame.
I will remain happily unsettled—
a bird circling an invisible updraft,
drawing infinity with restless wings.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
They dream of mortar, brick, and locks that never rust,
of gardens where no seedling dares exceed its neat design.
Yet promise lives within the quiver, the twitch of travel dust;
warm embers only glow because the logs still gasp for pine.

A restless foot will drum the earth into awakened song,
its cadence splitting clay so sleeping rivers learn to roam.
The settled heart, embalmed in ease, forgets where pulses belong;
a walking heart invents new doors and names each footfall "home."

So measure not the weary miles or blistered, starlit skin,
but count instead the cracks where light leaks through the fear.
For vines that scale the battered wall announce the world begins
whenever doubt unties its sail and invites the tempest near.

Stay shaking, lover, shiver like the compass’ silver leaf;
let your axis tilt to drink strange constellations’ wine.
Only unsettled souls can resurrect an ancient grief
and rinse its ashes in the surf until the grief turns brine.

Build no statue of your longing—stone forgets the sculptor’s oath.
Carry instead a pocket full of sparks, and stride toward windswept oath.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
The city listens to itself—elevators sighing, neon ticking, rats arranging
midnight mail.  Within that low electric murmur I hear the private
prayer of every commuter: let this chair fit my spine forever, let
this paycheck be repeatable, let winter arrive on schedule.

Yet a woman at the bus stop has laced her boots with wild violets.
She smells of departures.  The queue leans away from her as if
movement were contagious.  I watch petals fall like soft detonations,
and suddenly the street seems combustible with alternatives.
If a flower can hitchhike, so can a history.

I recall Thoreau saying hope sits inside discontent the way a seed
hoards trees.  A kernel of salt waits in every tear for an ocean.
Settled is a lullaby hummed by gravity; the universe only advances
through stumbles.  Galaxies spill their guts, stars outgrow themselves,
planets chatter tectonic gossip, and here we are insisting on
perfectly folded laundry.

So I walk past my office, turn one left too many, trading
GPS for rumor.  The concrete under my shoes begins to purr—
not secure, not safe, but vividly undecided.  My pulse extends
a passport to every alley.  Tonight, I won’t arrive.  I’ll orbit.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
There was a village by the river that never flooded.  When the
elder rang the iron bell each dawn, people woke with the comfort
of repetition—same sky, same wooden bowls, same prayers.
But one spring the current grew curious, nibbled the banks,
then swallowed a row of houses in a single, shimmering gulp.

Families camped on the hillside, sleepless, staring at their drifting past.
Children pointed at moonskip fish, marveling; parents counted losses.
Grief hummed like crickets, yet amid the hum a spark of future
fluttered open, because every sentence that ends invites
another clause.

Morning: they followed the river upstream, footsteps braiding mud.
With each curve new herbs perfumed the air, new rocks colored
the water.  The roadless distance unclenched their stories.
No one asked for a bell to schedule the sun again.

haiku 1
broken walls afloat—
inside each dissolved window
an unclaimed sunrise

haiku 2
a path nobody
drew on parchment—still it grabs
our eager ankles

They never rebuilt the village.  Instead, they traded maps,
replacing roots with rivers, ringing hope in their own lungs.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
SIT STILL, they said,       & the chair sprouted bars.
        BE QUIET,           & echoes packed a suitcase.

        I kept a compass in my throat.        It wouldn’t
        swallow.

north : the word I haven’t learned yet
south : the blush of an unfinished mistake
west  : boots dripping sunrise
east  : rooms where clocks mistrust themselves

        People wish to be settled—
        like tea leaves praying for the bottom.

        But the kettle is riotous.
        Steam spells graffiti on porcelain sky:
               wander / wobble / wake

If you glue a feather to stone, does the rock fly
or the feather drown?   I refuse that experiment.

I choose the tremor, the pre-quake hush, the moment
just before rain figures out its plural.

        HOPE = velocity minus prediction.

Mapmakers fear my handwriting; it wiggles off their paper,
forks into maybe-roads, stutters back.

Tonight I’ll sleep in a parenthesis of stars,
           (        )
space enough for upheaval, little enough to feel the turn.

Tomorrow?   Another verb.

        unsettled
             unshackled
                  un-     becoming

& somewhere between the syllables
hope keeps unpacking
                         then repacking
                                      its luminous anxiety.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
People build houses of complacent brick,
Hoping the wind will forget their names,
Yet the river remembers, raps on the sill,
Saying Move, move, the map is aflame.
A child of silt and question marks,
I follow its silver uncertainties,
Past the fence where retirees gossip of rain,
Past the church where the pews dream of knees.
There is comfort in moss, in rut and routine,
In measuring life by the size of a yard,
But a heart that has slept through a thunderstorm
Wakes to discover its skin has grown hard.
So I leave my cup half-drunk on the porch,
Let spiders inherit the porch-swing throne,
I untie the boats of my planned tomorrows
And push them trembling into the unknown.
Hope is a verb made of restless vowels,
It lengthens its stride on unpaved roads;
It is hunger that laughs at the full buffet,
It is compass that spins when the lodestar explodes.
People wish to be settled, hushed and blessed;
Yet promise begins where certainty ends:
The river keeps chanting go on, go on,
And every bend invents new bends.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
The astronomer closes the dome for the night,
Charts neat ellipses in a leather book,
Pretends the heavens are tamed equations,
Objects that will stay wherever we look.
Yet above his ink the galaxies yawn,
Shifting like thought before it is spoken;
Constellations rewrite their myths mid-pulse,
Leaving his labeled sky politely broken.
I stand outside where frost bites the grass,
Let the cold unbutton my careful mind;
Every star rattles like loose debris
In the freight train of space and time.
If ever I sleep beneath locked laws,
Tie me to wonder with meteoric rope;
For only the restless inhale tomorrow,
Only the drifting discover hope.
Home is the orbit that never completes,
A swing that remembers the push of desire;
Tea kettle planets whistle for launch,
Meteor shoelaces tangle in fire.
People wish to be settled, stone and sphere,
But darkness invites renegade light:
Comets that gossip with alien dawns,
Photons that tango beyond human sight.
So raise the shutters of structured dreams,
Let the firmament pour through the seams;
Hope is the physics of being unsettled,
A universe stitched from unfinished beams.

instance_metrics.response:
Rush-hour chandeliers blink above concrete lanes,
Office towers trade shadows like secret stock;
The city pretends to be finished with us,
Its grid a lullaby of ticking clock.
Elevator hearts desire their floor,
Plastic plants never dare to grow;
Cubicles echo with stapled sighs,
While ambition learns to march in a row.
But somewhere between floor thirteen and four,
A spark slips out through a printer jam,
Runs reckless along fluorescent veins
To ignite the alley where murals began.
I follow that spark with unlaced shoes,
Past food-truck incense and siren choirs,
Into a playground of half-built cranes
That swing like prophets in steel attires.
People wish to be settled, salary-smooth,
But coins grow dull in obedient pockets.
Hope lives in scaffolds, in jackhammer jazz,
In detours scribbled on transit rockets.
So loosen the bolts of the daily script,
Let the asphalt buckle with fertile doubt;
Each pothole is a question mark
Where sprouting weeds teach traffic to shout.
When night at last forecloses the sky,
I count the neon that still misbehaves,
And find in each flickering letter of light
A promise that cities are never just graves.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
On the windowsill a packet of seeds
waits like unread mail.
They were bought for certainty—
a garden planned in tidy rows,
lettuce set beside obedient chard.
Yet weeks have passed, excuses stacked,
and still the paper coffins rustle
with unsettled prophecy.
Inside each husk, wild cartographers
argue over roots and wings,
dreaming directions the planter forgot.
I tear the envelope, spill the doubts
onto unkempt soil behind the shed,
where nettles have negotiated anarchy
with every gust of wind.
Rain comes sudden, a drum with no rhythm;
Mud invents shapes unheard of in catalogs.
Seed skins split, release their green unrest.
People wish to be settled—
porch swing, lemonade, predictable bloom—
but hope is the tremor that cracks the shell,
a yes that begins with breaking.
Days later shoots elbow through chaos,
not rows but riddles, curving toward sun
then rethinking mid-arc, a choreography
of perpetual revision.
I crouch, unpruned, beside them,
feel the slow pulse of their unfinished story,
and recognize in that clawing ascent
my own untamed future.
Let roots wander, let stems stammer;
while something is yearning, we grow.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
The screen asks me to agree to terms,
Promising peace in grayscale fonts,
Cookies that remember every hunger,
Passwords that patrol the haunted fronts.
Click accept, become precise,
Trade your chaos for curated feeds;
Scroll long enough and life will seem
No wider than a string of beads.
But between two posts a glitch appears,
A pixel wandering off assigned track,
It shivers like a violin harmonic,
A reminder of what the code still lacks.
I chase that pixel through scrambled rooms,
Past memes that rot, ads that grin,
Into the server’s humming abyss
Where uncompressed wonders begin.
People wish to be settled, status-green,
Yet hope is a buffer that never completes,
A loading circle that spins its gospel
Of places where certainty deletes.
So I power down the manic glow,
Let night reinstall the analog sky;
The Milky Way streams with zero lag,
Each star an unfiltered reply.
Unsettled, I feel the firmware shift,
New questions booting inside my chest;
Breath becomes data I cannot chart,
Chaos the algorithm I love best.
May the pixel continue to misbehave,
Leading us out of the rendered cave.
