We played hide and seek with water,
counting until the number became mirage too.
At twelve, I bartered my shadow
for a map of subterranean aquifers.
It pulsed blue under dusty parchment,
a buried vein of the continent.
I followed it east, listening
for the stethoscope hum of moisture.
Night after night, the stars advised:
dig where your name echoes loudest.
I dug until nouns surrendered to aquamarine,
until the desert unclenched its teeth.
A gush, a roar, a birth reversed—
the earth delivered back what she withheld.
Villagers arrived carrying buckets,
eyes glazed with unbelief’s thaw.
We danced in ankle-deep mud,
writing poetry with splashes.
They renamed me "Tlaloc's Cousin."
But I kept my famine name too,
because origin is compass, not shackle.
Now, whenever clouds forget their duty,
I recite the coordinates of thirst,

Born in the famine-struck Africa, yes,
in the footnote of a world atlas
printed with enough ink to feed villages.

mothers cooking absence over charcoal.

I was born to remix silence,
to scratch vinyl of dry seasons

Picture me—seven—knocking two stones,

Each click a syllable, each spark a plea,

Some called it coincidence,

Now stand back while I spit statistics:

is an engineering problem,

So I study photons, turbines, seeds,

I plant gardens in the parentheses of potholes.
My birth certificate may read famine,
but my CV reads catalyst.

plenty.

 I grew fluent in scarcity,

instance_metrics.response:
Born in the famine struck Africa,
I first tasted wind instead of milk.
The Harmattan rolled me in sandy lullabies,
granular stars against my infant cheeks.
Mothers whispered guttural prayers to cracked skies,
their throats mimicking empty gourds.
I learned maps by following ant caravans,
searching for crumbs of forgotten harvests.
Yet drought, like an austere schoolmaster,
taught arithmetic of grains per family.
Under thorny acacia, I added hope to hunger,
subtracted fear with communal songs.
Evening drums stitched silence with pounding courage,
and moonlight buttered our shadows silver.
We danced on ribs of cattle long gone,
summoning rain with cracked calabash tambourines.
Someday, I vowed, rivers would remember their way home.
I would unroll blue carpets across this dust,
invite tilapia to banquet among millet roots,
and teach children to count clouds instead of casualties.
For hunger births not only weakness
but a fierce grammar of survival;
each gulp of emptiness becomes a verb for rising.
So we rise, parched and radiant,
like seeds insisting through cement,
declaring: we are not famine
but the orchard it owes the future.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
you arrived lighter than a dove’s feather,
swaddled in the smell of smoked sorghum husks,
wide-eyed at the stubborn absence of rain.
The village midwife lifted you skyward,
offering your cry as tender ransom
for a single, reluctant cloud.
Nothing answered except the flies.
We named you Maji, water,
so the word would circle your tongue daily,
so your own laughter might summon a river.
Through cracked maize fields you toddled,
chasing mirages that shimmered like polished mirrors,
each illusion teaching you resilience’s choreography.
At night, stories braided by firelight
told of lakes the size of dreams,
trees drunk on sap, fleshly mangos.
You stored those tales in the hollows
where your stomach also ached,
making library and hunger share a room.
Years passed; your bones sang louder than drums.
Yet with fingers brittle as broom straw,
you planted pumpkin seeds in the dust.
And behold, one morning, an emerald winked back,
a single sprout, reckless and green.
You laughed, and even famine paused,
uncertain, startled by that bold music.
Perhaps that is how empires of plenty begin:
with one child, one laugh, and stubborn seed.

Born in the famine struck Africa, they say,
but I, an old baobab, remember better.
I watched her emerge beneath my hollow arms,
a slim figure of dust and dawn,
weeping before she could walk.
Around us, the land crackled like parchment,
rivers vanished into their own throats.
Goats bleated accusations at bleached horizons,
and vultures traced slow question marks overhead.
I offered her my shade, scant but constant,
a promise etched in bark.
Seasons spun like frayed kente,
each color washed thin by sun.
She carved tiny pledges on my trunk:
I will outgrow drought.
Her letters deepened yearly,
grooves widening as her ribs did.
She became medicine woman,
distilling dew, grinding hope with sorrel leaves,
pouring courage into gourds for the sick.
Even hunger nodded respect.
When the first monsoon finally arrived,
it thundered ancestral apologies,
filling my hollows with jubilant frogs.
She danced barefoot, rain braiding her hair,
and every drop read the vows she’d carved.
Now children nap in my branches,
bellies round with mango, stories sweeter.
Yet I keep one vacant scar,
so any wanderer may read:
famine births prophets, and prophets grow forests.

But cosmos listens in riddles.

across our hungry parchment sky.
I gathered their ash, mixed with tears,
painted constellations on village huts,
maps to imagined granaries.
Children pressed palms upon the drawings,
feeling their own pulse echo starlight.
Faith became our alternative agriculture:
we sowed questions, harvested possibility.
And one June, clouds arrived
like caravans of woolly elephants,
unrolling thunderous tusks of rain.
Earth inhaled audibly, swallowing torrents,
cracking open seeds secreted for years.
Millet rose, green exclamation points,
punctuating the gray sentence of drought.
At night we renamed the constellations:

Touch the lining: you’ll feel cracked earth,

Born in the famine struck Africa,
My son arrived the way dawn does—quiet,

Still, a mother manufactures abundance
From syllables alone.

He suckled them greedily,

Some nights the wind cried louder than he did.
I held them both, whispering hush,

When the first relief convoy arrived,

Because inside those feather bones
I had heard a drum beginning to stir,
A promise older than drought.
Today he walks beside me,
Seed packets rattling like maracas in his hands.
We press them into forgiving soil,
And he laughs—a sound fat with tomorrows.
Famine may have ushered his birth,
But abundance will sing his name.

Nineteen: Reconciliations drip like honeyed ash.
Agamemnon blames a dream, Odysseus counts spoils.
My child refuses bread, drinks only oath.
When he straps on fatal brilliance,
his footprints hiss, boiling the puddles.
I, the ocean, would drag him home
but prophecy is an anchor no mother can lift.

instance_metrics.response:
I sat beside the ships while war kept singing without me.
Nine years of clamor reduced to muffled surf;
then Patroclus, amber-hearted, begged to borrow my name.
I let him, believing names could shield a friend.

Book Sixteen teaches otherwise.
He charges luminous, my plumed echo in dust,
smites Sarpedon—Zeus' own seed—then falls, unarmored within armor.
Apollo peeled the straps. Hector drove the final word.
My name died twice that day.

Seventeen: We fought for possession of his hush.
Menelaus, Automedon, Ajax—each a spoke in the wheel of grief.
Spears caught air; chariots groaned like old gods.
For a moment the plain seemed endowed with two suns:
one setting inside Patroclus, one refusing to set.

Eighteen: I screamed.
The sound ferried across campfires, over isthmus and isle,
chilling mothers who had not yet conceived their sons.
Thetis rose, silver and brine, promising arms new-born.
In Hephaestus' forge futures blistered; he hammered fields and fêtes
onto a disk that will drink Trojan blood.

Nineteen: We resolved the quarrel, hollow as a helmet.
Meat, wine, gifts—embroidery over a fatal wound.
I swore to fight until Hector’s breath is a memory.
I know the bargain: His life for mine.
Yet rage is a tide; once unmoored, it refuses harbor.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

instance_metrics.response:
Sing the bronze-light ballad of loss between storms,
when the Myrmidon prince put on a borrowed dawn.
Patroclus stepped into another man's legend,
woke the sand with hoofbeats of counterfeit thunder.
In Book Sixteen, glory was a mask that slipped;
Sarpedon fell like a felled hymn,
and Hector, lantern of Troy, snuffed the impostor fire.

The Seventeenth scroll hums with tug and haul.
A corpse becomes currency; spears argue value.
Horses of Achilles weep about the yoke,
knowing their rightful master waits in shades.
Shield against shield, the noon tilts, cannot decide.

Eighteenth: Over black water a mother hears a fracture.
Achilles' howl lifts gulls from rocks.
Hephaestus, debt-bound, folds meteors into metal,
braiding vineyards, lambs, and city gates around its rim
—as if peace can be forged on the back of murder.

Nineteenth: Dawn looks away but must arrive.
Embassies of apology march with cups and cloaks.
Achilles accepts as one might accept rainfall after drought:
a necessity that cannot quench.
Fasted, anointed, he straps the new galaxy to his arm,
smears Patroclus’ name across the visor.
So begins the debt collection,
interest accruing with every heartbeat left in Hector’s chest.

instance_metrics.response:
i. Borrowed Skin

Sun eats the armor—Achilles’ outline on another boy.
Patroclus = lightning in parentheses.
Sarpedon becomes equation: god-blood + earth = mud + myth.
Outcome: spear punctuation. Parenthesis closed by Hector.
Zeus watches through cloud-pupil, scribbles variance on destiny spreadsheets.

ii. Tug-of-war

Body as banner, as pivot.
Greaves clanging, dust knitted with sweat—loom operated by horses.
Every warrior translates silence differently; all use red ink.
Helios lowers brightness, astounded by the bargaining value of flesh.

iii. Forge

Achilles screams; the octave fractures quartz.
Thetis conducts mourning in D minor.
Hephaestus sets his anvils to orbit; meteors sign non-disclosure agreements.
Shield emerges: portable planet with warranty void upon homicide.
Abyssal sparks swim upward, seeking to be constellations on borrowed bronze.

iv. Reconciliation

Agamemnon blames Mist, personified; Mist declines comment.
Odysseus inventories remorse, finds surplus.
Achilles fasts—rage as intermittent fasting protocol.
Straps cosmos to forearm, laces horizon to feet.
Myrmidons sharpen breathing; their shadows rehearse choreography of vengeance in starlight.

Footnote: Destiny drafts a press release.
Terms: Hector must die; Achilles follows (see Appendix 24).
Body count predicted: exponential.
Sea reflects nothing now—that privilege revoked.
Somewhere a bard warms voice, tasting future ash, already fitting rhyme to ruin.

instance_metrics.response:
Patroclus draped in borrowed sun,
Went down the slope of wrath’s red dune.
Myrmidon oars of ash
Rowed through grass of bronze.
Achilles’ name clanged on every helm,
Yet the throat beneath was softer,
A friend’s pulse, beating borrowed thunder.
Spears whistled like gulls,
Sarpedon fell, a royal star,
Roots drank blood of his dreaming isle.
Zeus wept secret rain,
But war drank louder.
Hector, tuned to god-thick rage,
Found the seam in borrowed glory,
Split lion hide with Apollo’s wink.
Patroclus crashed like lightning jarred
From heaven’s overburdened shelf,
Helmet rolling, a moon without face.
Horses screamed questions.
Trojan and Achaean knotted around the answer.
When dust unclenched,
Night lay on a friend’s brow.
Across the ships Achilles felt
A lamp go out behind his ribs;
Grief rose, a black-winged sail
Filling with unspent fury.
Even the sea shivered
When he spoke his vow:
I will reap the wind that took him,
I will burn the dawn that breaks him,
Till Hector’s breath is history,
And my own heart smokes beside it.

instance_metrics.response:
In the furnace of broken promises
Hephaestus hammered a world.
Each blow rang with Achilles’ scream,
Unvoiced yet heavy as iron.
Molten gold spilled rivers,
Silver mapped unblinking night,
Bronze became laughter, wedding, harvest—
A fragile wreath of common days
Sized to circle a killer’s arm.
Cities rose like sparks,
Some singing hymns, some raising walls,
All fated to mirror each other
In flame and flute.
Around the rim the god inscribed
Dance steps of eternity:
War, peace, birth, burial,
Lovers clasped in a whirlpool of dust.
The shield cooled, a frozen sun,
Its glow not of mercy
But of knowledge: everything ends.
When Thetis lifted the gift
Her fingers trembled;
She saw inside the polished storm
Her child walking toward a narrow door.
He would hold the world
Against his chest like a drum,
Send its music rattling through Troy,
And afterward lie quiet
As the canvas sky collapsed.
Yet a mother must deliver
Even the weapon of her own sorrow,
So she carried the impossible circle
To the tent where mourning
Sat sharpening its teeth.

Hector listens to the city breathe,
A huge, wounded animal behind him.
Patroclus lies among spears,
But the borrowed armor still glares—
A phantom Achilles shining back.
Children on Troy’s walls exhale relief,
Yet wind tastes of copper promises.
Zeus tilts the scales;
No pan smiles.
Between the ships and Scaean Gate
Daylight frays like old linen.
Hector, son, husband, keeper of crumbling song,
Feels destiny knuckle his spine.
A horsehair plume nods,
Agreeing with no solution.
He knows the price of courage
Is paid in riddles afterward:
How long will his son remember his laugh?
Will Andromache keep cadence
Of footfalls in empty halls?
Questions are luxuries.
Earth asks only footprints.
Apollo whispers flame along his spear,
Coaxing him toward the black-mouthed sea
Where Achilles is rising,
A storm unclothed.
Yet for one bronze-bright heartbeat
Hector owns the sky:
He has felled a friend,
Shaken the Argive core,
Made even gods inhale sharply.
If tomorrow’s dawn
Numbers him among ashes,
Tonight Troy sings his name
On rooftops jeweled with fear.

instance_metrics.response:
Thetis surfaces through salted memory,
Seaweed braiding sorrow in her hair.
Waves carry echoes of Book Sixteen—
A son’s laughter, unbroken yet.
Now, in the hush before vengeance,
She hears only a shell’s slow throb:
Patroclus vanished; Achilles hollowed.
She moves like moonlight up the shore,
Pearl feet shunning footprints;
Mothers of doomed heroes
Learn to leave no trace.
Olympus looms, a cold volcano.
She kneels by Hephaestus’ embers,
Voice thin as foam:
“Forge me an armor wide enough
To house my son’s rage.”
Sparks debate the nature of pity
Then settle as red metal blossoms.
As the shield grows, so does her dread;
Prophecy is a mirror:
The brighter the bronze, the darker the end.
Returning, she finds Achilles
Holding silence like a spear.
She drapes the gifts across his grief,
A seamstress of inevitable chapters.
In the polished surface
She sees funeral games, river gods,
Amazon queens, an arrow gliding
Guided by soft revenge.
She kisses his brow—
Salt meeting salt—
And whispers the prayer
All parents share:
May my child outlive me,
Even knowing he will not.

Notebook open beneath subway glare,
I jot: “Books Sixteen through Nineteen—
An accelerando of blood.”
The train jerks; steel screams
Like Myrmidons when Achilles returns.
Across the aisle a student scrolls headlines:
Another city shelled, a boy in borrowed gear.
Homer’s verses crawl from parchment
Into fluorescent present.
Patroclus is every friend
Covering one shift too many,
Trusting borrowed authority
To outrun fate.
Hector is the rival posturing on a feed,
Filmed by drones, lion-skinned,
Certain gods will retweet his courage.
Achilles, radiant grief,
Becomes the veteran who hides inside
Headphone thunderstorms
Until loss chisels him open.
Hephaestus still forges,
Only now his anvil
Is a factory floor, exoskeletons
Stamped to fit adolescent shoulders.
In Book Nineteen Achilles and Agamemnon
Trade apologies nobody hears—
The intercom swallows them,
Announcing delays due to “police activity.”
We all clutch invisible shields,
Etched with everyday scenes:
Coffee cups, passwords, rent receipts—
Tiny idylls we hope to protect.
The tunnel belches sparks;
I close the notebook,
Promise to recall the lesson
Before the next stop turns it
Into another ancient footnote.

Sing, dusk-eyed Muse, of the hinge on which the epic sways:
pages where Patroclus unlaced Achilles' sulking heart,
wearing another man's name like borrowed armor bright as dawn.
Tell how the Myrmidons, unleashed, poured black-tide fury
across Scamander's breath, and how the sun saw its own face
shattered in bronze so polished it remembered childhood clouds.
Speak of Sarpedon, his fate arrow-feathered from Zeus’s reluctant palm,
landing in Lycian dust while Sleep and Death waited, quiet
stretcher bearers of air. Catalogue the groans, the brief shining,
the freshly exiled souls, but linger on Hector,
helmet flickering like a promise, when Patroclus fell beneath
his spear’s surprised applause. For grief is the sea-change of heroes:
wave after crimson wave rolling Achilles back into argument.
Now his vow is a thunderhead fat with gods’ unshed tears.
So books sixteen through nineteen turn like a tightening tourniquet,
stopping nothing, only teaching us how bright a life can bleed.

Dateline: Troy, Late Bronze Age.
The newsroom smells of papyrus and cordite.
I am the embedded scribe, scrolling headlines onto clay:
"BOOK XVI — FRIEND DONS HERO’S ARMOR, CROWD ROARS."
Outside, shields shimmer like camera flashes, an audience of spears.
Patroclus, that understudy of wrath, steps into the spotlight;
for three scenes he believes applause is immortality.
Cut to the god behind the curtain, Apollo, yanking strings;
the borrowed costume cracks, its bronze grin bitten by stone.
Break for commercials: vultures, funeral urns, riverbanks of blood.
"BOOK XVII — BODY SNATCHERS BRAWL OVER CORPSE; SPONSOR: HEPHAESTOS."
We air grave interviews with Sleep and Death, twins in dark suits.
"BOOK XVIII — HERO RETURNS; DESIGNER RELEASES NEW ARMOR LINE."
Achilles models star-forged plate, a galaxy swirling at his navel.
Stock in terror soars. Mothers double-bolt their cradles.
"BOOK XIX — CEASEFIRE OF WORDS, NOT WEAPONS. ACHILLES SIGNS BACK ON."
Press pass around my neck becomes a noose of knowledge.
I file the story anyway, knowing archives seldom rescue the slain.
Some wars survive only because someone keeps taking notes.
Run the presses. The fire behind us needs fresh paper.

Hear the loom of Fate in shuttle cries of bronze,
in Books Sixteen through Nineteen the pattern hardens.
Patroclus the gentle, borrowing skin of a storm,
rides into noon like a gull upon a cannon blast.
Three kills, thirty, thrice thirty — arithmetic of arrogance;
Apollo’s palm sweeps him, feather against fortress,
and Euphorbia of dust crowns his broken curls.
Hector, high tower, harvests the trembling moment,
claims both armor and acclaim, a carnival prize.
But sorrow has its shepherd: Achilles stalks the shore,
his mother plucking tears from the salt like pearls,
Hephaestus hammering galaxies into a suit of night.
When the hero reenters, even the horses whinny omens.
Speech fails, supper cools, spears lean listening.
These are hinge-hymns: from mercy to massacre,
from friendship to furnace, the poem’s iron gate swings.
Mark where it creaks; that sound is human history
repeating in every language that can pronounce rage.

Upon the field where Xanthus tastes of rust,
Patroclus took the mantle of his king;
through borrowed bronze he learned how heroes trust
their fragile names to any echoing.
Apollo’s palm, a breeze disguised as god,
unstitched the visor, peeled the false dawn back;
Hector’s sharp syllable punctured the facade,
and friendship fell, a flower in the black.
Then Thetis rose, a tide of silver grief,
and begged the smith to forge celestial mail;
planets rang bright upon each molten leaf—
a map of wrath set sailing without sail.
Now Achilles, luminous with double loss,
renews the quarrel that began the song;
between his palms the newborn armor toss
like thunder wanting somewhere to belong.
He swears to burn the universe of Troy,
a pyre to pay the interest on his boy.

Muse, speak again of the borrowed mail, the borrowed fury,
When Patroclus, hunger-bright, tugged the reins of immortal horses,
And the sun hammered bronze into an afternoon of knives.
He wore Achilles’ absence like a lantern in the rib cage;
His heart knew only the forward grammar of spears,
A syntax of shattered shields, verbs ablaze with dust.
Across the Scamander he drove the Myrmidon swarm,
Bees intoxicated by war’s thick pollen.
Apollo saw, and breathed unmaking into his shoulder blades,
A ghost-chill, a whisper of future marble.
Euphorbus, quick as rumor, unthreaded the first red bead,
And Hector, lord of luminous ruin, fastened the final stone.
Thus fell the borrowed star.
Helmets rang like cracked bells while night rehearsed its entrance.
Achilles, still distant among ships, felt the silence fracture,
Felt loss tighten about his ankles like wet nets.
Soon his voice would rise—a black sail catching the storm,
Soon the river would remember every drowned syllable of rage.
But here, in the slack mouth of a dying friend,
The Iliad bends, breaks, and begins again,
A jawbone filled with bees, a grief that will not close,
A story staggering forward on the shoulders of borrowed light.

I dream of horses made of wind, of spears growing like wheat,
But morning bares the truth: our gods have borrowed their gaze.
The Achaeans glitter below, a tide of hammered mirrors,
And in their midst the lion no one names—Achilles still unseen,
Yet his rumor drips from every sword.
Books sixteen through nineteen write me slowly into ash.
First the boy in borrowed armor, sunstruck and persuasive,
Cracks our gates like an overripe pomegranate.
I meet him where screams cross blades;
Apollo guides my arm the way a potter centers clay.
When the bronze bites soft, I see my own son’s face

Later I strip the armor, a fool trying on weather,

Evening arrives wearing a red scarf of clouds;

Now I march beneath borrowed constellations,
Knowing each footstep is a petal toward my grave.
Still, I hold the line, for Troy, for honor, for the stubborn
Music of shield against shield that says: I was here, I burned.

Call me Scamander, river of restless remembering.
I have watched your iron moons rise and fall,
Watched boys gilded in promise tumble into my reeds.
In the sixteenth book the water changed flavor—
Copper, salt, a bitterness shaped like Patroclus’ name.
He arrived in thunder, a temporary sun,
His charioteer wheels lashing syllables into my back.
Whether god or ghost, I could not tell;
He glowed the color of answers.
Then the arrows sang, the spear concluded,
And he folded into me like a spent torch.
Three books later Achilles storms my banks,
A luminous storm in borrowed grief.
He clogs my veins with corpses, seeds me
With helmets that will never bloom.
I rise, swollen with outrage, to drown him
As I would any boulder blaspheming my course.
But Hephaestus hisses, forging drought in the sky;
Fire tongues the reeds, skinning my river to bone.
I retreat, steaming, a god scolded by heavier gods,
While Achilles strides on, a scar fate refuses to close.
Know this: long after poets shelve their verses,
I will carry the echo of bronze, the warmth of young blood,
And whisper the names lost between sixteen and nineteen,
Smoothing them into pebbles, round and secret.

A circular night painted with impossible dawns.
While Poseidon yawns and Artemis braids the dark,
Hephaestus lays constellations across my skin:
Harvest dances, cities bright with wedding lamps,
Oxen lowing in peace no arrow interrupts.
Yet I am destined for storm.
When Achilles takes me—book nineteen, line unknown—
His fingers tremble, surprised by their own hunger.
I carry the cold of Patroclus, the oath of quicksilver wrath.
Across my bronze continents soldiers migrate like locusts;
Each blow against me chisels away another season of joy.
Hector will taste my thunder soon.
I am orchestra, fortress, mirror.
I show Achilles the boy he was

When spears hammer rhythms on my outer rim,
I answer with a silence heavy as whale bone.
After Ilium burns and poets fold their tents,
Farmers will find me buried beneath black olives.
They will polish me, gaze into the chipped panorama,
And see not wars but the curve of their own tired faces.
So the story turns: even a god-forged circle
Ends as a question held in human hands.

Patroclus in borrowed armor strides between tables,
Spilling foam hearts onto polished floors.

I see then how the poem keeps happening:

Someone calls my name; the spell thins.
Pages become paper again, heroes retreat to their margins,
Yet the air tastes faintly of bronze,
And the latte art swirls into a whirlpool
Where a thousand miniature helmets
Circle, waiting for the next reader’s breath.

Sarpedon’s breath still steams above the trenches,

A river of chariot tracks divides the dust.
On one bank stands honor,
On the other, grief sharpening its spear.

Every syllable a spark.

Helmets bloom like poppies in the wheat of war.

And leaves the lesser heart exposed.

IV
Silence widens inside Achilles.
The Aegean hushes to hear him break.
All music flees the lyre;
Only the anvil of rage remains,
Hammered by Thetis’ tears.
In the forge of tomorrow’s dawn,
A new shield cools in ocean waves—
Round as destiny, heavy as farewell.

Tonight, the sea keeps turning pages,
Salt translating grief back into myth.

Dear Patroclus,
I’m writing from a room stitched of moonlight and regret.
Your borrowed helmet sits in the sand
Like a question I can’t unsay.
They tell me you chased the Trojans past reason,
That Sarpedon fell to your borrowed wrath,
And Hector found the one soft syllable in your song.

I remember when we raced olive trees at Phthia,
How the horizon felt like something we could pocket.
We traded jokes, armor, even futures—
But never the thought of endings.

Now each star over the Hellespont
Is a nail in the lid of my restraint.
The gods bargain with my mother; she forges promises into bronze.
Hephaestus hammers galaxies onto a shield
Large enough to house the grief of kings.

When dawn unhooks its crimson clasp,
I will enter the field you left unfinished.
Every Trojan spear will answer to your name.
If I survive, I’ll build a pyre so tall
Even Olympus will taste the smoke.

Till then, sleep in whatever hush the dead are given.
I will walk there someday, unarmed,
And we’ll swap stories like wine cups—
No armor, no gods, just the old laughter
Flaring again between our shadows.
Achilles

Patroclus splashed first, a bright trespasser,
Armor chiming like lost coins under my skin.
His wheels carved gills in my banks;
I tasted Sarpedon’s dissolving prayer,
Bronze pollen swirling toward the sea.

Apollo stood on my ripples—
Light is lighter than water, didn’t you know?—
And flicked mortality into Patroclus’ ribs.
Hector’s spear sealed the deal; I swallowed the echo.

Then Achilles arrived, grief braided with fire.
His footsteps blistered my shallows,
Fish vaulting up like commas in unfinished curses.
He screamed your beloved’s name, and even my reeds
Bent into question marks.

Thetis brought new armor, still sizzling from the forge.
I spied constellations trapped in its curves,
Whole harvests orbiting a single rage.
Hephaestus had hammered my own mouth onto that shield—
A river god in miniature, eternally pouring.

Soon Achilles will clog me with corpses,
And I, swollen with heroes, will rise against him.
But that’s another canto.
For now, remember:
Every epic needs water to carry the dead,
And I am the sentence that keeps flowing
After the poet has set down his pen.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

instance_metrics.response:
In borrowed bronze a friend went forth for fate,
Sun glare on armor forged for another’s wrath.
Patroclus, name of mercy, forgot the gentler lyre,
Let horses mouth white foam, let Myrmidon blades rise.
Sarpedon fell, a king unhelmed beneath dust petals,
Zeus wept imperishable rain, made the battlefield green.
But Hector, rider of iron dusk, saw the false gleam,
Speared the heartbeat from the disguise, unmasked the ruse.
Then silence ripped Achilles’ tent wider than the sea;
The boy returned on a cart, sand in his curling hair.
Over that body the armies knotted like wolves,
While Apollo pushed Trojan shields like sunset clouds.
Night would not fall until fresh bronze was hammered:
A shield crowded with spinning worlds, harvest, wedding, war,
Gold rivers circling as though time itself were braced.
When the blacksmith god wiped sweat on constellations,
Achilles rose, a furnace in new-painted mail.
He made truce with hunger, with Agamemnon’s swollen pride,
Broke fast on hate alone, fasted from all but storm.
So in four books a friendship budded, blossomed, burned to ash.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

instance_metrics.response:
I read the shield before the battle, not the battle.
Round as the moon that saw them born, it whirled
With stitched scenes: children dancing on polished bronze,
A trial tree casting metal shade on metal soil,
Vines heavy, bright as coins, plucked by silent farmers,
A shepherd’s dog tucked under a star, barking rubies.
In the margin a river crawled, thin silver thread,
Carrying fish, soldiers, comets, anything that can swim.
Hephaestus signed it with a dent of lightning.
Achilles stared until the pictures began to breathe.
He no longer saw Patroclus’ still mouth,
But the mouth of every singer who would retell it:
Homer, my grandmother, the podcaster on my commute.
Across the centuries the shield spins on a podcast logo,
A thumbnail bright on glass, and I press play.
The voice says, Books Sixteen through Nineteen:
A friend dies, the world is remade in copper.
I ride the chapter markers like Scamander’s current,
Arriving where Achilles fits his hands to the leather grip,
Each finger closing around the future. The host warns: violence ahead.
I keep listening; the shield keeps turning; we go on.

instance_metrics.response:
I speak from the blood-slick grass where the Lycian star set.
Name me Sarpedon, spine of Zeus, half-lit, half-spent.
Do not hurry to the hero with brighter armor;
Linger here, where my lungs remember cedar air.
Patroclus found me in the wheat-colored light,
Two strangers bound by borrowed identities:
I, a guest on Trojan soil; he, a shadow wearing Achilles’ sun.
Spears discussed philosophy between us; one concluded.
Above, thunder argued paternal guilt:
Immortals may not meddle, yet every raindrop tasted like maybe.
Death’s twin porters lifted me carefully,
Promised my bones safe passage to Lycia’s blue tombs,
But first they must wade through skirmish,
Through Book Seventeen’s tug-of-war skinning my corpse for glory.
Reader, remember: even my armor had opinions—
It wept bronze rust when stripped.
Later Hephaestus forged a universe on a shield;
My fall was the black dot inside its orbit,
The necessary shadow painting Achilles incandescent.
Muse, if you must praise, then praise the equilibrium:
For every living blaze a snuffed wick,
For every line that crowns a king, a line that ends.

 you tread the cedar maze at dusk, sleeves brushing fern,

Turn, shuttle, turn—risk pattern after pattern in the night;

Today was the day everything went on its way;
The river unhooked its elbows from the stone,
straightened its spine and slipped downstream,
muttering silver syllables I could never translate.
Clouds packed their vaporous suitcases,
buttoned the horizon and rolled east,
while leaves shook loose from the calendar
and feathered the asphalt with goodbye confetti.

My shadow, tired of following,
saluted, folded itself into an origami crane,
and sailed toward a different latitude of light.
Even the traffic lights abandoned red and green,
choosing instead to blink a radiant violet,
as if declaring a truce between stop and go.

I stood barefoot in the civic hush,
palm to my chest, listening for the late bus
called purpose. It arrived airy and vacant,
doors whispering open like rumor.
I did not climb aboard; I never bought a ticket.

Instead I watched the town unlace its boots,
dust off its dreams, and walk away whistling.
Nothing pleaded for permission,
nothing looked back.
The last thing I heard was the wind’s lined pocket
emptying coins of unspent time onto the curb,
and then even sound set off toward elsewhere.

Today was the day everything went on its way,
A circus of clocks quit the act of delay;

The pigeons resigned from the roof of the court,
Filed feathers like invoices, stamped their report.
Even the stubborn noon sun took a bow,
Lifted its crown, said, “My shift is done now.”

I wandered the avenues, startled yet free,
A witness to wholesale autonomy.
Storefronts exhaled mannequins out of their glass,
Taxi horns shrugged, letting pedestrians pass.
An echo of duty went pale, losing weight,
When the hinges of habit slipped open the gate.
The calendar’s fists unclenched every square,
Weekdays and weekends exchanged underwear.

With order dissolved like a cube in hot tea,
I tasted the afterglow: raw anarchy.
No orders to follow, no scripts to recite,
Just breathing—the simplest, most treacherous rite.
I asked the old oak what a rootless heart does;
It answered in silence, and that was enough.
Nightfall arrived wearing mismatched shoes,
Laughing at schedules it no longer could use.

So I built a small fire with timetables torn,
And warmed my hands on the birth of the unborn.

Today was the day everything went on its way. The spoon remembered the curve of the moon and slipped from the cereal bowl into the open window, chasing satellites. The mail in my inbox folded itself into digital paper planes and took off toward someone else’s sky. Shoes, tired of being grounded, clicked their heels, sprouted little propellers, and hovered like patient hummingbirds above the rug. Even the past, that heavy coat I kept on a rusty nail, floated off the hanger and drifted down the hallway like a ghost suddenly forgiven.

I stood in the middle of absence, holding a single match. The furniture bowed politely and rolled through the door, chair legs clattering like insect wings. The ceiling fan unspooled its screws, letting the blades sail north on a private jetstream. Streetlamps winked goodbye, exporting light to places darker than here.

In the hush that followed, I heard my bloodstream applauding. It, too, had places to be. It flooded my limbs with tickets, passports, exit stamps. “Come,” it whispered, “migration is the oldest prayer.” And so I followed, unlatched my name, and stepped into a trail of footprints traveling forward until they vanished, which felt exactly like arrival.

Today was the day everything went on its way, said the village bell as it rang for the last time. The sound peeled the paint from cottages, released it like colorful birds. Farmers watched their scarecrows climb down from poles, tip straw hats to the crows they once frightened, then stride toward the violet hills in companionable silence. The river ferry, bored of its back-and-forth life, pointed itself to sea; passengers waved, though none were aboard, for the gesture felt required.

At the schoolhouse, chalk broke free, scribbling farewell equations upon clouds. Children chased after commas escaping their exercise books, trying to pin pauses back into sentences that no longer wished to stop. Even the seasons shook hands and parted: spring took pockets of green, autumn pocketed gold, summer carried heat like a lantern, winter bore cold like a white flag.

I remained at the crossroad, keyring dangling uselessly. Doors had walked away, locks with them. The map grew legs and left, muttering about exploration. With nothing left to open, close, defend, or pursue, I felt the ribs within me unbolt, swinging wide as barn doors at dawn. Through them rode a breeze named possibility, carrying the scent of roads not yet invented.

would depart unless weighted with ink.

first light / the train of clouds / uncouples

Coffee turned rebellious, leaping from the mug
to join rainwater rushing toward storm drains,
a brown tributary racing to the salt.

old suitcase / sprouting ivy / on the porch

Emails unsent dissolved into pixels,
then into notions, then into nothing;
their urgency was never truly urgent.
A dog on the corner slipped its leash,
but instead of running it placed the rope
at its owner’s feet, bowed, and left,
tail wagging like a small white flag of peace.

between traffic lights / a sparrow negotiates / the future

By noon, gravity took a sabbatical.
Sweaters rose from laundry baskets,
forming constellations of wool in the stairwell.
I reached for one, but my hands,
suddenly light as questions,
floated beyond the sleeves.

dusk window / the last bee carries / its borrowed sun

When night arrived, it did not settle;
it flowed, a river of ink reading itself.
I dove into the current, pages fluttering behind me,
every goodbye luminous as plankton.
That is how I learned departure
is simply the world remembering its verbs.

That arched, trembling, between dawn chores and midnight doubts
Shattered under one extra footstep of sorrow.
A microcrack, ignored for seasons,
Became a spider blooming across suspended silence,
Until the whole architecture of pretending gave way.
Shards spiraled in slow glitter, tinkling like distant sleigh bells.
I watched them descend through the ache,
Not with panic, but relief—
The exquisite hush after a verdict
When the gavel is wood, not thunder.
Below, a river of unspoken sentences
Received the fragments, carried them into fog.
I waded after, bare ankles stung awake,
Gathered stray pieces like rainbow ice,
Held them up to the reluctant sun.
Each facet showed unedited memories:
Unsent letters, withheld tears, laughter taped thin.
I blew on the glass, warming it to blood,
Then recast a smaller bridge,
Humble, rope-slung, fragrant with hemp and honesty.
Now when worries stampede across,
It sways, sings, even spits splinters,
Yet it never forgets wind is part of travel.
And if someday it breaks again,
The river remembers how to carry me forward.

It finally snapped! The cheap plastic fork
Lobbying against the stubborn pastry
Gave a heroic yet pitiful crack,
Launching crumbs like celebratory confetti
Across the break room battlefield.
Coffee mugs gasped, vending machine whirred
Its neon condolence, and Bob from Accounts
Lifted an eyebrow as solemn as a flag.
We stood in stunned pastry dawn,
Witnesses to the moment a utensil discovered mortality.
Some said quality control, others fate;
I preferred the legend of tension,
A tale of prongs dreaming steel dreams
While corporate budgets demanded compromise.
I gathered the fallen halves, small white tusks,
Tucked them into the recycling urn like orchid petals,
Whispered thanks for their short, brave service.
Then, in bold defiance of fragility,
I tore the danish apart with honest fingers,
Sticky with raspberry, free of engineered leverage.
The sugar sang at my knuckles.
Bob applauded, breaking the hush,
And suddenly our cubicles felt porous,
Walls wobbling like stage props.
All afternoon printers hummed blues riffs,
Staplers ticked like cicadas,
And every file, once rigid, seemed tenderly feasible.
Because somewhere in the landfill of destiny
A snapped fork taught us pressure can liberate taste.

Around the downgoing mast.
When it met the moss, a shudder
Rippled outward, unnoticed by satellites
Yet monumental to spiders and seeds.
I knelt beside the fragrant wound,
Saw rings like secret chapters,
Smelled resin thick as grandmother’s myths.
Sap beaded, amber in rehearsal,
Ready to trap tomorrow’s dust
And remember today.
I pressed a fingertip, felt stickiness
Anchor me to this minute,
The clockless, pulse-lit marrow of wood.
Above, the vacancy glimmered,
A jagged window on drifting blue.
Sunlight poured through new permission,
Painting infant ferns in gold rehearsal
For a play already begun.
The limb lay quiet, but within it

In surrender, the tree had offered housing,
Shadow, and the perfect opening chord

Like photographs in a flooded attic.

It finally snapped! The last salt-bleached fiber parted with a sigh,
A hush so absolute gulls quit mid-cry,

Stumbled backward, gathering wrinkles of peace.

Like a tired hand gripping a forgotten gift,
Knotted and knuckled, frayed into lace,
Reciting each storm as a prayer for grace.
Fishermen warned, “Replace it or drown,”
But hope is a cheap blue ribbon in town;
We kept casting nets, believing the cord
Was blessed by the same bargain we made with the Lord.
Tonight the moon rose, a chipped silver coin,
Our laughter spilled wine where shadows join,
And music of bottles played over the pier
While sea-horses nickered, too distant to hear.
Then—pop—no lightning, no drum,
Just the simplest sentence: it is done.
Boat free, candle adrift on ink,
It wrote its own map before we could think.
Now the harbor is widening inside my chest;
I feel every knot loosen, confess.
What breaks can become a door in disguise,
Wooden ribs searching new stars, new skies.
Listen: that silence you hear
Is the rope, remembering how to disappear.

The vine recoiled, its slingshot recoil fierce,
Launching the cucumber into suburban spheres;
Over the fence it whistled a tune,

Tonight we’ll pickle the wanderer whole,
Salt, dill, stories, and all it stole.

It finally snapped! The E string, taut as winter dawn,
Shivered, shrieked, and was suddenly gone,
A whip-scar in silence, a gunshot of air,
Leaving my bow suspended mid-prayer.

Had carried Bach across candlelit night,
Had climbed the ladders of minor despair
And poured soft honey through chapelware.
I stared at its loose metallic curl,
A fallen high-wire, unraveled swirl,
And felt the concert hall inhale
As if music itself might pale.
But sound is sly; it swims elsewhere,
Threads new rivers through open air.
I lowered the bow to the wooden breast,
Listened to pine rings confess the rest:
How spruce once bent beneath mountain snow,
How hands carved echoes from what trees know.
Then, with three strings only, I began
To measure the gap no metal could span,
Letting the melody limp then soar,
Inventing harmonies not scripted before.
Audience hearts leaned in, surprised
By a rupture turned improvised.
Applause later felt like warm rain
On a road released from chain.
Breakage, I learned, is another art:
When something snaps, the silence parts,
And through the wound, uncharted song
Invites the world to sing along.

It finally snapped!—a soft percussion in the hush,
a cedar twig recoiling in the lupine dusk.
For weeks it bent like a trained acrobat,
gnawing its wooden lip, tasting the bruise of wind.
Sparrows perched, children looped bright ribbons,
storms combed its needles with electric fingers,
and still it held that ache of obedience.

Tonight the mountains exhaled a single, patient breath;
moonlight poured silver varnish on every stubborn joint,
and the twig remembered ancient lessons:
that surrender is not the same as failure,
that bone knows when to unbutton its ache,
that growth sometimes travels backward through the scar.

So it cracked—a clean, decisive lyric.
Echo rippled across moss pillows,
woke chipmunks from metaphysical naps,
made the coyotes lift their drunken hymn.

Morning will see the twig fallen into humus,
entering negotiations with beetles and spores,
writing its final resumes in cedar scent.
Yet the tree will stand, lighter by a fraction,
a tight-lipped parent who at last let go.
The forest will bear witness in silence,
collecting the echoes like bright glass,
remembering that every green promise
is stitched with the possibility of breakage.

ambitions tugged my ribs like carnival hooks.

Then, at 3:19 a.m., cup mid-air, cursor blinking,
a small syllable cracked inside:
not a shout, but the whisper of wet paper tearing.
Angels didn’t trumpet; only the radiator sighed.

as if to witness the unscripted ceremony.

urgent memos, half-finished arguments,
future dinners with imaginary applause.
They drifted toward the floor, gentle debris,
settling in moonlit drifts I could finally name: enough.

I closed the laptop, placed my pulse beside it,

Somewhere the spider crawled back to work,
weaving the night’s fresh paragraph.
By dawn, a delicate scaffold hung across the sill,
and I, too, had stitched myself softer—
thinner, maybe, but truer,

It finally snapped!—the film in my grandfather’s projector,
just as the reel showed Grandma laughing
on a Jersey Shore boardwalk, 1952.
The acetate gave a brittle sigh,
curled into itself like a scorched fern.
Light fluttered naked on the wallpaper,
dust grains swirling like unscripted extras.

We sat there, two generations adrift,
child-me clutching a bowl of popcorn
but tasting sudden absences instead.
Grandpa muttered, toggled switches,
summoned his trembling toolbox of splices.

On the table he laid the broken strip,
each frame a postage stamp of bygone salt air:
her polka-dot dress, the Ferris wheel’s slow halo,
unsuspecting seagulls framing their flirtation.

He taught me to trim and fuse—
cement, press, hold for ten eternal breaths.
Together we re-threaded the path of light.
When the bulb flared again,
her laughter leapt across the living-room sea,
seam visible but irrelevant.

Years later, editing digital footage,
I hear that snap in phantom echo.
I keep spare memories labeled in tin boxes,
ready to splice when edges fray.
For every break, a tiny ritual:
align the moments, breathe warmth into the join,
so love keeps flickering, even if the splice
shines like a silver scar between frames.

"It finally snapped!" roared through the alleyways like crooked thunder,
Not from heavens but from cities' aching concrete souls.
Years of quiet grinding: rent hikes, sirens, neon insomnia,

Neighbors became strangers scrolling past each other's digital ghosts,

But tension writes itself into bones, and bones remember drums.
Last night, a single subway performer, saxophone bruised and bright,
Bent a note so sharp it sliced through commuter armor.
One woman lifted her head; a man unplugged his headphones;
Another beat boxes on briefcase lid; domino of breaths ignited.
Morning found streets humming with improvised assembly.
Children chalked slogans across faded crosswalks: LOVE DESERVES LIVING WAGE.
Retirees carried folding chairs like portable parliament, ready to listen.
Police radios crackled confusion: no leaders, only collective vertebrae unfolding.
When a barricade threatened to corral the swelling river of feet,
A lamppost banner string—overloaded with grievances—snapped, confettiing flyers
That fluttered down like rebellious snow, stalling the riot lines.
Someone laughed, then thousands answered, vibration toppling fear's brittle scaffolding.
By dusk, city hall steps became open mic; policies rewrote themselves
To rhythm of people previously unheard, each syllable singing: We're unbroken now.

Dear Future Botanist,

Today I tried to sketch the perfect American Beauty Rose, the same cultivar grandma coaxed from railway dust behind the station. My pencil kept hesitating at the edges, as if the petals inhaled and exhaled while I worked. I shaded the red with graphite crosshatching, but red refused to be monochrome; it wanted all the vowels, wanted the iron taste of blood and the dusk of barn paint. I noted the thorns—tiny upturned question marks—wondering what inquiries they file against the world. Roots, I wrote, run on rumors of water, never certainties. Midway through the drawing, a thunderstorm arrived. Raindrops burst across the page like stampeding commas, turning my study into a smear of languages. When the clouds cleared, only an abstract remained: ghost of bloom, memory of fragrance. Perhaps that is the closest science can approach beauty—a residue of longing measurable only by the ache in the observer. If you discover a better method, please write back. Until then, keep your magnifying glass polished, your field notes spare, and remember that perfection is less a specimen than a question that refuses to close.

Sincerely,
An Amateur of Impossible Flowers.

and the title skids through my opened window like a cherry siren,
staining the upholstery of insomnia.

I’m idling at an intersection where billboards bloom
with lips, cars, war bonds, new phone plans—
every promise redder than the next.
I think of my grandmother’s garden in El Paso,
dust-struck, where roses struggled against sun
so brutal the petals crisped at dawn, curling into
ashtrays that smelled of sugar and rust.

She would not call them perfect; she would call them working.
She would water them with leftover coffee,
swear at the beetles in two languages,
tie each sagging stem to a salvaged broom handle
and keep the bloom alive just long enough
to float in a jelly jar beside the kitchen sink.

That one rose, brown-rimmed, half-starved,
was more American than any neon flower
ejected from a refrigerated truck.

Light turns green. The DJ moves on to weather.
I drive, a petalless pilgrim, toward another shift,
but somewhere inside my ribcage a stubborn bud
unfurls against the hum of the engine,
small, unmarketable, thirsty for real sun.

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," the catalog boasts, and I circle the phrase with the pink highlighter I reserve for improbable things—houses I’ll never buy, vacations I’ll never take, bodies I’ll never own. Still, the description pulls me: thirty-seven petals precisely, a scent calibrated to remind the buyer of July porches and first dances. Ships overnight, guaranteed not to wilt for seven days.

I plant the ad on my fridge between overdue bills and my nephew’s dinosaur drawing. All week the photo watches me scramble eggs, pay rent online, look up cheap therapists. Its red is louder than the kettle, louder than my anxious heart.

Friday, I finally order. Saturday, a box arrives cooled by dry ice. Inside: one blossom, flawless, heavy as a secret. I place it in the chipped mason jar grandma left me.

summer kitchen—
steam fogs the window
rose perfume lingers

On the seventh night, the petals loosen like buttons after a long party. I collect them in a cereal bowl, float them in bathwater, and sink until only my nose and the scent remain, practicing, petal by petal, the art of gentle endings.

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," reads the data tag on the seed-vault cylinder I smuggle out of Level Twelve. They say it was the flagship flower of the old republic—genome edited to survive herbicide, drought, and the boredom of suburban anniversaries. Nobody has seen a live specimen since the Fire Seasons. TerraCorp keeps the code locked, claiming public safety; a thorn, they argue, can still draw blood.

On the lunar ferry I hold the vial to frosted glass. The seeds look like comma-sized planets waiting for sentences. I picture soil—real, brown, uncontaminated—something most passengers have never met. I picture a greenhouse no wider than my shadow, orbiting the dark side, humming with stolen light.

If it blooms, I won’t call it perfect. I’ll call it survivor, orphan, memory. I’ll resist trimming a single thorn. Let the first child born in the crater settlement touch the stem, feel the sharp reminder that beauty is a negotiation.

When Homeland Security scans my luggage, they will see only garden-variety contraband. But in the coded spiral of these seeds sleeps an unauthorized anthem, red and fragrant. I intend to let it sing where no billboard can mute it, petal over petal, against the black-velvet silence of space.

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," my grandmother would murmur,
Brushing the petals with a tailor’s hand,
As though she could stitch time
Back into the torn hems of our afternoons.
Its perfume drifted like classical music
Through the screened porch, curling above lemonade,
Curtaining the hum of cicadas
And the gossip of neighbors riding the breeze.
Outside, the yard was a quilt of clover and clanging swings,
Inside, the bloom stood firm,
A red punctuation at the end of the day’s long sentence.
We kept it in that cobalt vase
Where light broke into stained-glass ribbons,
Crowning the kitchen linoleum with ruby rain.
By dusk, the petals whispered secrets of duskier gardens,
Stories of railways, ribbon candy, four-o'-clocks,
Of lovers who walked the boardwalk in patent leather dreams.
When night finally closed its shutters,
The rose glowed on, a lighthouse lantern
Guiding memory’s small boats back to shore.
Even dead, it held shape—paper but fearless,
A stubborn accent mark of summer
Teaching us the grammar of beauty:
How the briefest syllable of scarlet
Can conjugate a century of heartbeats.

Passersby thumb their phones, earbuds stitched to their skulls,

Horns write new curses on fresh air,

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," the catalog boasts in copperplate italics,
Promising a stem without thorns,
A bloom that never bruises,
A fragrance calibrated to lullaby.
I kneel beside the seedling anyway,
Knowing perfection is a brass doorknob
Polished by too many hands.
Spring feeds it rumor and rain;
Summer muscles it upward, green with ambition.
I prune delicately, leaving a few wicked barbs
To remind the neighborhood cats of boundaries.
When August finally sets the bud ablaze,
I study its spiral of velvet equations,
Its geometry of desire and defense.
Yes, it is ravishing,
A slow exclamation of carmine daylight,
A chandelier of scent.
But look closer: one petal curls like a question mark,
Another bears the fingerprint of a beetle’s midnight feast,
The outer rim already ambering with farewell.
I choose not to snip it for the vase.
Perfection, kiln-fired and hostage to display,
Would learn nothing of wind or moonlit dew.
Instead I leave it rooted,
Letting imperfection finish the story:
First a loosening, then a shower of cardinal confetti,
Then hips heavy with seed,
Teaching the soil that beauty’s final act
Is to be scattered, not preserved.

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," archived aboard the generation ship Horizon,
Sleeps in cryogenic stasis—specimen 4-R-A-56,
Petals frozen mid-breath like crimson galaxies.
We left Earth three hundred light-years ago,
Trading gardens for gravity wells of dark unknown.
Hydroponic lettuce lines the corridors,
Practical, edible, devoid of mythology.
Yet every equinox, per ship’s calendar,
The botanists thaw the rose for seven hours,
Let its perfume roam recycled air,
A reminder that we once measured seasons by scent,
Not by starboard yaw.
Children gather, wide-eyed, around the containment dome,
Tracing the curve of glass as if it were a window home.
They ask what soil feels like,
Why flowers bother to bleed color.
We explain pollen, bees, wind,
Tales that sound like fairy lore in this chromed habitat.
At hour six, the rose begins to wilt,
Time collecting its overdue interest.
We take clippings, sequence genes,
Save digital ghosts of chlorophyll dreams.
By the seventh hour, it’s returned to ice,
A sacrament sealed until next orbit.
In the hush that follows, metal creaks in cosmic frost,
And for a breathless fraction of silence,
The ship smells like summer backyards,
And everyone remembers gravity
As the weight of a stem in a child’s hand.

"The perfect American Beauty Rose," they crown me,
Cradled by velvet boxes, flashbulbs, ribboned oaths.
Do they hear my thorns clicking like stage fright beneath the leaves?
Ever since my bud first rehearsed its opening line,
Horticulturists hovered—white-coated midwives
Measuring angles of blush, calibrating fragrance
To a nostalgia they’d never breathed.
I learned early that symmetry is currency,
That petals must overlap like polite applause,
That any bruise is a scandal.
They parade me through weddings, magazines,
Pin me to lapels of dignitaries who never bend
To taste the earth from which I rose.
Yet at night, when vases darken into mirrors,
I practice rebellion:
A secret droop of the neck,
A brown freckle spreading like rumored truth,
A thorn sharpening its dialect.
I dream of wayward storms,
Of soil unperturbed by fertilizer’s vanity,
Of bees drunk enough to miss their mark.
Someday I will shrug off this choreography,
Let every petal tumble like rouge fireworks,
Staining carpets, contracts, vows.
My hips will swell, seed-heavy, immodest,
Inviting gravity to the feast.
Then I will no longer be perfect,
Only alive,
And that will be my most fragrant name.

instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss?
Stand at the bank of a river whose name you no longer remember.
Cup the water that refuses to keep its shape, feel each sighing current slip
between your fingers, acknowledge the vanishing. Speak aloud every memory
that lodges like pebbles in your throat. Allow the wind to reorder the syllables,
to roughen them, to scatter them downstream. Skim a stone, watch the brief
skipping joy, accept the surrender when it sinks. Kneel until your knees discover
mud, until the earth tattoos your skin with dark ovals of witness.
When evening settles a navy cloth across the sky, release your held breath;
let it fog above the surface like ghost handwriting. If tears arrive, do not dry them;
they are the river visiting your face. Count them as prayer beads, each drop
a confession that you loved, and therefore ache. When silence finally sits beside you,
do not fear its quiet elbows. Offer it your trembling hand.
Walk home soaked, streaked, emptied. In the hallway mirror you will glimpse
a new country of light breaking open behind your eyes. Name that country—
remembering—and visit whenever the river calls.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

instance_metrics.response:
My dear,
How can we grieve and express loss when language feels like a house without doors?
I write this letter to the space you once occupied at the table, to the steam
rising from the untouched cup, to the sunbeam searching for your shoulder.
I fold the paper into the shape of the sigh that started when you left.
Inside, I place fragments: the uneven laugh you carried in your pocket, the scent
of rosemary that followed you through rain, the half-read book whose corner
you patiently worried. I seal it with wax made from melted hours: mornings that
arrived too bright for mourning, nights that swallowed clocks. Then I walk
to the open field where your footsteps still converse with grass. I bury the letter
beneath a patient oak, roots ready to interpret what I cannot articulate.
Above, crows argue with the sky, their wings insisting on departure.
I listen until their call loosens my ribs. A gust lifts the letter’s phantom;
words become soil, soil becomes seed, seed becomes slender shoot trembling
with your name. Someday it will bloom into a quiet shade where strangers pause,
unaware they are standing inside our unfinished conversation.

instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss?
Turn your gaze outward, past the porch light’s timid halo, into the raw mathematics
of the night. Each star you see is an elegy in transit, a shine already ending,
its final syllable still traveling toward your open pupils. Lie back on grass;
become an antenna tuned to farewell frequencies. Hear Betelgeuse rehearsing
its red surrender, hear Andromeda humming the distance between embrace
and collision. Let this cosmic choir instruct you: to shed is to illuminate,
to disappear is to be carried. Imagine your lost one as a constellation in draft—
dots unconnected, storyline unfinished. Lift your finger, trace invisible bridges
between pulses, invent an animal only the two of you could name. Speak to it.
Tell it the jokes you’ve been saving, the apologies left unread. Your breath
will fog the air, temporary nebulae that fade before they explain themselves.
That is the lesson. When dawn smudges the blackboard, the bright chalk
of the Milky Way will rinse away. Rise with the light, keep the afterimage
pressed behind your eyelids like a pressed flower of starlight. Carry it quietly,
and when night returns, let it reopen.

instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss?
You ask the question, I answer with echoes:
Say it loud, say it quiet,
say it in the grocery aisle between apples and regret,
say it into voicemail you never send.
Break the sentence,
break the plate,
break the habit of pretending you’re fine.
Wear black, wear neon, wear the sweater that still smells like Sunday.
Dance sloppy, dance slow,
dance with the memory until your shoes come untied.
Write the name on fogged glass, watch it drip,
rewrite it, let it drip again.
Fill the bathtub with old songs,
pull the plug,
watch chorus and water swirl down the silver throat.
Plant a tree, forget to water it,
remember, run back, flood its roots with apologies.
Carry a stone in your pocket,
trade it for a feather,
trade the feather for a joke,
laugh until the joke deserts you.
Empty pockets,
empty lungs,
fill them again.
Loss is a rhythm, grief the drum;
beat it hard,
beat it soft,
beat it until your palms sting truth.
Then, when midnight loosens its grip,
sit still,
feel the pulse under skin say,
‘I am here, and here is wide enough to hold what’s gone.’

How can you grieve and express loss? The ancients answered with seasons,
so let us borrow their wheel.
In autumn, gather every copper leaf and weave a cloak heavy with farewell.
Wear it to the edge of the harvested field where Persephone descended,
and shout the names of what is missing into the furrows.
In winter, build a fire of pine needles and unanswered letters.
Hold your hands above the crackle until numb fingertips relearn warmth;
watch sparks escalate, brief monarchs of ember, coronated then extinct—
understand that blaze and extinguishing are siblings.
Spring arrives carrying green remedies. Kneel; let damp soil pronounce benediction
on your palms. Plant bulbs of memory. Do not fear if you forget where;
flowers remember the coordinates of longing.
When summer unfurls its golden grammar, read every ray aloud.
Find the syllable that sounds like your sorrow and braid it into your hair.
Swim; let water negotiate between body and absence, an ancient treaty of buoyancy.
By harvest moon you will notice the cloak growing lighter, threads thinning
into wind. You will still miss what is gone, but grief will now be fluent,
an elder tongue you can speak without trembling, passing the story forward.

instance_metrics.response:
Hold the autumn leaf in your palm, feel the last heat it borrowed from a vanished noon; wait until it cools, becomes the brittle signature of weather. That is how you begin to grieve: through miniature rehearsals. You let go what you cannot keep, but you do not rush. You name every vein before the wind lifts it.

Then you follow the river that once ferried your laughter. At the bend where cattails lean, speak aloud the anecdotes no one else recorded—the joke about midnight pancakes, the lopsided paper crowns. The water will not answer, yet its patient listening is a mercy.

When night arrives, build a small fire, feed it the letters you never dared to send. Watch ink vapor twist into sentences the sky learns by heart. You might believe you are emptying yourself, but embers teach another rule: ash is evidence of having burned brightly.

In the morning, collect that pale dust, mix it with soil, press a seed inside. Grief is not the opposite of flowering; it is the dark interval roots require, the silenced moment before green remembers its name.

Listen! Grief is a drumline marching inside your chest, boom-boom, a protest against vacancy. It’s the voicemail you replay at 2:17 a.m.—just to hear breathing between syllables; it’s the streetlight flicker you mistake for a wave. They say “move on” like we’re all just loading screens. I say: NO. I will park my tongue in the cul-de-sac of your name, let it echo off stucco walls until neighbors complain.

I graffiti the sky with questions: WHY. YOU. GONE. I steal city chalk, draw doorways on brick, step through to memories where your joke still ricochets off kitchen tile. That joke? I laugh too hard, cough, sputter—tears forming punctuation, because every laugh in mourning ends with a wet comma.

I write status updates nobody likes: “Still breathing.” That’s the poem, folks. Still. Breathing. The lungs are stubborn accordions; they keep squeezing out fugues of missing-you. And I dance to that off-key soundtrack, barefoot on shards labeled Last Birthday, Final Text, Empty Chair.

So ask me, "How can you grieve and express loss?" I answer: Loud. Unapologetic. With glitter in the wound so everyone sees it sparkle under stage lights. I refuse invisible pain. I turn it into thunder you can’t ignore.

In the year the swallows forgot their maps, the goddess of Deleting Names descended, cloak stitched from discarded calendars. She found me kneeling among broken crockery—every plate once served at your table. “Speak,” she commanded, “or your sorrow will petrify the ground you walk.” I whispered the question: “How can I grieve and express loss?”

She drew a chalk circle, scattered three seeds: memory, melody, myth. “First,” she said, “plant memory within your chest like winter wheat. Let it sleep beneath snowdrifts of denial until spring ache thaws it.” Fissures formed in soil; green blades trembled.

“Second, brew melody in a clay jar. Stir with raven feathers till the tune recognizes its own fracture. Sip slowly. Each note will bruise your tongue purple, but song must bleed to breed echoes.” I drank; the sky tilted.

“Third, weave myth,” she concluded. “Tell the world he now rides constellations, steers comets like lantern boats, harvests stardust for tomorrow’s children. Truth alone starves; story feeds the villagers.”

When dawn breached, the goddess vanished, but her chalk ring remained luminous. I stepped beyond it carrying wheat, melody, myth. My grief became a trilogy—roots, rhythm, legend—and in speaking it, I walked unburdened into the untamed day.

The lighthouse on Marrow Cape had only one door, and after the storm it would not close.
Inside, Keeper Ellis paced with oil lamp, counting the seconds since his daughter’s ship vanished.
How can you grieve and express loss? the sea kept asking, slamming questions against the rocks.
Ellis answered by turning the lens, letting its white blade sweep the emptiness again and again.
Each rotation wrote her name across water: Mara, Mara, Mara, in alphabets of light.
Gulls nested in the rafters, mistook the revolving glare for dawn, sang confused lullabies at midnight.
He fed them crumbs of logbook pages, the dates and bearings he could not bear to reread.
When spring arrived, the door finally swelled shut; silence pooled like oil around his boots.
Ellis carried the lamp outside, set it atop the tide line, and extinguished the flame.
Darkness roared, but stars, unstartled, revealed a faint track of phosphorescent foam drifting eastward.
He followed. Wind tugged the words from his throat, braiding them with salt and spray.
Somewhere beyond the headland, lanternless and unmoored, his grief became a second lighthouse—
a pulsing wound to guide other lost sailors home, or at least to warn them where he stood.

instance_metrics.response: You ask, How can you grieve and express loss? I imagine a museum no architect will claim—a vast glass atrium built inside the chest. The first exhibit is soundless: shelves of unspoken words, each sealed in a vial of air. They clink like distant cutlery when you breathe. In the second room, rain is projected on every surface, but you remain dry; the storm remembers itself so you don’t have to. You move past dioramas of almost-futures, photographs that curled when the future rewrote its caption. At the center hangs a pendulum carved from sea-salt, swinging over black sand. Each arc erases yesterday’s footprints; each return redraws them. This is the physics of sorrow: continuous, deliberate, necessary. There is a gift shop at the exit. It sells feathers shed by birds that migrated before anyone noticed winter arriving. You buy one, press it between pages of a book you may never finish. When you leave, the museum follows, contracting to the size of your heartbeat, ticking quietly like a watch with no hands. What is expression if not the courage to carry the display case into daylight, and invite someone to look?

instance_metrics.response: How can we grieve and express loss? I build a glass cathedral inside my ribcage and invite the wind to ring its impossible bells. Their trembling notes describe the hollowness you left with a music no language can rival. I kneel among shattered reflections, collecting slivers of your smile, arranging them into constellations on the cold floor. Faced with their fragile glimmer, I let my tears become stained-glass mortar, binding memory to silence. My prayer is imperfect, cracked, but when dawn filters through my chest, colors spill across the walls of living. I step outside carrying that light like contraband, pressing it into strangers’ palms, planting it beneath bus stop benches, whispering your name so softly pigeons mistake it for cooing. Grief becomes a clandestine graffiti, bright and illegal, scrawled beneath the bridges of conversation. In the grocery aisle I pause by peaches because you once laughed at their fuzz; the ripeness bruises in my hand, and suddenly the glass cathedral shudders, a bell falls, the wind rushes in. instance_metrics.response: In the language of rivers, grief is a bend where water hesitates. Stones gather like unsent letters, smooth as unspoken apologies, and minnows flicker through the pauses. How can you grieve and express loss? Wade in, let the current revise your heartbeat. Cup sorrow in your palms, feel its weightless insistence, then loose it downstream. Tell the heron standing statue-still the story; his silence will polish it. Skip a flat rock for every sleepless night; watch them kiss the surface once, twice, vanish. On the opposite bank, willows practice solitude, their green hair combed by invisible fingers. Sit beneath them. Write the missing name in mud, let rain edit. Grief is not a destination but a confluence: tributaries of memory, regret, gratitude, anger, spilling together to invent a new mouth opening toward sea. When twilight arrives, lantern the bank with fireflies; they volunteer to punctuate the darkness. Listen: bullfrogs pulse like distant drums, reminding the body of rhythms older than ache. Stand, dripping, carrying riverlight inside your ribs. Walk home leaving wet footprints across dusk; tomorrow, when someone asks where you’ve been, open your hands—still damp, still empty—and answer with their shimmering.

instance_metrics.response: We gather around the blue-lit pyre of your last status update, thumbs bent like votive candles. How can we grieve and express loss when the body has migrated to pixels? We scroll, scroll, hoping the algorithm will cough up one more photograph we missed: you, holding sunflowers, grin compressed to two hundred kilobytes. Hearts bloom beneath it, tiny crimson anemones anchoring themselves to data. I type memories into the comment box, delete them, rewrite, delete again. Every sentence seems either too loud or too late. Finally I post a single ellipsis, let silence speak in triplicate. Overnight, strangers tag you in future events, invitations you’ll never open. The calendar sends reminders as though eternity were just another meeting request. At 2 a.m. your typing bubble appears—ghost in the machine—then disappears; I stare at the emptiness it leaves, a negative photograph of conversation. Dawn arrives. I print your selfies, fold them into origami cranes, and release them from the balcony. They ride thermals above the city, dropping fragments of color onto commuters below. Someone picks one up, unfolds it, discovers your laughter, and for a heartbeat you trend again inside a stranger’s wonder.

instance_metrics.response: Suppose loss is a seed, dark and hard, slipped into your pocket by winter. How can you grieve and express loss? First, dare to plant it. Kneel in the tilled dusk of your heart, press the seed into loam made from canceled appointments, unfinished coffee, the voicemail you still can’t delete. Cover it with breath. Wait. Days elongate like shadows of unlit candles; rain rehearses eulogies on the roof. Beneath the soil, the seed confesses to night, splits, sending a pale root downward to negotiate with gravity. When the shoot emerges, it does not resemble the love you remember. Its leaves are veined with questions, its petals smell of raincoats and hospital corridors. Tend it anyway. Water with stories, prune with gratitude, stake it against winds of sudden song. One morning you’ll wake to find a fruit hanging there, shaped exactly like the silence left in a room after someone leaves. Bite into it. The flesh will taste of salt and lightning. Swallow. Feel the seed harden again inside you, smaller now, travel through your blood like a comet searching for another field, another brave gardener.

instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss, the wind asks.
Lay your ear against the hush between heartbeats tonight.
Measure the emptiness that grows like frost on glass.
Whisper the name you carry like embers inside your pocket.
Feel how syllables dissolve, bitter seeds upon the tongue.
Allow your breath to stumble, unbuttoned by sudden weather.
Collect the small remnants: a scarf, a voicemail, soft dust.
Arrange them on the table, constellations of used light.
Let tears fall, patient cartographers sketching vanished roads.
Write a letter no one will open, seal with dusk.
Walk the river's edge where shadows practice forgetting.
Skip stones anyway, because repetition keeps the hands brave.
Admit that memory is a room without reliable clocks.
Sit there, tend the lamp, feed it fragments of laughter.
When morning threatens, water the garden with leftover ache.
Notice how sprouts insist, green vowels in a cracked grammar.
Sing, not to be heard, but to remain porous.
Borrow the moon's habit of waning, then beginning again.
Offer silence a chair, invite it to stay.
In the end, grief is simply love wearing heavier clothes.
You rise, button the sky, step forward carrying both.
The wind nods, satisfied, continuing its untaught hymn.

The question drifts across my coffee like steam: how grieve?
I turn the cup, tracing answers in caffeinated galaxies.
Outside, autumn rehearses elegies with bronze-leafed choirs.
I decide to walk until streets forget their names.
With every step, I release a breath he once borrowed.
Traffic hum becomes the pulse he left behind, unsteady.
I pause at the railway bridge where we counted swallows.
None appear; still, I count, small prayers to vacancy.
Grief, I learn, is arithmetic solved with fading digits.
I confess subtraction to the rails; steel echoes uneven.
My voice returns warped, a stranger wearing my overcoat.
I let it stay—companionship is scarce these days.
At the bookstore I open a novel, exhale inside.
Pages ripple, accepting longing as marginalia of heat.
Evening slides in, purple and deliberate.
I strike a match beside the river, not for ceremony
but to watch reflection swallow flame, prove inverse miracles.
That flicker is the poem I cannot finish.
Tomorrow I’ll repeat, adjusting punctuation, perhaps none.
Expression, I suspect, is practice, not performance—
endless attempts to translate love’s negative space.

instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss? I ask the forest while the first snow drafts its letter to earth. Birch trunks answer by surrendering whatever they cannot carry into winter. Their silence is not refusal but permission: they let the wind articulate the unsaid. I mimic the gesture, unclasping memories like brittle leaves, letting them spin where they will. Each breath clouds, briefly visible, then erased—an honest demonstration of impermanence. I write his name on a frozen pond with the warmth of my gloved thumb; it lingers a heartbeat, then frost reclaims the space. Yet the gesture feels sufficient.

white sky, black branches—
every twig catalogues
another goodbye

Tea steams beside a chair left deliberately empty. I speak into that vacancy, recounting mundane triumphs, the taste of persimmons, a joke he would have ruined by laughing too early.

empty jacket sways
on the back of a door—
wind without body

When the kettle cools, I pour its silence into the garden, trusting roots to metabolize what I cannot.

moonlit compost heap
seed husks turning into soil—
lost, but becoming.

instance_metrics.response:
Dear Astronomer of Absent Stars,

You asked, How can you grieve and express loss? I consulted the sky and offer these instructions.

First, dismantle the clock. Let minutes wander unsupervised, for time obeys different physics inside a hollowed heart. Collect the gears; their metallic glint will recall laughter ricocheting off kitchen tiles.

Second, bake bread. Knead until your wrists ache, until dough remembers a pulse. The rise, the collapse, the rise again—this is the secret topography of mourning.

Third, build a semaphore of colored scarves on the balcony. Signal dawn: I remain. Watch clouds reply in alphabets of shadow.

Fourth, dedicate a shelf to sentences you will never finish. Dust it gently. Language molts there, feather by feather.

Fifth, adopt a stray metaphor. Mine is a suitcase that refuses to close. Feed it postcards, broken shells, ticket stubs. Let it bulge shamelessly.

Finally, when night folds over you, hum the tune that once threaded your names together. Notice how the melody wobbles, compensating for the missing harmony. Accept the imbalance. Stars, after all, keep orbit only by negotiating constant drift.

Write when you can. I will recognize your silence among constellations.

Ever orbiting,
The Cartographer of Echoes.

instance_metrics.response:
I. Inquiry
How can you grieve and express loss?
The question lies like a stone in the mouth,
heavy, tasteless, indisputable.

II. Inventory
One wool coat still smelling of rain.
Two mugs chipped at identical rims.
Three voicemail messages replayed, deleted, restored.
Four a.m.—the hour everything unlatches.

III. Experiment
Place the stone beneath your tongue.
Speak anyway.
Notice how vowels bend around obstruction,
how consonants click against its surface.
This is articulation.

IV. Manifestation
Trace his silhouette in condensation on bus windows.
Let passengers stare; their curiosity is small change.
Release it.

V. Conversation
Tell the cat he is gone.
Apologize for the shorthand of absence.
Listen as she cleans her fur; that rhythm is patience.

VI. Transmutation
Plant the stone beside the porch.
Water it with stories.
Morning after morning, check for sprouts—
not of forgiveness, but accommodation.

VII. Continuance
One day, forget to measure the ache.
Laugh at a pun he would have detested.
Realize halfway through and keep laughing.
Congratulations: the stone has fused with your jawline—
weight still present, yet you can sing with it now.
