instance_metrics.response:
How can you grieve and express loss? the question hangs like mist at dawn,
beaded on spider silk, fragile, trembling.
I walk the wet grass barefoot, learning
how silence can blister the tongue.
First, I name what is missing:
your mug stained with tea rings,
the uneven laugh you left on the answering machine,
the lamp you always forgot to switch off.
Then I unname them, let the syllables
dissolve under my breath like moth wings in rain.
I place my palms to the soil—
how mercilessly the earth goes on making roots!
Worms tunnel hymns beneath my fingertips,
translating sorrow into dark nutrition.
I learn the language: soft collapse, slow renewal.
I let the wind write elegies across my shoulders,
let the sun cauterize the ache.
At night I fold myself inside a quilt of old shirts,
listen to the seams confess stories of travel and sweat.
When tears arrive, I cup them as proof
that rivers still believe in gravity.
Every morning I rise and rearrange the furniture
so memory must work harder to find me.
This is not forgetting; it is choreography—
steps etched into a floor you once crossed.
Loss becomes a dance I perform alone,
partnered by the echo of your name.

Throw paint at the brick wall of your chest—

like subway tokens for the next life.

When silence returns, do not bolt the door.

Write your name on the fogged window,
then theirs beneath it; watch condensation dissolve the boundary.
This is how you grieve: a remix of letting go
looped with the chorus of remember, remember.
This is how you express loss: turn the volume
up until the stars vibrate, then fade to black.

Dear Absence,
How can I grieve and express loss when your handwriting
still lingers on post-its stuck to the fridge?
I draft letters to you daily, address them
"General Delivery, Nowhere," then tuck them
into the hollow of the oak out back.
The tree knows secrets; its rings record
our summers in sepia swirls.
I tell it stories of the night you left:
the kettle screaming like a distant train,
my shadow pacing the hallway tiles.
I confess how I hoard your voice in voicemail jars,
open them only at dusk, release moths of sound
that orbit the lamp until wings fray.
Ink becomes my surrogate bloodstream;
I bleed paragraphs across envelopes,
seal them with breath warmed by tears.
Some mornings I hear replies—
leaves rustle syllables, rain punctuates.
I gather those commas, those ellipses,
string them into bracelets I wear on pulse points.
When people ask why I smell of storm,
I say I’m wearing your last rainfall.
Loss, I’ve learned, is correspondence
that is always returned to sender.
Yet I keep writing, keep walking to the oak,
because grief is a postal route with no final stop,
and every stamped silence keeps you slightly less gone.

Follow neither entirely. Instead, braid them

Night creatures—owls, feral cats, forgotten passwords—
will escort you. Offer them breadcrumbs of sighs;

Do not sing yet. Taste its metallic ache.
Bite down. Let starlight fracture into words.

walk backward and forward, play music of breaking,

Light breaks where no sun shines,
and a man learns to pray
not upward, but inward,

They were indeed simple people,

while tuning his telescope
on the hill above their village.
Below, roofs glimmered like beetle backs,
cook fires smudged the air,
and laughter carried upward
thin and uncertain as smoke.
He saw them wander streets
with baskets, with babies,
with slow deliberate hellos,
as though time were a shy dog
they did not wish to startle.
Their rituals were small:
wash the stair at dawn,
kiss the bread before cutting,
whisper good-night to the lamp.
Nothing to publish, he mused,
nothing to name a nebula after.
Then the lens drifted
and the astronomer watched
galaxies collide billions of years ago,
a violence of light and ruin.
He thought of their baskets,
their cautious hellos,
how each collision up there
would fit inside a single pause
between their spoken syllables.
He lowered the telescope,
folded the tripod,
and walked into town.
At the fountain he asked
to borrow an empty cup
so he could drink night directly.
They passed him one
without question.
He tasted the quiet water
and felt the rush of stars within it.
They were indeed simple people—
and the universe was simpler for it.

They were indeed simple people, the archivist wrote before the ink dried. His ledger smelled of dust, like an attic teaching its lungs to breathe again. He had followed their footprints across generations of river mud, noting every patch where the current rewrote the story. No palaces, no manifestos: only reed mats hung to dry in sun that refused to hurry.

Children played with shadows because toys were too proud to survive such frugality. Grandmothers weighed gossip on kitchen scales and sold the surplus to wind. Men carved whistles from stray feathers, proving emptiness can sing.

At dusk they held a festival for Lost Things: each villager wore a mask made of yesterday, paraded to the edge of the fields, and set it on fire. The flames applauded, grateful for the encore.

Morning haiku found on a gatepost:

A bowl of clear soup—  
moon dissolves into miso,  
night tastes like cedar.

The archivist closed his book, realizing the margin after the final sentence was bigger than the story itself. He left it blank, a silent invitation to whoever reads: take a breath, lay the ledger down, listen to the reed mats exhale.

They were indeed simple people—mark it well—

certain some wandering idea would return for it.

just sixteen notes hummed while sowing rice.
Listen: you can almost hear wingbeats,

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'They were indeed simple people'

instance_metrics.response:
They were indeed simple people,
living at the edge of the enchanted wood,
where spells often wandered out like cattle.
Their cottage smelled of cinnamon bark
and cautious hope.
They knew nothing of wizards' feuds,
dragons' taxations, or the politics of clouds.
Yet each dawn they set two bowls
on the sill for passing pixies,
sprinkled oats lest a unicorn arrive
thin from prophecy.
When thunder rattled kettles,
they whispered maps to raindrops
so storms might find the sea.
Once a prince arrived,
boots glazed with destiny,
demanded directions to a sleeping princess.
They offered bread, hand-drawn charts,
and advice: wake her gently, dreams bruise.
He galloped off, forgetting his manners;
they washed the dust with dandelion soap,
returned to weeding carrots.
Occasionally the royal bards visit,
seeking epic angles, heroic gloss.
They shrug, point at the garden,
explain heroism is simply watering
what thirsts beside you.
The bards leave puzzled,
quills itching for fireworks.
But fireworks are brief,
carrots feed longer.
At dusk the couple sits
among fireflies rehearsing dawn,
their quiet laughter making even
the moon feel ordinary,
which, in fairytales, is the rarest magic.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'They were indeed simple people'

instance_metrics.response:
They were indeed simple people,
or so the inquiry insists.
Allow me, sworn witness,
to complicate the record.
Yes, their hands smelled of loam,
their ledger barely inked.
They owned no clocks
beyond the rooster's impatient throat.
But simplicity, gentlemen,
is not absence—it's choice.
I watched them refuse the caravan
of glittering inventions,
choose instead the slower yoke:
time measured by sap ascent,
wealth tallied in blooming orchards.
They greeted strangers with chairs
before questions,
stored gossip in barrels
until it fermented into story.
When my carriage broke a wheel,
they mended spoke and spirit alike,
charged nothing but a verse.
I offered patents, bridges, gold;
they countered with a seed,
said, 'Plant this where your hurry lives.'
I confess I have yet to do so.
Now you examine ashes,
wonder why their houses burned
without insurance, alarms, wire.
You catalogue what is missing
and call it lack.
I remind you: they danced barefoot
on the courthouse green,
left footprints the fire could not erase.
Check the soles of your own boots;
some earth from their dancing ground
is already traveling with you,
petitioning for gentler verdicts.

Empty me out,

When nothing is left but air

with river stones and birdseed,

with moonlit sand.
A pocket is only a mouth
waiting to speak or be fed.
Shake it, friend,
until memory and promise
ring together like wind chimes.

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call,

a map drawn in the handwriting of water.

The field listened, ears of grain
tilting like golden satellites.
From the scattered debris a cricket climbed,
wearing a key as a cuirass.
Turn me, it chirped, and the hinges
of every unanswered door will sing.

I turned the key.

that migrated south on sentences of light.
The scarecrow bowed, straw ribs rattling
like applause in an empty theatre.

Now the pockets hang inverted, galaxies
bleeding into soil, and every seed
is a syllable of midnight.
I walk away lighter than rumor,
empty as an oath before it is sworn,
carrying only the hum of that cricket
vibrating inside the shell of my ear.

When morning arrives it finds the field
sprouting compasses, all pointing
toward the place the scarecrow walked.
Somewhere there, perhaps, my pockets
wait for me to fill them again
with daylight uncounted.

Beatbox thunder rolls across the subway hall;

Launch it down tracks where the third rail sings.  
A sparrow of fiber, it flares, then is gone;  
But smoke scribes verses the tunnel ticks on.  
Empty-threaded, I board the evening train,  
Light as a chorus, rich as refrains.

Spring apple blossoms drift across the wall,

Midnight’s carnival unfurls its velvet pall;

A clown with galaxies smeared on her cheeks  
Catches my coins in paradoxical beaks;

Shake out my pockets! Out plops a stair,  
Spiral, ivory, impossibly spare;  
The barker plants it under a glass-bell sky,  
"Climb," he whispers, "or ask why."  
I climb; each step is an echoing door,  
Opening to rooms I have been before:  
A classroom humming, an attic of rain,  
The hush in my throat before I knew pain.  
Reaching the top, I find only a seam,  
Which I pull like thread on the edge of a dream,  
Unravelling night till carnival’s gone,

Out flop coupons expired before the last ice age, a kazoo bent into a question mark,

There’s a marble that believes it’s Jupiter and levies taxes on the lint moons.
Listen: the kazoo wheezes parliament, the rubber band votes abstention.
My pockets are a parliamentary democracy of nonsense; bills are passed in crayon.
They impeached a rogue paperclip last Tuesday for conspiring with trousers next door.
I tried to keep order, but chaos campaigns with free stickers.
Now you’ve arrived, bailiff of common sense, to empty this carnival.
Careful! The gum wrapper has diplomatic immunity and the peppermint is booby-trapped with glitter.
Yes, that tiny notebook containing only the word ‘why’ repeated—vital evidence.
Once the detritus hits daylight, it performs interpretive dance and files for workers’ comp.
Still, every absurd fragment carries a joke waiting for a listener.
When you laugh, the marble’s moons align and the kazoo declares peace.
Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call—
There’s room yet for one more ridiculous miracle: your smile.

Whispering of bison ghosts and thunder slow as breathing.

Every plastic coin we clink is engraved with the hourglass tipping.

When the oakling pries apart asphalt, that is the invoice arriving.
Empty me completely; compost the lint, water the ticket stubs until they sprout trains running on dawnlight.
We will walk ticketless, fare paid by our footprints growing moss.
If my pockets become soil, my heart may learn photosynthesis.
Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call—
The planet speaks softly, but only because it has given us all its thunder.

And there, beneath the floorboards, time kneels beside a candled skull,
Whispering prayers in reverse, blessing endings to begin.
I offer my pulse, small flame cupped against eternity.
The violin hushes; the skull opens one rusted lid
And dawn, pale pilgrim, hesitates at the threshold of its gaze.

proof that dawn begins inside
long before it colors the sky.

Brighter than all my doubts combined.

To leak through the interstellar keyhole.
When dawn smudges the sky butter-yellow,
I will close the hatch,

IT is the dead of night:
The kettle whistles in a memory
No longer tethered to flame.

Tiles cool as unspoken apologies,
Windows curtained with moon-washed lace.
Her chair is empty yet warm;
Time has only just stepped away
To fetch more sugar from the cellar.
I touch the worn wood of the table,
Fingertips reading an alphabet of scars—
Places where rolling pins fought dough,
Where comic pages bled with spilled tea,
Where I learned five ways to say love
Without using a single noun.
The radio cracks its brittle knuckles,
Releases a slow waltz into the air.
I follow invisible footprints,
Remember how her slippers sighed,
How her breath scented the night with cinnamon.
She spoke of dark as a friend,
A quilt big enough for the whole street.
Now the quilt remains, but the friend has gone.
I pour two cups anyway,
Steam rising like twin prayers;
One for the ghost beside me,
One for the child I used to be.
When morning unlocks the window,
Only lukewarm silence will remain,
Sweet enough to keep.

An alchemist promising gold for shadow.

Yet somewhere a seed turns in earth,
Feverish for light; somewhere a clock
Rewinds its beating heart.
And I, courier of sleepless minutes,

IT is the dead of night: the forest holds a council.
Pines lean like conspirators, swapping resin secrets;
An owl scribes minutes in staccato hoo.

Log-throne set for the moon, absent monarch—
Clouds have kidnapped her silver gavel.
Still, proceedings commence:
Crickets file motions for louder summers;
Moss petitions for softer rain.
A brook offers budget forecasts in liquid arithmetic.

From the understory, a lone firefly speaks:
“Let us discuss the tyranny of darkness.
I propose a thousand-light coalition.”
His abdomen blinks applause.

But the bats object, citing navigation rights.
“Light pollution!” they squeak.
A debate flutters, wings versus glow.

In the hush that follows, wind arrives,
Carrying ballots of cedar scent.
Trees vote by rustling leaves—
Yes, No, Abstain—all at once.

Finally, the verdict: coexist.
Glow a little, fly a little, listen a lot.
The owl stamps approval with a talon.

Just then, the moon escapes captivity,
Slides into her sky-seat, radiant and late.
She ratifies the treaty in pearl ink,
Drapes luminescence over fern and fur.

I, unseen auditor beneath my blanket of stars,
Record the minutes in heartbeats,
And slip away before dawn adjourns the night.

Both hush and humming memory.
Night yawns outside; I welcome it—
A lullaby without a lyric.

They've felt sirens at the door.
I nurse a mug of bitter brew,

Each swirl a case I didn't solve,
Each gulp a vow I won't forget.
Somewhere the radiator ticks,
A time bomb in metallic codes;
Somewhere a saxophone inflicts
A blues confession down the road.
My fedora rests on armrest ledge,
Its brim still damp with alley rain;
Evidence—one lipstick smudge—
Clings to the wool like guilty stain.
But for a heartbeat, sirens fade,
Files close, the world suspends;
The couch plays willing barricade
Against the leads and loose-end friends.
Streetlights bleach the parquet floor,
Traffic mutters underfoot,
Yet I stay grounded, evermore,
In corduroy of softer truth.
The city's full of restless grit,
And I’ll return to chase its myth;
For now, the case can call it quits—
Upon this cozy couch I sit.

Transforms to streamlet, clear and bright;
I sip and feel the minnows flow,
Silver thoughts in gentle light.
A book left open on my knee
Sprouts clover leaves along its spine,
Poems braid with bumblebee,
Margins drunk with dandelion wine.
The dog's soft sigh at carpet’s edge
Rolls over hills of amber grain;
His dreaming paws tread clover hedge,
Chasing scents of summer rain.
No chores can breach this pastoral,
No ping, no clock, no rigid plan;
Just muttered hearts of miracle
Beating low as earth began.
Evening clouds in window frame
Migrate like sheep to fading west;
A shepherd moon will call them home,
Will guard the valley of my rest.
So I remain in sunlit myth,
Worlds away, yet perfect fit;
Fields bloom beyond the room's thin writ—
Upon this cozy couch I sit.

Upon this cozy couch I sit,
cradled by cushions that remember
late-night laughter and popcorn salt.
Outside, sparrows embroider the sky
with zigzag stitches of quick wings,

carrying cardamom rumors and warm clouds.
Somewhere, the city’s iron heart
keeps grinding its relentless gears,
yet here, fabric blooms into silence.
I sink, a stone in velvet water,
until worries drift beyond reach.
Dreams sprout like houseplants,
leaning toward the lamp’s false sun,
leafing through possibilities I forgot to plant.
In this small republic of softness,
I crown myself monarch of pause,
issuing gentle decrees: breathe, listen, be.
When I finally stand again,
creasing the cushions back to innocence,

stitched from this square of evening repose.

Upon this cozy couch I sit,

a muted, kettle-tempered hum.
The fireplace performs a dance
of copper, gold, and cherry red;
Its sparks attempt a brief romance
with stories spinning in my head.
I summon knights of tarnished pewter,
a shy court jester, painted skies;

between the pillows’ corduroy sighs.
Each squeak of leather, faint yet bright,
becomes a trumpet in the hall;

where paper snowflakes gently fall.
Outside, the world may growl and spin,
its engines soaked with oil and fear;
But here poor dragons rest within,
hushed by the music of my sphere.
So let the storm coils hiss and spit;
Its teeth cannot pierce dreams tonight.
Upon this cozy couch I sit,
a kingdom built of foam and light.
And if I drift to slanted sleep,
let songs of hearth and rain remain,
so in my mind this warmth may keep,
till dawn redeems the night again.

beneath a tea towel of cable-knit throw.

turning my cheeks a golden brown.

train for a marathon—pop pop pop!

as I butter another slice of time.
Remote balances on the armrest, skeptical.

retrieve a tribe of rogue popcorn kernels,

so I munch chocolate, declare new holidays:

In this republic of fluff I’m president,
passing legislation with a single yawn.

Eventually, sunset paints the windowsill honey,
and even bread must cool.
I wiggle upright, dust off crumbs,
pledge to be productive tomorrow—
really, tomorrow—and shuffle to bed
like a baguette searching for dreams.

We sink into the dust,
while glass towers stare, hollow-eyed,
across the cracked mosaic streets.
Escalators hang frozen mid-sentence;
advertisements fade to ghost-colored sighs.

Someone once called this a city.
Now cicadas speak louder than commerce,
and ivy negotiates prime real estate
on the marbled steps of banks.
I walk through revolving doors
that no longer revolve, spill
curtains of sunlit pollen instead of profit.

Elevators yawning in their shafts
are organ pipes for the wind.
It plays a hymn of dismantling,
a requiem that somehow lifts.

I find a child’s toy car,
rust-kissed, roofless,
stuffed with stems of goldenrod.
Even ruin dresses itself
in small ceremonies of color.

When evening crosses the power lines,

"We sink into the dust," sang the oracle, her throat full of silt and ember. She stood atop the last stair of the ziggurat, while below, the river retracted like a silver snake into its cracked shell. First went the banners, unthreaded into ochre ribbons that joined the swarm of sand. Then went the stories, peeled from tongues like old paint. The air smelled of forgotten libraries. Children tried to catch letters tumbling from their mouths, but the alphabet was already turning into dunes.

At dusk the horizon split; a red seam opened where the sun should set, and from it marched shadows shaped like our better selves. They laid their hands upon our shoulders, gentle, coaxing. We were tired. We allowed ourselves to kneel.

Kneeling became reclining; reclining became settling; settling became sediment. Our hearts ticked slower, softer, until they matched the patient metronome of planetary drift. A final exhale, collective and warm, billowed upward, curving into nascent clouds. Above us, the first rain in centuries began to write new sentences on the cooling skin of earth.

let ashes stipple dawn with brief confetti.

and the air smells of possible soups.

paint chips flaking from city benches, 
stray coins sunning on asphalt, 
the public facts of sparrows. 
Secrets behave like mercury:

contain them, they still poison the glass. 
I have watched how they shimmer 
in the corners of eyes, 
strained smiles trembling like tightropes. 
Feet deserve earth, not wire. 
Let’s ground ourselves in sidewalk sincerity—
call a cloud a cloud, 
a doubt a doubt. 
If vulnerability is a door, 
knock with an open palm, 
not a locksmith’s grin. 
I will answer honestly: 
I, too, fear empty theaters; 
I, too, hum to broken kettles. 
But the stage is safer unrigged, 
the melody clearer without muffled drums 
of covert thunder. 
So keep the clandestine sealed 
in jars labelled PRIVATE, 
stored on a shelf I need not dust. 
Together we’ll cook daylight into stew, 
dipping ladles of candor 
that steam but never scorch.

Secrets fled like moths before the noon,
Their wings burning into simple dust.
What remained was a room, four honest walls,
And a single cedar table where strangers could meet
With nothing to barter but open palms.
I left then, lighter than prophecy,
Carrying nothing but the sound of my own footsteps,
Loud, clear, and mine.

"Please spare me your secrets. I have no more shelves for jars labeled ‘Fragile—do not expose to light.’ The pantry of my mind already rattles when the wind passes through, glass against glass, histories clinking. hands like mine, unlike mine,
creased with similar moonlines of labor.
Their laughter, their fatigue,
float between the ripples,
turning bitterness to velvet.
Shade meets light, dark courts pale,
and in their union I taste
midnight merged with morning.
When the cup is empty,
a ring of brown, black, white remains—
imperfect orbit, reminder that
separation was never the point.
The day ahead will fracture:
meetings, sirens, headlines,
guards at invisible borders.
But for one swallow I carried
a world dissolving safely into itself,
beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
proof that even bitterness can be sweet
when shared, when stirred,
when lifted to astonished lips.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Beautiful brown mixed with black and white'

instance_metrics.response:
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white
spreads across the universe like star-dust pastry,
a helix of soil, bone, and coal
kneaded by galaxies’ invisible palms.
In the beginning, says an amused photon,
color did not stand in line;
it pirouetted through vacuum,
leaving fingerprints on meteors,
trailing pollen behind comets.
Now telescopes collect its letters:
sepia storms on Jupiter,
ashy cliffs on Europa,
frosted craters veined with rust.
Astronomers argue hex codes,
but the night itself keeps forgery;
its cloak is woven from melted echoes—
brown of forgotten forests, black of collapsed suns,
white of embryonic flames preparing to roar.
I lie on damp grass, binocular heart tilted upward,
and feel that same mingling inside my pulse—
violins of ancestry, drums of desire,
wheezing accordions of grief.
Blood remembers the cosmos’ first palette
and refuses to dilute.
A shooting star drags chalk across sienna sky;
I wish for a future that matches its streak:
color crossing color at impossible speed,
leaving nobody untouched.
The meteor fades but the wish remains,
humming quietly, gravitational, true—
beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
spelling, again and again, the shape of infinity.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Beautiful brown mixed with black and white'

instance_metrics.response:
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white
was the crayon I could never find in elementary school,
so I made it myself—
pressed ebony into ivory until dusk appeared,
threw cocoa on top until it tasted like home.
The art teacher frowned at the mess,
but I was busy inventing my own face.
My father’s midnight skin, my mother’s paper moon,
meeting where my freckles bloom like small rebellions.
On parent night, their hands wove together
above my smudged drawing,
proof that pigments, too, can love.
On the playground, other children asked,
What are you?—
as if a single answer could color the wind.
I kept a secret palette in my pocket:
arena soil, chimney soot, chalk dust from hopscotch lines.
During recess I’d grind them between thumb and forefinger,
letting them whirl away in the breeze,
so the whole yard became a kaleidoscope
nobody could name.
Now grown, I paint murals on city walls—
vines of walnut and pearl, ravens wrapped in snow.
Each stroke tells the next child watching,
Make your shade louder than their question.
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white
is not confusion; it is crescendo.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Beautiful brown mixed with black and white'

instance_metrics.response:
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white
carpets the forest after rain.
Mushroom caps, tipped with soot and milk,
bristle from cinnamon loam.
A deer steps through veils of birch bark,
its hide a parchment scribed by shadows,
and pauses to drink from a pond
reflecting winter clouds in peat tea.
The world is brewing itself.
Earth exhales petrichor—
coffee grounds, fire ash, flour—
and every breath sticks to my lungs
like damp clay begging shape.
I kneel, press palms to soil;
hands come up stippled, marbled,
painted by an impartial god.
Under the top layer, roots converse,
telling stories in braided threads:
how they share sugar, how they warn of beetles,
how difference is merely direction.
A crow cackles overhead, feathers slick with oil and chalk;
when it opens its wings I see
a monochrome cathedral lined with cocoa velvet.
It lifts, scattering drizzle that beads on my hair
like miniature planets unsure of their orbit.
I taste them and find nostalgia—
for fireplaces, for inkpots, for bread crusts—
flavors speaking fluent dusk.
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
forest tongue licking the silence clean.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Beautiful brown mixed with black and white'

instance_metrics.response:
["Brush in hand, I lean over the silent canvas,
beautiful brown mixed with black and white, newly awakened earth.
Walnut, moonless midnight, first snowfall, swirling into wet conversation,
pigments quarrel, flirt, then settle into impossible topographies.
There are deserts being born where bristles hesitate,
and thunderheads gathering wherever the solvent whispers.
I tilt the frame and continents slide like friendly tectonics;
rivers invent themselves, coppery then charcoal, suddenly pale as sighs.
What story might a color tell when freed from lineage?
Perhaps the evening deer drinking sky-stained water,
or the long, low note of a cello searching dusk.
I only know the spiral keeps widening, widening,
as if creation remembered the very first compromise:
light agreeing to become shadow so that shape could speak.
Somewhere behind me, the studio lamp blinks twice—applause
from the universe’s cheapest seat—
and I laugh, elbow deep in recombinant dusk.
When finally the swirl rests, it resembles no flag,
no map, no heraldic badge of ownership,
only belonging itself: a pilgrim hue
that refuses single pronunciation, carrying every tongue.
I lay the brush down. The room smells like rain
about to fall on lands I’ve never seen.",
"I was born between a coffee bean and a snapshot of snow.
Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
my mother’s lullaby a gospel riff, my father’s whisper of frost.
Neighbors asked what I would be when I grew pigment,
as if skin were a résumé.
I answered in crayons, melting them on the radiator
until they dripped into marbled lakes,
colors refusing to separate, choosing a shared citizenship.
Schoolyard sunlight questioned my edges,
but wind braided my hair with bridge cables,
and every pigeon on the telephone wire voted me in.
Grandma showed me quilts stitched from funeral clothes and wedding gowns;
she said, Harmony isn’t the absence of contrast,
it’s contrast seated at the same small table.
I carried that table to parks, to buses, to voting booths,
inviting strangers to rest elbows on the possibility of together.
Some still search for pure tones,
polishing their mirrors until they forget to look through them.
Let them search.
I’ll keep dancing inside the pause after thunder,
where branches, asphalt, and clouds trade secrets,
where coffee, ink, and chalk kiss like runaway teenagers,
where my name is longer than dusk and just as wide.",
"In the cafe at the corner of Yesterday and Yet,
beautiful brown mixed with black and white performs
an unrecorded symphony each morning.
Steam from espresso rises like rumor over the chessboard tiles,
matching the swirl in my porcelain cup:
sienna crema drifting through obsidian brew,
milk descending in whispering snowdrifts
that never quite reach the bottom.
Across from me, an old man hovers his rook,
fingertips stained with newspaper ink,
soft thunderclaps of headlines no one will remember.
We study patterns—on the board, in the cup, on the street—
dark squares, light squares, the subtle midtones of spilt sugar,
humans crossing asphalt crosswalks striped like zebras,
traffic lights blinking abstracts of permission.
The rook lands, capturing my knight;
simultaneously, the crema shapes a horse’s head before dissolving.
Everything is a lesson in fleeting geometry:
how opposites share borders,
how flavor expands by refusing singularity,
how victory and surrender swirl together, indistinguishable, delicious.
When the game ends, we tip the pieces into velvet night,
sip the last lukewarm swirl, wipe foamy mustaches,
and step outside where dawn is steeping
the city’s brickwork in a fresh batch of sepia.
No winner, no loser, only stories tasted
and the echo of porcelain settling into saucer.",
"On the mountain pass where seasons braid their hair,
beautiful brown mixed with black and white
writes calligraphy across cliff faces.
Clods of peat, raven feathers, quartz dust
circulate in the river’s reckless wrist,
inking verses no cartographer can translate.
Dusk kneels, emptying its pockets of cinnamon soil;
night pours obsidian, filling crevasses with unscripted depth;
dawn scatters flour of newborn snow,
each layer negotiating with the next,
never erasing, only annotating.
From a distance, the strata resemble library shelves,
each color binding a chapter of temperature and pressure:
volcanic tantrums, glacial patience, the love affair of roots and rocks.
A mountain goat leaps, leaving commas in midair;
an eagle circles, placing parentheses around the entire valley.
Even silence here shows its palette:
the hush of moss, the hush of shadow, the hush of blinding glare.
I press my palm to a boulder warm with afternoon memory
and feel the pulse of ages slow but stubborn.
It tells me balance isn’t stillness;
it’s the choreography of substance accepting change,
earth sipping darkness and light in equal, deliberate measure.
When I descend, my boots are stained with thesis:
the world becomes whole by refusing to sort itself.",
"I unscrew the cap of the fountain pen—
beautiful brown mixed with black and white
waits in the barrel like untold gossip.
Sepia base, a dash of nocturnal pitch,
and one snowflake of titanium powder
glinting like sudden truth in half-finished sentences.
I tilt the nib and watch alchemy tumble forward,
stringing itself along cotton paper pores.
Words emerge tasting of campfire and midnight paper cranes,
each letter a color that cannot be named on paint chips.
Sometimes it leans chocolate, promising comfort;
sometimes charcoal, whispering secrets of windows left open;
sometimes pearl, forgiving yesterday’s erasures.
Margins fill with migratory footprints,
dialogue between shades negotiating punctuation treaties.
I remember classrooms where ink had to be uniform blue,
where deviations were corrected in sterile red.
Now the page grows a forest of mixed-trunk trees,
birch hugging walnut, ebony sharing sky with ash.
Story thrives in the underbrush where colors overlap,
where plot twists hide like foxes beneath fallen leaves.
When the final period settles, it glimmers bronze,
then black, then nearly white depending on the lamp.
I close the notebook, ink still drying—still deciding—
a restless spectrum unboxed, unbottled, unfinished,
eager for tomorrow’s sentence to widen its horizon."]

instance_metrics.response:
["ADIEU, O soldier! The harbor bells are weeping low,
Their copper throats swallow the dawn's pale rose.
Your epaulets glitter like frost on raven wings,
Yet my fingers tremble at the thought they cling.
I stitched you a pocket of violet-scented lore,
A thimble of summer tucked inside the war.
Take it, my bold one, press it to your chest,
Remember the orchard where we once confessed.
I will linger there with a lantern's gentle glow,
Charting constellations only lovers know.
If musket smoke clouds the compass of your breath,
Close your eyes, step beyond the riddle of death.
For love is a spy that slips every trench,
Skips over ruins, unfastens each wrench.
It tastes like rain on an iron barrel's rim,
It sings through whistles when daylight grows dim.
Should drums impose silence on your beating heart,
I will steal the cadence and keep the art.
And if you return, crowned with mud and grace,
I will wash the distance from your traveler's face.
But if you fall where crimson poppies rise,
You will bloom in the Europe of my eyes.
ADIEU, O soldier! My goodbye is a seed;
May it sprout into peace, may it answer our need.
I whisper your name to the merciful tide,
Let the waves deliver what fate may decide.",
"ADIEU, O soldier! the cradle rocks in my mind,
A ghost of lullabies that you left behind.
I once buttoned your coat against autumn's chill,
Now the nation straps armor my caress cannot fill.
Your boots rang childhood across wooden floors,
But the march you follow now has steeper chores.
Remember the sycamore shading our lane,
Its bark mapped with initials you etched with a cane.
When artillery thunder mimics summer storm,
Recall how I wrapped you safe, small and warm.
The bread I bake will cool on the sill,
Waiting for footsteps that shadow the hill.
Each dawn I polish the window glass bright,
In case your silhouette alights with the light.
I have folded prayers into kerchiefs of white,
Tucked in your pocket for the darkest night.
Let them unfurl when courage feels thin,
Like wings released from a chrysalis skin.
The orchards will blossom without your gaze,
Yet every petal rehearses your praise.
If letters arrive, smudged with distant clay,
I will trace every line the tears convey.
But should the silence of folded flags descend,
Know, my dear soldier, love cannot end.
I will meet you where stories refuse decay,
Past gunmetal horizons, in eternal May.
ADIEU, O soldier! Return to my arms someday.",
"ADIEU, O soldier! I speak to the stranger within,
The boy I was before drums taught my skin.
I polish my rifle until it mirrors my doubts,
In its steel I count the reasons and routes.
The train platform yawns like a canyon of years,
Families waving confetti made of unshed tears.
I taste farewell in the grit of my teeth,
Yet adventure hums like a sword in its sheath.
War is a riddle without any why,
Only the thunder that lives in the sky.
But comrades depend on the heft of my name,
So I shoulder the weather, the guilt, and the flame.
I pack no medals, only ink and a pen,
To sketch every silence I'll meet again.
If courage retreats before bullets and blame,
I will think of the kitchen lamp's amber flame.
The smell of fresh rain when school bells rang,
The echo of mountains where shepherds sang.
These will be armor no smithy can cast,
A relic of futures, a relic of past.
Should I return with shadows stitched tight,
Guide me through doorways back into light.
And if I remain where barbed lullabies call,
Plant me a tree that remembers us all.
ADIEU, O soldier! I march with both fear and grace.",
"ADIEU, O soldier! cried the fickle sea,
Foam-fingered, restless, forever free.
It watched you board the iron-gray craft,
While gulls composed elegies on the shaft.
Your silhouette shrank to a charcoal mark,
A dot of ink on the page of dark.
The ocean, that archive of tidings and bones,
Hummed ancient ballads in submarine tones.
Remember, it whispered, my salt is your own,
Blood and brine by moonlight sewn.
When shells fall heavy as meteors of rust,
And earth becomes powder beneath the gust,
Call on my tides to cradle your dread,
I will rock the bullets to coral instead.
I have seen empires rise like foam,
And empires sink where leviathans roam.
Cannons are brief as the blink of a whale,
Compared to the span of a sailor's tale.
If you are swallowed by trenches of sand,
I will ferry your story from land to land.
Fishermen's nets will lift your refrain,
Children will hum it like summer rain.
Yet if you return, boots damp with brine,
I'll crown your stern with a mariner's sign.
ADIEU, O soldier! Though you depart from my quay,
Know every far battle begins in my spray.",
"ADIEU, O soldier! we echo from shards of time,
Phantom recruits formed of dust and rhyme.
We float between bugle and battlefield hush,
Our footprints bloom in the poppy's blush.
We have tasted the cordite of centuries past,
Watched banners ascend, watched banners fall fast.
Yet the cycle reacquires its ravenous spin,
Another bright heartbeat is ushered within.
We gather around you, invisible choir,
Stitching your shadow with filament fire.
Take our experience, weigh it like lead:
Courage is living while dancing with dread.
We have feasted on thunder and drank from despair,
But even in ruins found music in air.
Remember the moon is a salt-lanterned drum,
It calls you home when your spirit is numb.
Speak to the silence behind every roar,
There you'll find reasons worth fighting for.
Not honor nor glory that rust in the rain,
But the fragile belief that love must remain.
If you survive, breathe slowly and learn
How fragile the candles of mortals burn.
If you fall, do not fear the undiscovered,
We will bear you where stars are uncovered.
ADIEU, O soldier! Step forth, yet be wise:
Peace can be born where the last soldier dies."]

"ADIEU, O soldier! We fold the dawn around your shoulders of brass,
And let the bugle spiral, a copper river through the hills.
You march away beyond the map, where clouds rehearse their drills,
Where poppies crouch like quiet flames in shattered shards of glass.
We learned to write your name in dust, to carve it out of rain,
To stitch it to the empty chair and pour it in the tea.
Night after night we rang the moon like coins for your decree,
Yet silence paid the only wage and absence signed the pane.
But do not think farewell is loss; it is a seed in flight,
A thistle on the migrant wind that travels for its bloom,
It brings us rumors from the front: chrysanthemums of plume,
A letter sealed with powder smoke, still warm with furnace light.
Return, return—though time may break the road you used to know,
Our beating hearts will patch the cracks with drums and candle glow.
Until that hour, we'll keep the watch, a lighthouse in the snow,
And whisper to the restless sea the vows we cannot show."

"ADIEU, O soldier! Polished alloy gleams in winter's ultramarine.
The city drones recite your code in corridors of steam,
While neon lilies open on the roofs like wounded screens.
You step onto the shuttle pad, a silhouette in green.
We reprogrammed our lullabies to fit your metric heart,
Syncopated pulses memed from satellites afar.
Children on the balcony trace wishes through the sparks,
Hoping that your orbit writes their names across the dark.
Within your chest, a planet spins—compressed in quartz and wire—
Carrying our fragile prayers like seeds of distant fire.
Remember us: the traffic lights that blinked just for your stride,
The corner stall that flavored soup with saffron and with pride.
Wars are waged in whispers now; no trumpet splits the dawn,
Only quiet algorithms turning sorrow on and on.
Yet though your armor's carbon light, your burden's heavy still,
For every victory calculation tallies one more kill.
When galaxies surrender and alarms at last are through,
Return to Earth, remove the helm, let dawn recalibrate you.
Till then, we'll wet the circuit boards with sacramental oil,
And set a candle by the screen where last we saw your scroll."

"ADIEU, O soldier! The cider river rolls between the orchards red,
And apple blossoms armor you more softly than the lead.
Your mother tied a ribbon to the gatepost by the lane,
A fluttering declaration that her love still stakes its claim.
You smell the August barleyfields, the clover and the hay,
The blackbird's fractal anthem knitting sunrise to the day.
Yet boots must press a different soil, and eyes must meet the glare
Of lands where dust devours the sun and mercy thins the air.
Carry with you—tucked inside the rations and the maps—
These homestead sounds: the kettle's sigh, the carriage on the tracks.
For when the cannons thunder and the sand turns salt with tears,
Let memory ferment like wine and drown the jackal fears.
Perhaps the gods of battle will accept a rustic song,
And trade their iron verdict for a field where lambs belong.
Should they refuse, we'll gather here when twilight drains the sky,
And pour an empty cup for you beside the firefly.
Till next harvest, blow a kiss along the barley's golden queue;
We'll feel it in the rustling leaves that whisper back to you."

"ADIEU, O soldier! My white sleeves flap like gulls along the pier,
Stained with tincture, iodine, and hours of volunteer.
You rise from sheets that smelled of smoke and morphine sterile snow,
The stitched horizon on your skin now healed enough to go.
Outside, the harbor cranes salute with riveted salute,
An orchestra of shipyard bells vibrating like a lute.
Remember how you drifted here: a broken mast, a scream,
Then bandages became a raft that ferried you through dream.
We talked of fishing villages, of childhood lemonade,
Of how the lilac by the church could bruise the evening shade.
Those stories were the medicine the pills could never match;
They threaded hope through shattered bone and knitted every patch.
Now, boots restored, you stand once more, a lighthouse-eyed recruit,
Ready to retrace the tide to undiscovered routes.
I hand you back your dog-eared book, its pages warping still,
And tuck a pressed magnolia inside the windowsill.
If shrapnel songs return someday, remember this calm bay:
The seabirds in their alabaster cloaks, the salt of early May.
Until the world relearns to heal and violence comes undone,
I'll wave my kerchief at the prow where once you lay, my son."

"ADIEU, O soldier! croaks the toad who wears a general's sash.
The moon rolls like a tambourine across a field of ash.
Here, armies are of paper cranes arrayed in boxwood squares,
Their wings whispering pacifist amendments to the airs.
You, lone conscript of kaleidoscopes, sling rainbows from your gun,
Turning checkpoints into gardens, bullets into tangerine sun.
But orders call you elsewhere now: a circus in the sky,
Where constellations juggle myths and comets learn to cry.
Pack lightly: just a swirl of jazz, a stanza full of smoke,
The memory of a carnival where every gear awoke.
When you arrive, salute the stars—they'll curtsey in reply,
And stitch your name on cosmic silk with letters two miles high.
Should gravity grow homesick and demand you pay the fee,
Feed it marbles from your pocket; it will set your orbit free.
And if the war turns serious—if trumpets start to sneer,
Unfold the map of laughter that I hid behind your ear.
Follow the dotted giggles until peace erupts in cream;
Then drift back down on custard clouds and join our lucent dream.
Till that absurd reunion, we toast with tea of indigo,
Murmuring your parting words into the odd afterglow."

Adieu, O soldier! The gulls cry at the ragged edge of dawn, scattering silver scales across the harbor’s throat.
Your boots drum salt into the pier while trumpets search for breakfast in the clouds.
I braid the wind with ribbons torn from yesterday’s flag, trying to knit a promise strong enough to follow your march.
Cannons sleep for now, but tremble in their iron beds, restless with the hunger of tomorrow.
You do not look back; discipline is a blade that forbids soft returns.
Still, I feel your shadow linger, tasting the last peach of my silence.
I will fold that flavor into letters that cross the sea inside green bottles, each bottle a miniature lighthouse steering you home.
Should shrapnel remake the cartography of your heart, remember the map we drew beneath the sycamore, when the river borrowed our names and kept them cool.
The world will spin its old machinery, grinding years into powders of regret and revelation.
Yet every turning gears a secret oath: that after war unbuttons its rusted coat, summer will stitch the sky with parade confetti, and my arms, no longer empty wharves, will open like sails to reclaim your breath.

Adieu, O soldier! You step beyond the picket fence where childhood crickets bow their tiny violins to dusk.
Helmets and kisses clash in the half-lit kitchen; flour ghosts still cloud your jacket from last night’s hurried bread.
Mother writes your name in sugar across the counter, believing sweetness might armor you stronger than iron.
I, your sister, crouch on the staircase, trapping tears between knuckles, afraid leakage will rust your courage.
Outside, the bus coughs impatience; sparrows zigzag like torn diary pages fleeing discovery.
You promise postcards, but promises are slender as the thread that once anchored Father’s medal before the trenches unraveled him.
When the door sighs, time elongates—a ribbon pulled from a magician’s fist: colorful, endless, ridiculous in its insistence on continuing.
We shall set an extra plate at supper, tricking the ache with porcelain silhouettes.
Night will slump into our living room wearing your cologne of gun oil and anticipation.
We will weave rumors into scarves, wrap them around the radio, and hope static can translate into heartbeat.
Over and over we will practice that aching invocation, letting its echo grow broad as a shield: Adieu, O soldier, return clothed in dawn.

Adieu, O soldier! I rehearse to the mirror while fastening brass buttons across the chest of my doubt.
The uniform clings like a prophecy too formal for dancing.
In the barracks laughter ricochets off tin lockers, bright yet breakable, a row of ceramic birds jolted by storms.
We polish our fears until they shine, pretending reflection equals invisibility.
Soon the train will scrawl its iron signature across the valley; its whistle already tugs at the roots of every flower trying to keep me.
I slide a harmonica into my pocket—a pocket-sized horizon of blue notes for when the sky burns red.
Before departure, I squat to lace my boots; earth presses its pulse into my fingertips, reminding me that soil is only fallen stars practicing patience.
The lieutenant barks Move, and we become commas in a sentence history drafts in gunpowder.
If I fall, let my body form a semicolon, insisting there is still more story.
Until then, the horizon flutters like an unturned page; I walk into its blankness, leaving the mirror to keep the farewell echoing softly behind me: Adieu, O soldier, commence.

Beyond the viewport, Mars glows like a cautious ember, while Jupiter flaunts storms the size of kingdoms we have never kissed.
My exosuit hisses, sealing air tight around skin and longing.
Somewhere in the galley, robots shuffle deck listings, wagering which of us will return with biological coordinates intact.
I slip photographs into the cloud drive—mom, a dog, a sunrise unfiltered by radiation—digital talismans immune to vacuum.
The launch siren crescendos; gravity shrugs off its ancient duties, and we float, weightless epilogues awaiting paragraphs of battle.
Outside, space is a manuscript with no punctuation, only dark between brighter nouns.
When plasma fire begins to draft casualties, I will whisper your name into the comm, hoping frequency itself can fold like origami into a safe house.
Should my orbit decay, trace my trajectory in constellations and teach our children to read the glowing script: Here drifted one who loved.
Until then, keep the telescope polished and your lullabies uploaded.
Adieu, O soldier, print my heartbeat among the stars.

instance_metrics.response:
ADIEU, O soldier! The station roof exhales its evening pigeons,
while lamps bloom like slow chrysanthemums above the tracks.
Your boots clink medals out of gravel, a muted ticker-tape
for departures nobody rehearses. I hold my breath as if
it were another telegram, words punched in Morse by the heart.
Smell of coal and oranges. Mothers unspool scarves until
they resemble sunset banners, trembling but brave.
You turn, half silhouette, half lullaby I once knew;
wind embroiders silver epaulets upon your coat.
Clouds march west in ragged platoons—little cousins
drafted by weather’s indifferent trumpet. I want to say
return, return, yet my tongue salutes the empire of silence.
Across the platform, a child releases a wooden boat
into a puddle, convinced the ocean begins there.
So too you wade into distance, small at first, then smaller,
until absence closes like a door I cannot name.
Somewhere beyond the horizon, cannons rehearse thunder;
here, sparrows rehearse morning. Both, I pray, will spare you.
Carry this farewell as a cameo in your pocket:
a tiny portrait of home, blinking whenever you open your hand.

instance_metrics.response:
In the valley where the foxgloves lean, a chapel bell rang true,
and every petal whispered soft, "ADIEU, O soldier, adieu!"
You marched beneath the alder leaves, your rifle kissed with dew;
the brook kept time, the lark kept watch, the sky kept turning blue.

We villagers stitched flags of prayers, embroidered sun and sheaf,
to wrap around your steadfast heart like secret handkerchief.
We set them sailing in the wind, bright pages in relief,
hoping they'd reach your bivouac and grant your soul belief.

Through fields of smoke and cannon roar, you trod the iron trail,
reciting letters yet unwrit, each pause another tale.
You pictured wheat that bowed in waves, not men whose faces pale,
and heard our bell inside the guns, a gentler, elder scale.

When moonlight touched the barrack roof, you breathed the distant tune;
you felt the foxgloves crowd your boots, the brook returning soon.
Though weary eyes saw barbed horizons fray beneath the moon,
the echo of a humble church became your silver rune.

So battle on, brave wanderer, let memory be your clue;
our chapel bell still waits to sound a welcome back to you.
Till then we keep the valley green and whisper night and noon,
"ADIEU, O soldier, briefly go—come home by lilac June."
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

instance_metrics.response:
Dear Brother,

They told me to say goodbye with roses, but roses bruise in our climate,
so I send you marigolds—stubborn suns that refuse to wilt.
"ADIEU, O soldier!" they cried on the pier, words shot from brass mouths,
but you know I distrust fanfare. I prefer ink, salt, and honest weather.

Father’s nets are mending on the fence. He has tied them with red yarn,
so the gulls think they are wounds and keep away.
Mother hums the anthem in reverse; she claims it unwinds fear.
I believe her because the moon still floats after being riddled with holes.

I painted your shadow on the boathouse wall to keep you present.
Sometimes it complains of boredom, so I lend it my coat
and teach it steps of the fisherman’s reel. It is improving.

Do the shells there carry our shoreline when you press them to your ear?
Does sand remember it was glass before it broke?
Wherever you camp tonight, carve one sentence into a ration tin:
"Home is not a place but a promise."

Keep the tin close. When peace finally spots you among camouflage,
open it and let the promise shine like a lighthouse at noon.

Love always,
Lina

On the ramparts of dawn, the gods unroll a crimson tapestry,

"ADIEU, O soldier!" cries the oracle, doves scattering like torn parchment.

You descend the mountain wearing silence for armor.
Rivers bend their silver knees; elk lower antlers in salute.
Still, war waits beyond the cedar frontier, sharpening its teeth on iron moons.

Nightly, Hera’s wind carries my voice to you,
singing of hearth smoke curling like serpents too tired to strike.

I have hidden a compass in your breath—exhale, and petals will point home.

When the last spear sleeps, return by starlit stair.
The tapestry will reverse its weave, drawing you upward
through layers of sunrise, feather, dream.

"ADIEU, O soldier!"
The whistle shrieks between our ribs,
a blade of steam that parts our clasping hands.
Platform pigeons scatter like startled medals,
grey feathers flashing silver as citations
no general ever signed.
Your boots are already marching
though you have not yet moved;
sound precedes the step
the way legend outruns flesh.
I keep the smell of gun-oil
folded inside my lungs,
an unposted letter,
a tarnished lullaby.
War is a clever pickpocket:
while it jingles bright trumpets
it steals birthdays, recipes, the ordinary cups
we meant to break together.
When the train lurches
I glimpse my face on its window,
a ghost promoted to widow by timetable.
I wave, ridiculous flag,
as confetti of soot
settles on my tongue, gritty Amen.
Go, carry the longitude of our bed
stitched under epaulette and skin.
Remember the latitude of my laugh
when cartridges rattle like spoons.
If night grows loud and faith grows small,
touch that secret map
and find the coordinates of return.
Until then
I will mend the sky with candle wicks,
sew blue after blue after blue
against the day we stand again whole.
ADIEU, O soldier! Not goodbye.

"ADIEU, O soldier!" the gulls intone,

until nothing remains but edge.
Somewhere behind that blade a harbor waits,
lamplight swinging like a mother's wrist.
I tuck its ember inside my breast pocket
with ration biscuits and photographs
bleached by a thousand thumbprints of longing.
War, they say, is a school of crows:
lesson one, how to speak in silhouettes;

Yet even a crow must return
to roofs it once adored.
So carve my name on the mast,
let rope remember my pulse,
let every gull carry a syllable homeward.
Should my jacket come back empty,
fill it with wind and violin,
dance with it under victorious rain.
For now, the bugle cleaves the hush—
ADIEU, O soldier! echoes again,
a farewell, a promise, a spinning coin.

for the inevitable museum invitation.

pop songs like distant artillery,
the scent of sneakers rather than gunpowder.

yard sale trumpets blared,

Now I stand beneath glass,
ranked among clocks and carnival spoons.

commenting on nostalgia and lead poisoning.
Some nights the security lamp flickers
and shadows of children dance on polished floors.
I salute their fleeting silhouettes,
content that war and play are cousins

I told her that her two teams weren’t playing,
Yet she arrived in face-paint, half crimson, half blue,
Carrying a cardboard thunderstorm of handmade signs,
Banners fluttering like restless birds stitched to her wrists.
She whistled an anthem to rouse invisible crowds,
Boot heels tapping bleacher ghosts into waking.
Ticket stubs rained from her coat pockets
Like leaves that refuse autumn’s dismissal.
I pointed at the silent scoreboard,
The blank rectangle swallowing sunlight.
The referee’s whistle slept in his velvet box,
Mascots lounged, headless, in the maintenance closet,
And the grass sighed at not being trampled today.
Still, she rehearsed every cheer,
Mouthing the vowels of victories yet to bloom,
Knuckling the air with choreographed hope.
‘If the game does not arrive,’ she said,
‘I will embroider it on the hour.’
She spun, arms open, carving a stadium from hush,
Paint smearing into magenta twilight.
The wind overheard her devotion
And struck up a rustling drumline of napkins.
By dusk, bleachers filled with silhouettes of maybe,
My own heart among them, startled and seated.
For love, it seems, is always on the schedule,
Even when the calendar swears it is not.

I told her that her two teams weren’t playing,
So the afternoon stretched wide with unassigned screams,
Flags rolled tight like secrets in a drawer.
She smiled, relieved, to feel the stadium
Collapse into a pocket she could finally fold.
Without the clash of colors to divide her breath,
She poured tea that tasted of a neutral sky
And spoke about her father who loved the home side
And her mother who stitched the away crest on quilts.
How tiring it is, she confessed,
To be a child of blinking scoreboards,
To measure belonging in divided chants.
We walked a river path instead,
Skimming pebbles like half-time coins.
The water, impartial, applauded every splash,
Doing what sports could not: embrace each stone.
‘Maybe next season,’ she murmured,
‘I’ll cheer for the silence between drums,
The seam that binds two jerseys into one.’
Dandelion fluff took flight as if hearing strategy,
Drafting a league of soft white possibilities.
I watched her braid her hair into a single stripe,
No longer red or blue, but the color of relief.
And in that unplayed game of ours,
I learned the scoreboard of the heart
Counts its victories in quiet evenings,
Not in the roar of sectioned seats.

‘Every cosmos is a stadium,’ she laughed,

I watched her invent two teams from breath:

When she finally returned, cheeks glittered with stardust,

‘Games are only cancellations of wonder,’ she said,
‘Unless we play them inside the dark.’

High above, stadium lights flickered on instinct,

So we sat in that half-lit amphitheater,

and crown a champion before midnight.

and cheered beside her cardboard bleachers,

When dawn lifted the cover of wind,
the specters dissolved,

I never doubted her stadium again.

Yet every rock I sculpt, every curve I learn,

Cloud becomes rain, rain becomes mist, mist becomes song on pine,

I sit between them, notebook open, pages bright and still;

For what is glory? A passing moth, powder on the night.
It lands, it leaves, my lamp remains, patient with its light.
So I fold the question smaller, origami moon upon my sill:
May I simply breathe, greet each minute’s texture, neither birth nor skill,

Even ducks mocked my pace. Yet each mile distilled the chatter inside my skull; stones taught silence, cattails taught flexibility, sandbars taught patience. I slept under bridges where graffiti saints blessed my stubborn bones. In the mornings I followed the river’s breath, that endless exhale toward something unnamed.

At the edge of a forgotten orchard I saw you, knees drawn up on the splintered dock, reading weather into the water. You did not look surprised—more like someone remembering a line they never quite finished writing. Between us the current carried twigs, lost words, a single red leaf spinning like a compass needle. We watched it together, neither speaking.

sunset undertow—
our shadows merging
with drifting pollen
